author: {'steamid': '76561198065834998', 'num_games_owned': 35, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 33789, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8746, 'last_played': 1674215104}
review:
I got this game because I got sick of waiting for the guy I watch to upload.
I regret not having done this sooner.

Reassembly is a game which is pretty basic and does not require you to understand complex mechanics if you just want to play the game.
You are given shapes; you assemble yourself multiple ships and blow everything else up.

However Reassembly is one of those games in which vanilla isnâ€™t everything, the normal playable factions are more like the tutorial level, the game becomes more challenging by the appearence of agents (Player-created factions).
You can even add your own agents or factions to the world generator, so you can go and try beating and succeeding your past self if you start a new save.

Each faction is different, in shapes, in playstyle, even in AI behavior resulting with the game becoming very replayable and the amount of possible play-throughs becomes pretty much endless as soon you take a look inside the workshop and spot the amount of ways to spice up the gameplay.
And even if you are still not satisfied, the love the developer put into this game becomes even more visible when you start reading through the documents he left for the community to make your own mod.

Concerning the music, while playing my brain was in shock, due to sudden realization.
I am normally the type of guy to turn the music off and runs his own playlist in the background, but the music of Reassembly (especially from the fields expansion) felt so in-place with the overall atmosphere of the game, even if I thought it was enough, I couldn't turn the music off.

However, the game is not perfect, there are small and annoying bugs you may encounter:

-Some ships forget what they look like whole or completely vanish.
-You sometimes encounter invulnerable ships which take no damage till they are rammed in an asteroid or take damage by driving into one
-Sometimes a part of the game becomes a black screen.
Quitting and reopening the game helps though.
-The game can crash sometimes, is normally no big deal unless you were in edit mode.
I recommend saving on a regular basis and making a copies of your ship (So you can still go back, since you would lose your undo-steps), depending on the complexity of the design of the ship you edit/build.
-Collision can mess up sometimes with ships suddenly clipping inside each other and sometimes can get [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2549911949]the enemy[/url] or [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2549912238]YOU[/url] inside an asteroid.

Overall the game is magnificent and I recommend to people who:

-like building games
-like puzzles, because the editors of some factions feel like one (especially the red faction if you try to build artistically-pleasing)
-wish to have themselves as teammates and enemy
-like blowing things up or explosions in general
-often have the fantasy of throwing things including your foes, your allies, your fleet, yourself, a rock or everything just stated into a sun
-like the small moments (They are almost guaranteed to exist.)

I also recommend to keep the rotation (r key) on keyboard settings, adding a spinal weapon or weapon with slow projectiles and no homing for your mouse-controls which turns this game into a factory of satisfaction, as long you go for greedy shots and hit.

review: Reassembly is a gem; if Asteroid had modular ships and factions that used different shapes for possible designs. It manages difficulty well with casualish hybrid of linear (more/bigger numbers) and nonlinear (ship design, fleet variety) progression, with each faction having a slightly different progression experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198964720447', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 3056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2633, 'last_played': 1692083345}
review:
I think this game is awesome. Ive been playing it quite alot. my only complaints are, since it actually is a good game that means you want more of it lol. need more blocks, maybe straight up wing parts and such. beyond that my real complaints are
-The thrusters are terrible. you get your ship set, add a single additional gun and it seems like you need 40 more thrusters. the bigger thrusters are out of portion with the mass. they create more weight then they thrust making your ship even less mobile. I ended up downloading thrusters with 500 thrust and no mass. even with the zero mass I constantly need more, that being said the lowest thrust should be 500-1000.
-the copy and past functions need improvement. It just seems to kinda break when you are changing up larger ships. pieces end up zig zag, out of place, what you selected wasn't what was copied, but for medium to smaller ships it works flawlessly.
-I dont know what it is, small meteores? ship parts from destroyed vessels? either way everytime I try to travel at full speed my ship seems to just fall apart and get destroyed by running into stuff I cannot see. I kept thinking it was just my bad driving because the creator did good at making this game, but when I respawn and return I cannot determine what killed my ship, sometimes I get spawn trapped.
-there's no speed control. its complete nintendo driving, you just add more thrusters for more speed and less for less. the issue with that is sometimes I'm going straight to an objective on the other side of the world, I just want to get there, while other times I'm looking for stuff to destroy, I can't go fast otherwise Ill zip right past them.
  Despite these issues, this is a great game, I would recommend it and I will still be playing it myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061538101', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 825, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 527, 'last_played': 1637493772}
review:
Can't recommend the game and sure as hell don't recommend buying the fields expansion. The building in the game is set to certain builds I find it quite hard to make good creations because there is no sense of symmetry in the building of ships. Not to even mention the AI has perfect aiming even when you're moving and you cant aim well because the game has an auto target system that you cant control so it will auto target for you making you unable to lead shots. Some super smart dude also decided to put in an auto-zoom in and out feature and you guessed it NO option to turn it off. 

Then you get to the fields expansion which just adds small circular fields in the galaxy system you start in (there are options to keep them from being in your game). There are 2 fields a super slow motion field and then the problem one, a field that introduces a strong gravitational pull around what looks like a dwarf star and if you get deep into the field with a small ship its impossible to escape the field and if you hit the star in the middle its instant kill. The real problem here is that stations or with some factions the moving spawn point ships will be stuck in the Dwarf star field so youre stuck in the loop of death and can never escape the field. Its best to avoid this expansion as for one it isnt even worth 5 dollars and two its pretty broken and hard to recommend considering the game is now dead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108044824', 'num_games_owned': 90, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 181, 'last_played': 1708672091}
review: I thoroughly enjoy the absolute freedom of this game. While understanding what function certain parts serve at first is a bit confusing, once you have the hang of it, it is a blast. You can make essentially anything that you so desire. And the clear but not necessary objectives make it all the more entertaining. Modifying, changing, seeing what blows up your enemy and what gets you blown up. It's all great fun. I would completely recommend this game for people who like to spend hours customizing and designing. The combinations are infinite!

author: {'steamid': '76561198116553667', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2837, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2837, 'last_played': 1615572443}
review:
This game is the like the crust of a video game sandwich; you might hate it, or you might think it's the best part of the sandwich.  tl;dr:  Reassembly is a game that lets you design your own ships, fight pre-generated factions, and take over the galaxyâ„¢.

This is one where you find out if you want to be an engineer or not.  The game is relatively simple in concept, but can get very in depth with designs, to the point where you spend a couple hours creating the perfect snub-fighter only to scrap half of it because it doesn't fit with the rest of your faction's theme.

You can play in a creative way, using out-of-the-box weaponry and ideas to destroy enemy ships (such as using tractor beams to ram into an enemy) or you can simply brute force through anyway (such as attaching infinite plasma cannons to your borg cube).  It's like a Minecraft for space warfare, but without the same universal charm.

I liked it, but it really isn't all too unique in nature.  I think it fills the role of a "cult classic" pretty well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143477655', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 5262, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1468, 'last_played': 1687577730}
review:
Think Spore's cell stage on crack
Reassembly is an addicting, challenging (with some workshop mods) and fun time waster

Hours go by as you try and wipe out other colours from the map.
The DLC adds flavour to the vast galaxy, letting you slingshot around stars.

With 7 base factions and all of them playing very differently to each other, you'll have no shortage of options to your flavour of galactic genocide

author: {'steamid': '76561198304272557', 'num_games_owned': 27, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 273516, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 10, 'playtime_at_review': 108349, 'last_played': 1712286530}
review:
An absolute must-have for creative builders or starsector lovers. With a 2d vector graphics-style, the game uses simple modular system combined together to create a one-of-a-kind experience, chucking together blocks to make what can be beautiful ships. Really, the base game and DLC is just the tip of the iceberg, there's a massive modding community that can do anything from adding cool factions and ships to completely changing the game's graphics and even completely changing the base game. And even from there, the discord is small but friendly, with  tournaments running every now and then, hosted by members. 

9.5/10 would buy again
Computer nee

review:
This game is a great classic for on-the-go ship building and space fair!

Easy to learn controls and resource system. Youâ€™ll be capable fighting enemies easily. Balance like a good game should be and offers a large playing field for the more rigged PCs. However also good for cheaper laptops. Also choosing your custom faction colour allows you to move through territory without needing to check a map. 

Fight other player ships and faction designs. Any design you make will appear with your faction. This is a great element of creativity and fun. 

Itâ€™s such a steal while on Sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198277168485', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1656822488}
review:
I want to love the game. I love just blowing stuff up and running around upgrading. But there are just SO MANY BUGS! When I remake my ship blocks get stuck in it and won't leave, I have to either kill myself or delete my ship. You can't destroy your own ships old blocks so you can't just shoot them away. Some enemies become invincible and just follow you around and kill you. I really really really want to like this game. But its impossible right now with the amount of bugs, the last update being December 2019 I doubt the dev has any plans. Sadly can't recommend the game.

Do not charge 15 dollars for a game with this many bugs if you don't plan on ever working on it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979724838', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 376, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1621242266}
review:
Reassembly is an odd chestnut. The ship builder is crazy flexible. A little [i]too[/i] flexible, actually, given the disparity between the various shapes and anchor points of the pieces, you'll always end up with gaps that are either a few pixels too far apart to be bridged, or too close together to fit anything in between. Then there's the rest of the game, which is a big ol' multi-faction space sim that makes little to no sense. Plants are growing here and there on the space rocks, and once in a blue moon they seem to generate resources? Factories, despite existing to spawn stuff, appear to never spawn stuff. Stations you claim will sometimes work and sometimes not. Sometimes they'll seemingly procedurally generate themselves, sometimes they'll generate from a ship design in your roster that doesn't actually work as a station. Sometimes stations will just vanish instantly when you claim them. Sometimes stations under constant enemy fire will be marked "safe" while the ones back in the core of your own territory are marked "unsafe". I can't tell what's a bug and what's intentional.

Basically, a lot of crap is flying everywhere, everyone's trying to blow each other up, and the stuff in between has no point and/or doesn't make sense. It's not that I outright dislike it. It's a curious novelty at worst. But it's not much in the way of a game, and NOT AT ALL worth buying for anything above half-price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003174259', 'num_games_owned': 1741, 'num_reviews': 317, 'playtime_forever': 803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 803, 'last_played': 1426423590}
review:
[h1] Some Assembly Required [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

So many games have come out like this where you build out your own ship in almost any way you want.  This one actually does that and feels like you can be a bit more free form than other games I have played.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

Not much that I recall.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I got my fill.  These games don't tend to satisfy me long, but I do consider it to be a good game.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

author: {'steamid': '76561198068982092', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 401, 'playtime_forever': 525, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 525, 'last_played': 1619058821}
review:
So... ship building is the only relevant part in this game... And some pieces just don't fit well together making ship-build a hassle with some shapes. Also there are other factions to play around with but the core mechanics are pretty much identical. They just have different weapons and shapes.

Wormholes and Agents were the community driven content but they simply don't work right now. Wormholes return an error message and Agents just don't spawn.

Exploring the world and fighting was fun at first but quickly got repetitive. Having more depth to it would have totally redeemed the game for me. It feels like perfect foundation for a RTS-like game or some kind of eco-system. However, right now, enemies randomly wander waiting for you to come destroy them and allies in your fleet follow you and that's pretty much it.

It's a shame because there are a lot of good elements in the game but the actual gameplay feels lacking.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033984581', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1519, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1519, 'last_played': 1618449358}
review:
I'd recommend this game if it were still 2015 or 2016, but unfortunately this game's age is showing because parts of it are no longer working. Who knows why, but I tried everything I could find online to fix the issues I was experiencing with no success. It's a pretty awesome concept. The gameplay is cool, the music is amazing, and the graphics are pretty to look at. But I was unable to complete several of the objectives and achievements because the "Agents" refused to appear despite my attempts to fix it.

Don't get this game if you want to finish it or have the full experience advertised. But I'd still recommend it if you don't really care about that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997973214', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 12385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11439, 'last_played': 1646568553}
review: Asteroids on steroids. Building new spaceships is even more fun than piloting them. Love this game and could play it endlessly. Brings me back to my childhood of building spaceships with lego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198354086182', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 15784, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9640, 'last_played': 1711131643}
review:
reassembly is a ship building exploration game in which you traverse the ninth circle of hell growing sentimentally attached to your ships and then having them be killed right in front of you by an four 6000p titans ships. 

this game will bring you so many fun experiences like spawning with one ship surrounded by red's unpolitley refusing to go away damning your soul for eternity. or you could install some mods and then risk having your ship explode in the editor effectively softlocking your game, 

there are many factions with unique appearances and roles within the galaxy some you may encounter are:
the red's
the flys
blue 
shiny rocks
literal plant hellspawn
and the cubes

there are also many subtle mechanics like plants (spiky plants pacifist cousin) which can be farmed for resources, and agents who hunt you across the galaxy becuase you forgot to pay your existance tax 

and you could have all this and so much more for around 10$,  so go get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979565688', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2226, 'last_played': 1617985347}
review:
Reassembly is a polished 2D ship builder game and features between 40-70 hours of enjoyable game play. Having completed all of the achievements this was a great way to unwind during my personal time.

Reassembly has just the right balance between action, creativity, and fun for those who enjoy more traditional style 2D space shooter games. I very much recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561197965735144', 'num_games_owned': 375, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 9905, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5358, 'last_played': 1626471892}
review:
"Tinkering in a garage" is going to be a game collection I start soon.

Reassembly is a relatively simple game about taking basic shapes, putting guns on those shapes, and then playing spaceships.  The control scheme will always be a point of contention as the game tries to mitigate your hilarious engine placement, consider a controller.  

The game is generous with the amount of space you have for creativity, and often if you do a little finagling you can make most things fit. Anything from small fighters to gargantuan battle cruisers are craftable and the shape options mean you can make it look like almost anything you like.  Check the community hub, your favorite spaceship is more likely to be there than not, and if it isn't, you can go ahead an fix that.

The game itself puts you in a space (the size of your choosing) and encourages you to build a fleet... or just be a huge lone battleship, your call... and go blow up other fleets, claiming space stations and purging the galaxy of all spaceships that are not your spaceships.  

It's a little hard to hit some of the smaller faster ships, but that's why you have beam weapons and tracking missiles.  There's a solution to your problem and there is no perfect ship. 

Although some of the more Kite-y frigates are a little frustrating to deal with.

Not a perfect game, but it's real easy for me to be stuck in ship building mode for hours when I really should be asleep.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060813750', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 23802, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21732, 'last_played': 1684650388}
review:
Reassembly is a Simplistic 2D ship building and stellar expansion game, I mainly play for the creative freedom with a not too overly complicated building engine.

With your ship you'll need several things, Resources to make credits, to then buy Power, and parts to expand the sizes and versitility of your ships, To get these, you need a ship, that requires a core, and the core needs protected, so you armor it up, witch needs propulsion to move, and weapons to defend itself, that need power, but power cells are explosive, so you need to seperate it, and the other modules from your core, needing more propulsion, and Repeat, untill you've ended up building titanic battleships pushing the limits of the game engine, like i have many many times over.

This cycle of gameplay has had me obessed on making fun new designs, layouts, shapes, and functions of warships, from my classic and horrendiously slapped together Scalpels 1-5, and Lancers 1-5, to my current Heavy Battleship Delta X, further up even, Juggernauts, Sigma, and Voulge 1. This game has had me enthralled and has been more than worth the pricepoint, if you like these kind of building games, In my Opinion, This is a Must-Have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027457402', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 10396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10184, 'last_played': 1618028900}
review:
Just realised that I had not dropped a review for this.

If you like top down arcade spaceship shooters then get this.
If you like ship construction, get this.
If you like playing as a midge like fighter or a superheavy battle cruiser, then you own it to yourself to get this.
If you like building fleets get this.
If you like influence speading with your (custom) space stations, get this.
If you like great sound and music, probably should get this title.

True little gem of a game for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198393019915', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 13245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9161, 'last_played': 1683449350}
review:
An excellent game, well worth the price. Reassembly is a building-focused space combat "massively single-player" game, where you select a faction, spawn a galaxy, and are free to go about that sandbox as you please. Don't be fooled, this isn't an in-depth space sim like Freelancer or anything in that vein. If you're expecting negotiations, diplomacy, relations, or anything in that vein, you will be disappointed. 

Abandon reason, know only war. If they aren't flying your colors, they are hostile. Exterminate the opposition and be the last one standing.

But Reassembly isn't a game about that. It's a game about building the coolest damn spaceship of them all and mashing them together and watching the fireworks. The building mechanics are slick and intuitive. I didn't think I would enjoy it, seeing as how I have a single brain cell to spare, but soon enough I found myself spending hours and hours making dumb ship designs to throw into Tournament mode (what if I built a ship with only torpedoes? Answer: you get frustrated because it can't aim, and then forget how frustrating it is when it lands a salvo and chews through a battleship like a hot knife through butter.)

There are some who say there isn't a whole lot to the game, and my response to that is it's really a game where you make your own fun. I wish there was a multiplayer element, among some other things - as fun as it is fighting your friends' Agents in Tournament is, it's very clunky. I've had a lot more fun building up fleets with differing capabilities and watching them clash in Tournament mode, but maybe you'll have more fun building an unstoppable juggernaut and plowing a path of destruction through a galaxy.

It's an outstanding game, and one I heavily recommend. Seriously, give it a try. The gameplay is slick, the soundtrack is soothing, and the visuals are fantastic. Other people have written much more eloquent and detailed reviews than I have, so I'll just leave you with this.

If you want to watch warships broadside each other with plasma cannons while hundreds of missiles race out and dive into flashing screens of laser point-defense, this is the game for you.

...

Also, there's a fuck-ton of mods in the workshop that add on every kind of faction you could ever want. So if you want to see something but it's not in the base seven factions, well, give that a try. I know I've spent far too long watching ADS Apollo-class Destroyers split ships ten times their mass down the middle with a gigantic railgun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157345225', 'num_games_owned': 154, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 2233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1827, 'last_played': 1612336307}
review:
Reassembly seems to be pretty niche game as far as I can tell, but it's actually quite fun and ended up becoming my time vortex for a while.

The game is essentially based on the "Reassembly" mechanic, hence the name. Ships are designed by connecting hull shapes and prefabs to each other, and the blueprint is then assembled by each of these pieces materializing one at a time in 'chains'. When a ship suffers damage, the lost pieces begin to reassemble in a similar way.

Stations also exist, which are designed like ships but lacking thrusters. These remain stationed in the sectors in which they are built and use ship-delivered resources to continually produce new ships using factories. Some of these ships can include factories themselves, which generally means that the rate at which ships are created increases exponentially.

If you are piloting a ship with at least one factory, nearby ships that do not have factories will transfer their resources to you for your own use. You can also choose to transfer resources to them for use by their factories. You may then decide which of your ships you wish to produce, and begin doing so at your own will. The ships that are produced will remain under your command, although you can dismiss them at any time or recruit other nearby ships using a credit-like currency if you do not wish to produce them yourself.

The units you command will continuously accompany you but in the meantime also perform duties that they are designated to fulfill, which is decided based on their physical designs. Essentially, a ship designed for combat will always remain near you, whereas a ship equipped with cargo containers will collect nearby resources and transfer them to you or to other ships or stations with factories, unless they have a factory of their own in which case they will also produce their own ships.

It is possible to command fleets up to about 60 ships in size, and in my experience this also has no performance drawbacks at all. This means you can lead massive swarms of fighting ships into combat, which is especially enjoyable to watch when attacking agents (naturally occurring, similarly large hostile fleets built by other players).

Despite the reassembly mechanic, poorly equipped ships can easily be destroyed in combat. You will generally need to retreat from any hostile zones in order to fully recover from damage. I've found that it's effective to produce large fleets of unshielded, relatively small fighters, and command them in a larger, shielded ship while remaining in the back line.

If you decide to do this, I would also recommend using the 'Engage my Target' fleet order, ensuring to find a new target after the previous one is destroyed by your fleet. This order causes all units you command to aggressively pursue and attack your targeted enemy, much more so than the 'Fire at Will' order in which they will instead hold their position near you and simply fire on nearby enemies. The downside to this is that they will obviously only engage your target, but somehow this usually doesn't seem to be much of a problem (at least with very large fleets) as long as you continue acquiring targets. The 'Disengage' order can also be used during a retreat.

Overall, it's definitely an interesting game and one I would recommend you purchase (perhaps on a sale if you mind the price tag). The only slightly aggravating thing I've come across in the game is enemy ships that have 8-10 large thrusters in each direction, giving them superb acceleration and the ability to even evade ships with afterburners. This can be frustrating as you have limited attack options when getting close to them is nearly impossible. To be fair though these are player designs and can't really be 'moderated', if this were to be considered a real issue.

review:
Could've been a great game, instead it's just ok. All the pieces are here, it just seems incomplete. 
No story. 1 or 2 factions are far more powerful than the rest. Still fun for a while I guess. 
Most of the time I just make ships & watch them fight on auto pilot in the testing room. Mods help.
EDIT: This game no longer works. It freezes at the menu screen. Changed review to NOT RECOMMEND

author: {'steamid': '76561198160620781', 'num_games_owned': 226, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11189, 'last_played': 1697552387}
review: Hell pain hurt bigger hurt. That's the game. And I love it. Played it so long in vanilla until I got bored. Then played Sandbox for hours. Got disinterested. Then played again, now with mods. Played for more than 100+ hours with mods. Got bored again. Played again. Got bored again. Played again created in the sandbox a living society which was awesome. Got bored again. And only now I recommend this game. Why? Its one of the most replayed games in my Library, One of the funnest painful experiences I got realizing I just spend a whole fucking day on one game and still didn't get to see the whole galaxy. Idk how much I payed for this game but god damn is 12,49 low for such a game where you can play for hours and hours until you realize that there is a workshop. Idk when the next time is when I will play this again, but when I do you bet I will try to get all the achievements this game has! Thx for this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095997869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 12170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7751, 'last_played': 1691208109}
review:
Reassembly is a ship building/fighting game akin to Captain Forever and Void Hunters from Funorb.com. The concept of building a spaceship to destroy hostile fleets is not new, but this game offers fleet mechanics that let you lead (and eventually build) armies to take over the world. The game's "goal" is really in your hands, as it's more of a sandbox game, like Void Hunters. I remember when I got this game last Chirstmas and spent 50 or so hours playing through it, after I misjudged it at first glance and replaced it with Transistor (or maybe it was Bastion, both good games). This game's also easy to mod, has a modding guide on its website, and sports a vast number of mods if you ever get bored of the base game.

I spent half of my playtime in the ship building menu/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197998410009', 'num_games_owned': 218, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 9321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7852, 'last_played': 1610773273}
review:
This really could have been something really really good. But it was not.
   Not much more to say. A pile of potential limited by nothing but itself.

   It should be good, The idea is good. But it has nothing to do with reassembling or getting parts from other factions.... In fact for some strange reason the AI CAN STEAL PARTS FROM OTHER SHIPS.

  Wouldn't that be a great feature for the player? Was this game initially made with the idea that you steal lose parts from defeated ships? It feels like it. But then you don't. Instead you buy stuff with points like every other generic poop shooter.

  Why did this never reach it's potential? No rly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054024348', 'num_games_owned': 18, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 80766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60616, 'last_played': 1678485336}
review:
What you need to know:
Requires a mega gaming rig for sure IMO.
Limit of 2000 blocks per ship.
Uses (C)urrency, (R)esource, and ship (P)ower metrics.
Free structural blocks, most available immediately.
Unlock (P) the ability to add more functional blocks.
Immediate access to build max size ships.
Each race has unique tech specialties.
There is no friendly fire/damage.
The AI is okay but not very advanced.
There is no complex galactic simulation.
Ships grow from one tiny block produced at a factory block.
There is a very simple mercenary fleet mechanic, only for you.
You can save and load your ships and entire fleet schematics.
Crowded areas will cause ships to overlap, causing massive game slowdowns.
Agents are copies of other players' fleets put into your game!
Go into a wormhole to add your fleet! Show off your designs!

Overall, the vanilla game leaves me wanting much more, but it scratches that creative itch. I spend much of my time trying to make ships that mimic the biological reproduction of cells that will multiply at maximum speed, making for very annoying Agents in other players worlds. LOL

author: {'steamid': '76561198333691889', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1608628612}
review: I tried this game a few times, and honestly I couldn't really get into it. The appeal is very very nice, and the customization along with workshop support is great and allows you to customize your craft & fleet to your liking. What this game suffers from is lack of appeal and substance. Every time I go  to a damaged space station or enemy territory I wander around a bit, kill things, realize how boring it is then leave. There isn't really a central goal, and there is little to no incentive to actually progress, which really sucks because I am a fan of these goal-less procedurally generated games. Its kinda cool messing around with your faction and ship designs, and the tournament mode is at least slightly interesting, but the whole experience just feels pretty empty; sorry but I cant recommend

author: {'steamid': '76561198133249853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1935, 'last_played': 1655529608}
review:
This game is totally fantastic, 100% recommend to anyone that enjoys designing spaceships and controlling them. Most enjoyable to me is the aspect of the game where you design ships at various cost levels and pit them against ships of similar caliber. The game gives you tons of options for customizing the ships and everything looks and feels quite nice. It's especially interesting to try to design ships that the AI can utilize properly to assault other fleets, and to build a fleet with a composition to protect the mother-ship. 

The cons of this game are far from deal-breakers, and are more things that I wish the developer would patch. Maybe there's an option to turn this off, but every time I begin the game with a new race, I have to click through a bunch of tutorial text that I already understand. 
Additionally, designing a ship that encapsulates its weapons or various blocks can sometimes be difficult, because the blocks fit together only at certain key points. That being said, this issue may be more to do with my own ignorance of geometry.

review:
This is hands-down one of my favorite games. Itâ€™s one of those games thatâ€™s easy to learn but gratifying to master, with enough simplicity to allow quite a bit of creativity. 
Itâ€™s like Asteroids, but instead of a triangle you get to design your own fleet and instead of asteroids itâ€™s massive space battles. Other games like Avorion have a similar concept, but I havenâ€™t found any that pull it off quite like this

author: {'steamid': '76561198065760824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 1134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1134, 'last_played': 1607018514}
review: A perfect sandbox space game. Create awesome ships and explore the map with your fleet. The problem? It's too short. Once you buy all of the ship parts there isn't much more to do. Additionally, most weapons are useless endgame. There should be a huge content update with new goals and achievements to strive for. Maybe some big boss battles. Custom space stations? Ship upgrades? Maybe speed and damage multiplier upgrades? So much potential in this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981138288', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2125, 'last_played': 1599260414}
review:
Reassembly is a procedurally generated twin-stick "massively single-player" shooter with a lot of interesting features.  Don't be fooled by the apparent visual simplicity of this game.  Years after my purchase I still find myself coming back to this game occasionally, largely because of its excellent music design and smooth gameplay loop.  

In this rogue-lite asteroid-like sandbox shooter, you start off with a pretty complete-looking ship that you can fly around and encounter different alien races that have their own divergent ship design philosophies.  As you merrily blow them up, you'll accumulate upgrade points that let you tack on some extra thrusters and laser emitters.  Very early on in the game, you'll realize you can no longer keep tacking on weapons blisters and need to delete your ship and build it back up from scratch.  This is where the fun happens.  

The ships you design  through your upgrade points can be saved to the cloud and spawned as enemies in other peoples' games, which is how it gets its "massively single-player" status.  It's an interesting alternative to PvP, uploading your best ship designs to appear as enemies for other players.  Assembling new spaceships is really fun and engaging and I was able to play and build new ships easily with my standard gamepad.  

The game includes a wide variety of unlockable alien races to play as which is a huge part of this game's replayability.  They did a really good job at making asymmetrical playstyles - aliens that have totally different approaches to combat and resource farming that you can fight against and eventually play as.  

There's this magical combination of textureless graphics with smooth atmospheric background music and arcade style gameplay layered over building/resource management and combat that makes Reassembly a unique gaming experience that is worth checking out.  Don't be turned off by the dated visuals, the developers have really created a novel gaming experience here that is worth your attention.

author: {'steamid': '76561198122800312', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 17107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14032, 'last_played': 1698644016}

review: Ever wanted to design your own battlecruiser, and crusade across the stars?  Then this is the sandbox for you!   Harvest the local resources, design and build fleets, and then throw them against the NPCs and player-designed fleets that will be seeded across your galaxy.  Hours of casual fun to be had, and the multiple factions you can unlock with their various playstyles adds some challenges and longevity.

review:
This game has enormous potential.  There are some bugs remaining to be fixed though.

Got a segfault crash, probably the worst bug you can have in a game.  Other than that, there are a bunch of little bugs that could be cleaned up, like mirroring on the long triangle hull, AI not using afterburners.

The game is beautiful and fun to play, I'll give it that.  A bit longer in bug fixing and it'll be ready.

author: {'steamid': '76561198188714328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 5127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4328, 'last_played': 1601165268}
review: This is one of my all time favorite games. I don't know how to accurately describe why, but something about the whole game is so satisfying. Earning points to make your ship bigger or unlock new parts is interesting enough that it doesn't feel like a grind. The new parts make me excited to try them out and see what they do. The separate factions are all unique, which isn't common in games. I feel like most games just make other factions kinda re-skins with slight variation, but in this game all the factions have different parts, and those parts usually come in different shapes meaning you literally can't build the same ships of other factions. The weapons have different strengths so if you prefer one play style like long range combat, through experimentation you'll find that it just doesn't work for everyone, and you have to explore your options. The only issue I've ever had is not being able to go through the worm holes, but I haven't tried it in a while so hopefully it works for me now! Can't recommend this game enough!

review:
Very nice game where you trying to find out which combination of ship components would work most efficiently.
Unfortunately, after 8 hours, you will see everything that the game has. And it will become borring.
But still, first 8 hours are awesome.

author: {'steamid': '76561198094424389', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 13476, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6152, 'last_played': 1681337008}

author: {'steamid': '76561198049430476', 'num_games_owned': 838, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 87, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 87, 'last_played': 1594101495}
review:
I bought this game looking for something like S.P.A.Z. This is not that....but it's not bad.  Just like all the other reviews have said, everything about your ship is calculated by the parts that you use, so managing your mass and thrust is super important.  I wish that the sprites that they used for the parts were a little less simplistic but o well. I was looking forward to the Star Wars mod but it doesn't really do anything for you since all the ships that come pre-built are super small....

If you like building, space ships, and min-maxing your designs then this is a game for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091456249', 'num_games_owned': 325, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 278, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 278, 'last_played': 1548954392}
review: There is nothing better than building up a small fleet over 10 minutes to get one shot by an overly optimized ship made by a random person you will never meet in your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970961755', 'num_games_owned': 1300, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2685, 'last_played': 1592081550}
review: To be brief - this is a gem of a 2D space shooter and well worth your time. The combat is smooth and fun, the ship building is versatile and intuitive, and there are five base races to choose from, each with their own particularly module styles. You'll even play against AI-controlled versions of other player's designs, which keeps the interest high and can occasionally be very challenging (in a good way). This game is worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198254073243', 'num_games_owned': 143, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2247, 'last_played': 1680162056}

author: {'steamid': '76561199035524564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1725, 'last_played': 1681778179}
review: possibly one of the best games i have bought on steam. The game is endless, and always fun. I have had a lot of fun designing ships, only to see them get crushed by player fleets/agents. The modding scene is also awesome, and they add many new ships, factions, parts. One of my favaraite mods is ALtered Vanilla, which is the same as the vanilla game, however the ships are redisigned for each faction. Definately give it a try !

review:

Honestly the only thing that I want from this game is a co-op mode besides that its really good

author: {'steamid': '76561198137788705', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 44880, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39415, 'last_played': 1635398377}
review: While there isn't much to the game, its a fun way to pass time and feels really polished. Being able to create aesthetically pleasing and/or very functional ships out of a handful of parts is very satisfying, and the upgrades allow a sense of progression alongside the more obvious progress points like Agent killing, station reactivation and reaching a wormhole. And you can do all of these at your own pace if you wish, which is the icing on the cake.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008294013', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 48735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46710, 'last_played': 1659381531}
review:
Design and build your own fleet of spaceships in one of several different factions style and then fly around and take over your local galaxy, fighting off various enemy factions, and occasionally fleets of spaceships built by other players. Building and testing your creations is a very enjoyable experience almost a seperate thing to the rest of the game.
The downside is that the game whilst open ended, is a little lacking in structure, particularly endgame type content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193870602', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 25075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23793, 'last_played': 1704156179}
review: Single player only!!! This game is really fun, but you have to spend a little bit on how to play it. Once you understand how to play, and the basics you can do really anything. Not to mention the modding aspects of the game. 3/5. Good, but not a masterpiece, definitely worth your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078292532', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 15845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6783, 'last_played': 1710468292}
review:
you ever play captain forever? bubble tanks? this is a niche that can be filled for some time with Reassembly, especially with workshop content. play around with the different 'races' as they all offer completely different playstyles just as a result of their basic hull shapes and of course weaponry. different enemies and races require different builds and tactics. early game is a grind for the best ways to make money/collect resources. and each item unlock can grant you more money if you put it to the right use, until you are able to make large ships capable of extermination in any way imaginable.

make a titanic-sized vessel that can 1v1 or 1v100 the same.

make an impenetrable fortress that can produce a fleet on demand and outlast the toughest forces.

make something totally new, like a large mass of tiny ships that almost act as a virus in numbers, replicating and overpowering large targets with sheer numbers and low production cost.

Either way you manage, you can try and dominate every sector of the galaxy or attempt to just wipe out the major forces and move onto the next wormhole...

author: {'steamid': '76561198044587698', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2496, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2392, 'last_played': 1591054168}

review:
wished i could have a space game that would be easy to understand and that would remind me of some old flash games i used to play on the net

yes i got it : Reassembly

you get to create your own ship factions to fight against, mechanics that varies with the faction you chose
difficulty not too hard but not too easy too

the game support mods which can add a few mechanics to the game

if you wanna chill, this game might be for you

review:
Un jeu de construction magnifique, on Ã  l'impression d'avoir toujours quelque chose Ã  faire, on a toujours un truc Ã  tester pour voir si ca fonctionne, si ca va mieux poutrer les autres. 
C'est joli, y'a plusieurs races diffÃ©rentes proposant des combinaisons de blocs et d'armes diverses, on crÃ©e ses premiers modÃ¨les, puis sa flotte et on la teste contre la galaxie entiÃ¨re mais aussi contre les vaisseaux crÃ©Ã©s par les autres joueurs. 
En effet, Ã  chaque fois qu'on passe dans un trou de ver on peut soit choisir de se transfÃ©rer dans une nouvelle galaxie, soit choisir d'uploader sa flotte pour qu'elle soit gÃ©nÃ©rÃ©e dans le monde des autres joueurs.

Le top du must pour moi c'est encore le mode qui permet de faire des simulations. AprÃ¨s avoir peaufinÃ© chaque flotte de chaque race en ayant donnÃ© naissance aux vaisseaux les plus impressionnants et/ou efficaces que je pouvais concevoir, j'ai passÃ© des heures en tant que spectateur Ã  laisser l'IA faire s'affronter le tout dans des tournois pouvant durer une bonne demi heure, Ã  faire des statistiques sur quelle flotte gagne le plus souvent contre x flotte, Ã  faire des ralentis pour ne rien rater du moment ou tel vaisseau gigantesque se faisait scier en deux par un autre vaisseau cracheur de piliers plasmatiques.

De l'Or, certes, mais il aurait quand mÃªme gagnÃ© Ã  ne pas sortir de l'Early Access aussi si vite. Aucune idÃ©e des raisons qui ont gÃ©nÃ©rÃ© ca mais ca reste un fait qui doit Ãªtre mentionnÃ©, malheureusement certaines races sont un peu en dessous des autres (voir Ã©normÃ©ment, bonjour la race des abeilles) ou manquent un peu de blocs, et sont donc dÃ©sÃ©quilibrÃ©es, de plus l'IA aurait gagnÃ© Ã  Ãªtre polie Ã  certains niveaux, et j'aurais aimÃ© que les comportements personnalisables de celle ci soient un peu plus variÃ©s voir simplement fonctionnels pour certains.

De plus on voit que les dÃ©veloppeurs avait de grandes idÃ©es au dÃ©part, l'univers aurait du Ãªtre plus vivant et je suppose qu'on Ã©tait sensÃ© pouvoir faire plus de choses que simplement se battre.

Heureusement, en l'Ã©tat, simplement crÃ©er et se battre reste largement assez satisfaisant et donne une durÃ©e de vie dÃ©jÃ  bien assez longue pour qu'il soit deux fois recommandable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101754840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 49381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49381, 'last_played': 1585660115}
review:
If you thought about buying this game think again. It is plagued by a host of unfixed bugs that break the game experience constantly. If you like games that come with bugs and crash at a moments notice losing you hours of progress then this is the game for you. If you can get past constant crashes and play the game you will notice that your ships AI is about as smart as a plank of rotting wood. It is an unfinished buggy cash grab of a game from a developer who doesn't care to finish making this a usable product.

Once you get past the host of problems in game you may then discover the game has a small mostly inactive user base on Discord crowned by some toxic players. I am not sure which is worse. The state of the game and its severe unplayability or the toxic users in its official Discord.

All in all its been five years since this game was released and it is still broken. For a while the developer was active but what updates the game did get made the bugs stand out more and still haven't been fixed. If anything the games AI now performs even more poorly than it did before it got "updates". If you want to spend money I highly recommend that you make a purchase on a worthwhile game that isn't broken like this one.

Buy this game and be prepared for:
Constant crashes.
Poorly programmed AI.
Mostly dead modding community.
Toxic players.
Uninspiring game play (game can be finished in a few hours then rinse and repeat).

author: {'steamid': '76561198374832312', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5488, 'last_played': 1661305325}
review:
It's generally a pretty good game.
It runs on even potato PCs like my old one at a good speed, has some beautiful graphics on higher-end devices, and the game play is fun.

Besides a rare crash, glitching through blocks on occasion if going too fast, or being pounded by a ship that literally destroys my entire faction, I can't point out much wrong with it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198367361512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 24745, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14395, 'last_played': 1688008296}
review:
A very interesting 2D space shooter that [was] worth a purchase.

Update:

I came back to this game after not playing it for a long time, and now I can't jump through a wormhole to start a new galaxy. This happens in all of my games - old save games, brand new games I've just created - it doesn't matter which game, I simple can't travel to a new world to continue playing.

If the issue continues, then I can't suggest buying this, as the most important feature to continuing to play (generating a new world when you need it) doesn't work.

If they fix the issue, then it's back to recommended. But until then, I wouldn't buy it.

Update: The wormhole issue still isn't fixed, making any advancement into new worlds impossible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083688383', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 5396, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 285, 'last_played': 1660113565}
review:
My frame rate was trash then they fixed it. The game was an absolutely blast, addictive and fun. It's like diablos + Istrolid + Spore cell stage. Fantastic game. Balancing seems weird tho.

Instead of a space ship game, this is more like a cell game where you evolve and set up colonies (stations).

author: {'steamid': '76561198121432275', 'num_games_owned': 834, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 2657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2515, 'last_played': 1692747007}
review:
Reassembly is a total gem. Spending hours crafting your ship to be the best, most precision-based war machine is such great fun. It's even more fun to lob random blocks together to see what works and what doesn't. It's even MORE fun to create ships and spacestations that you can replicate over and over again, to slowly take over an entire galaxy.

Also, this game is optimized absurdly well. I remember this being one of the first games I ever played on Steam, and I played it on my grandma's old Dell computer that was made in 2005. This game is amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043002927', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 895, 'last_played': 1579475765}
review:
Fun until you realise that this game is as repetitive as it gets.
The whole game basically consists of:
- shooting things 
- building ship designs (and getting annoyed at the restrictive building format)
- flying around and pressing a button to pop out more ships 

Yes that is it.
And the mods just augment the shooty and buildy part a bit.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108466761', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 147, 'playtime_forever': 1600, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1073, 'last_played': 1583091590}
review:
Extremely good open world space game.  Build any type of ship you can imagine from agile fighters to lumbering Dreadnoughts and conquer a procedural galaxy before entering a wormhole and moving onto another or uploading your fleet online to allow other players to test their mettle against your designs.
Excellent graphics and particle effects and satisfying individual part destruction as you tear enemy ships apart piece by piece.
Plenty of different races to unlock each with their own unique parts, strengths and weaknesses and mod support give this game everything you could want.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993403472', 'num_games_owned': 57, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3398, 'last_played': 1578505383}
review: I have mixed feelings for this game. While it's fun to design 2D ships and to hunt out agents and dominate areas, it does get old in vanilla. Mods really do bring life into this game, but since there really isnt much of a storyline, its just an open map that's got no other feeling of accomplishment. I wish it had a trading system between stations or something like that just to kick it up a notch.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057817586', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 12661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8457, 'last_played': 1665487520}
review:
With over 140 hours played in this game I can 100% tell you the game is fantastic but every time you get your save into the late game... It will corrupt. GUARANTEED every single time. And there will not be any update to fix it. It's been this way for years. Is it worth the money? yes. Is it worth your time? Probably not. Since every save will corrupt. (crash out with an error nobody has a fix for)

Imagine grinding on WoW for 7 hours only to find out your account gets magically reset. That's what this is like. I can see my save. I can click my save. I can load my save. But it WILL crash before I can control anything. The log is not helpful. There is no fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121636801', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 4846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3123, 'last_played': 1700020911}
review:
Great game to play if you like sandbox games that allow you to create your own stuff. On top of that, there are a shit ton of mods available that can enhance the experience even more. Designing ships and stations  and then having your creations battle it out is a major staple of this game. 

PS, If you get annoyed from the max 8000P limit, there are mods for those who want to make massive titans.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992566364', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1581042517}
review:
Impressive technology in this 2 dimensional physics system. 
With the daunting number of parts and components in flight at once the framerate stays silky smooth and my setup is many years old now.
At first I found it confusing and wasnt sure what I was supposed to be doing at all, but once you get through the tutorial objectives it starts to become more clear and the fun beings to reveal itself. 

After a couple hours I found myself mumbling "dammit!" in frustration when I would die and wipe my fleet.
Generally that is my measure for any game that is engaging and fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019159426', 'num_games_owned': 1871, 'num_reviews': 433, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1579824838}
review:
extremely versatile, fresh, unique, - Like Nova Drift, but endless. RPG-Like, you may freely explore the space random, generated realm, according to your tastes. [spoiler] Save + Exit [/spoiler]
This is a Freelancer freedom experience, with Physics , orbiting stars, or planets, working with the customizable you, to play this. 
There are a few modes, but ultimately, this is a space sandbox. Play to unlock new, different ships. There are lots of guns on a ship. Customizable hotkeys.
The price, to infinite ratio that this game will last, is a bargain.
It's beautiful, it feels different, but there are still learning curves ;) it's a great game.
Solid investment;
Oh, Last useful tip: Exit + Save = Taking a break from the game :) Destroyed - otherwise ;D

author: {'steamid': '76561198107889634', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8129, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6216, 'last_played': 1668577507}
review:
This game is pretty fun. I would recommend it at its full price. The gameplay is pretty simple and can get pretty repetitive as the progression loop is pretty much the same across all factions including mod factions. The progression loop being kill ships, get R, turn to R into P, spend P on making ship bigger repeat. 

There's also not a  whole lot of strategy involved in this game it's more about having more gun than your enemy and at some point your ship is going to be so powerful that literally nothing can touch you. Even once you start building a fleet of your own you're not going to start pulling off tactical moves or anything like that you just point at a target and all your little dudes will move into range and start firing thoughtlessly until it explodes. Honestly I found fleet building to be a bit tedious and not as fun as just creating one really big over powered ship that can knock out fleets by itself.

Over all it's a fun little time waster with some visually pretty nice looking battles and a satisfying if not overly simple progression system revolving around customizing your ship. If you're like me and don't like playing videogames for more than half an hour at a time this game is probably a good pick up for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120798572', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 377, 'last_played': 1601024800}
review: if you ever played shell core the flash game and wondered what it would look like with more resources and more fleshed out this is it. you battle across a masssive sector at 200% size it goes to like a 1000% or something. designing a ship at first but then later on you get the factory part. then you become a rolling fleet. selling off ships to get money and furthering you groups cause. the AI is surprisingly adaptive to basic attacks growing around you and you need to have a decent fleet comp to even hope to catch all the units fast units for the small targets and huge battle ships to hold back larger ones from fleet wiping you.

review:
I really want to recommend this game, but it crashes every 20-30 minutes for me once I have a large fleet going. The last crash wrecked my savefile, so I have to start over if I want to keep playing. Pretty bad.

64GB RAM, RTX2080. Happens both in XP mode and regular.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004732104', 'num_games_owned': 408, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1808, 'last_played': 1627322809}
review:
Growing up in the age of Newgrounds, Armor Games, and other flash games, I loved a good ol' upgrade game. Being able to upgrade your ship/base/player to defeat increasingly difficult enemies was my cup of tea.
Reassembly takes that idea and pushes it further than it's ever gone in a beautiful but simplistic way. The upgrades are deep and meaningful, the factions diverse, and the difficulty quite high at times. This game is fantastic.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061336011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 2601, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2556, 'last_played': 1578254446}
review:
[b]9/10 - Excellent game that succeeds at what it advertises, but if you aren't really into a building-focused play style then you'll probably find yourself quickly bored.[/b]

[u]Full Review Below[/u]

Reassembly is probably one of my favorite indie releases. The premise is simple: build your own ship, then squadron, then fleet. Then take the fight across the galaxy. 

The meat of the game play is in building your own ships. If you're the kind of player who loves full creative freedom, and the simple loop of building something from scratch -> seeing how it does -> revising, then you will absolutely love this game. If you'd rather just figure out one thing and then go shoot things, you'll probably get bored relatively quickly. 

That being said, the "shooting things" play style is very well supported in the early game, because you gather resources from destroyed enemies and can use them to unlock new bricks. This changes once you're out of things to unlock, as their is no longer the rewarding gameplay loop that comes with unlocking things. 

On the presentation side of things, the graphics are gorgeous and the soundtrack is rich and moody, making it an easy game to get lost in while you experiment with different options and different builds. The first play through impression that this game leaves is [b]magical[/b]. You'll be discovering new types of ships and civs pretty consistently for a while, many with their own tricks and challenges that you'll need to adapt to. 

Eventually you'll discover everything the game has to offer, and you'll be left with optimizing your fleet, designing mother ships and stations, and attaining dominance. If you get bored of one civ, you can always play as one of the others. Each one has its own style and weapons, complete with different shipbuilding styles due to the differing tile sets. 

When you get bored of what the base game has to offer, then there's an incredibly lively Workshop scene ready to add myriad new choices. I played for about 30 hours before even considering adding Workshop content. 

To top it all off, the developer recently became active again and added a fascinating expansion that explores gravity wells, as well as tightening up the core game. Even if you don't like the new gravity "terrain" features, the expansion is worthwhile for the new soundtrack alone, imo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967688217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2449, 'last_played': 1577828889}
review: Have had this game for a long while, used to enjoy it, it ran well and was fairly interesting. That was all good until recently. Recent updates have broken the game completely. One whole faction is entirely unplayable due to consistent crashing, which is a known issue. And random other crashes have happened during all recent sessions. Having reviewed the supposed support channels, you just get told to use the "new" one, wherein you get direct to some other "new" support channel, etc. The developers discord doesn't have any obvious help / bugs section, and overall, with reports over a year old of system crashes gone unanswered in various places (steam, dev forums), there seem no interest in fixing game breaking issues. I cannot recommend this game to anyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198361030201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 77875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 979, 'playtime_at_review': 58359, 'last_played': 1711841240}
review:
My original review was:
[code]build boat. shoot.

:)[/code]
so i thought i might as well write something useful
ok so. 

 As a person that almost plays exclusively space games and building games, this is my favorite game. By alot. Beautiful effects, a [i][b]perfect[/b][/i] soundtrack, and a building system that lets you make anything you want (but if you want something structurally sound, you'll have to do math xD). The combat and gameplay is fun and satisfying to watch and I love the way ships can slowly fall into pieces/get cut in half/explode into a million pieces. Not only is there infinite freedom in the base game, but the game is incredibly easy to mod as well. If you want to test your skill in min-maxing monstrous mobile machines, there are many active community-hosted tournaments as well. Most of the hours post-campaign (likely "won" after 30-40 hours) will either be modding or competing in tourneys.

However, its not without imperfections. First off, updates are very rare: the developer has his hands full with his half-grown human that he had in 2019. There is no tutorial for the sandbox, many of the controls, and many of the cooler features. There are bugs that, while workaround-able, new players will not know what is causing them or how to fix them (also some that no one knows what/why/or how they're there. The game is haunted man...). The ai sometimes decides it will do nothing and engages at strange ranges (mostly observed in tournament mode, campaign ai is fine) and also has trouble using some of the newer features. Lastly, as said before, the campaign part of the game is relatively short.

 Now, does this make this game unenjoyable? Absolutely not. Any thing the game may be missing, the community can supply. Someone (identity unknown) has stepped up and is acting as a temporary developer to squash some of the bugs the game has in an upcoming update (all hail Bugnonimous). If you need help, there are dozens of guides on steam and the internet, and if you still can' find what you need, the community [url=https://discord.gg/8fCjt3J]Discord Server[/url] is friendly and helpful. And regarding the short campaign, most of the endgame is building for tournaments and modding. Heck, I'm making a mod at a snail's pace because I'm having too much fun playing with what I've made!

 So TLDR. If you're an engineer looking to make the best [2d] spaceship you can; if you're a competitor, a creator and artist with an unhealthy obsession with spaceships; if you want to blow chunks off battle-carriers with bombardment from cruisers while your buddy's crowd around and boo at your crappy boating...

get this game :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197982920009', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 826, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 826, 'last_played': 1577005890}
review:
Its a great concept, you can build up a nearly infinite army of space ships you designed to dominate the galaxy. But it has a few problems:

-It's buggy, hitboxes glitch out on each other and sometimes you'll have a ship that is essentially destroying itself because parts of it keep smashing into other parts for no reason.
-I was about 10 hours in and after pretty much owning the area I was in I went through a wormhole, game immediately crashed and the save became corrupt.
-The music gets annoying.I know you can turn it off but to set the amothphere it would've been nice to have less intrusive soundtracks, more ambient sc-fi would've done the trick.

Either way I had fun with it.

Take over the galaxy for the price of a latte.

review: I wish I could recommend this game; it's loads of fun to play. There's a showstopper of a problem going on for me, however. Saves seem to work only sporadically and mostly not at all. I've spent a bunch of time building, progressing and in fear that "save and exit" will only exit and not save. I finally decided to just play and leave the game running (on pause) when not playing. That worked until the game crashed and all my latest (and very significant) progress was lost. I'm kinda done at this point. Sigh.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025442533', 'num_games_owned': 279, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2779, 'last_played': 1574202908}
review:
While Reassembly feels less like a full-scale game and more like a flash experience, it is still incredibly enjoyable and there's certainly not a lack of content. Ship building is straightforward but with a satisfying amount of depth, combat is similarly simple yet fun, and amassing a small (or massive) fleet while roaming the galaxy is great. I'd recommend this game to those who want a laid-back spaceship game with a lot of customization and can use their imagination to create their own experiences.

Final note, the soundtrack is awesome and evokes feelings of being lost in a vast galaxy full of new mysteries to be uncovered.

author: {'steamid': '76561198196609931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 96286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 92568, 'last_played': 1674427168}
review: This is the game for people who always dreamed of building a spaceship. Also for people who like shooting pesky flies :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198184897393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 653, 'playtime_forever': 1533, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1435, 'last_played': 1574046404}
review:
At first I had trouble controlling my ship and was quite frustrated. It took a while to both build a quality ship with good controls, and get used to navigating. Still, most "flight" time is spent careening more than anything else. 

Building ships is fun with many options and endless configurations. Some of these are shared and automatically downloaded from other players (as competitors). Ships can also be tested prior to returning to the game. 

[h1]Additional Details[/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561198140788229', 'num_games_owned': 152, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10954, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9389, 'last_played': 1679713937}
review: I freaking love this game. Hands down the best $15 purchase I have ever made. It has it's glitches and can sometimes get a little slow but if I come back to it after a long break I always forget how much fun I have with it. And then I proceed to stay up until 4 am with it... whoops. Whenever I see updates for this game it makes me smile, even when they are few and far between, they always have something great about them. Would 100% recommend this game to anyone who loves sandbox games. (And anyone who doesn't.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198076317360', 'num_games_owned': 197, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 6472, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6447, 'last_played': 1630907051}
review: One of the absolute greatest games I've ever played. I think its wonderful atmosphere through art and music is what drives me to love it the most. At the end of the day, it's a simple re-imagination of another game rather than a pioneer. It's been modded heavily, but it's never going to be the outlet that Minecraft or other engineering games are. It sits right in the middle between guiding you and letting you roam free - and the soundtrack and art keep me moving.

author: {'steamid': '76561198224617884', 'num_games_owned': 63, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 59172, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7147, 'last_played': 1709451054}
review: This game is as fun as you are creative. While the vanilla gameplay can become stale pretty quickly, the modding offered by the game is incredibly simple and opens up almost infinite customization. Personally, the game is no longer fun to play- trying to create ships out of nothing that look good in comparison to stuff the community is currently making is just really disheartening. Having said that though, I got 1000 hours out of the game before I reached this point, so I think a positive review is deserved.

review: It's a simple premise that gets as complicated as you want it to. Lots of interesting mods, ODDMR is one of my favorites, runs on just about any PC if you tweak the settings, and it's pretty cheap.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028941219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 7583, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6570, 'last_played': 1605927535}
review:
Quick list of personal favourite aspects that stand out in this game: 
Amazing music and sound design
Intuitive simplicity in ship building
Incredible modding community and ease of mod creation
Virtually unlimited replay ability
Intelligent AI
Seamless integration between building and flying your ships

I would say it is well worth the buy at full price

review: Dynamic and engaging game.  You win or lose based on your skill.  But you'll die a lot. But the penalties for death aren't that bad, so it's okay to experiment.  Seeing what other people do in-game is amazing and provides inspiration to keep playing.  A tight skill feedback loop helps you feel like you're improving.  A very easy game to get sucked into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198934229427', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1502, 'last_played': 1588893517}
review:
Reassembly has a very unique style to it. Everything, from the ships you design to the soundtrack itself feels very organic but alien. The ship designer is great, and flying the ships themselves is easy and fun. My only real problem is that the campaign gets boring fast. It only takes a few hours to unlock the max number of building points. A couple more minutes grinding, and you can have a whole fleet of max-level ships. I've never actually conquered a galaxy before, because it's just too boring. Installing mods makes Reassembly much more fun to play, but a game shouldn't rely on mods for a campaign.

7.5/10 for low replay ability
