author: {'steamid': '76561197974228301', 'num_games_owned': 196, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1691, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1581, 'last_played': 1595699040}
review:
I found this game to be very good. It's fascinating with the simple graphics that gets combined into such weird things as the game progresses. 

You harvest "space flowers" and trade up. Your ship is entirely of your own design limited only by the current max threshold, but that will rise when you get more experience. At one point you can make bad ass battleships that can produce other ships, of your choosing.  Suddenly you swing along not-so-empty space with a whole armada of minions helping you.

After the ship designing, the best feature of the game is the regeneration. Say you dive into an enemy nest and after a while you realize that this will not work, then you escape and the ship will slowly regenerate as if nothing happened.

And the music is awesome. It really captures the feeling of being alone in the big black space, and it also captures the feeling of "things are heating up, I better watch out" and so on.

I learnt the game from this guy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swxfEZJtZAk

He also runs Reassembly tournaments where normal to super-huge custom designs of the different races fight each other in 1-on-1 sandboxes. Worth watching even if you don't play the game. https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8vKf_mXH-u7A8xd-NghdMRaeNCkVEJBm

author: {'steamid': '76561198006996339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1349, 'last_played': 1620068429}
review: Great game for the price. I really enjoy building ships and seeing how they do against other ships. This game would be amazing if it were multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025021719', 'num_games_owned': 559, 'num_reviews': 165, 'playtime_forever': 3491, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1634, 'last_played': 1702921095}
review:
This is the best 2D non-economic space wars game I've ever seen. Especially if its on sale you must get this game.

The amazing thing is it's simplicity. R is the only resource, P is the only limit on ship size, and C is your only upgrade/tech point. Collect R (either find it or kill enemies and steal it from them), carry R back to base to get C, then spend C to increase P and unlock modules. Then rebuild your ship as desired. Perfect. Oh, and all ships in the game heal themselves slowly over time which keeps it action-oriented (at least when you're not trying to improve your ship design). 

There's actually a little more to it than that, such as the ability to command fleets of ships and use a factory module on your ship to build more ships, but even without that it's fun as hell. After 7 hours I haven't even gotten into that part yet and I'm already amazed.

The graphics are very minimalist vector style but still kind of flashy with all the particle effects. No complaints there. And the music is good too.

So don't buy this expecting a detailed economic simulation with space trading, a storyline, technological realism, or any of that stuff. It's quite abstract, but it's the best 2D space wars-like game I've ever seen and I haven't even touched on all of the game mechanics or multiplayer yet. The guys who wrote space war for the PDP-1 in 1962 would approve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066942871', 'num_games_owned': 174, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1764, 'last_played': 1701036409}
review:
I've only owned this game for... Around 48 hours? I love this game. So much.
I only have three factions unlocked, so far. Terran, Farmers, and Red.
I figured I'd play Farmers, to kinda chill out and, ya know, farm some space plants.
Five hours of straight gameplay later, I'm flying what looks like a weird popcorn machine, leading an army of rocket-laden boxes on a quest to purge the system of thorns, and *eating through entire asteroids* in the process.
There's something oddly satisfying about flying through deadly space in a defenseless ship, hiding in an endless shield wall of rockets, stronger than the eight shields on my ship combined.
In all seriousness, though, the Farmers are really good if you want to lead a fleet of super-warriors, but not fight, yourself. Like if you want to put together a plan and just watch it unfold, sort of. Maintaining an income in a combat zone becomes a mild issue, but generally, you don't need it. And I should point out - no part of what I've said in this is an exageration. Except the "army" part, it was only, like, a dozen... or two..

author: {'steamid': '76561198055635068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 20322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11319, 'last_played': 1591260112}
review:
This might seriously be my favorite game of all time.

Ok, I have scene a LOT of reviews for this game saying that it not worth getting. And I have to say, I kinda see where they are coming from. There are parts of this game that are kinda boring, the flying/shooting in this game isn't spectacular, and it's kinda buggy (sometimes the bugs are funny though). However, I can most if not all of this games faults becuase of its greatest strength:

The ship building system. OH MY GOSH is it good. You know how this game's building mechanics are frequently compared to legos? Well, let me tell you, that's accurate. The building mechanic are so good, it single-handedly upgrades this from a compitent but generic shootemup with pretty but equally generic graphics to one of the most fun games I have ever played.

Ok, I can't really do this game justice telling you how good it is. So let me tell you my experience with my first faction:

So, early on, I had a tiny, weak ship, as you alwias start with. I go about the game as normal for a while. Maybe an hour in, I come accross a huge station by another faction. WAY too big for me to handle by myself. But I didn't. There were a lot of AI ships in my faction nearby. And we were all teaming up on this big huge station. None of us capable of handelling it ourselves, but together, we beat it. It really made like I was a part of something bigger, like I was fighting for the greater good of my faction.

Fast foward a bit. I now have a huge ship, with a massive fleet fallowing me. I'm no longer a part of something bigger. I'm not longer fighting for the greater good of my faction. I AM the greater good of my faction. I have risen through the ranks and now I am leading my faction towards greatness.

I can't garantee that you will have an experince as good as mine. But if it's even half as good as mine, you are going to love this game. I have played as eight factions (all seven of the vinella factions and one modded faction) and as of writting I am making my own modded faction, and I'm still not bored of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198237689422', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 20304, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17756, 'last_played': 1696322306}

author: {'steamid': '76561198027285887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 117490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94748, 'last_played': 1579559302}
review:
Man, where do i even begin?

First and foremost, my playtime should attest to that if you are capable of making content for the game yourself, the playtime is almost endless.

You can almost never "finish" a ship, there will always be possibilities for either making a creation "cooler", or making it more efficient, sometimes, you can be stuck in an eternal back and forth between them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029839679', 'num_games_owned': 900, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 2766, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2721, 'last_played': 1527442344}
review:
[h1]Reassembly plays like a highly entertaining mixture between top-down shooter and sandbox rogue-lite. It offers 7 playable factions with vastly different ships, loadout and weapons. On top of that the variability in designing and assembbling your own fleet is endless. Highly recommended![/h1]

I owned Reassembly for quite a while, but was hesitant to play it, as the for the first few minutes you feel a bit lost in the large universe. But after playing around for a bit, the smashing and stunningly colorful combat in combination with the addicting upgrading and constant redesigning of your ship make for a highly fascniating and fun game!

The living and evolving world, including you, your allies, as well as your enemies make the game feel very dynamic. In a sense it is somewhat reminiscent of Spore, but this time around the game is actually a blast to play!

The only negative is that this game truly is a sandbox, with no goals, objectives or story, which does make it feel stale, once you've played long enough with a faction.

review: Pretty much the most modular game out there. There are ways to modify how blocks work, look, shoot, how they shoot, and pretty much everything else. Must have, although this game is pretty old. Really fun to nuke everything

author: {'steamid': '76561198142786196', 'num_games_owned': 204, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 563, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1524979277}
review: Reassembly is a unique, albeit somewhat confusing at first, experience. That being said, I mean that in the best possible way. Reassembly is a game unlike probably anything else out there, and I was quite pleasantly surprised by this. The game progresses naturally and seamlessly, with more to do than what initially meets the eye. The bottom right corner has tips and tutorials to goad a new player along, and seasoned players enjoy a multitude of creative options for ship building. The game has a wonderful modding community to go along with it. I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a game that they can sit back, relax, and play. It's actually quite a calming game. There's little to no consequence for death, yet the player is driven to avoid it still, and all the while it's probably one of the most relaxing games I've played. A very good job by the devs. The soundtrack is also very good. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198025201936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 48349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35009, 'last_played': 1656895870}
review: Reassembly is a fun game and you can build tons of different ships and the mods were great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066263110', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1021, 'last_played': 1612635451}
review: It's fine if you like grind-like games but otherwise it gets really tedious really quick. The game isn't strategical, you barely have control over you units. In-game AI on your team is seriously stupid to reduce the grind thus you have to really do everything yourself. There is no way to even tell your units to "STOP PICKING UP CRAP" and just follow me (because they do pick up crap that more often than not just makes your unit to spin out of control. Idea is good though, maybe I would like it if it had multiplayer and some proper fleet control/management.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007813619', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1126, 'last_played': 1703286446}
review:
It's a fun space shooter with economical elements that ultimately lets you build and customize your own ship.

One essential part of your ship should be the factory, which allows you to build ships for your fleet. These ships can also be assembled by you, leading to a lot of interesting possibilities (think: Mothership).

Fun and easy to get into. Seems well optimised to handle a large number of ships and particles without slowdowns.
Great for quick game sessions when you have 15 minutes to kill.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981772565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4483, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3264, 'last_played': 1641037951}
review:
Reassembly is a top-down ambient space sandbox that gets pretty much everything right.

You start with a small ship and head out into a galaxy filled with varied but distinct factions. Destroyed enemies and space plants that die off naturally both drop "R"esources. At first you need to return to a friendly space station and transfer your R to them, rewarding you with "C"urrency that be used to upgrade your "P"ower limit, unlock new blocks and technology, or recruit other friendly AI ships into your fleet.

It won't be long before you get into real meat of the game - the ship desginer! With familiar features like drag-selecting blocks, duplicating, mirroring, and so on, it's very easy and satisfying to use. Blocks snap together at points on their edges, just like Lego. Each faction has its own palette of blocks and technologies that can somewhat limit the range of designs you can build, but there are loads of mods that offer expanded palettes and even entirely new factions with their own custom block shapes.

Eventually you'll add a factory block to your ship and start creating a self-replicating doom fleet - but watch out for "Agents", the game's system of asynchronous multiplayer! They are groups of ships designed by other players around the world and uploaded to the Reassembly servers via wormholes. Each new game you play includes some of these player fleets for extra Fun (tm). You never now how lethal they will be until you meet them, so be sure to prepare a capable fleet first...

With a sublime chill soundtrack and crisp vector graphics, the hours will fly by while you Reassemble your way toward taking over the entire galaxy. It's also a plus that the game runs smoothly on pretty much any PC or laptop from the last decade.

Recommended 10/10!

author: {'steamid': '76561198044753375', 'num_games_owned': 250, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 3862, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3280, 'last_played': 1622268856}
review:
Reassembly is a great game for those who wish Captain Forever gave you more time to build your ship.

But vague, incomplete comparisons aside, Reassembly is a game where the player selects a faction and is dropped into a 2D galaxy sandbox where here is no particular win condition. Dropping into the game, the game states that ships similarly-colored to the player ship and â€” apart from some tutorials to teach the player how to do stuff â€” just turns the player loose.

[h1]Early Game[/h1]
Some immediate goals the game may give to the player is to reactivate the faction's stations. What defines a station in this game is simply a ship without thrusters and they usually have ship factories. The initial situation seems to be that the player faction was pushed back by some galactic enemies, as there are destroyed factories in enemy space that need reactivated. Station reactiviation itself is easy, the player needs only to hover next to the station for about 5 seconds. The trick, however, is clearing the area of hostiles, which is hard early on with the small starter ship.

[h1]Mid Game[/h1]
Eventually new components can be purchased as well as higher "build caps" so the player can build bigger ships to make themselves more combat effective. This is around the time agents might wander into the player faction's territory. Agents are ships that another player built and sent through a wormhole that ended up in the player's game. These ships are AI controlled, but they're typically pretty overpowered and are sometimes built in some stupid "meta" fashion without any kind of aesthetically pleasing elements. They're hard to kill, but it's doable. If they're too hard, I'd recommend just slapping a bunch of missiles on a ship and bombarding them from afar.

[h1]Late Game[/h1]
Later in the game, the player probably has a massive dreadnaught that can stand up to pretty much anything. With everything unlocked, though, it gives thet player more options for ship design experimentation. Most if not all of the agents spread around the galaxy have probably been dealt with at this point. This is pretty much where the only thing left to do is galactic conquest, creative experimentation, exploration, or just starting a new save with another faction.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
There's not much to say about the combat - it's just great. It's crisp, the weapons feel good, and the combat feels physics-based because of the way ships break apart when their core is destroyed. (Which is very satisfying to watch. I'll make an [url=https://imgur.com/a/KjoE9]Imgur album[/url] of moments like that)

[h1]A Living World[/h1]
The AI in this game is actually cool. Enemy ships might attack the player on sight if the player seems vulnerable or just run away if the player has a massive dreadnaught as mentioned in the Late Game section. Stations in this game build ships, those ships go out and gather this thing called "R," (something that grows on asteroids) bring it back to the station, and that station can use the gathered R to build more ships.

Unfortunately, the AI doesn't seem smart enough to form up and attack other factions, as I have witnessed them just hanging out around their station, but it's still cool how the AI has something to keep themselves busy instead of just wandering aimlessly. It's not as if factions never collide in this game, they just don't seem to ever coordinate attacks.

[h1]Factions[/h1]
As mentioned, this game has multiple factions. [url=http://reassembly.wikia.com/wiki/Category:Playable_Factions]The playable[/url] factions are Terran, Farmer, Tinkrells, Bees, Crystallitet, Sentinel, and Red; Terran being the default faction. What I didn't mention is how stylized and inspired each faction is. They're not just recolors of the default faction, each faction has their own aesthetic, build patterns, ship parts, naming conventions, etc. This allows the player to project an ideology onto said factions. The Red faction gives off a galactic tyrant vibe, so I kill them on sight, the Farmer faction has a pretty peaceful-looking aesthetic, so I generally avoid them, and the other factions seem to give off something in between, so I sort of just treat them as neutral.

There are other factions, but the playable factions seem to make up the bulk of the game. Factions are unlocked by destroying the largest ship (The flagship, basically) of said faction. I'm not sure where the game positions these flagships, as I've only ever encountered them by accident. They're not [b]that[/b] big, but they are the largest ships in their respective faction. I remember the Crystallites in particular had some pretty big ships, indimidatingly so. I actually had to spend some time drilling into their flagship with torpedos (Very powerful weapons) to bring it down.

[h1]What Happens Next?[/h1]
In the time I've put into the game, about 40 hours were spent on the default faction. I wasn't focusing on galactic conquest, but such a task would be pretty tedious and I was mostly just messing around with a beautiful and unstoppable ship I created. After a while, I created a new save with the Tinkrells faction and they are [b]very[/b] different from the Terrans. Terran ships are more about having a wide array of weapons to choose from, weapons expected of human ships, and Tinkrell ships are more about weapon amplification. Through stackable muzzle attachments that amplify damage, fire-rate, range, and projectile velocity, the player can experiment to create multiple different flavors of plasma cannon, which is what serves as the base of all of this faction's projectile weaponry.

Another playstyle the player can engage in is never actualy designing a ship. That's right, this game actually supports a playstyle that involves never having to design a ship. Going into command mode, (Default: 2) the player can target allied ships. While mousing over an allied ship, the player can then bring up their ship design storage (Default: 3) which will then populate the target ship design into the main window, name and all, where the player can then drag it into the design storage area. [url=https://i.imgur.com/L2BiPvl.png]Here's[/url] a screenshot of what I mean. All of those entries are copied from my faction's default ships that I've seen flying around. I've even been copying station designs.

[h1]Building a Fleet[/h1]
This is a good time to get into how fleet building works. Fleet AI is very basic. You can only tell them â€” and I mean all of them at once, order groups aren't a thing â€” to Disengage, Engage Your Target, and Fire At Will. It's basic, but not in a bad way - it does what it needs to do.

New ships are built be having a factory attached to the player's ship with enough room to spit out the core of the ship that's being built. Once the core has been spit out, the ship will build itself and be the player's minion. They even give the R they collect to the player, which is mega cool. This is also how new factories are built, which is a critical part of holding territory. If there isn't a factory churning out new ships, the sector isn't going to hold.

[h1]Playstyles[/h1]
Why is the "Building a Fleet" section below the "What Happens Next?" section? Because I got through my entire playthrough without focusing on building ships and factories. I just wandered the galaxy in an unstoppable doom dreadnaught designed to near-perfection. I only started focusing on building ships and factories on my new save.

So this is a game that's more or less about designing cool ships, and it allows for a playstyle where the player copies designs from already-existing ships instead of making custom ones. This game is a good example of how a sandbox is done.

[h1]The Verdict[/h1]
This game is good for creative people, same goes for a lot of other games I praise. Go play Captain Forever, which is a free browser game that's similar to Reassembly. If you liked playing that game, you can probably justify dropping $15 on this game.

[Character Limit]

author: {'steamid': '76561198020010718', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 23270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9881, 'last_played': 1657408753}
review: very fun game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969367952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1904, 'last_played': 1551281813}
review:
Not a hugely popular game these days; It doesn't get a whole lot of exposure.

So, with that said: congratulations on finding this hidden (and forgotten) gem!

While simplistic, the game offers amazing gameplay and a good deal of replayability in the form of both default factions as well as modded factions. Each faction brings something different to the table. Some are combat oriented, other factions focus on defense, and some even focus on things like farming or cranking out hives. 

To truly enjoy the game you have to like creative building, as it takes up a large portion of the game. I would compare it to a cross between the first creature stage of Spore, the combat of FTL, and the building of Besiege.

While I wouldn't mind a decreased price, if this game actually interests you I believe it's worth the non discounted price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161516521', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 3065, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2286, 'last_played': 1684216820}
review: A game you could easily dump hours into designing your perfect ship, and then adding on to it or making an entirely new ship. Overall, an amazing game, much love to the mod developers keeping it alive. Sadly haven't seen any updates in a while. Just the satisfaction of seeing the beautiful graphics at work blowing up enemy ships or just exploring the seemless infinite space. I've personally had this game nearly since launch and have loved it ever since, I would reccomend it to anyone with a computer to atleast give a shot, because this game has really brought me joy and I think it can bring joy to you as well. I'm 13 so that's why this isn't written perfectly, just wanted to share my thoughts.Thumbs up!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062985238', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 805, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 805, 'last_played': 1485199168}
review: Fun space battles and learning to be better and stronger. Like a mini rpg-ish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055533326', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 2035, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1535, 'last_played': 1588296002}
review:
This Game really took me by surprise in a good way, I got it mainly so i could play it on my laptop (which it runs fine on). I was expecting it to be a crappy 2d Avorion but it wasn't. You have to constantly manage your faction expand your territory, build stations and grow your fleet to fend off the other hostile factions in a massive living map. I spent 10 hours in this game on the first day, it was flipping awesome.

The ad video isn't very good in showing you what the game is all about, watch some gameplay on youtube to see what it's all about.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035492528', 'num_games_owned': 353, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 7839, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5220, 'last_played': 1618543800}
review:
Happy to say that since I played it last, some years ago, whatever issue was causing the near constant crashes has been resolved. Also the expansion adds a nice new element to the game that I imagine will keep this fresh for a bit longer. I am looking forward to picking this back up when i have some free time!

Leaving original review below:

At one point this was my favorite game on steam. I have over 100 hours played time. However, I stopped playing for a while, and came back to a buggy mess. Game has crashed 3 times on me in 30 minutes tonight. Once with old mods, so i removed them, then once with only 1 new mod, so I removed that and uninstalled the game, reinstalled it, it crashed 5 minutes after starting with no mods. It really makes me sad to have to down vote this game, hopfully these issues will be addressed.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198083543623', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 8711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5485, 'last_played': 1637342390}
review:
Dieses Spiel vereint auf wundervolle Weise Design, Sandbox, Weltraumgefechte, Fraktionsgefechte und ein offene, dynamische Welt. Auch wenn ich mittlerweile alle Steam-Achievements zusammen habe und langsam auf die 100 Stunden Spielzeit komme werde ich immer mal wieder bei Reassembly reinschauen. Es gibt interessante Mods, die mich noch die ein oder andere Stunde beschÃ¤ftigen werden.

Vielen Dank an die Entwickler! Ihr habt ein wunderbares Spiel geschaffen! :-)

author: {'steamid': '76561198135358797', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 9297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7172, 'last_played': 1671815271}
review: One of the best games to play, its really well optamised and you can build anything, there is loads of mods you can install and mod making is not that hard either. I love the tournament mode where you can watch your designs/ fleets combat each over which lets you see which of your designs is the most succesfull. Like this is the game if your bored and dont have anything else to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989452470', 'num_games_owned': 409, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2591, 'last_played': 1555389486}
review: I like this game a lot. Level of customization is huge, and different races each have a distinct feel to them. You start as a fighter and can eventually work up to creating ships that create ships that create more ships. A lot of fun, I'd say worth the $15 full price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043064736', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2853, 'last_played': 1517171384}
review: This game is very underdeveloped. There is next to no weapon balance between factions, and not all factions are unlockable. The ship Building process is handicapped by the fact that pieces almost never share the same ratio of dimensions so that nothing lines up right, so that every ship you will ever build will just be slightly off symetry wise unless you want to spend your entire time playing attempting to line things up perfectly. The description of this game is misleading, as there is really nothing in this game to explore or do other than build ships, and destroy other ships. This game is very dissapointing and it takes well beyond the 2 hour playtime limit to discover this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064445937', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 11060, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7152, 'last_played': 1626310964}
review: The fluidity of movement is a joy in itself; I love just cruising through space. Great fun. Having a great time fussing with my ship designs to pack more weapon power into less space and keep my ship nimble. Don't overlook the "Test" button on the ship design screen. I've spent a ton of time just putting my designs up head-to-head against comparable designs. Love that I'm going up against actual designs from other players. I've learned lots of design tips from ships that beat me. The galaxy is beautiful. I love the organic growths within it. Great fun blowing up all the agents then jumping through a wormhole to do it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198319303472', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 206, 'playtime_forever': 27498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 700, 'last_played': 1699891797}

author: {'steamid': '76561197964905076', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 9339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9166, 'last_played': 1584899783}
review:
Good: 
1) build your own ship design as you want
2) select color's of your ships
3) varied control methods
4) some sense of procress ( currently going for the last achievement of taking over the entire map)
5) each race really does play differently, to a point.

Bad:
1) not an empire game.
   a) the stations and ships you produce do nothing when not in the sectors you are in.
   b) enemy factions will spawn into cleared areas from nothing if you don't leave a base there and after a minute an enemy fighter escaping into that empty area will cause the instant spawning of 5 to 6 other ships
3) there is no sense of territory
4) your army is not really your army and they will snatch globes of R right from in front of you.

ugly:
1) the enemy factions are never a challange, unless they are the rogues and rarely even then.
2) not really challanging.

Summery: It is a fun game to waste time and uses several features that are enjoyable.

review:
Ok, ho giocato anche troppo questo gioco; Ã¨ un bel gioco, meccanicamente, ma diventa noioso dopo 1 ora che ci giochi, sopratutto visto e considerato che Ã¨ troppo FACILE.
Si ok, non Ã¨ facile sopravvivere, piÃ¹ o meno, ma Ã¨ troppo facile "finire" il gioco e una volta che hai finito il gioco riparti da zero con lo stesso obbiettivo, non c'Ã¨ quasi la ben che minima longevitÃ  in questo gioco; ci sono le mod, vero ma, apparte i problemi di update e a volte tecnici, e i problemi di bilanciamento, una volta che hai "conquistato" l'universo che fai?
End game inesistente, ripetitibilitÃ  del gameplay non ne parliamo; unica nota positiva Ã¨ il genere e la quantitÃ  industriale di mod.
Disintallo e mi faccio ridare i soldi, sconsiglio vivamente se non volete sprecare i soldi.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999111677', 'num_games_owned': 950, 'num_reviews': 116, 'playtime_forever': 761, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 745, 'last_played': 1657070487}
review:
I held off getting this game for a couple of years but decided to try out it during the 2017 Winter Sale.

I have no idea why I waited so long because I was hooked instantly just from watching a random YouTube lets play just before I bought the game.

Played a four hour session last night, six hours straight when I woke up today, and I'm quite determined to capture every square on the map with my 8,000P missile spamming ship with total self replication.

Would recommend to anyone who likes the following:
 - Building / Designing / Sandbox
 - Open-ended Gameplay
 - Faction Warfare / Territory Control
 - Spaaaaaaaaaaaace

author: {'steamid': '76561198307302212', 'num_games_owned': 92, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 15788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10287, 'last_played': 1683649241}
review:
Reassembly is one of the best games I have ever played. With enjoyable combat and clear goals, you don't get bored of playing. The music is stunning. It definitly has a learning curve, ecpecaly with the ship editor. You do need at least a meh pc for the late/end game. As your fleet grows larger, playing on a mac will drop below 5 frames per second, and the game will stutter to a halt. But, with a decent pc it is fine. I have an i5 with a 1060 3gb, and 8 gbs of ram, and it runs flawlessly. Gameplay wise, it is extreamly fun, for the first 50 to 70 hours, but then exploring and minor ship upgrades begin to feel repetitive. That's were the classes come in. By destorying an enemy ship over 1000 p, you can play as it. This allows for nigh on infinite gameplay, and is well done. Each class has somthing defined and special about it that makes it feel like a new and fresh experiance. The only thing is, you may find is that the grind will get very intence later on. But, this game does a very good job in that it dosn't feel like grind. Some weapons or parts might cost over 20000 of the games currency, but it is ok that it does, because it adds much more staying power for the game, because you will feel motivated to play it more. I have played over 8 full days of this game (Over around a month), and my only real complaint would be the lack of classes like borg being vanilla playable, or classes like 15, who you don't even see! Also, there is a screensaver mode for some reason, and its beutiful, but not implemented or usable for some reason. 

Pros: 
Many hours of entertainment
Well made
Cheap
Controller support
Beautiful
Gives you that happy feeling
Trigger happy

Cons:
Not quite done in a few small senses
Will waste a lot of your life

author: {'steamid': '76561198015059593', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1695, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 830, 'last_played': 1662054585}
review:
First of all: I love this game because of its minimalistic (retro) style and because of its addictive game play.
The graphics could have been done on an Amiga 500 with its very good vector graphics capabilities and would fit there very good too (-> retro style). The 'what nice thing could I change next on ship (s)' works very well and keep you playing for hours.

The other side of the medal unfortunately is that the game runs good only on windows with the recommended hardware settings (but there I had no crashes and strange behaviour yet). It seems that the game was tested only on better graphics cards and perhaps nvidia only? My laptop AMD card does not work that good. On linux I get no visuals at all.

The controls work good but still need some fine tuning: menu flows, showing the state of used controls.

Perhaps it should have been marked as early access game so far even if there is hardware out there were it works flawlessly. It is still beta in my opinion.
With the very addictive game play experience already all energy of further development should go into bug fixing to run on more hardware and OSes I think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074385518', 'num_games_owned': 487, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 1374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 703, 'last_played': 1656476692}
review:
This game is fun. The ship customization is great. It's a solid top down shooter. Why don't I recommend it? It crashes constantly. No help in the forums besides 'hur dur its yer hardware.' NO. It's this fucking game. At the time of this review I have 6.4 hours of playtime, and it has crashed no less 3 times every time I have tried to play it. And every time it crashes, as if that isn't bad enough, it treats it as if my ship was destroyed, which means I lose all resources and my fleet. 

The ship customization is great, but not amazing. Each block has only certain points where it can connect to other blocks, which means that sometimes you just can't connect a block where it OBVIOUSLY fits, because the little connect points don't quite match. 

This game is really fun, and has great potential, but it comes off as a rushed beta.

author: {'steamid': '76561198189331769', 'num_games_owned': 450, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 5939, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1431, 'last_played': 1690737562}
review:
Even thought the game is at it's end and the developers aren't really updating and supporting the game the community thrives. The entire game is supported by the communitys creativity and ingenuity. It is truly amazing that a dead game can blossom so much thanks to all of the indeviduals. 

The base game sure is fun but after your first playthrought on each faction you realise that you can't build that massive battleship that you wanted to thanks to the 8k limit. Quickly you turn to the community workshop where all good starts in Reassembly. You quickly get the mod and find a lot of cool factions you want to try out most of the have their unique playstyle and some are just remoddels of the standard factions. 

This game is not for every person. It's a sandbox filled with asteroids and enemy battleships. Most of your time will actually be found in the creator designing spacecrafts that can survive anything. Well mostly anything you may find those player created agents a bit hard but after one hour of modifications you are set to go murder them all and loot their corpses.

10/10 Will play again. Well i think.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011852546', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1345, 'last_played': 1530491456}
review:
Reassembly is a fantastic fun game.  It lets you build a fleet or just a single ship and explore/battle on a 2D space map.

Good aspects of the game:
[list]
[*]Makes it really easy to build ships
[*]Can test out designs quickly, watching fun AI battles
[*]Provides a nice progression from a small start to huge battles
[*]Fun exploration aspect with great mod support
[*]Doesn't block progress if you don't do well
[*]Nice graphics
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198032014940', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 816, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 730, 'last_played': 1538586727}
review:
Reassembly is what you get when you put a space theme on the first stage of Spore. It's great fun to build highly customizable vessels and cruise around collecting stuff from "plants". 

However, things tend to get tedious afterwards. Reassembly is not particularly immersive, you're just looking at basic geometric shapes that shoot other geometric shapes. I'm not sure I fully understood fleet control, I tend to just end up with 100+ ships that are painfully slowly following me and if I want to actively fly somewhere they can't keep up. The game's entirely battle oriented, no trading, diplomacy or anything that would make you want to go somewhere. Instead just let the bosses (which are underwhelming if you have 100+ ships) come to you.

Also note that development seems to have stopped. Whatever community's left seems to be because of the workshop support, which is always a plus.

All in all it's a nice game for the general concepts involved and I hope it inspires others to make something more fleshed out. At a slight discount, you can't really go terribly wrong with picking this up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143777676', 'num_games_owned': 53, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9170, 'last_played': 1699989822}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002078465', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2356, 'last_played': 1576740983}
review:
Reassembly has no end game, but it does NOT need one. 

You will spend hours just building your ship, enjoying the creative process and then thowing it into the fray. Somtimes simplicity in a game works rather well. And dont forget that other people might have some interesting creations lurking around.. 

 There might be some issues with fleet control and maybe some things that could use expanding, but for an indie title this much is perfectly fine!

It is a heck of a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135651914', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 10724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8469, 'last_played': 1686350717}
review:
This game is a very good game about a futuristic space game where you upgrade your ship to become the best! I have already done that but the thing I really like about this game is that you can upgrade it your own way, go to different alternate universes, and more! Yes, yes I it sounds simple but you don't games like these anymore and its just wonderful! You can add lots and I mean lots of firepower. So, this game is perfect for you if you like space, building, and explosions. I'll rate it 10/10 for the gamestyle and 8.5/10 with the selections of guns and new cool stuff you can buy. (If you include the mods i'll give it 10/10.)

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198029179641', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 37918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33351, 'last_played': 1596601222}
review:
This game is a wonderful single player experience with hours upon hours of gameplay if your willing to find them, It provides interesting "build your own vehicle" gameplay with its unique take on resources and territory, and features immense modibility that is so easy even an idiot like me could do it.

If your looking for a casual and laidback experience of destroying vector space ships to a smooth, soft soundtrack, this game experience for you.

review:
This game is surprising in many good ways.

It is surprisingly fun to play, I enjoyed listening to the soundtrack for longer than I would have expected. The ship building got tedious quicker than I would have liked, but produced results that I enjoyed and were fun to play myself and play against when the AI controlled it.

review: This is a great game. I've seen people saying it crashes a lot. author: {'steamid': '76561198165266310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 7757, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4112, 'last_played': 1701468087}
review: This is a great game, the play style is highly customizeable and feels organically different each play through. Ive never had it crash, with or without mods on the old or new version. Some people have been saying the game is broken, but for me this is one of the most stable games Ive ever played. Ive left it on for a day and got back to it, played another 9 hours no problems no lag build ups. As far as single player space build and shooters go this is a gem. Still fun even with the dev moved on long ago, there isnt much to fix.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003163487', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 112, 'last_played': 1626215812}
review: It's a very good idea, and the trailers present a very cool premise, build your own designs, take them into battle, and conquer the galaxy. The problems begin to arise almost immediatly, with a tutorial that tells you WHAT you should be doing, but not HOW you should be doing. Add in unresponsive flight controls where you are telling your ship to go up, and it's still drifting bottom left (For clarification: yes I do know how newtonian phyics work, that's not the issue). Plus a UI that is vastly limited and not very understandable, and you've got a nicely designed ship that doesn't work well, and you have absolutely no idea about what you should be doing or how. Then we get to the next problem: fleet building. Sure you can build your own designs, make stations that churn out ships, but they all automatically join your fleet. Why is this a problem you ask, it's a problem because the ships completely clog the nearby areas making it impossible to navigate, you end up spending half the game in an interstellar traffic jam, and that's when they are not ramming you for no reason, stealing all your resources, and stealing the credit for killing enemy ships. Seriously, when the ships that you built and command kill enemies, you don't get any reward for it. They are literally a financial liability. A great concept, poor delivery.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997555711', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 9327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5566, 'last_played': 1676772725}
review:
You build ships, fly around, blow things up, and suck up space plants for money. A very good time waster.

The ship construction is very intricate. You build ships brick by brick, and tock by tick, just like Legos.
Although I like it, usually I just try to find the base models of ships and modify those.

It's also very easy to make mods, and there are quite a few good ones in the Workshop. There's even a helpful program by a guy named TTFTCUTS, located here: http://atg.lychnobi.com/ttftcuts/rwdk/

The soundtrack is very relaxing, and I'd recommend getting the OST. Be warned, though, you don't get it in MP3 format, so you might want to (or have to) convert it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198099244824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 14383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4616, 'last_played': 1697862205}
review:
Reassmebly is a remarkably...unique...game. There isn't necessarily much to do, just explore, kill things, get money, get bigger. Same as a vast amount of other games. There is something about it though that's just SO ADDICTIVE!! With 172 hours clocked up overall I just keep coming back to it. Itll get boring after a while, of course, but then you get nostalgic for it and do the whole thing over again.

EVERY time you play is  completely different. Whether it's something as seemingly insignificant as your shipshape (yeah I noticed what I did), or something as big as other players fleets invading your game and, 9 times out of 10, giving you hell, there's always new ways to play and experience the endless, yes ENDLESS (provided you go through wormholes), reaches of space.

Overall I HIGHLY recommend this game, even if just as a pastime. Might not necessarily seem fun to some of you but blink and hours have passed.



Only a few things I'd recommend for the devs to...tweak:

1) Don't make space so bland!! Where are all the nebula and black holes and planets and stars and all the beauty that makes space sooooooo interesting and [welcoming?]!! Even if just in the background it would be great to see something other than darkness.

2) Make drones mean something!! When only effective when ALL YOUR POINTS are thrown into drone launchers, there's no room for being able to combine them with other weapons. Except as a distraction they're practically useless.

3) Why not add some of the most popular mod factions into the game itself? (Disclosures included of course). The base factions are great...at first....but when you know exactly what their strengths and weaknesses are you start designing your ships the same way all the time, thus contradicting one of my previous pros.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083748614', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2613, 'last_played': 1688261092}
review:
Reasonably fun Top Down Shooter, more of a sandbox than what the game appears. 
for me it crashes all the time though for some people it doesnt, either way you  get used to it.

-Controls 4/10, theyre just not as you'd expect.
-AI 5/10, not the worst, not the best, Just kinda dumb sometimes
-Gameplay "4/10 Campain" "8/10 Sandbox", the campain gets boring pretty quick for me but I love playing around with sandbox and tournemants
-Community 8/10, very helpful, and very pleasent, not much else to say on that one
-Mods/Workshop and modding community, 9/10, pretty fantastic, makes up for most of the games errors.

-Game 48.3/100, I reccomend, but dont get your hopes up too high for what the game appears.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053120200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5069, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 808, 'last_played': 1687194678}
review: So im going to have to not recomend this game but first i would like to say that i did enjoy the game the thought of only building with a few different shapes to design a ship sounds stupid at first but once you get into the game and start to figure out the design process and what makes a good ship you start to make these actuall cool looking ships that are effective and fun to play with the game itself is fun and fairly relaxing that is if it dosent crash in the 10 hours i have played i probably have arround 20 or so crash reports and spent maybe  2-3 hours designing and testing shps and i could have cut that time in half but there is no autosave feature and when the game crashes there goes this huge capital ship you just designed and were in the final stages of testing or maybe your grinding p and c in the game and it crashes and your set back again or maybe you have taken a good chunk of space and it crashes and your back to ground zero you get the point not to mention when looking into the game at this point you find out there hasent been an update for at least a year now which is dissapointing considerin it looks like it was updated every 2 months nearly its a great game to play well worth the money if it didnt crash all the time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198131410340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 844, 'last_played': 1658031687}
review:
What a wonderful game. The modding community made it all the better especially with "Extra Reassabmly" which pretty much adds in a new games worth of content.


Controls- 3/10- Kinda hard to menuever around for some reason but it just may be me...

Graphics- 8/10- Its a top down shooter, wasnt expecting something insane.

Gameplay- 9/10- VERY ADDICTING. A nice gradual and calming way of progressing to the top.

Quality- 4/10- Now there is ALOT of bugs that needs to be fixed but currently all of the community says the Devs gave 
up so im taking their word for it.

Overall- 7/10- Worth the money and easy to play. Bugs are indeed a little cumbersome but the gameplay and replayability makes up for it.

Should you buy it?

Yes

author: {'steamid': '76561198271456620', 'num_games_owned': 216, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 6185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5871, 'last_played': 1579675658}
review:
Reassembly is a great little game that is reinforced by mods and the community around it. It's a pretty simple game, where you build spaceships, blow up other spaceships for currency that you then use to build a bigger, better space ship. You start out as a tiny fighter, but by the end you will be controlling a 100-ship strong fleet to take over other galaxies.

 Since every ship, station and asteroid is made out of different shaped parts, each individual part has it's own health and can be destroyed. Because of this, when building your own ship there is a ton of strategy involved as you can't just slap parts together and hope that it works. There are hull parts, which are just basic blocks to use as armour or to get the right look on your ship, Thrusters, which you need to have all around your ship so that you can turn, reverse, brake etc and weapon/utility parts which can be something from a homing missile launcher to a shield generator to protect your ship. Each part requires uses up a certain amount of power and you can increase your total power by upgrading it. 

When you destroy an enemy, explore a new area of the map or re-claim a damaged station you get some of the games currency. You use said currency to do one of three things: Unlock new parts, which allows you to put an infinite number of said part on your ship as long as you don't go over your power limit, Hire ships to follow you around and join your fleet, or increase your power limit. You can also get 'resources' from a destroyed ship or a few other things which you can turn into currency by going to a station and trading with it, or spend to build a ship if you have a factory attached.  

There are multiple factions that are all randomly placed in the 100 x 100 or so grid map, which loops around if you go of one side. The factions do vary, and if you destroy a ship worth 1,000 currency from a faction you will unlock them to play as in a new game, instead of the default Terran faction. Factions will expand by them self, destroying ships of your faction and others to build more ships and stations for them self. Most of them will attack you on sight, but there is one faction that is passive and just harvests resources, making them a good early-game target to grow stronger fast. When you design a ship, your own faction will also build said ship every now and again so you can end up with a huge fleet of just your ships if you want.

There isn't really any end to reassembly, but there is a sort-of end goal to try and achieve. Conquer the galaxy. If you can explore every grid of the map, and wipe out every other faction from it, you will get an achievement and the game is essentially over. There are wormholes, however, that bring you to a brand-new galaxy so you can start all over but with a huge ship and a fleet that you brought with you. If you do this, your ship and fleet will appear in another players world as an AI controlled boss type of thing.

All in all, reassembly is a great game that can last for a very, very long time, especially if your into modding or just installing mods, and is a ton of fun no matter how many hours you've played for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972238246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1203, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1074, 'last_played': 1513612068}
review:
I enjoyed this game a lot but unfortunately ever since they added this weird new plant species which shoots millions of projectiles the game is unplayable for me. The game is slowing down as if you were playing a slide show (I believe this effect is even intended by the devs because apparently those plants are supposed to slow you down) and you drop a lot of FPS on top of it (I think this is unintened). 

I NEVER understood why they added this stupid plant species, it broke the entire game. It was absolutely unneccesary and it is just not fun at all to play with this species in the game.

Cannot recommend this to anyone...

author: {'steamid': '76561197981447023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5904, 'last_played': 1705453936}
review: Probably the best part about Reassembly is not the building, but the environment you are presented with. While admittedly, the AI needs some serious polish, it behaves in a way that you don't see in games of a similar genre. Rather than it's goal simply being "Kill the player", it actually appears to be "Reproduce and Survive". Almost everything is dynamic, including the flora (It actually reproduces). This game gives the impression of a living, and breathing organism, constantly in flux (It is worth mentioning that nothing is simulated outside of your "vision", which is for obvious optomization reasons). I love watching smaller ships collect resources from plants (Once they or their seeds die, they turn into 'Resource'), and larger ships acting as predators. Anywho, while many aspects are very, very, rough around the edges, I would seriously recommend this game for any fan of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091733856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 5016, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3442, 'last_played': 1692770329}
review:
An incredible game that comes across as simple; but underneath the seemingly plain surface is a very satisfying top-down shooter. The factions are very diverse, and the ability to customize and create to your heart's content is one of the shining attributes that this game has to offer. The movement is fluid and very responsive, and the combat is fast paced and deadly. 

This incredible game is made so much better due to the active modding community; enjoy this wonderful game. You won't be disappointed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116189109', 'num_games_owned': 122, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 9300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2604, 'last_played': 1694802806}
review:
Today, I'm going to write a review for Reassembly, and I hope it reaches everyone who is thinking about purchasing this game.

Where to start...
Reassembly throws you into a hostile universe, riddled with factions that care only about your destruction.
When starting, there is a very gradual, and intuitive learning curve, with just enough complexity to keep you coming back for more. Even after unlocking all factions, and playing with a few which are community created, I still find this game highly replayable. Reason? Space domination of course!

There still seem to be a few balancing issues with several of the factions, but this game is damn well polished.

- Very high replay value. With an endless combination of building possibilities, Reassembly rivals some of the more well known indie games. With multiple universes/galaxies to explore, and constantly discovering new player created enemies. I have to give this game a 9/10 for replayability alone

- Very nice points system (R, C, P). The system seems designed to make you feel very powerful, and like you are accomplishing a lot when playing. However it does not make you feel over powered (except some player created factions). Player factions aside this game makes you feel like you are getting your moneys worth. 10/10

- Excellent use of propulsion/collision, and super cool, almost retro feeling graphics make Reassembly feel very polished. 9/10

- Amazing ecosystems. Reassembly has one of the most organic ecosystems I have ever encountered. From enemies repopulating, to the way a single space plant can launch a seed, stick to another asteroid, and begin growing to produce more seeds and plants, alone, makes this game worth it's price point. ShUT UP AND TAkE MY MUNNY! 10/10

- Music. I don't even know how to explain this one - The soundtrack to Reassembly is one of the absolute best soundtracks you could ever hope for in a space game. It really makes you feel at home in the game, and is extremely well done. Whoever created the music for Reassembly deserves a raise of epic proportions! I would have to say that the soundtrack drew me in more than anything. Usually when playing a game, I like to mute the music volume, and play my own tunes, but with this, I just like to turn the music volume up! Bravo to the Maestro! 10/10

Overall I have to say that I have fully enjoyed the experience bestowed upon me by Reassembly. If you're thinking about getting this game, I absolutely recommend jumping the fence, and going for it! I hope to see updates to this game in the future, but as of right now, the game is amazing as it stands.

Overall score for this game:
9.7/10

Great game, and very cool creations by the community. You will enjoy this game, if your thing is ship building, and quasi space exploration.

Thanks for reading! I hope you enjoy it as much as I did!

review:
A fun game which lets you muck about with space ships. Unfortunatly the dev seems to have abondoned the game, and won't be fixing the plethora of remaining bugs (crashes, ship designs becoming corrupt) or adding much needed quality-of-life improvements. 

If you want a game like this, get Boss Constructor.

(Note: I've left the game running for a few hours a few times, played less than Steam says)

author: {'steamid': '76561198082484338', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 127, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1468952673}
review:
This game's concept was made with a randomizer.
"Let's see... top-down... bullet hell... building game... in space. Aces, let's make this."

author: {'steamid': '76561198053300738', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 97765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60298, 'last_played': 1710671166}
review:
This game is a lot of fun! Their are endless possibilities of the types of ships you can build. I have had so much fun playing this game, and I even got my friends to play it too!

This game has been updated recently, just like my review. I now have over 1000 hours on it, and I would definetly recommend this game to anyone. Mods can be created and downloaded from the Workshop, which is fun to do and play with. This game is amazing, despite some problems, but it is fun. Also, there aren't very many people working on the game (there are at least 1 or 2 developers), so I think it is awesome that a tiny development group has managed to make this amazing game!

I definetly recommend it!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022004199', 'num_games_owned': 109, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 41210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20386, 'last_played': 1707952213}
review:
Excellent game. It is the ultimate customisation game in 2d for ships. You can even break E V E R Y limits with mods. In more you can perform anything a space game could offert : construct, battles, pratice, tests, modding, even play ANYTHING you wish to make fly. You just can't control stations. 

Oh, it is an single player game with not really story... So sandbox!

Fr : 
Excellent jeu. C'est l'ultime jeu de personnalisation en 2d pour des vaisseaux. Il est possible de brisÃ© T O U T E S les limites du jeux avec des mods. Sinon, tu peux faire presque tout ce qu'un jeu dans l'espace peut faire : Construire, combattres, pratiquer, tester, modder et mÃªme jouer n'importe quoi qui peut se dÃ©placer! Tu ne peux juste pas contrÃ´ler des stations. 
Oh, il n'y a pas vraiment d'histoire... Alors bac Ã  sable!

author: {'steamid': '76561198114668346', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 7460, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4364, 'last_played': 1705883466}
review: By far the best part about the game is its soundtrack, its fitting to point where I`d call it dynamic since it seems to change in accordance to the situation. The graphics are very simple, allowing it to run very smoothly on low end machines, and adding a minimalist look to the game. While there is only about 7 factions to play as, you have Steam Workshop support, so you can not only get more content, you can also make your own. Getting started in game is very easy as there is an in-built tutorial with every new game. (An option to turn this off would be nice though :) Building is easy but somewhat infuriating as you will build something that may not fit right, this is due to the geometry of the parts, and makes you wish you paid more attention to your Geometry class. As of gameplay, there is a variety of playstyles out there, and there seems to be a faction for everything. Overall, Reassembly is a simply elegant game that just asks to have hours poured into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068536790', 'num_games_owned': 163, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1885, 'last_played': 1679198898}
review:
For someone the likes of me, the concept of building your own shenanigan and pitting it up against other contraptions has always been fascinating to me. Seeing who comes out on top, your fucking box, or the other guy's weaponized dildo with missile spam sprouting from the tip. To your surmise, the dildo won.

Reassembly conforms to a style of a top-down spaceship shooter. Controlling your own manufactured ship, your "goal" (though indirectly implied) is to dominate every sector on the map by removing the inhabitants that subside in said sectors. Attempting to dominate every sector can be met with an implication of meeting that inevitable doom ship that you don't have a chance against.

//-[I][b]Factions[/b][/i]
There are 17 total factions in the game, but only 7, by default, are playable. Each faction is unique in their own ways, particularly design, weapon versatility, and how well they fend for themselves. Most notable feature they carry is what they specialize in, a faction might hold the title of being the most balanced faction, while others hold the title of owning the most powerful weapon arsenal, but at the cost of lower defenses. It all comes down to the preference of the player.

//-[i][b]Agents[/b][/i]
Agents hold a synonymous definition of player-made ships. They occur when a player travels through a wormhole, in which they have the decision to stay or leave to a newly birthed location. Upon leaving their current world, their fleet (along with their ship designs) are uploaded and randomly placed through other player's worlds. In the form of a large fleet, Agents are forces to be reckoned with as their design holds true to a lethal mind of a human player: ship design ingenuity. [spoiler]Okay, the last part is an exaggeration, but they typically have better designed ships than NPC's[/spoiler]

//-[i][b]Progression[/b][/i]
There's not really much to hold when on the topic of progression for this game. It's made simply through three easy mechanics.
1) Killing enemies to gain [b]resources[/b]
2) Return resources to a ship/station with a factory installed, so you can trade resources for [b]currency[/b].
3) Purchase ship parts to your liking.
It's simple, but obliterating ships for resources is fun anyway.

//-[i][b]Steam Workshop Support[/b][/i]
Unfortunately the game doesn't hold a tremendous amount of following to really accommodate for the Steam Workshop. The game can be modded to a certain extent by bringing in new factions, a modified world (either bigger or more content placed), graphical enhancers, etc.
Though initially excited for the idea of bringing in new factions built by players, it can only go so far. If you're playing with a custom faction, attempting to enter a wormhole will prompt you with an error message exclaiming that you don't have a fleet, or that your fleet couldn't be uploaded to the server because your custom faction isn't officially in the game. It is where I realized that I've met the limitations of the Steam Workshop Support and with a frown expression, I leave it to that (from the time of this review, the game has been presumably left alone and will no longer receive developer updates [Last update given was November 10, 2016]).

But hey, what's not to love about this game. It's like revisiting your old childhood memories when you played with your Legos. It's fun putting your ideas into reality (in the form of a videogame). Stepping on a Lego is just like meeting that gigantic enemy ship, add in a swarm of missiles, a few lasers, and a deathray. It's all fun in the end, right?

Go build some shit, or ship.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973153165', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1579, 'last_played': 1499810082}
review:
So initially I bought this and tried to play it and encoutered some problems (spacetime segfault).

After some digging I found my way to filing a bug report, and the developer got back to me quite fast.

So far we have narrowed it down to some Razer drivers not playing nice (and I have razer chroma everything).

I uninstalled the razer synapse software (the only razer software) and the game started working.

While this may not be the best long term solution, I have changed my review back to a YES because:


The game is a blast. 

I die a lot, its actually challenging, I like that.

How you design your ship makes a difference, it is immersive.

And the dev is active and seems eager to make this a better product.

Do recommend!

author: {'steamid': '76561198217947289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 10650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5930, 'last_played': 1634414518}
review:
As I'm writing this reviewI still have to choose: do I recommend the game or not? I guess, in the end I probably will. At this moment I have played 33 hours of Reassembly. And I'm likely to play many more. 'Cause the game is lots of fun. 

If you're reading this you most likely know it's about building spaceships. Unlocking new parts by exploring and harvesting the universe. Upgrading your old ship or building a new one from scratch. Recruiting allies to join your fleet. Fighting huge battles against alien races. Ships will regenerate as long as their command module is not destroyed. There are many different factions to play (you'll have to unlock them though). The game runs smoothly (only one crash so far), the building is simple but with enough depth to be interesting. Plus: it's modable! Again, lots of fun.

However, at this point I'm getting increasingly frustrated. Every single game I started ended after a couple of hours (at the most) because of what I believe to be a flaw in the game's design. At one point in every single game my ship bumped into a floating piece of spacestation debris without me noticing immediately that the (piece of) spacestation was in the proces of regenerating. And within seconds my ship was "overgrown" with spacestation, unable to manouvre or shake and wiggle itself loose. At that point I usually (rage)quit the game just to start again the next day because the gameplay is still fun. But add to that a bug (?) that is semi-gamebreaking: After the first time it seems I cannot use wormholes anymore (these take you to new maps). All I get is an error notification. This could have something to do with the mods I'm currently using (didn't test that yet) but anyhow it's getting increasingly annoying.

So yeah, great game if you like designing and building spaceships to fight huge battles with. But I would advise to take a look at yourself first: do you think your frustration-tolerance is up to the standard required? If so, by all means, buy this game, 'cause in the end it's lots of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043822724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1503, 'last_played': 1656212506}
review:
This game doesn't get enough love for what it has to offer - I could find relatively little information about it online aside from this page and the wikia for it. A highly stylized space game that's half ship design building and half arcade-style gunning, with no messy plot or other details to get in your way other than 'grow, kill, expand'. 

The best part, for me at least, is the ability to see your ship grow from a piddly fighter that needs to run and gun against all but the smallest of enemies to a capital ship bristling with weapons. You can also be the commander of a fleet which is...well, uh, not that good TBH. The AI is fair, but depending on your skill with ships the others will lag behind your inevitable beast of a main ship and have a tendency to get themselves caught in you or pieces of terrain. Still, it's not too damning and there's nothing like a full on war between your ships and two-three other factions to show why the game is amazing!

Other cons to note: the Spiky Plants and Bees with MESS YOUR FPS UP if you piss them off, so don't. You'll also find sectors controlled by other factions and it's because there's literally one tiny ship flying around that dodges all your weapon fire. Minor elements, but still worth noting.

review: If you like the "get money to grow stronger so you can get more money" type of games this is a great cheap singleplayer game you probably want to play! You start of with a spaceship and explore the universe to fight against other races in order to get money with which you can upgrade your ship and unlock new weapons. I really like the aspect of the game that allows you to design your ship whichever way you like; nible and fast or slow and with weaponry that makes the deathstar look like a  childs toy! Find the right balance to improve your experience and unlock new races. Really fun game overal and i sunk more time in this game than i should've for the price i paid :P

author: {'steamid': '76561198042481172', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1928, 'last_played': 1641786436}
review:
It has been quite a while since a game has held my interest for so long.  This has become my new addiction in gaming.

The concept of this game is simple: 

1. Build your spaceship using guns, armor, and various other parts depending on your play preference.
2. Pilot your spaceship in real time on a 2d plane against A.I. faction ships.
3. Kill other ships and collect what is essentially their XP orbs.
4. Turn in XP for money.
5. Increase your build capacity and unlock guns and blocks with your money.
6. Improve on your ship or make an entirely new one to add to your growing roster of ships for your current faction and watch the A.I. build your new creations to use against your enemies!

It is so satisfying to see your own ship builds being made and used by your own faction in just the ways you intended.

Make a farming ship to cultivate plants for resource orbs.
Create a ship designed with massive cargo holds solely to collect resource orbs to turn in for massive profits.
Create a ship with the ability to heal other ships using beams and drones.
Focus on shields and beams to burst your opponent down from close up.
Make high armored missle-clad monsters to take out your enemies from a distance.
Cover your ship in drone launchers and swarm your enemies with mosquitos!

You can do all of this and so much more, your imagination is really the limit.

The modding scene with this game is surprizingly great and the community is very welcoming and also surprizingly large.

Hopefully, this game gets much more attention.  It certainly flew under the radar for me but once I picked it up I was easily hooked without intending to be.  I've already put in 25 hours in just a few days and I guarantee that will rise steadily over the next few days as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120091280', 'num_games_owned': 4846, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 1224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 718, 'last_played': 1598033764}

Read on r/GameDeals: "played it start to finish before even looking at another game".  Or, if you want, this game can satisfy your atavic sensation to "not owning enough Lego" you felt when you was younger . Hours and hours of immersive beautiful lively space exploration and ship building. Played just a few minutes but felt when was buying Factorio, or Terraria: you are pretty confident that this is what you [b]need[/b] to play. 

Hit that [h1]Buy[/h1] button.

review: This game is a modern piece-by-piece, block building game that features geometric voxel-like space ships shooting in a 2D environment. The game itself has no exact end game except destroying every other faction and building big, amazing ships of doom. You can export your ships designs to fight as NPC fleets in other player's games as well. My favorite part of this game is it's easy modding and mod support.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112639485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1498434525}
review:
Cool fun ship creator sandbox game. 
You have a pretty good ship creator with lots of options in different factions. 

Pros:
-Lots of parts to customize ships with. 
-Great graphics. 
-Different controls schemes for your liking.
-You can make fleets of your custom ships, which if given factories can make more ships for your fleet. 

Cons:
-Once you have encountered all factions, that's about it. Not much more to do. 
-Limited save space. It is an ever changing world, which will eat up the allotted space in not a lot of time. Has multiple save files, but you will only get two or three because of this. 

The last con is the biggest for me. I still enjoyed my time playing it though.

review:
One of the smartest and funniest games I have played in a while.

The feeling of building stuff with the editor is the same I had when I was a kid, playing with lego bricks which, by itself, is a reason enough to grasp this thing.

I also find the off-line multiplayer mechaninc extremely nice and well thought: the idea of battling against other people's fleets and send mines in other people's game spices the (otherwise a bit repetitive) encounters.

Great.
