author: {'steamid': '76561198105373748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 635, 'last_played': 1526347998}
review:
Wow. This game is amazing. Don't let the flat graphics deceive you. Beneath the flat exterior is a game that has much charm even with the simplicity of it. The graphics, though adminteedly not flashy and 3d have a unique character all of their own. 
Each faction in the game has its own unique blocks which gives the game great replaybability. The editor is easy and fun to use. The modability further extends the playability. Do you want to play as the Galatic Empire? There is a mod for that. Want to play as the Tyranids? There is a mod for that. 

Building spaceships, even when they are complete failures (not that I know about that ;) ) is fun and very relaxing.

10/10 Would build star destroyer again.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984014266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3427, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2980, 'last_played': 1596336655}
review:
Virtually unlimited play. With fully customizable ships, being able to build them from scratch and design them with any number of variation of weapons, engines, defenses that you want, the game really has continuous replayability. Simple interface and instinctive controls, with the backing of the steam workshop, this game is a bargain for its price.

Innovative idea, being able to design your own faction and ships to your own taste, its a definate winner.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992143146', 'num_games_owned': 828, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 16330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2972, 'last_played': 1667519434}
review:
For $15, this game is great.  For less, it's a steal.
Build your own ship out of geometrically interllocking modules.  Guns, shields, power plants, armor, missiles, mines, and a dizzying array of other parts are combined however you see fit.  Make the most efficient design, and compete in the arena mode.  Make a troll face, or some other silly phallic themed space vessel.  Make a hopelessly flawed design, and enjoy the challenge of trying to overcome vastly superior foes.  Whatever, I don't care - it's a free country, do whatever your dark heart desires.  That's the point.  This is a game about dogfighting, exploring a universe full of player designs, and evolving your own designs to meet new threats.

That being said, it does get stale after a bit.  I sort of wish there was a story mode.
I still played for more hours in this game than I did in No Man's Sky.

16 quintillion/18 quintillion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014028724', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1238, 'last_played': 1498966558}
review:
First time I write a review for a game on Steam,
I felt this game was deserving it.

Imagine creating an ant colony in space, but having the ability to customize 100% of everything about your swarm,  this game feels like that.

It is the first game I play where I feel like i'm actually not the God of my army or colony, but part of something that is bigger, growing stronger.

The physics is beautifully crafted, and even though the graphics are simple, the gazzilions of things on your screen at the same time makes an art of itself, no need for texture, the world is texturing itself with polygons and quads, no intervention required...


The World is just big, like f..ing huge, and if that wasn't enough, there are wormholes getting you to yet another universe to conquer...
Plenty of races to conquer and find, only your imagination can stop you from advancing further...

The crafting for building ship, station, is very simple, yet extremely detailed, working with mass vs speed vs physix is realy cool, and gives your brain an opportunity to try things, 


It is the best game I have found myself grounded to my chair for 6 hours in a row ( 9h pm till 3h am ), in a realy big while, this game just did it.

Gratz to the dev, a very original and addictive game, 

Hope to see a Multiplayer friendly version sometime soon, maybe with some persistent server ( like a game of 30 days etc )

author: {'steamid': '76561198196159251', 'num_games_owned': 130, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9338, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4100, 'last_played': 1664145582}
review:
Amazing game, especially to just chill around. Best indie game I've played in quite a while.
Completly underated game sadly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000431775', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 207, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 207, 'last_played': 1476389981}
review:
There are serious problems with this game. Serious enough that this game's development cannot be said to be complete. There are game-breaking performance issues, game-breaking UI bugs, and the AI wasn't finished being programmed.

[h1]Problems[/h1]

1. Laggy. I don't have a power gaming rig, but neither should I need one for a game like this. My computer has a decent processor and subpar graphics card, but the amount of lag is unreasonable. The big problem with this is that the way the physics engine has been programmed, the game physics slow down when the GPU can't keep up. Consequently, I often find myself unable to determine whether I'm flying at slow speed or experiencing physics lag. This often makes me crash into things and makes flight uncontrollable in general because I can't determine my actual in-game speed.
This is an unneccessary issue, as it's possible to program a physics engine with a fixed timestep that only draws frames as the graphics card can keep up. So there's no excuse for physics lag, really, even if the user has a subpar graphics card. It's just poorly programmed.
I'm quite sure the issue is with the video card not keeping up, since I have a pretty good CPU.

2. Bug: You can change the mouse-bindings on your ship to control what is activated by the left, middle and right clicks. However, if I go into the menu to change this binding then exit, it NEVER sticks. It doesn't save the change. I've been able to work around this a couple of times, I think by alterring something in the physical construction of my ship which 'tricks' the game into recognizing that some change needs to be saved.

3. Bug: There's no point having a child ship spawn order option if the game doesn't pay attention to it. You can set four ships to spawn from your own, and the order in which it will happen. The first one to spawn for me was number 4, then number 1. So there's no discernible order here.

4. Controls: I can't gel with twinstick shooters, so I opted for the keyboard and mouse. The game seems to be designed around this anyhow. You control your ship using the WASD keys, but the W key doesn't make you go up. Nope. It makes you fly forward with respect to the current direction your reticle (mouse) is from your ship. I find this counterintuitive, but perhaps there's a good game design reason for this.
Also, it's impossible to shoot in a direction other than the one where you're ship is facing (or currently turning to face). Why? The turrets are capable of pivoting, and if for example set to "Point Defense", will automatically shoot at enemies no matter which direction you're facing.

5. AI:
I find there to be way too many ships around stations owned by the player faction. It wouldn't matter, except that they crash into you. A lot. They don't seem to have any desire to avoid crashing at all.
For some reason, laser/beam/idunno weapons set to "Point Defense" will not shoot down enemy rockets, even if they have nothing else to do. Why? I can shoot them down manually with these weapons, so the capability is there. It's just unfinished AI.

6. Limited Ship Building parts:
From what I can tell, there's no 'structural integrity' component to designing ships. Parts don't experience torque or rip off or anything like that; I think the way it works is that each part is rigidly attached to every other part, until it takes sufficient damage to disappear and disconnect anything that was connected to it. That's fine. 
The problem is that sometimes you want to connect an important part (say the ship's shield) to multiple other parts of the ship so that there isn't just one link in the chain that needs to be broken for it to fall off of your ship. You can sometimes do this, but often there are times when parts are *almost* snapping together but there's a teeny bit of space between them. This comes about from the developer not paying enough attention to the geometry of the parts provided to ensure that this will happen less frequently. An easy way to solve this would be to put in a sort of 'strut' part that can have variable length and just serves to connect two bits of the ship. But nope, that's not in the game either.

[h1]Good Things[/h1]

I appreciate the detailed options available in this game. You can change the number of physics timesteps per second, V-sync, and various gamepad options. I can't think of anything else good to say about this game, as my experience was so seriously hampered by physics lag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095090612', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 7185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5395, 'last_played': 1583434183}
review:
Reassembly Ã¨ un gioco di costruzione, esplorazione e combattimento spaziali.
Ed Ã¨ una figata totale. Punto.

Oh, volete di piÃ¹?
In generale, Ã¨ un gioco molto molto ben fatto. Ogni fazione ha uno stile di gioco diverso (sebbene i Sentinel siano stupidamente OP e i Red siano praticamente impossibili da giocare), ed Ã¨ molto divertente esplorare ogni lato di ogni fazione.

L'universo sembra davvero vivo. Le altre fazioni combattono tra di loro e i confini del loro territorio cambiano continuamente.

C'Ã¨ un bel po' di strategia per quanto riguarda la costruzione di una nave, altrettanta per la costituzione di una flotta, e ancora di piÃ¹ per l'organizzazione della propria fazione.
Personalmente, adoro restare nel territorio della mia fazione e organizzare le stazioni e le diverse navi, in modo da espandere il territorio della fazione. 

La grafica Ã¨ unica ed estremamente carina. Non stufa e dÃ  al gioco personalitÃ .

Reassembly Ã¨ uno di quei giochi (Minecraft, Starbound...) dove se finisci per annoiarti, puoi scegliere tra MIGLIAIA di mod per rendere il gioco piÃ¹ longevo.
Le mie personali preferite sono Reassembler e Infraspatia. Se vi annoiate del gioco, non lasciatelo a marcire nel computer senza fare niente, date un'occhiata alle mod. Vi divertirete tantissimo! :D

Ci sono principalmente due pecche in fatto di gameplay: una volta raggiunta la massima grandezza per la nave, e si ha costruito una flotta decente non c'Ã¨ piÃ¹ sfida. Tutti i nemici si diassemblano completamente ed Ã¨ quasi impossibile morire. Per questo, perÃ², ci sono gli agenti: flotte costruite da altri giocatori, che arrivano fino alla massima grandezza e spesso richiedono strategia per essere battuti. Se gli agenti in una galassia sono finiti, si puÃ² sempre passare alla prossima con un wormhole.

L'altra pecca Ã¨ che ci vuole una certa quantitÃ  di tempo ad arrivare alla massima grandezza. Diventa frustrante dopo molto poco dover fare tutto da capo con ogni fazione. Per questo, perÃ², ci sono varie mod. Potenziamenti gratis, soldi infiniti...

Insomma, potete fare quel che volete. Anche se il gioco non vi piace, c'Ã¨ sempre una mod per risolvere ogni problema.

Consigliatissimo, anche se secondo me non vale il prezzo completo. Vi consiglio di prenderlo ai saldi.

Quindi andate, miei discepoli! Conquistate l'universo con il potere del cazzeggio totale!

author: {'steamid': '76561197987202309', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1474866096}
review:
This game might have simple graphics and no real story to it but for what it is it is really close to perfect. Very easy to get into but plenty of depth the more you play. Everything is so polished and well done that you can really tell the developers put a lot of time and love into getting things just right. The only issue with the game at all I have seen, and it is unfortunately a kind of big one, is that when you form a fleet of ships to follow you they really don't follow you all that great sometimes. I have had over 100 ships with me then just by flying ahead straight to explore for a bit that number dropped down to 55. You can go back and get most of them added back to your fleet but that really shouldn't be a problem at all. I'm hoping they add the ability for your follower ships to simply warp jump back to you if they get too far away at some point soon to fix this, or something.

Upgrading your "P" so you can build bigger and better ships or add on to what you have is pretty fun and addictive, and producing your own fleet of ships you designed, including ones that can build other ships too to make a self replicating army, is great. 
Once you are at the point where you are flying a giant mothership armed to the teeth and can dominate the galaxy, you can always go to a new galaxy or start over playing as one of the many other very different and fun creatively designed factions you've unlocked. 

Other player designed ships invade your galaxy, which makes sure you always see something new and often challenging. I can see a ton of hours going into this game for just about anyone. You don't have to be really creative to make fun and effective ships either, but creativity does add to the fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074625094', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 4786, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1694251568}
review:
To give you an idea of how good this game is, just know that i pirated it and fell in love with it. You see guys, this game is so good that i came 'round and bought it when i didn't even need to. 15 bucks for a 150mb game (at most) and it's totally worth it. 

It is a huge sandbox made of "voxels" (hate that word) that lets you do what you want from the very start. You can build ships anyway you want, create the perfect fleet, conquer the map (it ain't easy), or just explore. Not to mention the mods that can do so much... Some make the game bigger, some remove certain limits so you can build humongous ships, some add factions, some transform the world into Star Wars, etc... 

I spent at least a hundred hours on the version I (shamefully) pirated and i ain't done playing. This game is worth every penny.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006590813', 'num_games_owned': 308, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 15334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5559, 'last_played': 1690077134}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057241222', 'num_games_owned': 355, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7514, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5931, 'last_played': 1600324929}
review:
I never write reviews on Steam, but I believe Reassembly has earned one. This game is easily worth the pricetag. The gameplay is fun, with nice yet easy-to-run graphics and good control scheme (rebindable too). The factions each have their own strength and weaknesses. My favorite is the Tinkerell faction; their modular guns can plow through any obstacle. My best experience is with the games many mods. Many add new factions, adding more enjoyment. My favorite mod removes the P limit and allows you to build ships easily 30 times over the normal limit. Combine that with the Tinkerell and you get weapons akin to the Deathstar with engines. With a simple FWOOM it pierces through asteroids and obliterates a station sectors over.
Pros:
-Fun and modifiable controls
-Plays on almost any PC
-Many factions and weapons
-Ungodly mod support that brings your enemies to their knees
-Deathstar
Cons:
-The Command mode could be more fleshed out, allowing for bigger and better battles
-AI could use improvement, I've had my own fleet push me into many bad situations (asteroids)
-I think Anisoptera is stealing my soul

author: {'steamid': '76561198127957838', 'num_games_owned': 14814, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 13379, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8549, 'last_played': 1694803503}
review:
This is probably one of my favorite Steam games, and I'm at fault for not writing a positive review sooner.

Reassembly has an immense amount of replay-ability and customization available. Each faction you can control has a unique play style and strategy to it, which makes it really fun to jump around from one type to another. Building a big agent-level ship and blasting everything to bits in one shot will not always work (though sometimes it does) - sometimes you need to spawn a swarm of one hundred smaller, probe-launching ships to take down your foes while you kite from a distance.

The game takes in other players creations (like Spore, but better, because your changes actually mean something here) and fills your space with varied and changing enemies. If you've conquered one sector, it doesn't mean that the next will work out the same way.

I haven't made any of my own personally, but I have downloaded some factions made by other players, which just expands all that much more on how much you can see and do in this game.

I'm not done yet with the game, and I probably won't be for some time to come. I've at least got to get the final achievements first. ;)

I almost forgot one of my favorite parts: The soundtrack is AMAZING. I could just idle for hours listening to it.

tl;dr
Buy this game, you will not be disappointed!

Update: I've nominated this game for the â€œJust 5 More Minutesâ€ Steam Award!
Another Update: Not that it's gonna win, but I've nominated this for another Steam Award.
Another Update: Not that it's gonna win, but I've nominated this AGAIN for another Steam Award.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044775200', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 368, 'last_played': 1473357085}
review: Wow, where to even start. Amazing game, great expandability/modability. Piloting is pretty standard for top-down space games (good options for control schemes though), but game expands into fleet control where you can spawn or commandeer other ships around you, bring them all into battle. Best of all, every ship is customizable, and there are different factions with unique ship styles and looks, and once again, everything is added to by modders. Amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198065703316', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4682, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1185, 'last_played': 1705874929}
review: A very fun and interesting game. I like building up my ship so much that i can just shoot through asteroids instead of slowing down and evading them. Simple yet complex. Lots of fun for such a small game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037300023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3239, 'last_played': 1645899737}
review:
This might deserve the title of Best Game in Genre. You play as a member of a faction and each of the seven factions have their own unique play style because they all have different ship blocks! This game is crazy addictive. Build ships and blow shit up. Simple but incredibly fun.

Note: I put cons and improvements because I think the cons are covered in mods and the improvements seem very possible to update in vanilla or put in DLC. These also don't greatly impact the gameplay. It's worth every penny, buy it!

Pros:
-Beautiful colors and light animations.
-A good amount of variety.
-The ability to map reset through wormholes allowing extended play.
-OR export your current fleet into somebody else's map through wormholes!
-The ability to export ship designs.
-Pit your ships against others in tournaments! (browse through the workshop for those fun times)

Cons:
-There aren't many weapon choices per faction, unless you're faction 4.
-The block limitation is annoying. Why can't I make a huge, intricate ship?
-More polygons for building, please!
-The AI of my fellow comrades is sometimes very disappointing, especially when they pilot a ship that I created.

Improvements:
-There needs to be a friendly way to implement mods through a modloader.
-Great ship editor. There could be a fill/brush tool and a more dynamic selection method to be near perfect.
When I say dynamic selection I mean selecting a group of blocks with a freeform selection, instead of the clunky box method.
-More anchor points on the polygons in the ship editor.
-You could easily add a story and missions. Annihilating other factions is fun and all, but I want a purpose. This game could easily have lore.

review:
Fun, stable.

You get to design your own starships.  As you travel you encounter more powerful opponenets which drives you designing more ships.  Fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038505314', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 14475, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8226, 'last_played': 1616385938}
review: This game is hands down my best purchase on steam. Reassembly is basically tangram spaceships with guns. The UI is absolutely flawless, and the building system is easy and intuitive. The animations are smooth, colorful, and beautiful. Reassembly offers a world filled with asteroids, derelict stations, plants, dangerous enemies, and sometimes even dangerous plants. You destroy enemy ships for resources, which you can then turn over to your faction for money to upgrade your ship size or unlock new equipment. If you find enemies that are too tough for you, you can still earn money by exploring and rebooting dead derelict stations or fighting weaker enemies. Wormholes allow you to reload the world and start fresh, and your fleet that you have designed gets uploaded to spawn in the worlds of other players. Whenever you start a world, fleets that other players have made will spawn as agents at the wormholes and start heading towards you slowly. This offers a challenge for late game players. Once you hit the upgrade ceiling, you can play another faction, and when you have played them all, you can mod more in. There is so much to do, and you can drop the game and pick up where you left off in an instant. The game can run on practically any PC, and I recommend it to everyone.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033462764', 'num_games_owned': 565, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3787, 'last_played': 1664382416}
review: Can't... stop... playing...

author: {'steamid': '76561198124672678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 5980, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2135, 'last_played': 1646774140}
review: I love the game, however the only problem, it can get incredibly repetitve, activating stations, travelling to another dimension and doing the same. The real fun in the game is the diversity between the existing races, each race has to be played in its own way, as well as that, you have to design new ships as they will be used by your faction. This gives many differing ways to accomplish your goal, a surgical strike with the help of fellow ships, a massive invasion as a factory ship, or idly stand by as your fleet advances with your designs. To conclude, the game gives you a single goal with many ways of achieving you goal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030120130', 'num_games_owned': 290, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 14222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3897, 'last_played': 1650926216}
review: If you like building games and space games with neat, ambient soundtracks, rave-space battles, and massive spaceships, this is the game for you. On an unrelated note, it's also extraordinarily easy to mod, which allows for really interesting stuff to be made.

review:

La 2D apporte efficacitÃ© et donne ici un gameplay simplement topÂ : on peut crÃ©er et personnaliser son vaisseau de A Ã  Z, le systÃ¨me d'amÃ©lioration et de dÃ©blocage de matÃ©riel (armements et autres systÃ¨mes) est idÃ©alement rÃ©alisÃ© (ayant jouÃ© Ã  un jeu similaire oÃ¹ la mÃ©canique Ã©tait assez obscure en comparaison). Il faut mÃªler technique, imagination et aussi limite de Â«Â puissanceÂ Â» (P) du vaisseau, que je trouve assez basse (8000 points maxi Ã  atteindre) mais suffisante pour rester en adÃ©quation avec la plupart des ennemis rencontrÃ©s.
Les commandes en vol ou mÃªme lors de la partie construction du vaisseau sont bien pensÃ©es dans leur fonctionnement (raccourcis clavier, actions avec la souris) et personnalisable.
Pour le cÃ´tÃ© action, il y a de quoi voyager et conquÃ©rir, sans compter les Â«Â univers parallÃ¨lesÂ Â» accessibles grÃ¢ce Ã  une connexion Internet. S'il y a point Â«Â nÃ©gatifÂ Â» Ã  citer, et il est dÃ©risoire, ce serait Ã§aÂ : certaines armes ont un effet de recul lors des tirs, qui peut Ãªtre une composante certainement pas nÃ©gligeable lors de tirs avec une batterie de ces armes. Personnellement surpris qu'il existe un recul sur une arme Ã  Ã©nergie.

En bref trÃ¨s heureux de Reassembly, une acquisition qui apporte de quoi s'amuser et dÃ©gommer tout vaisseau qui croise son chemin Ã  condition d'Ãªtre parÃ©. :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198004877754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1508698815}
review:
I love this game. It's like one of those super addicting browser games where you just keep getting more powerful until it's just rediculus, yet there's always a chance of defeat and a purpose for reinforcing your ship. 


Only downside is that the game is really easy to cheese, and if you play effectively(abuse some mechanics) you'll have max'ed out every part of your ships stats and unlockables within an hour.
The AI isn't really good either.

Still, i do recommend this game, with multiple factions and playstyles and an almost infinite amount of ship designs this game is a ton of fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060695704', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 173, 'playtime_forever': 1801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1413, 'last_played': 1478336165}
review:
A game where you design your own ships and eventually your own fleets. You control a single ship and can build other ships which the AI controls. 

You unlock a set of parts which all serve a different purpose and build your ships with as many of those parts as you would like. Armour & Shield parts for protection, Various weapon parts (Which vary from race to race and can be used in many different combinations to great effect), power modules (Which supply power to everything else), engine parts (Which also need to be used as thrusters to allow you to turn or slow down) and many other 'specialist parts such as construction parts

Ships for the AI to control need to be quite simple to manage though as the AIs ability to fly any non-conventional ships are quite limited (Such as 'vortex' ships and ships which generate huge amounts of recoil)

However its a fun little game which should keep a person entertained for a while

author: {'steamid': '76561198006112905', 'num_games_owned': 462, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2006, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1488, 'last_played': 1609941176}

author: {'steamid': '76561198082622857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 4130, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3970, 'last_played': 1608695660}
review:
I haven't played this game in a while, and I probably won't any time soon. For the most part, I've gotten everything there is out of this game. For $15.00, this game is decent value. If ever it is on sale, snatch it up! Then it's definitely worth the money.

When you first start out, this game is great. Lots of things to test and explore. The real problem comes later in game when you have some experience and you've played with all of the blocks/weapons/mechanics. Then the game begins to turn stale--and that's why I probably won't play it anytime soon.

I definitely encourage people to check it out, though. It's pretty cool, for what it is. Like all the "professional" reviews discuss, this game harkens back to legos and all the nostalgic dreams attached thereon.

Hopefully the dev is still out there, still thinking about Reassembly. Maybe he has a secret Reassembly 2.0 bubbling away. I hope so.

If there was a "Maybe" button, I would click that. This is certainly a Good Negative or a Bad Positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989255823', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 420, 'last_played': 1470717257}
review:
This game was fun while I played. It has an interesting style of gameplay, and you can build your own ships. These ships "evolve" while you play, and you can unlock factions. There are a few quests, but mostly in the form of completing tutorial objectives. I enjoy seeing other players fleets (agents). 

But then I completed one faction 100%, unlocking all factions along the way. Made an 8k P ship, a few stations, and a few additions to my fleet. I completed another faction 100% in a little under two hours. And now I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. If you are efficient and play the game (the way it wants you to play), any eagle-eyed player would see there are game breaking ships that can be built in just about every faction.

Personally, I feel the game has little content and replay value. While, exciting at first, it just drops off. Stops. Turns stale and boring. 

Pros:

-Good gameplay and shooter physics
-Great graphics made better by Splinter's Mod
-Seven Factions with different parts and playstyles
-Lots of variety, but only when you face off againt agent fleets

Cons:

-Once you figure out the game, you can max your faction fleet in about two hours (getting to 8K P and constructing your fleet).
-No real endgame beside tournaments/sandbox
-Too easy (at 8k P and your wits, you'll decimate everything)
-Too repetetive, even changing factions
-Not enough blocks
-Small Workshop selection of Mods (mostly factions)
-Game Breaking Ships (See forums for threads or the guides on this)
-Agent fleets can troll players making it not hard, but annoying (ships with 99% missiles or drones for example)
-Not enough real variety
-No real bugs, but there are some issues (getting stuck in quick regenerating stations, thrusters on ships not activating).

The game just left a bad taste in my mouth. It's a cool idea, but it doesn't really feel complete. There isn't enough to  keep me coming back. There was so much potential, and it's wasted. Maybe there will be a #2. 

If the game were a dollar, or maybe two, the value would match the game.

review:
A game that makes you build a ship that can rule an empire, without a fast strong ship anytime you explore you take a chance of getting annihilated by any random factions gunships. Never start a fight when you don't have backup, because the probably do. The game can have you playing for days if you let it, the need to build a strong empire and the calming music will make you lose track of time.
10/10 for the cool ships.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991590760', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1395, 'last_played': 1679084841}
review:
This game is really neat. I know I as a kid always built a fake LEGO spaceship and then put way too many guns on it to be practical. This is that game. You can do that in this game. You SHOULD do that on this game. I love it!

I will say that once you've put way too many guns on your ship it's kind of hard to start over as a new faction, and suddenly not be absolutely wrecking everything, but that's minor. You'll upgrade again and be putting way too many guns on your slightly different looking spaceship again before you know it.

Sometimes you may feel like you should make a utility ship for your fleet that is not just riddled with guns. That's okay too, eventually you'll come to your senses and realize that hull frame could be made of autocannons and you'll be back on your way to using weaponry as your primary means of propulsion. Who needs thrusters?

author: {'steamid': '76561198068647490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 7674, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2417, 'last_played': 1701190486}
review:
Reassembly is a sure way to have a ton of fun. Its simple, and doesn't have much in it - but its just so beautifully executed that I have a hard time criticizing it. The first thing you'll notice is just how damn good it looks. The simple style mixed with the flashy bright particle effects make every ship look fantastic, even if your not a skilled builder. Basically, you start as a faction with a little plot of territory in the galaxy, and must build ships with increasing size and power, collect resources, conquer and annihlate opposing factions, and eventually control the whole galaxy. 
You manage your faction in a simple screen that essentially says "what ships should we build?." Not every ship you construct will be your own, you'll find yourself making everything from Carriers to Gatherers to Melee brawlers, all supporting your faction on a galactic scale, not just following you around.
Pros
-Visuals: Just look at them. They're mesmorizing...
-Simplicity: This may not be for everyone, dont expect complexity and depth. Though this DOES NOT MEAN ITS NOT SKILL BASED, more on that later. The simple building system allows you to make pretty ships that are functional in minutes, and make enormous detailed bohemoths in about 20 minutes. Its just so easy to do,  you dont even have to be creative, really. (That is not saying there isn't lots of room for creativty.) 
-Skill: Outside of building, you've got to know how to pilot your ship. ou can die fairly easy and lose control of your entire fleet, so you've got to be careful. You can play just bumrushing everything, but you'll die a lot. I recommend lots of mobility, even in ships that wouldn't ordinarily need it. I cant count the amount of times I failed to remember to make good thruster systems and ended up with a floaty brick.
-Faction Growing: By far the games greatest strong point. Over time, as you see A.I. ships you created flying about and taking territory for you, it gives you a nice feeling of progression. You can even costomize what the stations you capture will look like. I found myself building unarmed civilian vessels and giant mining ships just so that our territory would seem lived in. I build a cheap but huge metropolis that I spammed all over my land so that it looked like there were cities. 
This stuff is not entirely nonefunctional. I found that building mini mining ships that gathered all the R (resource) they could, letting all my stations spam them out, then just recruit them all so they'd give me more R then it costed C (credits) to hire them. I would then sell the R for C and make a fortune.
-The organic galaxy: Unlike most games, the galaxy is all in one map. Its not particularly big, you can fly across it in five to ten minutes with a fast ship. (Though you likely wont make it, the amount of enemies flying around and waring with eachother will kind of get in the way.) However, I think the map is better off small. You see, if it were big like actual space, it'd be empty. This map is anything empty. In fact, its a bit of a cluster****, and thats a good thing. The map is one giant asteroid field, inhabited by countless factions all fighting for territory. Whilst exploring, you will frequently find crashed and destroyed ships, stations, etc. And there will always be plenty of ships to fight. Once you get bigger, most of them wont be two much of a threat. But every now and then, a giant mothership will pop out of nowehere and blow you to pieces.
Ships dont just spawn when you get close, they all came from somewhere. And you can, if you blow enough of them up, completely genocide them. The factions will all be trying to do this to eachother (though they likely wont ever succeed due to the sheer amount of eachother) and you will constantly stumble across epic space battles and land grabs. Indeed, the whole galaxy is a warzone, and a chaotic one at that. There will sometimes be so much going on screen all you can see are particle effects( despite this and my fairly low end PC, the games runs like butter) Being able to zoom in and out greatly adds to the games scale as well. Oh yeah.. And also, SPACE PLANTS! SPAAACE PLAAANTS!
-Soundtrack: The fantastic ambient space music fits the game perfectly, with its Psychill electronic style making for a very relaxing genocide war.
-Tournements: I had a fun time with two friends, just playing the game locally during a get together, in which we all build ships of the same P limit and made them fight in the tounrement. Making your ships fight eachother is addictive enough without it being a competition between friends, so I recommend checking it out.
-Gameplay: It plays a lot like the old arcade space shooters, just far smoother and a bit more physicsy (eiiy? Eee?) This works really well with the open world aspect, making it a joy to play. Works really well as both a timewaster and a longer effort. There are a number of ways to play Reassembly, you can spend all your time making perfectly crafted fleets and sending them through wormholes to fight other players, or you can just make one ship and be a lone wolf, building your ship to perfection over time. Me? I prefer to play it on a large scale, assembling fleets and building military strength.
-Agent System: One of the better semi-online systems I've seen. Basically, you can upload your best fleets into wormholes, and they will appear in other players worlds to wreak havoc. Its kind of like Dark Souls's world invasion thing, but you dont control the fleets you send out. They are A.I. cotrolled. Agents appear as little red triangles, and vary in strength. (depending on the P (ship size) of the fleet the player sends out). If you destroy their flagship, the fleet breaks up and stops building new ships. They will spread out, raiding your stations, but will eventually all die.
This is a fantastic way for players to show off their creations. Although you will inevitably see a few giant blocks full of guns, most of the designs I've seen have been quite good looking.
Cons
-Lack of weapon variety: Weapons are a crucial part of the game. Sadly, most weapons are just generic projectile weapons, with some doing more damage then others. To be fair, there are lasers, drones, missiles, AoEs, but every faction seems to have most of those. The faction variation is more in their visual style and armour then their actual difference in combat. There are some more interesting weapons, such as the Proton Sword, the Borg Drones (Yes, Borg), and it seems as though every faction has at least one special gun, I would like to see more weapon types in the future. Stuff like wave guns, tracking lasers, force guns to blow enemies away from you, etc. 
-Can get repetitive: Make sure to play this game in successive bursts. Playing for hours and days at a time will get boring fast, its better picked up and played for a few hours every now and then. 
Procons?
-Balance issues: I dont really know about this one, its undeniable some factions are better then others (Red sucks, Crystalline are gud) but I wouldn't really call it a bad thing. Its more of a progression system, as the tougher factions are usually closer to the centre of the map. Make of this what you may.
Overall - worth a buy. One of the best games I've seen come off Steam, and an excellent example of what Indie Devs can do!

author: {'steamid': '76561198132194853', 'num_games_owned': 147, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 765, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 413, 'last_played': 1659666430}
review:
If you like Captain Forever, top-down shooters or the flash game series Bubble Tanks, then this is the game for you. With mod support and the ability to create your own ships, this game will last you a long time. Also, if you have a potato for a computer, you can probably run this at a fairly decent framerate. Intel HD Graphics will even get you a solid 60 on high settings.

Did I mention the soundtrack is relaxing? Buy it.

10/10 would destroy a faction again

author: {'steamid': '76561198068061111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 9103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4695, 'last_played': 1692190644}
review:
Awesome game, 2D space shooter with customizable ships and a nigh-infinite sandbox world, got plenty of other options like tournament or even sending off your ships to dick around in other player's games.
From a strict look at content hours, the 15$ tag is basically robbing the devs blind of their work. You don't even have to grab it on sale and can still entertain yourself for a very long time without tire, definitely worth a buy.
Once you get deep into the game, it can easily take on another genre with you managing a fleet of your own in what can only be described as TRON on steroid. Space battles just got retro'd and it's looking fine as hell.
It's still being updated and the game still have some rough patches here and there but once you look past them and just focus on the bright flashing explosion of your ship ramming high speed into an asteroid cause you forgot to add front engines like a dumb ass, it can get VERY addictive.

Overall, solid tittle, cheap as hell, grab it and get that neon going

author: {'steamid': '76561198051639206', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 18978, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7083, 'last_played': 1694913685}
review: If you have ever played a flash game called "ShellCore Command" and you enjoyed the ship construction aspect of it then you will love this game, Vibrant Colors, Soothing gameplay and the steam workshop make this game fun to play. Fun for daaaaaaaaayyys. Some workshop items clash with each other causing instability but if you remove the offenders than it will work perfectly. Music pairs amazing with gameplay. 10.3/10.7 (V) (,;,;,) (V) Worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005884406', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 13125, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3801, 'last_played': 1706126876}
review: This game will probably take you a while to figure out at first, but once you get into it, it's pure gold. It plays like a combination of asteroids and lego. If you have ever played the indie project Battleships Forever then you will find everything is comfortably familiar. The game is probably one of the best space builder sandboxes out there and has a very simple premise;  Create a fleet of ships that can dominate a galaxy created randomly for you on every new game, each ship customised and built from armour, gun, thruster and various tech parts by you! (or maybe someone else :)  It''s small, light, programmed well and will give you hours of entertainment.  I love this game and have taken a very long in trying to create the perfect killing machine, but the endless combinations of ships and parts along with constantly being challenged by community creations (which are blended in seamlessly) along with workshop support, have brought me back to test my mettle again and again. Also if you and a friend both have the game you can load each others fleets to fight each other. Well worth it.

review:
A very good game.  I'm not sure why it hasn't had the hype it deserves, hugely underrated.

And the soundtrack is fantastic.

There's a steep learning curve, and a tutorial/guide to take you through the key steps would be really useful to newbies who may otherwise find it intimidating/confusing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024988088', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 1490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 190, 'last_played': 1576445322}
review:
This game is awesome.

It takes a moment to figure it out, and the controls aren't the simplest, but they make sense and fit with the idea of flying around in space.

You get to kill stuff, make your stuff bigger with the money you get from killing stuff, to go kill bigger stuff, to repeat the cycle? Sounds fun.

Oh, I get to get bigger guns for killing stuff? Even better!

Wait! I get to manufacture my own fleet, on the fly, to kill my stuff for me?! Oh, yeah!!

WAIT. ONE. DAMN. SECOND. I can build my own fleet, on the fly, to BUILD EVEN MORE FLEET FOR ME, ON THE FLY, TO KILL ALL THE STUFF?!

Hell.

Yes.


I recommend this in a heartbeat. Twice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120058773', 'num_games_owned': 1717, 'num_reviews': 122, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1468383907}
review:
Reassembly is the "Love-it, else Hate-it" tittle. What you see on the store page is what you get. It is well-worth my purchase. Here is my opinion;

[h1]Core Concept[/h1]
You start with a predefined ship. Explore, gather resource, destroy enemies, build/upgrade your ship, then repeat the whole process until you conquer the space, perfect your ship as far as your idea can go.

IMHO, this is where it determines Love/Hate opinions. If you like the concept, you will love the game as it has been executed very well, but for those that turns off by this kind of gameplay, it is a skip for Reassembly.

[h1]Control & Combat[/h1]
One of the two main core element. It has very common control for the genre, which can be floaty, weird, need some get used to.

The combat is rather simple from the looks, but actually there are some depth behind that plain looking combat. Weapon positions, projectile ranges, projectile speeds, special attributes, timing, and elae play the major role in the combat.

These come down to the second core element ...

[h1]Ship Editor & Management[/h1]
Simple, easy to use, but powerful ship editor. It's snap'n build style, so it is easy to understand, and to get into. You can turn you ship into anything limited to your imagination, and ... system limitation, not the all you can build.

Each part you put into your design has its purpose, and different in stat. They will affect how your ship fly, either for exploration or combat. I haven't gone much deeper into this, but it is trials and errors until perfection, imo.

You can have AI-squadmates too, which is positively nice, but a little annoyance at times.

Here comes the twist, you can fly into other players creation during your gameplay. They are AIs with custom ships, which can be ranged from wackiest ship that annoy you to hell, or the flying box of death.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
It is a good game for this genre at this price. Recommended !

author: {'steamid': '76561197971136467', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 14316, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11635, 'last_played': 1640892232}
review:
This is a really fun game that bears a resemblence, visually, to the old vector-graphics games such as Battlezone or Asteroids, but bought forward into a much more modern environment.

Like many space games of this type, you start out with almost nothing, a tiny ship with very little firepower that is going to die against most other ships it encounters, but that's ok, because you aren't alone. Scattered around near you are bases and ships of your own faction that you can, with a bit of strategic thinking, use to your advantage to defeat even large enemies. Just be careful not to drag anything TOO powerful over to one of your bases.

You can earn money by gathering resources and selling them. These can be obtained from harvesting space 'plants' that can produce resources in various ways, or from destroyed vessels. This money can then be spent on parts that can be added to your ship, and that's where the real fun begins.

The ship editor is, simply put, brilliant. You can drag and drop parts onto your ship to create a vast array of different craft, and once a craft is designed, your own faction stations will ALSO build those ships (alongside the standard designs), so you will see your own vessels and stations being used as part of the overall design of the map.

Physics apply, it might seem like a good idea to build a small ship with an enormous cannon on it (or a large ship with several), until you find yourself being thrown backwards every time you shoot, the positioning of things like thrusters will affect the manouverability of your ship etc, which means you actually have to think about the design of your vessel, and yet somehow the whole thing feels simple to use and doesn't over-complicate itself. Each faction is unique and requires a different approach to vessel design and gameplay, so you can either choose a faction that suits your style, or attempt the challenge of one that requires you to leave your gaming comfort-zone.

The music works incredibly well with the game, and takes me instantly back to the late '90's with groups such as 'Future Sound of London', and that works incredibly well with the visual themes.

Even the issues I CAN think of are largely based around things like Mods that use vast quantities of things like drones or missiles, causing the game to AI-lag or possibly even crash, or the fact that, in factions that have resource-generation modules such as Solar Panels, you can build an enormous ship filled with these modules and your factions A.I will become obsessed with them, pumping them out seemingly in preference to fighting-vessels.

In summary, this is a 4x game stripped down to its core, and it works brilliantly. Very much worth the investment.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105885393', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2378, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1673, 'last_played': 1657782861}
review:
Pros:
Fun game
Fun ship design
Interesting economy and the like
Unique world
Great factions, 2 more over powered than the others (favourite being sentinals)

Cons:
CONSTANT CRASHES

Yes I enjoy the entirety of the game.
It's very unique and very enjoyable.
But still I give it a negative rating.
Reason: This game is over a year old. It has mod support and a good healthy community. YET it crashes so often it is frustrating. There is no pattern to the crashes, the game isnt intensive in anyway. Nothing beats the frustration of spending a good 30mins on a ship only to the game crash on you. Or even worse, finally kill that stupid enemy that spawned in and destroyed most of your economy, only to have the game crash and have to do it all over again.
If you can stick through the crashes, then yes get it. But if not just avoid the game. Been 2 months since and update too... just saying

author: {'steamid': '76561198078558792', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 24983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4954, 'last_played': 1620848647}
review:
Space ship building meets Lego. Build your own spaceship from simple blocks and watch it grow. 
Make a fleet of hundreds of smaller ship and rule the galaxy as a swarm.
Or build one giant ship and destroy anyone who stands in your way.
...Or do both at the same time.
Fight against fleets made by others and send your own fleet to conquer the galaxy of someone else through the use of wormholes.
It's highly addictive.  
add workshop support and you have a game worth hunderds of hours.
At least give it a try before you hate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042559963', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6535, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5915, 'last_played': 1527116764}
review:
When I started into the universe of Reassembly, I wasn't really certain what to expect. What I got for a 15 dollar game was something amazing. You start with only one faction which you then are to use to take out at least one capital ship of another faction to unlock it. You start out tiny. As you explore and grow, learning lessons and tricks, dropping starbases and capital ships across the universe- and other universes for that matter, you will find yourself just looking to find something new. The thing is, every new discovery just sets the stage for the next new find. Different factions play radically differently, some with powerful custom built cannons, to another with few weapons, but a severe penchant for ramming- and the equipment to make it hurt when they do. 

Perhaps the most striking thing of this game, to me, is the amount of thought that has gone into it. Want to build a starbase? Build a design including a factory but no thrusters. A monster capital ship which can build more of itself? No problem, include plenty of storage. Almost everything can be resized. Changing sizes increases mass, storage(if applicable) and armor, which means youâ€™ll need more thrust to maneuver. You can not only build other ships, but build ships which can build other ships. Then tell them what you want them to build.  

All and all great fun.

Edit: Just a small addition to this to round out this review. I have found after a while the game can grow repetative. I would dare say this does not happen untill you have at least tested each faction.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007791329', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1466896959}
review:
While I already know it from the kickstarter, I didn't think much of it. It looked like a fun little arcade shooter. Something to keep you busy for a while, nothing more, nothing less.  
   
I was COMPLETELY WRONG. 

Reassembly is much deeper than you'd suspect, offering many hours of gameplay due to its well-executed procedural generation, plenty of weapons and a dozen factions. Although the game lets you roam free immediately after the short but very good tutorial (it teaches you all the basics while still letting you free to do as you please, and you'll have to learn the rest by playing), there is more than enough to do. You can build a sizeable fleet, design perfect ships, take over all space stations, wipe a faction off the map, destroy asteroid fortresses, take down strong fleets created by other players, or warp to an entire new map with your fleet.

Combine the simple, yet deep and very addictive gameplay with the amazing, trance electro music and the colourful, pleasing graphics, and you've got a great game for a great price.

I absolutely recommend it as long as you like top down / twin stick shooters and constantly tweaking your ship designs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017136894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 16194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6846, 'last_played': 1659252458}
review:
If you like games where you build a thing to do a thing, you will love this game. With all the modded factions there are endless possibilities for ships to make. Flying around is fun and the different weapons allow for a good variety of combat styles.

My only complaint is unfortunately a major one: Performance. I have an i7 4930K, 16GB DDR3 RAM, and a GTX 1060 but I struggle to achieve >10 FPS on a regular basis. A true testament to the addictiveness of this game is that a still put up with such performance, but it is *extremely* noticeable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110844526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2529, 'last_played': 1640573131}
review:
Overall, I've greatly enjoyed this game. I wasn't expecting much going in because this isn't the type of game I typically play, but I've been very impressed. The open-world style keeps the gameplay interesting, and the ship-building aspect makes for a nearly infinitely customizable experience. The process of acquiring credits to buy new ship components and weapons is a bit of a grind, but the addictive aspects of this game make that issue disappear relatlively quickly. And once you've built up to capital ships with relatively few challenges from default factions, the agent fleets mostly present consistent challenges. Additionally, with Steam Workshop support, there are many customization options.

All together, it's a highly addictive game that I've probably spent too much time playing.

review:
This game is really awesome. The mechanics are good, the AI acts not like a moron and the factions have beautiful different behaviors, tactics, stations and environment. The graphics are also quite beautiful.

Ship and control depend completely on own crafting skills. In short: It is possible to build a agile, fast and strong battleship without major weak spots.

Conclusion: This game has been made with love and the result is woth every cent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156387570', 'num_games_owned': 1053, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 4357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4243, 'last_played': 1465742802}
review:
A great game focused on building ships from a variaty of parts and weapons, and useing them to fly around fighting other ships.

The ship creation is extremely fun and you can spend hours at a time in it trying to make a perfect ship, though there are  few blocks that just don't seem to fit in due to being just the wrong size or shape, the presented challenge of working around this sometimes makes it even more fun working out a good combination between makeing the ship look good and makeing it work well(and not have weak points that one shot will disconnect half you're ship).

The other part of the game, focusing of flying and fighting is also a huge amount of fun, you can really feel the weight of the larger ships and it is always fun to kill a tiny ship with a shot the same size as it. The only limiting factor in this part of the game is the fleet of ships you can build and make, as they seem to lack a bit in the way of AI and commands you can give them, and they tend to just fly around in circles, get in the way, or get lost behind you and leave the fleet because they are too far away. That said it is awesome atacking a huge cluster of spikey plants (or as i call them lag plants) with a massive fleet of ships that you desigened and basicly melting them of the asteroids they cover.

All in all this is a great game for those with a creative streak and spaceship lovers, but keep in mind that if you try to go for the completionist achievement, you are in for the long haul, and may be driven slightly insane.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022441212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 8219, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3511, 'last_played': 1688077082}
review:
It's really a blast to play, whether it be for 10 minutes or 5 hours.  Jump in and goof off or set off on your campaign of galactic domination, both are good fun.

Every aspect of the game controls in a way that I can only describe as dead-on.  All of the control scemes not only work, but work very well.  The shipbuilding editor works fantastically well, somehow managing to correctly interpret my frenzied cursor at least 99% of the time, and comes with a full suite of hotkeys (yay!).  Even the friendly AI settings function very close to perfect.

My only recommended mod, after you've gotten good at the game, is the one that gives you 100 hostile players per world instead of 6.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003181194', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 652, 'last_played': 1542845795}
review: Fun little space shooter game. Your success or failure is heavily dependent on your skill at building successful starships. It has a high degree of replayabilty. The AI quality makes this a decent sandbox due to the fact that the factions and the world is not static; unlike other sandbox games where the game is effectively frozen in time unless you do something.

Yeah, it's pretty good.
The game itself is fun but unfortunately it's kinda hard to get in to.

The building editor is nice but sometimes can be frustrating when thing's dont snap properly
Could do with symmetry option for building.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022009669', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 17918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10431, 'last_played': 1656383041}
review:
I bought it to combat my ever-present Escape Velocity withdrawls, figuring it would buy me a couple days of relief. 

I thought wrong.

Late into the night I find myself modding files and building "the perfect ship". I love this game. Definitely the most time I've spent on a game that I originally planned to play for a few hours.

9/10 Great game at full price. Add an economy, multiplayer, and a story...you'de have the love child of EV: NOVA and LEGOS.

BTW: I'm pretty sure the ship-building in this game is actually some sort of experimental government-run IQ test. Be a dear and give them some more data.

review: I've had this game a while now, and I can't ever seem to be able to drop it. Every time I reach the endgame in one faction, I start again in another. The game is limitless, and so perfectly well done. If I could, I would give this game an 50/10. Of course, it's not for everyone, but if you like survival games with lots of progressions, sandbox games, and such, then I would recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032042257', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 366, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 366, 'last_played': 1463655584}
review: This is a surprisingly fun game.  But, although there is a tutorial, it needs to be more explicit.  That is, at least for me, when I started playing and I was exhausted and sleepy and mostly dead to the world I needed the tutorial to really drill into my head the basics of the game.  How do you repair your ship? It repairs itself.  How do you gather materials?  I'm still not quite sure. . .  maybe add a 'Gatherer' to your ship, shoot lots of enemies and absorb space debris by tractor field.

review: This game is fun and you should get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198169151606', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 637, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1566086415}
review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]
I picked this game up on steam for 15$ after i saw the game void expanse and wanted a better version of it. Well, this game is nothing like voidexpanse, its not an RPG. This is a creative game that lets you build your own space ships. AND I LOVE IT.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
You fly around space killing other faction's people.

[h1] Creativity [/h1] 
yes

[h1] Replayability [/h1] 
yes.



and it is so easy to mod, make your own blocks, factions, ect. You can be a modder with no experience if you follow the guides
10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198034299991', 'num_games_owned': 183, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 9731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3171, 'last_played': 1710717164}
review:
I can't stress this enough: [b]buy this game.[/b] 
You won't regret it. It's got beautiful particle effects, a soundtrack that makes your ears melt (it's that good), and limitless possibilities with ship design. The aspects of "ships that grow and evolve" is captivating in itself, combine that with lots of parts to choose from and an easy-to-use editor and you've got a spaceship sandbox. I really love this game.

tl;dr buy reassembly before it's too late

review: This game is hours of fun. Things that I would improve is #1 game play machanics: I would love to be able to aim myself instead of hoping the ai can get a hit. #2 objectives: Having more to do would make the game feel more alive and not get boring and repetitive. #3 Multiplayer: This game would be awesome with friends being creative together and destroying the Ai would be a blast. Over all this is a great game I would recommend it to others, however if the game was multiplayer like I  said they would be more apt to get the game and play.

review: This is a great game if you really enjoy sandbox build your own warship type of game. The controls for the piloting of your ship can be very unresponsive at some points. But this game does offer many great features as well. A few of them being a large amounts of mods have been created and are supported for it which add many new features into the game to keep it interesting. Has a bit of stale combat as it can be repetitive but otherwise this is a great game to waste time in.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065116302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3527, 'last_played': 1463670242}
review:
Summary: Very fun game where you can let your creativity run free for hours at a time or in short bursts in breaks. Excellent modding capabilities.

Just because Reassembly lacks a third dimension, it doesn't skimp on content. Design your own ships to wage war on the rest of a barren voidspace filled with factions wanting to ruin your day.

Vast variety of gameplay styles, from the passive Farmers to the rush-them-first-and-ask-later Bees.

You can also pit your creations against others, or even your Steam friends', using tournament mode.

'Agent' fleets you fight are actually from other players after uploading them through wormholes.

Massive modding options from a good community. Choices range from hardcore mode factions to easy overpowered ones. Various quality of life mods too.

Would recommend to anyone who enjoys: Space Engineers, From the Depths, Kerbal Space Program.

review:
Quirky, odd, but methodical. If you have enough firepower, you can blaze through everything like a flamethrower in front of grass, but at the same time, it takes time and effort to get there. Not much, but enough. 

Kind of like territory conquest campaign mixed with advancements with no set directives. I would imagine this to be the ... special ops of the games, if CK2 was the field marshall of the games. 

Like a single player Star Sonata.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009927041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 582, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 582, 'last_played': 1461475860}
review:
Do you like building ships without a clear goal at the end? Do you like the controls of SPAZ? If so, this is the game for you. A lot of things about this game will not make sense like the purpose and lifespan of the plants. Or how your 30+ ship fleet got reduced to half size in a matter of seconds with no opponents around. Or why spikey plants are so formidable.

BUT

This game IS still a lot of fun. Not to mention that your fleet might make someone elses game a living hell if you're good enough. You should expect about 5-10 hours of playtime before you've run out of reasons to go on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109752549', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 10760, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5738, 'last_played': 1669941251}
review:
Reassembly is a game that takes place in a genre of space games that allows you to create your own ships and use them to fight other ships. The main difference is, Reassembly does this is a very unique and different way. You have full control of what you ship, or station, will look like, except for the manditory command module. You can use a variety of parts for all of the playable factions and many modded factions. You can build a fleet to your specifications and can use it to conquer the entire universe that was generated for your faction to reside in. Each faction has its own special parts with their own specifications aswell as their own types of weaponry. 

(Note: These numbers I am using are not based on faction id's in the Sandbox.) 
WARNING: SOME PEOPLE MAY CONSIDER THIS NEXT PART AS A HUGE SPOILER. DO NOT READ IF KNOWING THIS INFORMATION SPOILS THE GAME FOR YOU. [spoiler] Faction 1 "The Terrans: The starting faction, it is very well balanced and generally simple to use. Faction 2 "The Farmers": Largest variety in parts, this faction tends to behave neutrally, but can be very deadly later on. This faction is known for its seed planter. Faction 3 "The Reds": This faction has the weakest hull armor. They do however, have the most parts on their ships, due to their blocks not being able to scale. This faction also tends to have the most weapons on their ships, and very good point defense. Faction 4 "The Tinkrell": This faction has customizable weaponry, making them have the ability to obtain the most powerful weapons in the game. Faction 5 "The Crystalline ships": This faction has very strong hull armor and some of the most powerful plasma cannons in the game. Faction 6 "The bees": This faction has very powerful lasers, and the most powerful thrusters in the game. Faction 7 "The Sentinels": This faction is well know for its nukes and obliterator burst lasers, a certain type of part can even used for melee damage. [/spoiler]

Pros:
-Massive level of creativity able to be put into your playthrough.
-Many ways to play.
-Variety of factions to play as.
-Many ships to fight.
-Very active workshop.
-Great community and fan base.

Cons:
-Their is a P limit based on the command module, amount of thrusters, and amount of weapons the ship has.
-Their is a block limit based on the amount of blocks your ship has.

Reassembly tends to the needs of players who like combat, building, or both. Their are many different ways to fight, just like their are many different ways to build.

author: {'steamid': '76561198182049209', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 30292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6773, 'last_played': 1678615361}

author: {'steamid': '76561198064558690', 'num_games_owned': 311, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 25959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1969, 'last_played': 1696797256}
review:
How to conquer the galexey in 5 simple steps.

Step 1: create an armed ship with a factory module.
Step 2: using that module, create a copy of that ship
Step 3: set the copied ship to produce more of itself (it will automatically produce other ships and even stations as well)
Step 4: congratulations, you now have your own self replicating fleet.
Step 5: Enjoy watching your fleet overwhelm anything in its way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000022908', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2053, 'last_played': 1698581818}
review:
When I first saw this game, it looked like a very pretty, simple space sandbox game I could enjoy. When I finally bough it, I fell in love with it inmediatly! I spent lots of hours creating my very own spaceships, optimizing and expanding them, and then again and again. It has several unlockable factions, each with their own blocks and capabilities, so that each one requires different playstyles, and thus different designs. Devs have been very active, so it seems this game will keep going for a very long time. If you like spaceships and you are a creative player, this game will keep you entertained forever!

PS: sometimes it's just pretty to look at all the NPCs doing their things and interacting with each other. It feels like an aquarium!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983323833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 3176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1611, 'last_played': 1667791418}
review:
This is a solid and fun game that combines space shooter elements with a sand box and ship design. The fact that you can both upload your designs to appear in other players' universes and encounter theirs as roaming and often deadly 'agents' along with the game's 7 inherent playable factions (there are some non-playable ones as well) plus workshop support make this game a lot of fun.

You start with a simple small ship but you can unlock both more systems to build with and larger ships via combat and resource gathering and can unlock the other factions via battle so you can try their unique playstyles in future games. The best part of the game's factions is that while they all have some similiarities, they are quite diverse and not simply reskins of each other.  Playing the starting Terran faction is quite different from the Reds which are different from the Sentinels and so on.

You eventually get to build ships from your ship and can keep them with you or release them and they'll defend areas as your control expands. Your AI allies will even build copies of your ship and you can use the interface to affect their production queues.

You also have a lot of control options and can even set how your weapons are keyed so you can fire every weapon via the LMB or put even big cumbersome weapons on point defense duty if you like. There's a lot to love here.

Heartfelt recommendation from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126406378', 'num_games_owned': 191, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 2741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1879, 'last_played': 1681658856}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090205613', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 2213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2101, 'last_played': 1474211675}
review:
A really fun little game to build ships, unlock the factions and just mess around in general.

What to expect:
Tonnes of fun, simple yet addictive gameplay in colorful, neat "geometry-graphics", a super fast download (the gamefiles are incredibly small. I guess they must have built the engine and all from scratch. + the game has pretty much no textures that need to be saved apart from the background. not much more than 100 mb to download, not mmuch more than 200 mb drive space required).


What not to expect(>as of right now<,28th March 2016):
Story, real-world orientated content, real multiplayer, Crispy shaderengine-graphics.

The soundtrack really does sound nice, but of course it gets old after some time. Thrusters behave mostly newtownian but are aoutomatically used in a blanced way (an asymmetric ship is possible, but if you don't have thrusters to break and turn, your kinda screwed.)
The current multiplayer is just that it let's you meet ships designed by other players (they come in strong fleets that have a main ship, they're called agents. The main ship is not the strongest ship but the one he player used at the time of upload.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198028166299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 13773, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12364, 'last_played': 1701418697}
review:
TL;DR: Amazing unscripted top-down space combat/expansion indie game with great community and plethora of quality mods to add content to game. If you liked SPAZ or Starsector, youâ€™ll LOVE this game!

For a game made by one guy, heck, even compared to other indie games with teams of developers, Reassembly ranks up with there with my favorites. Reassembly can be compared to Space Pirates and Zombies and Starsector, 2 other top-down space exploration/combat games; however, Reassembly has them both beat in customizability, unscripted expansion/development of the player faction, and ambience. The gameplay is easy to get into and gets as complex as your creativity can make it, yet still retains simplicity which makes it easy and fun to sit there creating a large complex spaceship tailored to your desires. As you expand and grow your faction, your AI will begin building ships you design for them and in order to expand more you could employ many ways to take over sectors of the galaxy. From bringing a fleet of ships to having a carrier with masses of drones or even piloting a singular dreadnought to carve through enemy territory, or even coming up with your own tactics as you can create any kind of ship you want block by block (even copy pasting big chunks of ships to create modular designs) the designs are limitless!

As for quantity of content, the base factions are interesting but when they get bland the developer made Reassembly open source allowing anyone to easily create their own factions or even universe altering mods and upload them for anyone to download and play from the Steam Workshop. The community, while small, is one of the nicest and most dedicated Iâ€™ve seen, and youâ€™ll definitely never run out of quality new factions to download and try out or play against. This includes mods that change the entire galaxy to a star wars themed galactic war to mods that create a 2 faction war between humans and zombies in space, to... well just check the Workshop and youâ€™ll see all the amazing stuff going on! 

P.S. Nominated this game for the "Just 5 more minutes" Steam award because I've definately played this instead of slept despite having class in the morning.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027202941', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1742, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1679522516}
review:
This is pretty much spore's cell stage, the reason why i bought the game. 
create whatever comes to your mind, test it out in a 2D environment and optimize your ship. 
Another reason why I bought it was because i wanted a simple (looking) space simulator, my wishes are totally fullfilled. 
Multiplayer would indeed be a nice thing to have, currently it's like spore: the game imports other player's creations and puts them in your game.

Bought it full price, no regrets...

author: {'steamid': '76561198053495672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 10679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5717, 'last_played': 1710781784}
review:
The game is a time sink for better and worse.

You can spend hours mindlessly pew-pewing enemy ships you stumble across with either massive fleets or solo with a massive warship that has a dozen energy shields and is armed to the teeth with offensive options.

My biggest gripe is that back when I tried using the modding elements native in the game, I would have to scrap an entire faction file I was working with because it would bug out ([i]back in 2016-2017[/i]).

It's impressive that this game is created from LUA coding.

I'd love to see a more robust Reassembly 2 ([i]or spiritual sequel[/i]) that manages to implement a way to add new factions and stuff without all the issues I had faced ([i]again, it was back in 2016-2017 when I played with modding this game[/i]).

([i]I am kind of traumatized to try to see if the 2022 updates fixed anything with the modding tools inside the game, because I hate having to redo things and I had spent a week at one point working out a faction just for the file to get borked. The editor was known for adjusting variables haphazardly that were not being adjusted and the experience reminded me of Bethesda's Creation Engine and how it would have similar issues that ruined mods I was trying to make for Oblivion and then Skyrim[/i])
