review:
Once you have your fill of the vanilla factions, go explore the workshop. Quadruple your play time. Then quadruple that. MODS EVERYWHERE!

What says more for this game than anything is the fact there are only (as I post this review) 61 negative reviews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052256616', 'num_games_owned': 344, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1226, 'last_played': 1661488014}
review:
Very good balanced game. Replayability is available from the fact that you can play as 7(?) different factions. It is also immensely satisfying to build your own masterful capital ship and after hours of tweaking declare it perfect.

I'm editing this review 5 years later just because even after all this time, I really haven't found another game that does what this game does better. There are plenty of customizable ship games, some with better objectives, better AI, or even actual story, but somehow this game manages to be the best at the actual construction part. This really is a great game that I just appreciate more as time goes by.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995079481', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 744, 'last_played': 1644704795}
review:
This game is dangerous. I sat down - and next thing I knew six hour had passed.

Endless upgrades, design revisions, trials, errors, and an eternal crusade acros asteroid fields and stars alike - leaving only wreckage and the dead in my wake.

I think I should stop playing this and start a hobby that is less addictive than games like this: Like heroin

author: {'steamid': '76561197989594474', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108, 'last_played': 1458488733}
review: Controls are a mess. I would expect a game like this to control like a twin-stick shooter but it doesn't. I tried all three of the control schemes and none of them allow me to control the ship reasonably.

author: {'steamid': '76561198105900139', 'num_games_owned': 115, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1753, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 754, 'last_played': 1509035148}
review: From the start this game looked really good, and after watching a few YouTube let's plays on it I decided to get it. This was a mistake. Not because the game was bad, but because I got addicted to it. It has a simple premise, but still manages to be fun, engaging, and alive. This game is definitely worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031399020', 'num_games_owned': 195, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 3981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3674, 'last_played': 1579210949}

author: {'steamid': '76561197990667177', 'num_games_owned': 2416, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 3144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1266, 'last_played': 1709912817}
review:
One of the best games of it's genre. This spaceship building game, combined with the freedom of creativity, physics and mod support makes this one of the most underrated games right now on Steam.
I can't express how much fun I had with this one. Worth the full price tag, and even more worth considering there's offers around.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965669702', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 631, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 631, 'last_played': 1440436680}
review:
It's not a bad game, but it's not a great game either.

It seems like with all the factions the programmer had some larger plans for this game. Such as inter faction trading or some sort of diplomacy. 

Sadly, there is only one thing to do in this game, build ships and blow up all the other guys ships. It gets old fast. Really fast.

Also, the ship designer really could have used some more work. All the parts don't fit together correctly. With some of the ship parts, the connection is just slightly off from the other parts. This means your dealing with small slight single pixel splits in your ships... arg...

If the developer for this game ever decides to improve this game, or bring out a sequel with high level functions like better trade and faction interaction that is more than just all out war all the time, I will be interested. Until then I have to put this game on the shelf.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040910824', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 3029, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2805, 'last_played': 1580079707}
review:
This is a really great game!  One of the best I have played in fact.  However, there is a lot of room for improvement.  

For example, an online mode that allows you to fight other players would be really awesome.  
Also, if command mode allowed you to control you ships more directly that would be really nice too.  
Finnaly, more difficult AI in the center of the galaxy as well as  a bigger galaxy would be awesome as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009844171', 'num_games_owned': 389, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4021, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3619, 'last_played': 1457000074}
review:
Reassembly is a decent sandbox shooter that has a relaxed atmosphere.  The best part, obviously, is building your own ships and experimenting with designs.  As you gather resources you can purchase better parts.  Each of the factions have a unique theme and require different strategies to design. The ship building interface is very intuitive and easy to use, which is a big plus.  

It's a nice, chill single player game but I think overall it lacks depth, which I will describe below.
There's really no need for specialization against any particular foe. With such flexibility in ship design I was hoping this game could push this concept more.  Once you have a decent ship it works against all factions almost universally. You can fiddle with designs for a while, but in the end, more expensive parts will make you better.  With many factions it's quickest to destroy enemy ships for resources, so that becomes your sole focus.  Once you max out your ship, basically nothing stands in your way.  Unless you tried to get all the Steam achievements, like I did, there's not much of an end game to keep you playing.  I spent most of my time on this game grinding out achievements. 

In conclusion, it was fun but lack of depth put me on the fence on this one.  After getting all of the achievements, I feel like I tapped out all of my reasons to keep playing.   I would have liked to see the ship building aspect developed further.  I'm leaning on the fence to recommend this game, but it was still fun for the time being.   If you feel like this game might be something you'll be interested in then you'll probably enjoy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080805910', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8762, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1806, 'last_played': 1692763441}
review: Best Game Ever

author: {'steamid': '76561198261808995', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 4470, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 267, 'last_played': 1624272183}
review:
Played this game for many hours outside of steam. This game is quite enjoyable, relaxing experience. Take your time to build ships however you want for whatever roles are needed - go out and expand your territory, or if you are like me and favor the Farmer faction simply populate surfaces with plants and watch as your fleet size grows. Of the very few down sides to this game is a lack of detailed instructions on the part functions ingame (you basically have to memorize them, learn from guides and videos posted by others). Some in-game mechanics are also lacking documentation (such as how to restrict building of ships). All the lack of documentation issues generally don't add up to much problem once you have played a faction for some time however.

Overall a very good game and an enjoyable experience. Definitely worth the purchase if you like building stuff and seeing how well it performs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072724466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 12829, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9348, 'last_played': 1470800003}
review:
Let's talk. Sit down. We're here because we care about you. Now we need to talk to you about your problem. Pick one from the following list.
- You bought Reassembly.
- You have not bought Reassembly.

This game is that sandbox you played in as a kid. While most people were playing GI Joes and army men, you were pretending that firetruck was a star destroyer. That Tonka truck was a Carrier. This game is that sandbox, and that Carrier is real.

Anything in your mind can be made in this game. Do you want to build unrealistic space gods that spin at 2000mph while sneezing death? Do it. Maybe you want to build a true to design Star Destroyer, or the BattleStar Galactica? I've seen CIS Control ships, the Serenity, a Borg fleet, and a literal pirate ship with tiny whale escorts. If the blocks fit, you can build it. And the blocks always fit(not).

As for actual mechanics, this game starts you out as a tiny little fighter. You destroy enemy ships, reactivate defunct friendly stations and gather resources. These resources allow you to upgrade your ship, until one day you too can build a battlecruiser the size of a small moon. You can also produce your own fleet, which can in turn produce its own fleet or follow you into combat or both. There are tons of ways to play the game, and little things you will find that feels like your own little trick.

TL;DR: This game is too much fun. You will get addicted. You will stop playing, and then come back and splurge another 50 hours on it after you think you forgot about it.

P.S. To whomever has been on the receiving end of my 190+ ship fleet dumps the last two days, I'm sorry, but I need your galaxy. Enjoy the SuperCap, 20 frigates and 170 teeny fighters :)))))

author: {'steamid': '76561197970278270', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3017, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1699, 'last_played': 1458518800}

author: {'steamid': '76561198275994761', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 36999, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10743, 'last_played': 1673930019}
review:
Reassembly is a topdown, vector, 2d spaceship building game where you can do anything you want to build with the multitudes of faction palettes. The game still gets updates and support, and has an expansive workshop collection that you can explore.

The background music is great, and really gets you in the mood to build and explore, especially with the new soundtrack released with the fields DLC.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041565318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 873, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 801, 'last_played': 1669014873}
review:
It's another "almost great" game. Trying to hit any but the biggest and slowest ships with ballistic weapons is nearly impossible, laser weapons have very short range, and missles are rediculouslly slow and half the ships can out run missles. Better weapons would have made this a good game.
Also, there is a way to make your ship pieces build in symmetry, so putting one piece on the right adds the same piece on the left, except I don't see how to make that happen. I had it working for all of 20 seconds, and it was great, but then it quit working and there is nothing in the help expaining how to turn that feature on/off, and guessing by hitting buttons didn't help.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063283014', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10861, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4694, 'last_played': 1600904933}

author: {'steamid': '76561198088170861', 'num_games_owned': 94, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 593, 'last_played': 1538468386}
review:
Incredible ship building/space shooting game.

I am a big fan of space shooters and the fact that you are able to build a whole FLEET of your own ships is amazing. However, the agents in the game is really a party foul when your travelling in space. For me at least, they would block my path to a worm hole and i kept getting shot down. I understand that you are supossed to grind and build better ships but the difficulty of the agents are too damn high...

Overall, this is very very VERY good game. Hopefully, they will be adding more playable matches and even a multiplayer mode where friends can work together  in the same fleet and conquer the universe.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008103529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 76249, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 259, 'playtime_at_review': 1083, 'last_played': 1711756689}
review:
I don't often find a game that I can't put down - but this is one. Now officially my favorite chill-out game. It's a strategy game set in a rich living world. Design your ship from scratch using basic building blocks. Pilot it round a large area of space using Newtonian physics - i.e. you carry on moving in the same direction once you have built up speed, without further thrust, and regardless of the direction you are pointing. The game uses a wrap-around map. Harvest resources, trade them to improve your spacecraft. Fight enemies and try to take space sectors from other factions. Recruit allies and form a fleet. Put a factory on your ship and spawn new ships. Travel to other maps using "wormholes". Fight other players' uploaded fleets (not true multiplayer but a contest of designs). You can also use the wormholes to upload your own fleet designs. Unlock new factions to play.

You could make it a fast and furious battle or a leisurely affair - up to you. I'm 9 hours in and feel I'm only just beginning to scratch the surface. A real indie masterpiece and a credit to the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965993239', 'num_games_owned': 955, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 1955, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 843, 'last_played': 1676183956}
review: This is a cool game if you love to build things, but like your games easy to learn, difficult to master.  Lots of upgradable pieces, and even mods on the workshop to expand the play to new factions and fandoms, parts and playstyles... from Star Trek, Star Wars, and Warhammer ship and faction mods to gameplay balance and new parts mods, added ships and more, this little game is something that is pretty much infinitely replayable, if a bit difficult to get started with as at the onset, money is slow to accrue for upgrades... But mods can help with that too, if you do a bit of hunting in the Workshop. Highly recommended if space and building spaceships is fascinating to you!

author: {'steamid': '76561198067145805', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 5009, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1961, 'last_played': 1628988923}
review:
So, I love the idea of this game, and hope it gets multiplayer in the future, but I have a few problems with it:
1. Ships can be made insanely fast, too fast for most weapons to even have a chance of hitting.
2. All turrets have the ability to turn 360 degrees, making ship design as simple as slapping as many guns into an armored ball.
3. Engines can be inside your ship, meaning there is no way to damage them without first destroying the components around them.
I love how the building works, but I feel like there's still a lot of balancing that needs to be done, since the meta just dictates blobbing up as many guns as you can fit with either:
a. shittons of armor (which is entirely free most of the time, so you could make a massive armored box at the very beginning)
b. shittons of engines, making you pretty much impossible to hit with anything but lasers (although the speed is best put into use by the AI controlled ships, since they can instantly dodge out of the way of almost any attack)

I love this game, but I hope it gets the things I mentioned.

Edit: I just also need to add that the only part of your ship that the AI shoots is your core, so it is optimal to leave extruding parts of your ship unarmored...

author: {'steamid': '76561198065602785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 5346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3341, 'last_played': 1677741610}
review:
Cannot wrap my head around the controls. Do not really understand the mechanics. Constantly dying.

The game itself is probably brilliant, but overall it is too difficult for me.

30 hour update: OK, I get it now. This game [i]is[/i] a brilliant, highly addictive combination of RTS, shoot-em-up, bullet hell, and sandbox. It's digitial space Lego, with a slick aesthetic and beautiful sound track to boot. The moment when my brand new Starcraft Battlecruiser, the Norad III, materialized for the first time was one of the most simply and deeply [i]satisfying[/i] in any video game ever.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034379048', 'num_games_owned': 429, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 1725, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 771, 'last_played': 1619319555}
review:
It's like spore's cell stage, but actually fun.

Seriously, though. It's an incredibly fun game, and though it suffers from the drawback of many sandbox games (in that the coolest designs aren't necessarily the most pracitacal) I enjoyed it a lot. A bit tricky whn you're starting out but once you unlock the factory and figure out how to build a fleet it's pretty awesome.

Great soundtrack and aesthetics. Fun gameplay. Overall a great game

author: {'steamid': '76561198110465176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 7767, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2952, 'last_played': 1617336781}
review:
This game is a simple concept expanded upon and made extremely entertaining (read: addicting). All you do is build a ship out of 2D shapes, shoot other ships, and try not to get blown up, all while making your blocky ship bigger and better. And yet, the game manages to do for me what even big-production space titles like Elite: Dangerous couldn't: absorb me in an expansive, living universe that I got hours of fun out of. It's easy to jump into, there's unlimited creative potential in making your ships, the destruction effects are satisfying, and you never run out of things to shoot, because the only thing there really is to do is expand your territory by destroying enemy ships, of which there are in (sometimes frustrating) abundance.
The "passive mulitplayer" mechanic is enjoyable, because while you can't very well taunt over the wreckage of destroyed player ships hoping to give your enemy some quality killcam footage, you can still feel smug knowing you just trashed the MVP of someone else's universe without expecting them to come back for revenge. 
The game world in its geometric minimalism is surprisingly atmospheric, almost organic, and this feeling is certainly helped by the Brian Eno-esque music. There's no real plot that ties the 6 factions together as far as I know, but I feel like any kind of story would weigh down the smooth simplicity of the gameplay.
All in all, Reassembly is probably the most fun you can have in space without doing cargo runs. 

(For bonus funtimes: Be the Sentinel. Get the Armor Spikes. Make buzzsaws. Be unstoppable.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198158113684', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 3529, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1060, 'last_played': 1681414419}
review:
Were you the type of kid who didn't care too much for following the instruction manuals of Lego model kits?

Did you instead prefer to do your own thing, namely invent and construct crazy space ships then have them battle each other on your bedroom floor?

If so, you'll love this game!

It gets a little shallow after the first 15 hours or so, but it's a real blast and the fun and replay value lies in all the wacky ways to put together a viable ship, plus the different factions you unlock all give you different arsenals to work with. 

Looks like there's a solid modding community too, but I haven't explored that yet as I'm still enjoying the base game.

This is a very fun game with simple graphics.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972265474', 'num_games_owned': 1143, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1454751319}
review:
Alright, so I just bought this on a wim because it was cheap and looked decent.

I'm glad I was right, wasn't expecting much at first, until a lil over 6 hours later and I couldn't take my hands away.  This game has SO much replayability, limitless customization, fight the creations of everyone else, and warp to different areas that are all different.  It's essentially endless gameplay value for just a few bucks.

10/10 def worth a buy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970627230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 37694, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22264, 'last_played': 1705205319}
review:
After some ridiculous number of hours assembling fleets of warships from fighter to super-death-machine 2X, I decided that this is probably the best top-down shooter I've ever played. Whether your death-machine is incredibly manueverable and flies circles while spraying white-hot death, or a slow-moving tank that absorbs hundreds of shots on its mile-thick armor plating before its quintuple banks of burst lasers burn through the enemy to the core, you'll have fun dismantling it, making it better, over and over again, unlocking new parts, more points to use on them, as your drone-launching, resource-harvesting, station/fleet-building monstrosity burns its way through the universe. 

After I maxed out the first race, of course I did the same with every one, having fun the whole time, testing my ships against the normal ones as well as the user-designed ones until I had achieved the proper mix of lethality and style. 

You build an incredibly customizable ship, an equally customizable fleet, in fact you can get a good list of ships and stations done and switch universes so that only your stuff is out there; or go back and order all the existing stations to change to your designs, telling stations to become warships and vice versa.

In summary; they could make it better. Could add more races? Maybe some more meaningful level of large-scale control? Yeah, this one's only good for a 9/10. 4.5/5. 97/100.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053508326', 'num_games_owned': 697, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 7636, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3721, 'last_played': 1698626653}
review:
This game is just like spore but without the civilisation part. and alot harder....ALOT HARDER!

Accidentally stayed up for 2 days straight trying to perfect and optimise my tiny lego bugship things for most efficient reproduction and combat. then stopped after trying to figure out what i'm suppose to be accomplishing...then continued playing some more with my tiny lego bugship things.

This game is mostly grind and becomes frustrating after a while of playing it for too long, especially with no clear endgoal. it's still fun to have though if you like spore

author: {'steamid': '76561198040335683', 'num_games_owned': 401, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1454900010}
review:
Reassembly is the game I never knew I wanted, but man, did I want it badly.

A 2D top-down shooter not unlike space invaders or asteroids in the sense that you fly around and shoot stuff. Reassembly takes it to a whole new level, allowing you complete customization of your ship. You can connect various parts, which snap together at points like legos, to create whatever your mind can come up with. At the beginning of a playthrough, your ships will be small and fairly weak, but as you advance you will be able to fly massive frigates followed by your very own custom fleet.

One of my favorite parts of ship creation is the physics of thruster placement. Where you put your thrusters actually matters a lot; your ship won't be able to turn very well if you only place them on the back. This also lets you build some funny creations such as ships that travel by spinning. It also means that if you are having trouble progressing, you can completely change the feel of your vehicle by moving or adding a thruster.

Creation aside, the game revolves around the aquisition of currency (called "C") and resource (called "R"). You get both of these basically by blowing up your enemies, the other ship factions. You use your C to buy upgrades and new parts for your fleet, allowing you to take on bigger enemies. If you manage to conquer your whole galaxy, no big deal, the game allows you to jump into a wormhole to enter a new galaxy with your fleet. You can also unlock new factions to play as; all of them utilize different base shapes for their ships, meaning you can create entirely new ideas playing one faction that you couldn't with another.

If you feel like you've peaked, you can upload your fleet, sending it to other players' games as a powerful opponent called an Agent. This is a really great part of the game, it keeps things challenging and fresh.

Overall, I put this game in the same circle as Spore. You create cool things and share it with others. The game is fun to look at, very colorful, and it has an awesome soundtrack. If you like building things, if you like space, or you like shooting the hell out of ships, just go buy Reassembly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043433121', 'num_games_owned': 193, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 3830, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1992, 'last_played': 1703383381}

author: {'steamid': '76561198097242570', 'num_games_owned': 177, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1979, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1780, 'last_played': 1557169938}
review:
Honestly, this is my first review. I have to say, I really like this game. There are somethings that could be done, like more content.There is just a lot of things in certian faction where as others, they're really empty. I spent my first session on this game, and completed it within 12hours(hit the cap and conqured the map (once) and got allraces). That's one sitting. (on weekend) I really wish some more things were added to it, mods filled the rest but it's just grinding and doing the same things over again. I built a fleet to the size of 700+ ships. NOTHING STANDS IN YOUR WAY. I'm talking cheap small ships though, like 42-45p. The 8000P Cap is dis-tasteful. Although I got a mod to increase the maxium amount of P. It feels dead. There is nothing striving me forward. Usually, when I play games were you reach an extent of 'stability' in a game, I would decide to expand and make things more efficient, bigger, better than they're suppose to be in the first place. (like an ever growing population) This game is diffrent. You have to Build a ship, and get stations, and farm resources. That aside, I really loved this game with building, customizing, there is alot of freedom to it that I enjoy. One things I found a very easy way to exploit was to just put all my weapons on Point Defense. No need for me too actually use my guns myself. Another thing I hated was the weapons, there wasn't any speacialization or limitations with what I could stick on my ship as long as it could fit with the P limitation it was fine. I am happy with the factions we have, I don't think neccesarily we need more. A storyline would be nice, I just go around shooting everything instead of expanding with friendlies, making alliances, trading, capital ships. I wish this game was a lot more than it is now. One more thing I like to add is the AI, the AI doesn't know how to do anything. All my weapons carve straight to their core after they decide to 'rush' me.


PROS:
*Great Community
*Great Mods
*Great custimization and build
*Great Potential


CONS:
*Lacks content and variation
*Limitation in P
*LACKS*** Challenging Enemies  <-- sorry typo. ^-^
*Once you hit endgame, nothing can touch you.
*AI Lacks


5.745/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197961342429', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1828, 'last_played': 1454969396}
review:
The first 30 minutes were quite confusing with stuff flying everywhere. Then I realized the potential and depth of this game. Even with simple graphics, it is possible to create awesome ships and fleets. There is also room for a lot of interesting strategies. Want a sentry outpost, just create one. Want a frontline factory, build one.

Already many great mods out there, that also add to the depth and complexity.

The only thing I'm missing is multiplayer. I know it is impossible to implement without rewriting the whole code, but if they ever make a sequel with MP, that game could easily be among the top games on steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014852545', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 5386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2892, 'last_played': 1604435623}
review:
Okay so i got this game last week and has already put in 50 hours, so in other words i really like the game, i think it's one of a kind i have never quite played something like it, i can spent hours in the ship making page, super cool, but i have found 2 problems which has had a huge negative impact on my experience

First off, factions seems to be kind pointless, because with over 50 hours, i didn't not once experienced that another faction acted as whole, in other words, a faction and all it ships just stand around completely idle doing nothing, never trying to take down station or conquer another faction unless they're within their detection range. making the game such a pushover as the enemy faction ai never challenge you, Also your own faction seems to have no AI of its own, when you're busy conquering the universe not once did a have a allied fleet come and help me unless i paid them or was in same area, unless you fly straight into the enemy fleets, which also as far as i know are completely idle if the player is not within its detection range or sector area

Second off why doesn't enemy ships evolve as time goes on? Once you have a max P ship at 8k or even 6-7k, you might as well just start another game because at that point the enemy is powerless against you, hell i even installed the mod that does so there is at all times like 40 agents on the map, and i download all the highest rate/sub modded boss fleets, even so once i hit that 6-8k P nobody can touch me...

Overall i think this game is the best sandbox space sim out there, giving it a 7,5/10 :theinterceptor:

author: {'steamid': '76561198003004240', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 3594, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2112, 'last_played': 1593255863}
review:
2 hours in and I knew it was a great game, 15 hours in I had to tell others about it!  So here I am.

A 2D top down space shooter whilst accurate, is a poor description for this game as there is much more to it than that.  The graphics although basic are perfect for the game.  The sound is also well chosen.

You start in a pre-designed ship but as time goes on you can add to the design or just create a new one from scratch.  There are a decent variety of weapons and other modules to choose from, like rockets, missiles, torpedoes, mines, lasers, projectile based weapons and crazier ones.  Your ships can also house a factory to build other ships on the fly, which in turn can have a factory and can build.  With a bit of time you can have a fleet of AI controlled ships following you around until you dismiss them to do their own thing, and they do.  AI ships not under your control will continue to gather resources and contribute to your factions efforts.  Time to colonise and control the galaxy!

The map is large, and the factions varied, although I am now starting to get slightly bored of the existing factions, but there are many more in the Steam Workshop.

My only criticisms of the game are as follows; Agents, which are player made ships that spawn into the game and severely ruin your day, are often too good and numerous when they first appear.  You could ignore them until stronger, however once you give them a foothold in the galaxy they are really hard to remove.  In addition, you reach the endgame of progression in terms of unlocking blocks and maximum ship size too soon, normally after a couple of hours.

All being told, an excellent buy.

EDIT: Nominated it for the Steam Award â€œI Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Awardâ€ Award.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148261941', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6912, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1666743514}
review: I love this game, super fun and addicting, with an amazing soundtrack. Although I do have some issues, the databank (where new parts are available for unlock)after the first time playing i closed the game after saving and then came back a few hours later and the databank no longer had a scroll bar or was missing most of the oarts, making it impossible to see/access all the parts that can be unlocked, If there is a way to fix this, I would appreciate the help, otherwise it is a great game in the making, after i fix the issues im having I may see how well the game can be modded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007334267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3096, 'last_played': 1516548844}
review:
I suspect more and more people will be buying this game! The mechanics are flawless, the music is very atmospheric, (like starbound!) designing spaceships is only limited by your imagination and its incredibly soothing to just sit for hours building then testing your creations. Its very sandboxy, you will not be dissapointed. My new Death Star is 75% complete, and takes up almost 1/3 of my monitor!

                            
  Would dream of building Death Stars at work/school/on the toilet again.     10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198012191131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 835, 'last_played': 1636924827}
review:
You know, I've been waiting for a game like this to appear. I love space, spaceships, and I love games where there's something that lets my creativity run wild. Glad I found this gem!

This is a game where you control a single ship of faction you choose at the beginning of the game. You can customize it however you want it with the pieces the faction provides. Each faction is unique in a way and none are the same. You fly around, you shoot enemies, gather resources, unlock new modules, grow in power, build up your ship to become an unstoppable destroyer, unlock other factions to play as, and so on.

Of course you don't need to fly alone, you can build up your fleet, or hire pilots from your faction to join you and fly with it. You'll soon be able to conquer the entire galaxy. Also, the galaxy has a fair amount of 'agents', which are fleets that were made by other players. Most of the ones I've seen so far were pretty formidable so if you see a red arrow, you should run until you really feel confident you'll break their ships with ease. Oh, and if you're done playing in that one galaxy you started in? Use a wormhole to fly to another one! This will also upload your current fleet, and chances are, someone, somewhere, on planet Earth, will be soon encountering your very own fleet on their computer. And he'll probably have trouble destroying you.

What's truly beatiful about this game is how simple it looks, and how complex it actually is. You could actually consider this game some sort of art. You start in a tiny sector, and you can see pretty early on how dynamic the world is. The AI harvests the minerals, grows in size, expands, it gets better with you, and so on. For example, I once built a single ship that could build stations. I manufactured it from my flagship, kicked it from the fleet so it could be independent, and guess what. Soon enough, when I came back, there were like, 15 stations there, and a whole lot of tiny little fighter ships scuttling around. It was an awesome sight. To be honest, the game kinda looks more organic than scientific. It's like actual organisms battling against each other. Sort of.

Well, either way, if you like space, spaceships, and space battles, if you like being creative, if you like shooting stuff up, if you like seeing your ship grow from a super fast tickling drone to a slow, massive hulking beast of absolute annihilation, if you like sending your enemies to oblivion, then chances are you're going to appreciate this game. It's got a fair amount of replayability, and even though it looks simple, it's really lots of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002604134', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 96, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1686, 'last_played': 1452909380}
review: There is about 15 hours of gameplay here that involves nothing more than shooting stuff. Recommended for what it is, a space shooter, though it could be a lot more if it involved some objectives or quests or loot or ANYTHING more than just shooting. The ship builder is very cool at the beginning, but eventually gets quite stale when you realize that all designs are  armor on the outside and everything else on the inside. X of this, Y of that, etc. Would be better if there were some proximity bonuses to make the designs require more thought. Mods help flesh the game out a bit more, but none offer what is most needed: more stuff to do.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069879270', 'num_games_owned': 290, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 22687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16853, 'last_played': 1647234015}
review: Reassembly is, in a nutshell, spaceship editing and combat done right. The editor is a snap to do just about whatever you want to do. For example, you can copy your ship and stick the new one on the front of your original ship in less than 5 seconds if you're even halfway decent at using the keybindings. Another good thing is that you can change reassembly from a miminalistic game to a Tron-esque visual style, allowing you to run Reassembly on an old or new computer and use whatever RAM you have. And if you're STILL not convinced, it has mods, adding new factions with surprisingly well-written lore and enormous assortments of weapondry. Some even add entirely new block shapes (sounds unimpressive, but just try to build a functional spaceship out of pentagons) . Then there's the challenge faction mods, with oddly shaped blocks, low energy generation, and an array of other problems to deal with. Overall, Reassembly gets a 19/20. If you're on the fence about it, buy it on sale for the price of three chocolate bars. However, it's worth noting that it hasn't been updated in two years, and is probably not going to be updated again. Also, player fleets are hilariously broken, easily wiping out anything if built decently (read: with enough thrusters to move and a gun that isn't short-ranged) since they're either cheap enough to build an army, or powerful enough that only 3 or so annilate everything. And so far there aren't any  mods that buff enemies enough for them to stand up to fleets, though at that point fleets would be mandatory. Melee damage (only with blocks that boost it) is also quite powerful, but balanced somewhat in that having enough maneuverability to counter melee blocks' mass is difficult. There also isn't a good endgame, as by the time you've built up your ship to the default 8000P (ship power, used for adding functional blocks to your ship) you're usually strong enough to blast through almost every faction alone. And then only one more ship turns the middle sectors from challenging to simple, especially if you specialise it. Despite this, it's still a fantastic game, but about 40% of that is the excellent mods. Grab a friend, each design a ship and send them into tournament mode for a interesting competition.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091873339', 'num_games_owned': 968, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 1735, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1641, 'last_played': 1560052010}
review:
-Can make any ship in this game.
-Decide to make aquatic themed ships.
-Makes resource-gathering crab,
-laser-stinging jellyfish,
-drone-summoning hammerhead speedster,
-missle-launching dual laser cannon turtle mothership,
-and the humble spinning sea urchin.
-Enemy fleet shows up.
-They end up destroying most of my ships.
-I start spam spawning sea urchins because they are cheap.
-Turns out 60 sea urchins wrecks everything on the map.
-I fly off with my spinning sea urchins and tanks full of resources.
-Repeat
-???
-Profit!!!!
A great game with a lot of replayability.
It is a top down space shooter with shipcrafting as the main focus.
There are several races that have specific blocks and weapons,
so they have different advantages and crafting outcomes.
Sit back, play some music, and wreck the galaxy.

review:
This Game is simply beautiful.

There are some minor inconsistencies when playing, for example you can spawn enough ships to get your system to lag but i guess thats better than having a cap on your fleet, but since this game is still in development one can only hope for it to get even better.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049017229', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 1635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 770, 'last_played': 1595988240}
review:
If you have ever played (and liked) Void Hunters on fun orb, you might like this one.
The creation editor is more complicated than I was expecting, and it can be a little frustrating to try and get a certain piece to attach a certain way, but other than that it is a fun game. Sandbox style open world environment, and glorious ship customization. There are different types of weapons, and so different strategies.
All in all, a fun casual game.

review: I love this game. It has a good amount of polish.Soundtrack fits this game seamlesssly and sets the tone. This game doesnt try to be anything other then itself, sure this game has smiliraties with games like asteroids and the like, but it ISN'T asteroids. It provides a sandbox feel  when you feel like killing time, or the ability to prep for war and attempt to take over other universes. (which I am not very good at) I would recommend this to anyone that enjoys crafting games, space games, or exploration games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981205497', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 2096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2063, 'last_played': 1611973361}
review: The game feels really unfinished and it seems as if someone got bored with working on it and just published what they got done. That being said, I have 19 hours on it for a reason: it is still a blast. I can't imagine how fun it would be if they actually finished the game. It is somewhat like old spaceship fighter games, but with a fairly complex designing system. The damage on the ships is pretty fun too- parts get blown off when they get hit and slowly you reassemble over time if you make it to safety. You are supposed to take over territory, but the system for it isn't complete and it is a somewhat broken, annoying bruteforce type of take-over required to gain meaningful territory,

author: {'steamid': '76561197974713479', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 8362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7593, 'last_played': 1453165881}
review:
People who should buy this game:
You enjoy building custom ships and pitting them in tournaments against other custom ships in AI vs AI matchups, much like Gratuitous Space Battles, but with far more detailed shipbuilding (and less "gratutious price gouging"). To me, this is where the value of the game is at and where the vast majority of my invested time has gone.

So if you get the game, I suggest you play with it for an hour or two, "Test" your designs against other ships and then google for "Reassembly forums" and find the online community and therefore the tournaments. That will take you down an amusing road that you can indeed spend 100+ hours on, as I have. I really enjoy designing and testing ships.

People who should probably not buy this game:
Anyone looking for a long lasting, interesting single player experience that does not involve building ships for tournaments. While this game does have a roguelike(?) portion to it, and I suppose some people may get dozens of hours of enjoyment out of it, there's really not much to it. You fly around and "conquer the galaxy" but the mechanics of doing this basically involves flying around and shooting everything in your custom ship, which IS entertaining for a few hours, as you grow and tweak the design, but I felt that part got old fast. It's just not very interesting. Maybe if the galaxy had more actual strategy to it or an overarching metagame... I mostly just play as a faction enough to unlock all the parts and then go design ships for possible tournament play because the galactic battles seem so droll.

Still, I can't NOT recommend it considering I've put over 100 hours into a game that I think I pay $9 for. This game probably won't knock your socks off but it's neat and interesting and not a bad way to spend a few bucks if your interests are at all like mine.

Oh, search YouTube for the tournaments too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025403939', 'num_games_owned': 941, 'num_reviews': 388, 'playtime_forever': 3981, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3981, 'last_played': 1440688438}
review:
Pretty fun game to mess around with. Designing own ship is really fun, I managed to make lots of different designs, but the one that's stuck in my mind is the spearlike ship I made (it's super fast in one direction and has lots of armor at front), that could run through any enemy or asteroid, given it has enough speed. "Completing the game" is quite fast, but the achievements really extend the things to do there. Although I'm quite bit ashamed of my "Completionist" achievement, as I find it was more work than fun, and certainly points to that I have no life.

Overall really fun game, I rate it 8 wormhole jumps of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197973012562', 'num_games_owned': 900, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 2922, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1067, 'last_played': 1594669567}
review: Those commenting that this is a hidden gem is right. Damn is it unexpectedly interesting. Yes, I did buy it due to the positive reviews and the mentioned ship building. However never did I expect it to be so refreshingly unlimited. Because every weapon can shoot through your hull (presumably because it is actually on top) and hull is free, you could make a giant ship right from the start. however, it would be slow or almost uncontrollable thanks to its mass, but fight a few more ships and you might just get the dough to add more thrusters. Suddenly you could build yourself a flying wrecking ball. Is insanely small, high impact more you? Go for it. Want to have weapons all over your ship? Sure. Everything is at your fingers and damn is it addicting to constantly build, test it in a fight just to lose horribly and then rebuild it in a different way to achieve glorious victory. Heck even after you win, you might just realize that you forgot to add enough storage so you cannot collect all those resources you just earned.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067564893', 'num_games_owned': 478, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4958, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 955, 'last_played': 1628990369}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025420022', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 723, 'last_played': 1589704337}
review: Most people will have grandoise ideas of the ships they can build and they are probably possible. But! you won't be making those ship right out of the gate or even soon after. There is a pacing to the game and it's done rather well. Depending on how content you are with the status-quo you can rush to make bigger ships or not. A very fun game that you'll probably get your money's worth before it possibly out stays it's welcome in unlocking different races.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128684968', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 5297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1583726692}
review:
I do enjoy this game, its fun to just sink time into and destroy an entire colony of spikey plants with your 20+ probe fleet.


Game Play summary:

Modify Ship.
Build a ship.
Build a ship (but this time you know what your doing).
ReBuild Ship with new parts.
Rebuild ship with the realization that the trapazoid hull block is a size adapter.
Die from crashing into space vines.
Watch your ship attack other ships.
Attack other ships.
Get a fleet.
Get your r stolen.
Press 'c' tp trade R for C.
Enter a worm hole.
Die.
Respawn.
Relize that the day is over.
Cry into pillow.

-edit-
Wake up.
Learn that each faction you unlock has different weapons and blocks and play styles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041185846', 'num_games_owned': 943, 'num_reviews': 155, 'playtime_forever': 3966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2546, 'last_played': 1585190242}
review: Love it

author: {'steamid': '76561197995985473', 'num_games_owned': 2646, 'num_reviews': 321, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1451163163}
review:
I... honestly have no idea what's even going on this game. Everything happens so fast and without explanation, tutorial objectives seemingly completed for a reason I can't really determine just because I happened to blink at the wrong time. If it's not that, I'm getting annihilated in 1-2 hits by any opposing ship, unable to defend myself because the default selection provided is so painfully underwhelming.

Scrapping and building from scratch isn't viable, either, the starting weapons absolutely worthless and block shapes that aren't particularly conducive or varied enough for sensible building in the long run. Could you theoretically grind for resources to eventually build the ship you want? Sure, but it seems counterintuitive when the core direction is undoubtedly combat.

That's not to say [i]Reassembly[/i] is completely flawed, of course; the music and art direction are indeed very good and it is a neat idea overall, just not very well executed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117811720', 'num_games_owned': 187, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1824, 'last_played': 1606920703}
review: Pretty amazing game, you can just make ANYTHING. There are almost no limits to your imagination! Amazing!

author: {'steamid': '76561198022107690', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 170, 'playtime_forever': 1642, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1642, 'last_played': 1520639751}
review:
I'm not sure if I should hate this game for having such a floaty and, to newcomers, hard to operate flight controls. 
I'm not sure if I should love this game for being so creative, offering an unlimited amount of customization options for me to shove onto my shop and make it look like a blatant ripoff of a Star Destroyer, while having rewarding combat, a pretty cool RTS kinda gameplay where you can build and create your own army to throw at enemies or other players, and so many different ways to play, whether I want to ram my ship into an enemy ship with a tiny little interceptor with a photon sword, or just show up with a massive supercruiser with guns coming out of every orifice. 

I'll give it a thumbs up to show you which option I went with. I'll also give it a thumbs up due to how much the devs put into working on the game and improving it. It's really nice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110991563', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1635, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 589, 'last_played': 1489037749}
review: It's like Asteroid, it's like Subspace, it's like Homeworld...  it's a pretty damn good concept, well executed and addictive.  You basically are thrown in the middle of space with a small ship and you have to gather ressources to make your ship bigger, and build more space ships that will themselves build other ships on their own.  It is a living game, where the environement changes and where enemy factions fight for control of the ressources.   Get ready for intense action: sometimes more than 500 ships fighting at the same time!

Reassembled Steam Reinstalled Reassembly Rechecked Result!  Restored Faith Revisited Reveiw to Recommended with Relish!

author: {'steamid': '76561198154584046', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5769, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2389, 'last_played': 1601758209}
review:
I have a total of just over 20hrs into the game. The first 15 were on an old windows computer where It was still very fun, but the graphics weren't as good as they could be and it lagged horribly whenever I went near the spiky yellow plants. Recently, I realized it was compatible with my brother's new Mac and the graphics were amazing and it only lagged when I made tournaments with hundreds of drone carriers.
Reassembly really has it all.
-fun piloting
-customization
-semi-realistic physics
-Mac compatibility 
-mod support
-giant AI battles

It doesn't get boring 5/5

author: {'steamid': '76561197990894638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 1852, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1603, 'last_played': 1610229101}
review:
WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOWWWWWWWWWWW Best game i played this year. Thank you!! So addictive... This year i have hough over 80 games including two consoles (xbox1 & ps4) but this is amazing, If you have PC this is a must buy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! :)))))

Basically you create your own spaceship and faction. All the other factions are bad. What makes this interesting is that you play agains real/uploaded ships. This is addictive bcoz you keep upgeading your ship and trying to take over. Since I intalled it today i havent stopped playing it until this review as it crashed for reasons unknown but im glad it did as in one go i spend 9 hours omg. i never done this in a game for awhile. 

Thank you :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198019038274', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 5818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3143, 'last_played': 1655641790}
review:
A very nice intermediately difficult / time consuming sandbox space shooter. It's fantastic, although the friendly AI can sometimes ruin your day by taking all your damn resources. 

I highly recommend this to anyone who prefered the single-cell stage of Spore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017246905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 119, 'playtime_forever': 4867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4822, 'last_played': 1538483558}
review:
Decent Game. I love the idea. The building and the concept. 

Sadly after you unlock everything the game gets stale very fast. There is nothing really to do at the end of the day. There is no goals or objective. Other than Agents that do not respawn, factions do not attack you and everything that is not in your area is inactive and dormant. 

I don't think it was worth 15 bucks, but because i love this concept i hope the dev uses my money to make an even better sequal that has more depth and content. 

Thanks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067645429', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 8977, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1301, 'last_played': 1602085459}
review: This game is just terrific. The Exporation as awesome and the ship building is fantastic. There are a few things I would wish would be put in the game. The ability to create stations and even colonies. That there was an economy and the ability to great allies amoung factions. Also, unit creation could use a tweek, like I can order different crafts in different tiered stations and space ports. Besides that, great game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198001217176', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 594351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 106296, 'last_played': 1708572483}
review:
[h1]Update (5/4/2017):[/h1] Wow it's hard imagining how hyper I was a year ago. Stat update: 90 products, 1 review, 2,276+ hrs, still a good game. Come visit us at our community discord at https://discord.gg/DSvmNbY when you get the chance, random stranger, passerby reader, friend.

[h1]Edit (3/21/16):[/h1] It's been 4 months. Looking at my stats it says: 51 products, 1 review, [i]1400+ hours[/i]; I know what you're thinking... DO NOT [spoiler]CALL 911[/spoiler], I have assuredly not been [spoiler]taken hostage[/spoiler] by this game. I just happened to leave the program running 24/7 every now and then. There is [i]totally[/i] [b]nothing[/b] to worry about (please don't judge me!)... 

I have found that most of this game's replayability lies in (1) - creating and enjoying the diverse player-created mods and (2) - pitting ship designs against each other in competitions amongst friends [spoiler]as a frantic cry for help[/spoiler]

Mods are incredibly easy to work with (using and creating) and can be downloaded or turned on/off with minimal hassle. With [b]absolutely zero bias none whatsover[/b], for a quick graphics spruce-up, you can visit my graphics-upgrade mod at http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=644263599  

[h1]Actual Review (12/10/15):[/h1]
I've always had a soft spot for the build-your-own-spaceship genre. I enjoyed Captain Forever, Battleships Forever, Gimbal,  as well as Stardrive 2. I have no idea how I didn't find out about it until now. 

I think Reassembly takes the great construction and space combat elements of all those games and puts it in one solid package. I was surprised to see it run smoothly during heavy action (unlike Stardrive), In its category, the decent amount of gameplay depth and accessibility help make this one a top tier 2D-space-builder-shooter. Sure there's some things that need fixing (such as the tutorial checklist showing up every time a new game is started) but even so I would wholeheartedly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006545785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 622, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 622, 'last_played': 1426108435}
review:
Gets pretty dull after a few hours when you are pretty high up, but those hours before that are highly fun.
Much of the territory control/claiming is obtuse and not easy to plan.
But if you like creative builders and space fights then this is a good game.

I generally count a game as being worth the price if I get 1 hour's fun per Â£1.  I got this on sale, so got plenty of enjoyment out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051684467', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 91527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4334, 'last_played': 1660659373}
review:
The base vanilla gameplay is quite enjoyable. You get your generic terrans and sentinel super weapons and blow up the opposition, while asteroids consistently takes layers of paint of your ship. The combat, controls, and effects makes the game remarkably satisfying.

However, the game's full potential lies within its mods. In the steam workshop, one would find a plethora of well-made and interesting mods that alter the game in numerous ways. From adding whole factions, unique plant regions, or changing the base game variables, there are a variety of mods to choose from. 

As an occasional modder for the game, I can testify that the options presented in modding are quite limitless. Many of the existing prototype concepts from the modding community simply cannot be compared to the vanilla content. 

Of course, there are other less shiny mods that liter the workshop, but we don't talk about those.

download temporum

author: {'steamid': '76561197972380519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6081, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1922, 'last_played': 1615781430}
review:
This game is super fun.

The game has many "parts" that can be put together to form a ship.  The ship builder screen is easy enough to use, but there are some weird bugs to it.  Each faction has its own parts with their strengths and weaknesses.

The gameplay is extremely fun, but it can be frustrating starting out as a little ship.  With some creative building and patience you can really create some powerhouse designs.  The worlds will also populate ship designs created by other people so you can really test your ship building acumen.

Overall a great, fun, arcadey shooter that takes the old school "Asteroids" game to the next level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110881362', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1595, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 667, 'last_played': 1695719059}
review:
Beautiful game.  The mechanical alien ships and structures you encounter have an almost biological evolutionary feel to them.  

Your faction ships take on characterisitcs of your own ship as you modifiy it, really cleverly done.  

The music and sound effects enhance the atmosphere perfectly.  The gameplay is original and rewards creativity.  AI tournaments on youtube are fascinating to watch.  

If you like to have everything spelt out for you in a game, you may struggle, otherwise highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156112695', 'num_games_owned': 62, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1545, 'last_played': 1605224745}

author: {'steamid': '76561197970849298', 'num_games_owned': 1784, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 4136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4095, 'last_played': 1541044794}
review:
This game is fun.   If you like games where you build fighting machines and let them loose, or if you like RTS/Tower Defence games then you will most likely enjoy this.

The only downside is a lack of overall objectives.  There are objectives during the in-game tutorial, but these should have been extended through the rest of the game.  There is also no "win condition", as far as I can tell.  These would be nice additions but the game is fun even without them.

A very good effort by the developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076104207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1559, 'last_played': 1634103123}
review: Reassembly fits into my chill-out group of games. You can mindlessly tweak your ships, grow fleets, etc, and just explore the region. Once that region gets boring you can jump through the wormhole to a fresh new one. Over time the game does start to feel a little bland - once you get to the big ships and the big fleets with them, the challenge seems to go away. For that reason, that's why it's in my chill-out pile. It's Flow, with spaceships and some neat mechanics allowing you to change your ships, share your ships in other people's games, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112844990', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 97564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46500, 'last_played': 1698190277}
review:
To be frank I am not qualified an any way : (

To describe in a congruent and un over enthusiastic method the utter pleasure this game has given me, in the short time I have owned it, is a task that could seem impossible, considering the choices /decisions I made in regards to the approach to articulating my point of view, of which there is more than one, of course this is all about the subject of sharing the opinion that arises from the experiences obtained by the direct consequence of deciding to spend the time, and at the time allowing for the time necessary to seal from possibility to reality the chance of owning this potentially entertaining game. 

Well... I am sure we are ALL glad that so has happened

I appreciate your enthusiasm!!! Thank you

Here is a list of what you get for your hard earned money, a list for all those that hate tricky sentences  that are not actually in english but give the impression that they are so ....

YOU get your very own game developer... an eccentric young talented and apparently stubborn enough to create a game where the clean coding approach has lead it to being the most optimized solution possible allowing millions and trillions of things to happen at once inside your computer and then you can see the calculated outcomes on the big thing with a side made of glass that shines when used properly. Please feed your programmer regularly

YOU get a game with lots of colours that you can change as well, these colours come in different shapes that can be changed as well but not as much as the colours ... those can be changed lots more than the shapes can, please be cautious with your colours...be very cautious with your shapes those you are NOT allowed to mess around with. Disclaimer these features do NOT work if your monitor is Black and White, also you can do anything with your shapes just don't do so in a messy fashion unless you wish to do so deliberately in which case you should be fine 

YOU get access to all sources of knowledge that up until now have been unseen by the academic eye and you will learn to master navigating the many choices you make, this is very important cause when you want to make a noticeable mark in a tournament you may do so by designing a cool ship that looks better than the others thus winning the Sweet generous award, it's crazy stuff! please consult your local foot therapist and take in small amounts !!

YOU can finally find a good use for your mouse, and start not to use it! As the developer does not really trust your inexperienced eye to hand coordination he has made a game that you watch! You might as well give your mouse eyes and allow it to watch the game with you, the days of bashing that poor mouse is over. Disclaimer there is a mode where you use the mouse. There are many modes, but I wanted the poor mouse to have his/her moment too... 

YOU are still reading this review, and I adore you for doing so, I am lonely, Perhaps I should learn to communicate my feelings better, my resume is looking great but people seem to get confused? Oh well, this game is great and has some great communities of gamers and you tubers that organize events constantly for you to have fun and meet new people, among them is myself, and lots of other people that can write good

YOU can get a really trippy soundtrack
and don't forget to look both ways before you cross or just follow a friend that is already crossing.

Richard Ernest Kabay

author: {'steamid': '76561198063865205', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 943, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1452466987}

author: {'steamid': '76561198098088786', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 4113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3540, 'last_played': 1571084164}
review:
Reassembly is a beautiful, enthralling top-down spaceship-builder/space combat game with sturdy mechanics and an intuitive building system that deserves the praise it has recieved.

The basic building blocks are two-dimensional shapes (guns, hull blocks, engines, and so on,) which are a joy to connect and shape into fighters, freighters, capital ships and stations. As the player becomes more experienced, new shapes unlock, leading to some truly impressive creations. What's more, the fleets that other players have made are imported onto the map as 'Agents', meaning that, in addition to the various types of standard enemies, the player has to go up against the creations of fellow players - controlled by the AI, but built by humans. Some of the are quite brilliant.

Unlocking the most expensive pieces can be a grind, and the game doesn't tutorialise nearly as well as it should (there is a fair bit of advice online), but after many hours I still find plenty to keep me busy.

And if you ever encounter one of my capital ships, here's a tip: keep astern. For the life of me, I can't seem to design a ship with a decent turning speed.

review: Reassembly is one of those games that just sucks you in. The world feels very much alive, and looks beautifull. The ships may feel a bit odd to control at first, but that is actually quite fun, as it allows for many different manouvers you wouldn't expect. This game has a lot of content, and a lot of mods, since it is very easy to mod.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045783529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1435, 'last_played': 1628196280}
review:
Mein Review zu Reassembly in einem Wort: groÃŸartig!

(Nachtrag vom 05. August 2021: immernoch groÃŸartig :) )

### Worum geht es? ###
Das Spielprinzip ist einfach erklÃ¤rt. Raumschiffe bauen, Raum erobern, Ressourcen einsammeln, grÃ¶ÃŸere Raumschiffe bauen. So weit so gut, einfache Sache. Der Trick bei der Sache ist: FÃ¼r den Bau seines Raumschiffs benÃ¶tige man Ressourcen, die im Raum auftauchen bzw. die auch bei der ZerstÃ¶rung von Schiffen anderer Fraktionen anfallen. GrÃ¶ÃŸere Raumschiffe verbrauchen mehr Ressourcen. Aber: viele kleine Raumschiffe kÃ¶nnen ein groÃŸes Raumschiff Ã¼berwÃ¤ltigen. Also ein kleineres, wendigeres Raumschiff bauen? Ausprobieren, denn es kostet nichts. Und: bei BeschÃ¤digung wachsen die kaputten Bauteile einfach nach.

### Flotte! ###
Ab einer bestimmten GrÃ¶ÃŸe ist es mÃ¶glich, im Spielerschiff eine Schiffswerft zu bauen und selbst Schiffe zu spawnen. Den ultimativen Status hat man erreicht, wenn man Schiffe spawnen kann, die selbst wieder Schiffe spawnen kÃ¶nnen. So folgen einem die eigenen Kinder durch den Raum, sammeln Ressourcen und bekommen selbst Kinder. Die Flotte wÃ¤chst selbststÃ¤ndig.

### WurmlÃ¶cher ###
Das absolute Highlight ist jedoch, dass genau diese selbstreproduzierenden Flotten (also quasi ein lebendiger Schwarm) eines anderen Spielers(!) durch eine Wurmloch kommen kÃ¶nnen um Deiner Flotte Konkurrenz zu machen. NatÃ¼rlich steuert da kein Spieler aktiv eines der Schiffe, aber die Schiffstypen der Flotte sind alle im Editor den anderen Spielers entstanden. So spielen weltweit Flotten gegeneinander, deren Erschaffer nicht mal selbst online sein mÃ¼ssen.

### Fazit ###
Das Spiel ist fÃ¼r Daddelfreunde mit KreativitÃ¤t gedacht, die immer etwas zu optimieren haben. Sehr empfehlenswert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067813339', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1739, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1739, 'last_played': 1446148238}
review:
This game gets a zero for the abomidable sin of level scaling. You will never be strong enough to wipe out all of the other ships in the solar system because this horrible game automatically scales enemies to your strength. As far as I'm concerned this is the worst sin a game can commit. 

Otherwise a good game. Level scaling is annoying as hell though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024083224', 'num_games_owned': 146, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11846, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3103, 'last_played': 1600239255}
review:
Reassembly is a game that has grown on me. 

I helped back it in it's early alpha days, giving its kickstarter my $30 donation. I liked the look of it. Sandboxish, procedural generation, top-down arcade feel. I played the very early alpha version and was entertained for a few hours. I soon lost interest, and the game became stale to me.

Since then I've come back to the game again and again. It's one of those games you'll get pumped about and think about all day only to come home from work and play it till you drop. It's enjoyment for me comes in short bursts.

Recently I've made a discovery. The game does not play itself. People complain about how tedious it is to capture systems and hold them. They say something along the lines of "Once you capture it there is no point. Your ships don't spawn there and you get no resources." Now listen here, that is where you are wrong.

You can build space stations that bristle with defenses and hold their own agains enemy capital ships. Alternatively, that space station can be covered in solar arrays to slowly farm you resources. Recently one of my favorite things to do is populate enemy territory with little "Outpost" stations via a factory on one of my ships. I then spend time fighting on the front line with my fleet to push the enemy out. This game is all about how you play it.

In summary, Reassembly is a great game. It's hard to find anything else out there even close to it (I think of S.P.A.Z. as the only other game that resembles it, another great by the way). Keep giving it a chance and you'll get a lot of replayability out of it. If you enter with a closed mind you'll get a closed off experiance. I highly recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041757297', 'num_games_owned': 945, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 1178, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1178, 'last_played': 1442981768}
review:
Reassembly is a fascinating way to explore creative darwinism.  You play a top-down space shooter with your own small (and terrible) ship.  You've kerballed together a random assebly of parts whose function you can only guess at.  You find a promising target, engage, and are instantly vaporized.  As you build progressively more useful and larger ships, you look back at these distant design ancestors and you can see a perfectly preserved narrative.  It describes what you learned, when you learned it, and just how much more awesome you are now than when you first started.

I fully endorse this.  You should try it at once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007748367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 770, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 767, 'last_played': 1443861611}
review:
Now that I've played through it I can say that I was bored from start to finish. Endless grinding for a solo game? No thank you! Lacking customization for a game that is pretty much sold for its customization? Not appealing to me either. The soundtrack wasn't of any interest to me either. In short: I did not find this game worth the price tag. At all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967199466', 'num_games_owned': 340, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 982, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 957, 'last_played': 1467006051}
review: While I had some fun playing this game, it's ultimately flawed. There's not much point to it, and there's a couple of derpy aspects: firstly the parts aren't all geometrically compatible. For example, the octagonal parts aren't on the same size grid as the square parts. The rectangular parts are on a different size grid again. That's just dumb. Then there's the reason I just rage-quit: I was being single-shot killed in my most armored ship (surrounded by shields and at least 2500 armor) by a weapon (I assume it's a weapon) that I couldn't even see, let alone buy in upgrades. Just a big boom, and my big ship is insta-dead. That's just massively un-fun.

Als Belohnung fÃ¼r die ZerstÃ¶rung feindlicher Schiffe bekommt man nicht nur Resourcen sondern auch die MÃ¶glichkeit spÃ¤ter bei einem neuen Spiel eine der Alienrassen zu spielen die wiederrum ganz neue Bauteile haben (Waffen usw)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993386137', 'num_games_owned': 397, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 1731, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1158, 'last_played': 1516557832}
review:
Anfangs bin ich sehr skeptisch gewesen. Der Preis erschien mir zu hoch fÃ¼r ein derart simples EA Spiel.
Es ist jeden Euro wert! Man startet mit den Terranern, kann im Verlauf aber noch mehr Rassen freispielen - die sich in Waffen und "HÃ¼llen"-Teilen unterscheiden. Dann spawnt man und sieht zu erstmal zu Ã¼berleben. 

Man nimmt Stationen ein und verdient damit seine ersten Credits, die man in "Masse"-Upgrades oder in die Freischaltung von Waffen/Supports stecken kann. Die masse sagt aus, wie viele Teile ich im Editor in mein Schiff stecken kann. 

Wenn man erst mal die Obergrenze von 8 000 Masse geschafft und alle Waffen freigeschaltet hat, dann kann man sich so richtig austoben. Im Editor ein mÃ¤chtiges Schiff erstellt und dann noch ein paar JÃ¤ger, Bomber und Fregatten - die man mit Hangar sogar selbst spawnen kann.

 Ab und an fÃ¼hlt man sich Ã¼bermÃ¤chtig, allerdings sind die Agenten (rote Pfeile auf der Karte) nicht zu unterschÃ¤tzen. Das sind Kreationen von anderen Spielern, die zum Teil echt fies sind. 

Es hat allerdings noch entwicklungspotenzial, mal verkeilt sich ein kleines Schiff in dem eigenen Schiff, man selbst steckt in einer Raumstation fest oder Gegner fliegen durch Asteroiden. 

Klare Kaufempfehlung!

author: {'steamid': '76561198035393265', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 256, 'last_played': 1442466019}
review:
A fantastic evolution on the module based ship games, there are few things more fun than making a 100 strong swarm of homing rocket equiped ships and watching enemies be destroyed. 

Unfortunetly, this game lacks a lot of polish, and the UI leaves a good amount to be desired. it makes me constantly wish for more control (of both my ship itself and the ships I am producing). A fantastic game to have running while doing something else, as after you get your factory it switches from a top down action game to a hugely customizable unit based RTS.
