author: {'steamid': '76561198093603927', 'num_games_owned': 2139, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 4023, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1903, 'last_played': 1603507470}
review:
An excelent open-ended game to pass a lot of time.
Although I think it could do with a few more features (and possibly a little more detail in the way of a tutorial) I am quite pleased to play this game.

Offering unlimited design possibilities, the only limit is your time and imagination.
Different factions offer different tools and weapons, as well as entire ship-structuring features.
The open-ended gameplay means that once you've got a ship that works, you can make other ships that make more ships. build stations to protect areas of space you have cleared and hunt down other players' designs that are loaded into your world throguh wormholes (and allow you to send your ships off as AI enemies to terrorise other players in their games)

I strongly recomend this game, but because of a few gameplay features I feel are vitally missing, i would recomend waiting for a sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198086576272', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1537, 'last_played': 1623284783}

author: {'steamid': '76561198085787305', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 3037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3037, 'last_played': 1449940525}
review:
Reassembly feels half-finished, and in the long run it's really disappointing. Yes, designing the ships is fun, and testing them is fun, and the big battles are fun. However, the fun runs out quickly and there are UI issues which pretty much kill any real possibility of sinking a significant amount of time into the game due to the repetition and frustration involved.

The User Interface has a very "Early Access" feel to it. At one point after purchasing I came back to the Steam store page expecting to see an Early Access tag that I had overlooked.

At first, UI clunkiness seemed like a small problem. I liked the game. I was having fun gathering resources, turning them in, and using the cash flow to buy new techs and to make my ships bigger. Eventually I unlocked the factory, and my ships were large enough to use it. At this phase of the game you think "Cool, now I can make fleets of ships and kick even more ass!"

And you can, but putting a fleet together and keeping it up and running through numerous battles is just such a fucking chore. It feels like work.

It would be so much better if you could configure the way your factory makes ships. Here's how it works:  you move up to 4 ship designs into boxes at the top of the fleet screen. These designs will be built by your ship's factory when you press 'F' in-game.

The issue is that pressing 'F' builds the first ship in the queue, then the second, and so on, repeating in order and there's no way to change this. For example, you can't set up four keybindings for the 4 designs.

Occasionally you can win a few big battles without changing your production queue, but more often than not you find yourself going back to the fleet screen over and over again to rearrange your build order. This is my primary complaint about the game. I might have reccommended this game and played it for months if I weren't forced to return to the awful fleet screen hundreds upon hundreds of times, simply because the developer only gave us one terrible way to build support ships.

This problem is only amplified if you decide you want to design and build some space stations. Building stations seems to be the only way to hold new areas you've moved into. If you move to an area of the map and clear out all the bad guys it will change to your faction's color, but the only way it will stay your color when you leave is if there is a station left behind which can spawn AI ships to patrol the area. So, basically, building stations is important if you want to conquer the map.

The problem is, there are good and bad places to create a station. The 4-ship repeating production queue gives you no easy way to be careful about your space station placement. If you want to be strategic, you have no choice but to go to the stinking, godforsaken fleet screen and drop a space station design into your production queue each time you find a good site where you want to lay down a new station. You'll have to make sure you drop it in the right place in the queue or it won't be next. After you've built the station and set up ITS production queue, you will have to return to your OWN production queue, delete the station, and replace it with another design.

In an area with a ton of drones? Fleet screen. Found enemy agents with large ships? Fleet screen. Is one particular type of your support ships taking heavy losses? Fleet screen. Hey, this is a great spot for a station. Fleet Screen.

So, the UI is bad. I should probably change gears: There's simply not much to do in this game once you've optimized all of your designs and you've assembled a nice fleet of ships. Once you can build full-sized ships, you will steamroll anything and everything with no surprises and no challenges to keep your interest. I was intrigued by all the talk of a huge, dynamic galaxy to conquer but the reality is that the endgame is just one-sided, imbalanced action and little else. 

The map is terrible. It's hideous. It's a super-chunky grid with different colors to represent factions. The result is very ugly, and gets more and more atrocious the more you explore. You can't zoom or scroll the map, and you can't change or hide the overlays. The minimap in-game is just as bad. It's hard to see useful information, and you can make it either small or smaller.

There are other issues as well. The AI is not that great. This is really an issue when you spawn 10 support ships and pray to god that they don't cause a pileup and all get left behind in an asteroid field. This will happen even with small ships that are the most maneuverable craft in the game. Yes, your fleet that you saved up resources to build can easily get left behind on a high speed trip because they are truly terrible at avoiding stationary objects.

Also, ships get stuck together all the time while they are "rebuilding" themselves after taking damage, or right after they spawn from your factory on your main ship. It's laughable, as the two ships are merged and the AI ship is using all of its thrusters trying to go somewhere making it impossible to go where you are trying to go.

So all-in-all this feels like a half-finished Early Access title with potential. Unfortunately it's a finished game.

Summary: Game feels half-completed. Good ship designing, good action, VERY BAD  interface, nothing rewarding to do after unlocking all the parts and build points.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007300752', 'num_games_owned': 540, 'num_reviews': 239, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1442173152}
review:
I purchased this as part of a Humble Bundle. I'm not the typical target audience for such a game and thus those who are will proabably not find this review helpful. I also know I'm in the minority on this game. Reassembly has a 94% approval rating. I'm in that 6%.

Given that approval rating it means that it is the player and not the game. It's probably done well but it is simply not my style of game. I find the controls confusing, the objectives unclear or poorly explained and I have no Earthly idea what is going on. If there is a deeper game here than running around and firing a weapon at targets that move too quickly to be hit, I haven't found it and the game isn't inspiring enough to make me want to look for it. 

Come again, Blackadar? What does that mean? Ok, simply put I can't tell what's going on. I see blobs and shapes on screen. It has an art style that just doesn't register with me. I feel like I'm looking at a Jackson Pollock painting in hyper-motion. While I like Jackson Pollock, I don't exactly understand what I'm looking at when I look at that art. I don't understand what I'm looking at when I look at the screen on Reassembly. Now when I combine that with things moving so quickly on screent that I can't hit them, my gameplay options kind of narrow quickly.

Actually, they narrow into one thing - uninstall and go find a game I can play. Like Peggle. Or Uno. (it's a joke people, check my profile!)

I guess my ability to effectively control a twin-stick shooter in an abstract art style game is nonexistent. It does, however, have the distinction of being the highest rated game in my collection that I've given a thumbs down to. So if you like the genre this is probably a fine game. If you are like me and you don't enjoy this genre all that much, this won't change your mind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997424809', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 2284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1454, 'last_played': 1473098784}
review:
TL;DR: Buy on a sale. 

I've had fun with this. I really have. For the first.. 8 hours. The game is great.

After that. it has been falling off. A lot.

I can't really reccommend this. It isn't "fun" for me.

But it is relaxing. not much fustration. just go through the motions and explore.

No real goals or anything. There is an end point where the faction you're in can't expand any more due to ship size restrictions.

It does what the developer set out to do, but that is it.

not a bad game.. just not really fun either.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970510854', 'num_games_owned': 1159, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 1843, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 768, 'last_played': 1471943076}
review:
Wonderful game. You design your own ship from parts and other building blocks, in whatever configuration you want based on those parts(I do wish there were more parts.), build more ships, have the ships you've built build more ships exponentially, and generally take over the entire universe slowly.

If anything, I'd liken Reassembly to a more fleshed out version(Though as far as I know there is zero connection.) of the freeware game Warning: Forever. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warning_Forever

It's great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161226649', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 17782, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2218, 'last_played': 1681012295}
review:
this game benefits from the following:
Extremely addicting gameplay; an easy to use shipbuilder; a simple, yet appealing art style; an amazing soundtrack; diverse enemy ships; the ability to battle with other people's ship fleets; and a vast modding community.

that said, it can sometimes get annoying when every single agent (Player-designed fleet) comes after you at once before you're ready. (but don't worry you can exact revenge on them soon enough) 

it would also benefit greatly from multiplayer, which, if it were to be added, might bump it up next to other big multiplayer games.

Overall, I highly reccomend this game to any who like Space, LEGOs, and blowing things up for money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027349749', 'num_games_owned': 1458, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5056, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5056, 'last_played': 1440746127}
review:
TL:DR AMAZING. 50/10

Ok so this is a game about your "fleet" in space, you control a ship and shoot things. Simple to understand, difficult to master. But then you try to upgrade your ship and its like WOAH wtf is all this......its......its freedom! You can build pretty much anything in this! Add the mods to it and you go past even that. My personal experience has seen me build a ship so weak a flower that I hit killed me, yet with this ship I managed to control a fleet so large I beat every faction on the map! Another ship I built spins so fast that the collision damage from its extremities is so high I can fly straight THROUGH asteroids as if its butter. Another ship has arms that cuddle my enemies to death.......it goes on.

You will play this game for a few hours then put it down, then suddenly some idea will pop into your head and back you are again for more hectic mayhem as you try to build your awesome idea! A brilliant game all round, design, artwork, playability and even very good controls systems for all manner and type of ship you could build.

nothing but errors and crashes, what a complete waste of money and time.

I spend upto an hour building large ships only to get a game error trying to save my design, have it crash and lose my ship.

No manual save, just a dodgy auto-save.
Ship movement is terrible, thrusters dont act the way they should.
Overpowered enemies that kill you every 10 seconds, with no thanks to the awful spawn system which puts you right near the horde of enemies that just killed you.
ship size also makes no difference.

the game feels like an early access game, not enough content to hold my interest.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069225634', 'num_games_owned': 169, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7907, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4396, 'last_played': 1640370641}
review:
Moin!
Dies ist meine erste Review:
Ich bin mittlerweile bei rund 80 Spielstunden angelangt. Das Spiel hat einen ganz eigenen Spielstil und eine ganz eigene AtmospÃ¤hre. Es macht mir sehr viel Spass meiner "Fraktion" beim wachsen zuzuschauen und zu sehen wie sie sich von anfangs kleinen schiffen zu groÃŸen Kreuzern weiterentwickelt. Ich verbringe die meiste Zeit im Schiffseditor meiner Lieblingsfraktion und tÃ¼ftle an neuen waffen und hÃ¼llen kombinationen rum. Der Vielfalt sein Schiff zu gestalten ist kaum eine grenze gesetzt. Mittlerweile habe ich alle Fraktionen angetestet und auf das Maximum an Punkten gebracht, aber noch nicht jede Waffe der jeweiligen Fraktion freigesschaltet. Im Tournament Modus lasse ich nun Ã¶fters meine eigenen Schiffe der unterschiedlichen Fraktionen gegeneinander antreten um zu sehen wie man sich auskontern kÃ¶nnte und wie sich die KI verhÃ¤lt. Im Tournament modus werden beide Parteien von dem Computer gesteuert. Mit dem letzten Update kam hinzu das man anstatt einzelner Schiffe nun ganze Flotten gegeneinander antreten lassen kann. 

FÃ¼r mich hat dieses Spiel einen sehr hohen Wiederspielwert und lÃ¤sst sich auch nach der Arbeit ganz locker noch spielen und sorgt fÃ¼r regelrechte Entspannung. Es gÃ¤be noch genÃ¼gend zu berichten Ã¼ber zB den Workshop und den Spielablauf im Einzelspieler, aber fÃ¼r meine erste Review sollte das ausreichen.

Wer einen leidenschaftlichen Reassambly Spieler auf YT zuschauen mÃ¶chte sollte sich mal den Kanal "Deluks Gaming" anschauen. Dort werden monatlich auch Turniere mit den Schiffen veranstaltet und als Ansporn Steam Keys an die Gewinner verteilt. Also wer sich gut anstellt kann mit dem Spiel sogar noch Gewinn machen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984961040', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1737, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1150, 'last_played': 1545687332}
review:
Reassembly is both awesome, and not. If you enjoy ship builder games this game has a decent amount of options to do so. However, if you like in depth ship builders, Reassembly isn't a complex ship building simulator.

Essentially the game amounts to getting resources, selling resources, and building bigger ships. There is an "Agent" mechanic which spawns other player made groups into your galaxy. Many of these squadrons will crush you until you can get to the very end game. These squadrons are really the only threat when you're powerful enough, so you either can leave them on and be demolished repeatedly until the end game, or turn them off and have a very boring end game.

It doesn't take long to get to the end game, and it's easy to run out of stuff to do. The best way to fight is to stack on piles of armor (it has no point value, so you can have as much as you'd like depending on how slow you don't mind your ship to be) and piling on a ton of a single effective weapon (most races have one or two weapons that are extremely effective, and a pile of flavor weapons which are functional against the standard ships, but not overly so against agents).

All in all it's a strangely balanced game, but I've had fun playing it. I'd say it's worth the price tag attached to it. If you need a ship builder simulator which has a lot of action but not a lot of depth, try Reassembly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998629714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1180, 'last_played': 1466288891}
review:
Very fun space combat/ship builder sandbox game. 

Spawns fleets created by players (and spawns your fleets in others' games) to give a ton of variety. Different factions also increase replayability. I found more of my time was spent trying to build or tweak my ships than trying to fly them.

I enjoy the fact that you can have your own little posse follow you around by putting a factory on your ship. You can even put factories on the ships you make so that they can make their own ships. This seems to need a bit more polish though as this doesn't seem to happen as much as it should. 

Also every "faction" including yours doesn't really do much other than sit around and shoot the breeze. It would be nice if they were more active. There are agents that can hunt you down and are very powerful, though. So that can add some suspense.

Very minimalistic on graphics, but there's enough explosions and such to keep me happy. Performance suffers a bit when there's tons of stuff on the screen (like drones, missiles, etc). Also got super annoyed by the "auto-zoom" feature zooming at the worst time until I figured out you can turn it off. 

There are some nice mods out there with some fun (though balance breaking) factions. 

Could use clearer tutorial/instructions at the beginning. I got stuck trying to figure out how to increase my P limit for too long IMO. 

Otherwise, a very fun little game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198237577814', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 3293, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1438, 'last_played': 1594169823}
review:
When I first saw this game being played, it reminded me of fish in an aquarium, just with the ability to shoot lasers at each other. Even now, after I know it's a space game, it still has that organic look.

This is a great game. It runs very well on an older laptop, and when things get too intense with the graphics, the program simply steps down speed rather than crashes. The design interface for the ship editor is very well done and you can zoom in and out. It has a lot of things you can use, but just enough so you do not get overwhelmed from too much inventory to choose from.

Piloting your ships is a little tricky, since it involves the cursor and the keyboard and even then you have settings to choose from. My best analogy of piloting a ship in Reassembly is like riding a horse, where you use rein to control the speed and steer your steed.

The conquer the universe mode is pretty straightforward and you got lots of time to build up resource. The tutorial helps you get things rolling though I was hoping for more, like for example what exactly am I scooping off these asteroids? To date, I've never been wiped off the map for being too slow. If you beat an agent, you unlock a faction to play.

THe sandbox mode? Okay, that's the first real negative on this game. I'm old enough to have played games that involved you using complex commands in a text editor  to create the scenerio before the game began, so let me tell you I've never seen a sandbox mode that involved command language since the 1980s. This would have been acceptable for the 1980s but this is the 21st century, and most computer users are not programmers. They would expect an Activision-esque style of interface where you select number of players, difficulty level, type of victory scenerio and so on. AFter seeing a dazzling UI, asking the user to create a sandbox match using command line languages gives this game a unfinished look. It's not a deal breaker. I got more than my money's worth out of it, but I would have loved to see what the sandbox mode was like.

My verdict? Worth it, lot of replayability value and you will have hours of fun designing things and watching them go blooey. Just skip the sandbox mode.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082318269', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2169, 'last_played': 1664763075}
review:
So, the first thing I have to say is... Wow! The entire map look wonderful, and the colors a vibrant and fantastic! I've seen a space age paradise, and I dont think I'll stop playing for a long long time. Second thing I have to say, Some of you fellow players have some tough builds, looking forward to fighting more! 

All shock and awe aside... THis game is great! You make custom ships, which then form into a custom fleet, which you use to dominate your quandrant of unlimited space. Succeed in that? Well, good things theres wormholes to new guardrants! Unlockable factions (by fighting them), which grant new games with different difficulties, builds, and weapons! 

I was and am a fan of Robocraft because of its custom capabillity and design. However, robocraft in 2D space? YES. 

I would like to thank the Devs, the players (even the ones whose Agents gave me a tough time), and everything that lead to this game's exsistance. 10/10 will dominate the galaxy again!

author: {'steamid': '76561197964338878', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 3836, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3411, 'last_played': 1520424781}
review:
Despite anything in the game that feels familiar, I have never played anything quite like Reassembly.

You might describe it as a mish-mash of SPAZ, Spore, and some other top-down space shooters, but the similarity ends there.  The procedurally generated 'galaxy' is full of varied enemies and dangers, and if you run out of baddies, you can dive into a wormhole for a fresh world.  Wormholes have another use, more on that below.

The main draw of the game though is the ability to build your own ships.  The ship editor is easy to learn, and has enough geometric shapes to allow you to produce anything you want.  The playable factions have different available hull and weapon choices, making each one it's own playstyle.  There is a progression curve, you must spend money earned in the world to unlock new weapons and increase the power cap limiting how much goes on your ship.  It doesn't take too long to max it out though, allowing for huge many-beweaponed designs.  You can also build space stations, it's as simple as building something with no thrusters and at least one factory.

Once you have some custom ships you like, hit up a wormhole.  Instead of following it to a new world, you can choose to upload a copy of your fleet roster while staying in your own world.  This uploaded fleet will then start randomly appearing in other players worlds.  These are called Agent fleets, and fighting other people's creations that appear in your world can be challenging and exciting.  I've encountered ships that were nearly unbeatable, forcing me to change my ships and tactics in order to prevail.

You needn't fly solo in your world either, you can equip a factory block and spend resources you collect to spawn AI controlled ships from your collection.  I'm not sure if there's a limit to how many ships you can have at once, I've gotten up to about 15 or so, plus a hundred or so drones if I'm in my Galactica carrier.  Tearing around space with a dozen ships blasting anything you target is super effective.

A caveat to mention is that there isn't any actual multiplayer, which would be great if it were possible, I can see why it would be difficult with all the physics objects that can occur.  Maybe a sequel could pull it off.  Also there are situations that cause the game to slow down significantly, particularly in Spikey Plant sectors once they start firing projectiles all over the place.

Many games out there let you build things, which is fine, but this is one of the few that lets you use and enjoy the fruits of your labor in actual gameplay.  The vector-style graphics are used to good effect and really get my nostalgia going.  I've only owned the game a couple weeks and have dumped almost 50 hours into it.  It's got good music too.

Grade A most excellent game 8000/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197985454173', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 7609, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1832, 'last_played': 1584826260}
review:
I've been playing Reassembly for just a few days and I'm kind of subjugated. 20 hours on the clock already ! I'm so glad that I got to learn about and buy it through Humble Bundle, now I've gotta get some friends to play it. :)

In a nutshell as other reviews put it very well, it's a dastardly 2D mix of Space Engineers and Agar.io, fun and addictive as hell. There is still a bit of balancing to be done and I've run into a handful of non critical bugs (an automated bug reported could be a good thing) but seriously, don't expect your usual "early access" unfinished game. This one is rather like a beta, with enough content for (I guess) dozens of hours of gameplay.

TL;DR : It's worth every penny, go buy it now.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984486124', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1267, 'last_played': 1468665717}
review:
I came expecting Spore microbiology phase.
I left with a space opera.

I made a line of cannons with a cockpit that I couldnt fly worth a crap and the AI used it to make semi stationary defensive barges. This game is fresher than a piece of lettuce. Finer than fine china, bring out the good plates.
10/10 would adapt again

author: {'steamid': '76561198066248283', 'num_games_owned': 1101, 'num_reviews': 297, 'playtime_forever': 1136, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 651, 'last_played': 1460256585}
review:
One of my favorite games, if you like customization and spaceships, or pseudo roguelike-likes. This is the game for you.

Psuedo due to, however many resources you collect when alive, when killed you lose ALL of it. But it isn't anything to cry over. The game features infinite ship customizational freedom with each part to the ship being in sections of small blocks, so you can create whatever you wish.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028534685', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1784, 'last_played': 1577280937}
review:
Reassembly is a very simple game, you are a ship for a faction and all other factions are enemies; that doesnt sound too different to most games; although the real point of the game is the fact that you can build and design your own ships. This mechanic is very well implemented and the game is really fun, flying round space blowing stuff up really never gets old. The building ship feature is very, very good (it could do with some fixs and some more variations), everything on the ship is down to you if it is too slow thats your faut (add more thrusters) or its just getting smashed against flagships and agents (add hull and shields) you can change it and upgrade it to fix these problems. Everytime you die there is something you can do to imporve the ship, you learn from every mistake and can adapt to it. There is something about this game that just brings me back to being a 5 year old playing with Lego and trying make HUGE planes and space ships. Really great little gem of a game.
TL;DR Great little gem, lots of replayability, buy if you have ever played with Lego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198092579242', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 2386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 881, 'last_played': 1686945875}

author: {'steamid': '76561198133564111', 'num_games_owned': 229, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 6404, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2429, 'last_played': 1673728410}
review:
That is one addictive game!.. One of my gems in my collection.
i am a strategy/survival/creative game lover. I like games like minecraft, terraria.  I personally don't like fps or space shooter games which looks like this one.

I pick this game to try couse it was offering that u can create your own space ships.  I saw that not only you create your own vessel but you create an echosystem actually. In this game everything acts like living beings they grow, they sperad and claim territories. You are the lader of the echosystem. You design how your faction will do acually by altering the designs. Game AI uses your designs if you have suitable one for a stuation.  If you don't, they have their own designs. Your resource also a space plant which is growing spreading around like your faction.

You start with a pre-designed faction with its own unique blocks and weapons. Simply you gather resources and grow to be better, stronger and dominate a huge map which is infinite like with its wormholes. You design your own ships with limited blocks at start and vary them by researching more which gives you like infinite combinations. Game also helps you with this by its pre designed ships.

i strongly reccomend this game if you define yourself like me

author: {'steamid': '76561198141915454', 'num_games_owned': 11, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17522, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3065, 'last_played': 1709294546}
review: Great game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012610173', 'num_games_owned': 853, 'num_reviews': 164, 'playtime_forever': 8078, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2971, 'last_played': 1538589715}
review:
This game is horribly addictive. The basics: build your ship out of a set of parts and unlock new parts and weapons. This works so well that it got me playing 3 days straight without even touching another game. Players unlock new factions by killing capital ship from the latter and there are plenty of mods extending existing factions or adding new ones.

The gameplay is simple, weapons can be bound to mouse buttons or auto-fire, every faction has its specialities and different blocks with different stats and forms, the game seems quite balanced at the moment, I played 6 factions to max and did not yet encounter problems with balancing.

Graphics are simplistic but beautiful, the soundtrack is hypnotic and does not get annoying and there is a lots of physics involved, the game may slow down a bit during heavy battles.

This game gets a whopping 9.5 out of 10 for making everything it wants right.

author: {'steamid': '76561198120213518', 'num_games_owned': 519, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 10995, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3291, 'last_played': 1520117914}
review:
Just, Absolutely, Fascinating.
Just imagine all the Campers in Flies
All the Rushers in Bees
All the Snipers in Faction 4
All the Medics as "Borg" class 
All the noobs as Faction 1
And the workshop just makes it a whole lot more exciting 

only thing it could have is multiplayer. 
the closest thing to multiplayer is tournament, but that doesnt get you out of the feeling that you're alone an noone else to enjoy your experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968577837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 693, 'last_played': 1570219403}
review:
A fun twin stick spaceship shooter with an organic feel to it similar to Pixeljunks Flow. You collect food called R(esource) and trade it for C(redits) to unlock new ship parts and raise your point allowance to stick more guns and thrusters to your ships body.

Damage taken is reflected on your ships, parts are removed and will regrow fairly quickly. Half your thrusters missing on one side of your ship? Have fun trying to escape without smacking right into the next obstacle. If you command block is destroyed you respawn at the nearest factory station or ship, while losing all R. No big deal, chances are you randomly crash you ship into the next asteroid at least a couple of times.

You expand territory for you faction by activating space stations and feeding them resources. Once you unlock the factory block you can start building your own fleet with your own designs, and even pop out your own stations. Massively fun for a bit but it's really a one trick pony. 

The good
[*]Controls are good, even though you can build clunky ships.
[*]Ship Designs are fun and designing your own fleets is quite neat.
[*]Lots of ship designs from user generated content, also workshop support now.
[*]The Organic world with it feeding and growing cycle is sweet, even if only rudimentary.
[*]Offer  at least 6-7 hours of [u]good[/u] fun. More if you enjoy the editor, optimizing fleets and trying out the different races. I doubt we see much more support from the dev that adds more replyability, but you never know.


The bad
[*]Controller support isn't complete, feels like 80% is there and the rest just never got done.
[*]Tutorial is a joke, it just checks for input and a couple of conditions, I accidently skipped almost half of it in the first 3 seconds. At the very list it needs to disable other inputs and walk you though it step by step.
[*]Simple block ship designs tend to do better than fancy. Wrong incentive.
[*]Editor has a snap function for connecting parts, nice but it only works 50% of the time making it almost useless.
[*]Some ship design are rather clunky and the AI does a good job of smashing into every solid body, Funny the first two times but it does get old really fast after that.
[*]Low replayability, the simulation aspect of the world isn't really complex enough to allow for new situations to arise.


Looking forward to a sequel, I would love to see the core concepts of the game flashed out and some support for drop in multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014174703', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 3679, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3508, 'last_played': 1616820148}
review:
Simply amazing!
At 1st, you build ships part by part, upgrade it, get bigger unlock weapons and stuff, try it out, very cool.
Then you realize you can build and spawn whole fleets, wow!
Then you'll get to spawn, spawners following you and getting that fleet bigger and bigger.
The reassembly mecanics also adds a great gameplay element. You'll often try to escape ennemy fire so you reassemble before blowing up.
I love the score too, it's the kind of music I don't feel like muting it.

The interface is counterintuitive at times, but it's almost top notch. There are some glitches and some elements are obscure, for instance, assigning ships to spawners and the mecanic of it all. 
There are not much of a clear goal as it is an open world and it feels right the way its done, The starting objectives starts as a nice tutorial, but I guess I need more time to grasp the whole picture.

All in all, it's a must have space shooter/explorer. One great kickstarter indie games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069660921', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 913, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 753, 'last_played': 1477758621}

author: {'steamid': '76561197971318812', 'num_games_owned': 347, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 13267, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6823, 'last_played': 1552213284}
review:
It's like good old "Asteroids", but with lego SPACESHIPS you've designed yourself. Except there are half a dozen different building sets, each with a completely different meta. Long vs short range guns, one fraction can grow it's own space plants for resources, another has no shields and hulls you must build from Penrose tiles!

Progress up from piloting nifty little fighters, through hardy brawlers, up to god-like monster ships with 100 strong halos of LASER drones, chewing up enemies to birth a fleet of self-(re)assembling ships out your rear end, all of your own design! Deep emergent game play that's immensely gratifying and dusted with sci-fi references to movies, TV and space opera novels. The most perfectly suited geekery I've ever experienced. :o)

The 'tournament' feature is basically Gratuitous Space Battles, with easier controls, where you can pit anyone's designs against each other in a space arena. The over-all experience of the main game is basically what Spore should have been; expanding out smoothly from the tidal pool stages. One of the few things that sometimes irked me is when friendly ships zip in and nab your loot from under your nose. I would have been tempted to make this game entirely RTS oriented, with truly conserved resources (shared within your faction). But the design is definitely spot-on as it is: putting you in the action and keeping the simulation scale (almost) within the capabilities of (my) PC hardware. It's interface is minimalisticly simple and pieces snap together in an impressively accurate anticipation of what you intend. It all lubricates that design, test, refine loop, preserving a perfect mental 'flow' state until all hours of the morning...

author: {'steamid': '76561197978737651', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 5279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3783, 'last_played': 1682881278}
review:
Since I bought this game I haven't shut it down, its all I play atm and why? because its damn addictive.

You begin with a rather small spacecraft and start your journey mining resources.
As you collect resources and trade them for money wich will be used to upgade you ship's power or add new pieces for your ship, you will explore a beautiful enviorement and face other factions throughout space.
At a certain point you will be able to build your own ships and spawn them yourself
*THIS IS WHERE IT GETS ADDICTIVE FOR ME*
As you soon will discover, the ships you built and spawned will follow you and defend you, even collect resources for you. 
You will have your own armada of ships and they are all fully costumizable! Like in, you build them from scratch till you and only you are satisfied with its looks.

So basicly whats good about the game:
-customize your own fleet.
-Nice environment
-Have your own armada
-game controls ( I play with keyboard and mouse)
-Grafix ( if you're into this kind of old school 2-d spacebattle-thingies)

Some things did bother me:
-No multiplayer (-You do have a sort of multiplayer as in sending your fleet to a friend (separate file) wich he can import in game and have an AI fight with. And there is a thing called agents wich are playermade ships who spawn in your map to haunt you.)
-No control over spawned ships. In command mode you can sell or buy allied ships but you cannot control them as in sending them in a direction, generally the spawned ships will follow you and defend you at their best ( wich is up to you on how you build them ;) )

Sorry for any mistakes and poor english
Hope you will buy this game and have as much fun as I do playing it

To the Dev: If you ever read this=> I will Buy Reassembly 2 early acces or even kickstart if you add a multiplayer/co-op!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198036273064', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1155, 'last_played': 1644468793}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089401087', 'num_games_owned': 2708, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 5114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1688509867}
review:
I'd had this game in my wishlist for a while, was one of those games i intended to pick up on a sale or something.

By Odins beard, i should of got it sooner.

Its truly amazing, the sheer addictiveness of it is astounding, and creating newer and better ships is such a fun aspect. Its essentially a game where you just constantly grind either mining or fighting, but thats the best bit. The grind is so good.

Everytime i go to close it and stop, i just think, ill get a little more, then upgrade. 

But its a never ending cycle.

IT NEVER ENDS

author: {'steamid': '76561197980090131', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1439858198}
review:
The idea of adding player-made ships to other players' games is genius.
Some ship parts are quite interesting, but many are ultimately kind of poorly designed and/or poorly balanced. Having one "race" that literally just generates resources is just stupid.

What the game ultimately falls down from is the lategame. There's just nothing to do outside of building stuff. And that's a problem when the building system isn't that stellar.
If you want something where you can build stuff I think games like Space Engineers and Robocraft are better to look at. If you want an upgrading, space-venturing RPG-ish game then SPAZ is something I'd recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961785156', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 102, 'playtime_forever': 16363, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2748, 'last_played': 1579352427}
review: There is a bit of a learning curve, but as your ship grows so does the addiction!

author: {'steamid': '76561197974262634', 'num_games_owned': 1430, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 888, 'last_played': 1666036323}
review:
Well... At first I wasn't really excited about this. But when you managed to destroy your first enemy ship, with something you build on your own, this game will capture your attention and your heart as well. 
 
Yes, the gameplay is simple, but it makes you want to build bigger, better, deadlier ships. The graphics are simple as well, but completely mesmerizing.

Normally I am not very much into sandbox stuff, because I don't have the patience to design something nice from scratch. But these things don't have to be pretty. Just glue weapons, hull and shields together and let 'em go. And if you fail - instant respawn and the possibility to make the ship better. So you "trial and error" your way through the galaxy. And it doesn't even make me mad - it would if it wasn't that way.

Highly recommended to players who like FTL or Spore. This is kind of a mix of both. And I love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048112885', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 3779, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1618, 'last_played': 1649211263}
review:
This game is almost perfect.

I just bought this game today but I've already had my share of experiences. The tutorial was a bit meh but after I got to the point where I could start exploring, the world opened up to me. While I wish that there was a little bit of written lore (an update would be nice!), the lore is almost self-explanatory simply based on what a faction's ships *do*. The mind wanders just you yourself wander, trying to infer whatever you can about this colorful, geometric universe. 

The combat is good and the physics behind movement take a bit of getting used to. This game isn't as much about that, though. It's all about building your perfect modular ship. Currently I am rocking a missile dreadnaught, though it has a few weaknesses. There is no *best* kind of ship in the game.

I would highly reccomend this game, and would urge anyone to buy it even if it's not on sale.

Now, as for things that could directly be improved upon (either through modding, updates, or hell, I'm so pleased with the game I'd pay for DLC) I'd like to see even more modules (sometimes I feel like I want even bigger guns) more factions (I want to see more cool and outlandish ideas that either impressed upon me a sense of wonder or terror), and story-mode/objectives (Some kind of diplomacy or even flavor text would be a nice addition to the game). This would be the first game that I would have liked to have still been in early-access because of the idea of even more content, instead of groaning. And believe me, I know how bad it gets; I bought towns ;-;

author: {'steamid': '76561198027785846', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1439872207}

review: Like if the cell stage from 'Spore' and gummy ship stages from 'Kingdom Hearts' had a baby! It's pretty, the music is good and you will spend hours designing ships only to toss them away minutes later in favor of designing something new.

author: {'steamid': '76561198121852984', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1439610438}
review:
The build and explore mechanics and ambient atmosphere give this game potential, but I can't recommend it in its current buggy state (8/2015).  The first few times I designed ships, the blueprints would often not save, shift around to other slots, disappear later on, or not even propagate to the real-time environment.  It also crashed within the first hour of gameplay.  For me, these are showstoppers that make it pretty much unplayable.  

Given all the positive reviews, it's evident the game is or was working for some people at some point.  If the devs can actually get it to save correctly and not crash that would be great.  You might say they have to "reassemble" it. *cough*

author: {'steamid': '76561198017225560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 933, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 852, 'last_played': 1656134623}
review:
Asteroids on Steroids!
Dieses Spiel ist eine mischung aus 2d Weltraumshooter & Echtzeitstrategie, eine minimalistische, aber gelungene Grafik, die ein wenig was von Tron hat und dazu ein atmosphÃ¤rischer Soundtrack, der gut in das ambiente hineinpasst.

Verschiedene Faktoren erhalten lange Zeit eine hohe Motivationskurve:
1.)mehrere Fraktionen mit individuellen Waffen, Designgrundlagen und unterschiedlichem Ressourcenmanagement
2.)Mod-UnterstÃ¼tzung
3.)Tournament-Modus (Spieler gegen Spieler)
4.)Sandbox 

Nachdem ich das Spiel erworben und installiert hatte, habe ich mich mit den Grundlagen der Steuerung und dem Raumschiffeditor (welcher an sich schon eine Art Sandbox ist und nur durch eine Punktelimitierung begrenzt ist) auseinander gesetzt und wie im Fluge sind 5h vergangen. Die MÃ¶glichkeiten sein eigenes, individuelles Schiff, bzw seine ganze Flotte, von klein bis groÃŸ zu gestalten sind immens.
Selbst im Anfangsstadium mit 1000/8000 Punkten mit denen ich mein Schiff basteln konnte sind mir unzÃ¤lige gute, schlechte und interessante Designs eingefallen. Man kann Stunden Ã¼ber Stunden damit verbringen, sein Traumschiff zu bauen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995234988', 'num_games_owned': 1155, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 867, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 867, 'last_played': 1439940149}
review:
[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
I don't usually write reviews, so please excuse the brevity, and rest assured that I do not flippantly say this:

[b]I wholeheartedly recommend this game.[/b]


[h1]Slightly longer version[/h1]
I got this game during a Humble Bundle sale (still ongoing, as of 2015-08-17), which was the first time I had ever heard about it. So, basically, I installed this game out of idle curiosity. The following are my impressions from playing it for a couple of hours. If you want to know more about what this game actually IS, I recommend reading some other reviews, or watching a video or two.

[b]Pro:[/b] It is really fun. Fly, shoot, collect resources, build, shoot some more, re-build from scratch, collect more resources, fly and shoot even more. For me, this game fills a gap I did not know I needed filled, somewhere between StarBound/Terraria (for the block-like, 2D assembly of things) and Space Engineers (for finding yourself trying to build something you couldn't even imagine when you started playing), but actually nothing like either.

[b]Pro:[/b] Pretty clever take on what you might call "asynchronous multiplayer" -- while playing, you can upload your current ship (or fleet) at wormholes, which then turn up in other player's games (controlled by the AI). Conversely, so called "Agents" lead incursions into your game, using ship designs made by other players. Personally, I enjoy imagining that my creations might be a challenge to someone else... Well, I can dream, at least :D

[b]Con:[/b] The UI is a bit rough around the edges; prepare for fixed-width font tutorials and rather simple UI elements. But really, it does not detract much from the fun -- you more or less don't notice after some time.

[b]YMMV:[/b] If you do not enjoy building stuff and trying the same things in different ways, this game might not hold your interest for long. However, if you DO enjoy building and trying out things, definitely give this game a try.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980171830', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 402, 'last_played': 1561258005}

review: Totally recommend this game. You start off as a small fighter, and build your way up through the ranks until youre a giant flagship killing things that used to be a challenge to you. the customization is very very very good, my only wish is more shapes for the hull. there is a part limit at 8000 P but you can easily download a mod that fixes that, from STEAM WORKSHOP. thats right, its got workshop support, mods could never be easier to install. this game does need more modders though, id love to see what intresting things they could add to this game, at the time of me writing this review ive only put in 13 hours, i got the game as a gift, but i can say that i would definitely pay the full price for this game. if you are hesitating to buy it, dont. just buy the game, and have fun...

author: {'steamid': '76561197993133567', 'num_games_owned': 474, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2882, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1947, 'last_played': 1441002111}
review:
This is like a modern super version of the old arcade classic Bosconian (look it up on YouTube). Except, instead of just being the lone hero ship blowing up all the alien bases by shooting at cores, you get to be the aliens and design your own ships & bases. 

Then, you assemble fleets to go after other factions' ships & bases and take over the galaxy. Fleets designed by other players roam around, driven by the AI to ruin your day and make you swear bloody vengeance. Once you've conquered the whole galaxy, you can take a wormhole to a freshly generated one. 

Kind of like Minecraft for top-down free roaming 2D shmup pew pews.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042263702', 'num_games_owned': 702, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 5368, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3222, 'last_played': 1641976225}
review:
This is a great game. At first I was a little skeptical over the price, but I'd say I got plenty of enjoyment and my money's worth. I very, very reccomend this game.

This is one of those "Easy to learn, hard to master" games. At least for the first few hours. There is so much variety in just the starting faction's arsenal that you'll spend plenty of time exploring your strengths and weaknesses. Then, over time you'll create the perfect vessel, one that is a Jack of All Trades or a Master in a specific area. But it doesn't stop there. You can build a factory on your ship, and then spawn other ships you've made to help you fight. (Assuming you've got the resources) Then, those ships can have factories too.

Another great feature is how both friend and foe alike will utilize battlefield debries to improve their armor or weapons.

 I like to play as a huge mother ship that is good at crowd control and sniping. So I make my ship's factory produce micro vessles I made, that pack a lot of fire power and speed at a cheap price. I even made a version that has it's own shields. They only cost about 300 RP, which means I can crank them out like nothing. I actually felt a sense of pride when  I saw them descend upon the Bee faction and absolutely wrecked them. They would gang up, six to one, and blast them to pieces. Hell, I had so many of these drones that they'd just crash into their ships at insane speads, cleaving off parts. I was prouder still, when I saw my lil guys loot their victim's shield module and use it. So they had the yellow shields of their enemies and my blue shields. :') Papa is proud. Except for the one that picked up a massive thruster and then spiraled forever, completely combat ineffective.

review: currently on Humblebundle.com weekly sale, $10 min for this and a slough of others. Bought 8/14, it's 8/16 and i've played 17 hours.........REALLY enjoy the game. build and refine your ships and blow apart enemies. you can play pretty relaxed or very aggressive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042249962', 'num_games_owned': 2601, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 2567, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1506, 'last_played': 1537560039}
review:
It really reminds me of similar games from newgrounds back in the days. I don't say this game is bad, but at the same time it does not have the ammount of content for a price above 5 bucks, or rather even less.

Yes, the the enemies act like they are in an ecosystem, and it works brilliantly. It feels brilliant. But your units usually act like... meh... and in that context you... with your unbalanced defenceless ships... Against those brilliant, sometimes upfront indestructable, like the battle wagon... you are slowly but steadily climbing through every part of the galaxy, untill dominating everything in it. Maybe it's just me, but the game does not make me want to evolve, it just makes me try to put as much guns as possible and ram the flagships untill the enemy is gone. With that in mind, prety much every chalenge can be completed in this way.

Seeing cool ships with super damaging front horns, slicing meteors like they are made from cheese, really upsets me. I want that too, but when i try armored blocks, they usually just fall appart while i turn near a rock.

Controls are unsatisfying. i died a ton of times from my ship pressing against a wall and trying to turn, crushing through all of the ship and destroying the core. There should be a version of "x" that golds ship from turning aswell, if you dont have static turrets.

Is it just me or are the other factions just broken? Bee's weapons are kinda too uncontrollable. Other, start of the game is impossible at all. Farmer really needs a nerf with all the solar pannels, because i just modded my ship  and idled just untill i had 8000p, and the farmer's aurocannons are really kinda useless, Even tons of them still break my heart. then they fire. most useless showerhead ever.

With that pointed out, i must say i'm still glad I got it. hope to see some fixes soon.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561197977902981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 3086, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1001, 'last_played': 1674070702}
review:
Very fun game, the ship editor is incredibly good, not overly complex. The combat and fleet management is very fun for a while.

There are some downsides:
- The game has a limited amount of gameplay, I unlocked everything pretty quickly.
- The weapons are hard to use yourself, in the end it's easier to use automated defences and huge missile batteries.
- Shields sometimes won't recharge depending on placment.
- Fleets are annoying since the ships add to their design and unbalance it, then fly around in circles.
- Fleet ships randomly disappear and it's hard to know if it's down to navigation problems or if they got shot out.

Despite the downsides I'd say it's a good game, though I do think the developer could do with adding to it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985545066', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1611, 'last_played': 1644123004}
review:
Have you ever played a game with spaceships and wanted to tweak the design a little?  "Why did they build it THAT way?" you wonder.  Well, now you can find out if you have what it takes to be a (fictional) spaceship designer.  You've got to grow your faction to control the galaxy, and you do it by building up a fleet of custom designed ships of every conceivable size.  Seven playable factions use different components and combat styles.  Another interesting twist is that there are "agents," special ships that are player-designed that get shared over the net when you go through a wormhole.  Beware the agents, for they are deadly!

Reassembly is a fascinating mix of cerebral ship design and combat strategy, mixed with arcade shooter action as you put those designs to work.  I recommend you read one of the game guides to get a feel for the game and get started on the right foot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027875625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 244, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 244, 'last_played': 1439681450}

review:
This game has a very steep learning curve. even after learning the controls, this game is essentially you throwing yourself to the wolves enough times to hopefully get enough resources to make a better ship that can also easily be anniahalaited.

I also lack all feeling of advancement in this game. Sure, you can make bases your color, and make a better ship, but that just doesn't do it for me. I might as well be sorting playing cards. No end goal, no story, no reason to stay. 

If you want a top-down solo Robocraft experience, this is it. Personally, I'd rather play robocraft.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995895393', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 798, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 792, 'last_played': 1442278290}
review:
I don't know if I'm the only one who did this, so I ask: Did you like creating impressive, huge ships in Lego and make them battle (using your imagination, of course)? Well, now you can do it for real, on a game that actually creates the battles for you (Imagination is overrated). With no true plot (You are part of a faction, you battle every other faction. That's basically it.) and no central objective, Reassembly is just pure fun. You design your ship with parts that actually have a significant impact in how your ship moves, fires and defends, and you battle other ships, some even designed by other people. 

I had a blast playing this game, and spent my whole day experimenting with different weapons and factions, balancing my fleet, spending credits to make my ship bigger and bigger, and dying because my ship was too fast and bumped against a wall, causing instant explotions. If that sounds fun, then by all means, play this game. You'll love it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975856499', 'num_games_owned': 123, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1088, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 779, 'last_played': 1441050105}
review: Really addicting game. The music and visuals go great together. Occasional crashes on my comp, but the gameplay makes up for it. It kind of feels like a sci-fi space Spore. Adding multiplayer and hardware mouse (maybe this is a frame buffer issue? I seem to get a decent amount of mouse input lag) would be the only improvements I could think of.

author: {'steamid': '76561198158907557', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 22881, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7806, 'last_played': 1708670823}
review:
Reassembly. A top down 2D spaceship fighting game. With several mods and 7 total venila factions, Its hard to get bored.

It is also unique in the way destruction happens. It doesnt give your ship HP and it gets destroyed when hp is 0. Insted each componet of your ship has HP, and, When destroyed, any componets attatched only with the componet that got destroyed falls of your ship as debris. If your ship regrows that part and is still in the vecinity, the ship will then tractor all the parts still there back onto the ship.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058839535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 4946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4199, 'last_played': 1504774735}
review: I bought this game out of nostolgia for a game I played when I was younger, but I got so much more than I expected. This game is a work of art, and my sense of wonder for the game was still strong 20+ hours into the game. It's like flying a spaceship through an alien terrarium. I was worried about the lack of multi-player, however there are few bugs, and the AI are detailed, and seem to have distinct personalities based on their factions that are conveyed without a single written word. Beautiful game, worth three times as much easily.

author: {'steamid': '76561198031042390', 'num_games_owned': 190, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1686, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1565, 'last_played': 1521851006}
review:
Reassembly is a fantastic game! It's a pretty looking, lego-like game, that lets you build your own ship from a measly fighter to an unstoppable jauggernaut capital ship. There are quite a few unique factions to unlock and build with that are all pretty fun to play as with their own special weapon types and building blocks. 

Although I full heartedly reccommend this game I think it's important point out some gripes.

End Game Is kinda boring
-Reassembly is one of those games where you become so powerful that there simply isn't strong enough competition to personally test your work of art against. There are some fleets you can battle that can be difficult but often times they can be really easy.

Faction Economy and territyory system isn't fleshed out
-Gaining and losing territory seems very ambiguous and pointless beyond %100 conquering the map, which is tedious and time consuming. There doesn't seem to be any benefit of having territory. You're supposed to give resources to ship building factories that will then go out and gain territory, but this is kind of un-engaging past bringing the materials in. 
-There aren't really any "capital" territories that faction forces are strongest at. Having these would bring in some depth to the world, adding difficulty and strategy to your campaign. Attack the capital of a faction and cripple it's economy so it can't reinforce other territories as easily. Some factions have cargo ships that don't really do anything but get killed by you for some free money. Giving them something to do that has benifits would be amazing for this game.

Beyond anything I've mentioned the game is a great time! If you're even slightly considering picking this up, do it! Especially if it's on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970338657', 'num_games_owned': 1217, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 1233, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1224, 'last_played': 1561586862}

author: {'steamid': '76561198091438836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 14478, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 22, 'playtime_at_review': 7476, 'last_played': 1712054719}
review:
Amazing! Would recomend getting the game and much of the workshop content.  (The workshop provides over double the content that the game has to offer)  Pretty sure my friends will get it as well.  A multiplayer option, even if it was just local would put this game over the edge of perfection.  
This game is for you if you enjoy hours on end of constructing and fighting unique 2D spacecraft, with many choices of weaponry, armor types, maneuverability options and shapes haha.
Judging by the time I have spent on this game you should understand that it can be addicting to play. (125.2 Hours at the time of this post)
Anyway, I Love the game! 9/10 would recommend.
Keep up the fantastic work Anisoptera Games, as well as all of the workshop developers that want everyone to have a better experience!

author: {'steamid': '76561198179121003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 17181, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4924, 'last_played': 1596995547}
review:
Reassembly is an interesting game, with many possibilities for building. The developers have managed to blend simplistic graphics with complex gameplay mechanics, creating a unique gaming experience which can not be experienced in many other games. Also, the recent introduction of modifications and Workshop support has made the game even more creative and community-based. Finally, the developers have created an interesting tournament mode, so those players who enjoy massive space battles will be drawn to this game too.

All in all, this game is brilliant for anyone who enjoys franchises such as Star Wars and Star Trek, and those who love a challenge or just a laid back session of messing around.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055340597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5112, 'last_played': 1615848336}
review:
This is an amazing game that I have spent (probably too many) hours on. It's based around the concept of being able to both design and pilot a ship to conquer the galaxy with (perhaps with the help of your homegrown fleet). There are tons of options/possibilities, and that's incredibly exciting.

TL;DR-Amazing game, would be the best game ever created if it weren't for the disgusting pile of bugs/glitches.

There are a lot of reasons I would recommend this game despite the issues I'll comment on farther down.
-When you get hit somewhere your health bar doesn't drop, you lose that part of your ship. Your thrusters got blown off and your only weapon faces forward? Sucks.
-Every faction truly plays differently. It's not a game of "What weapons am I gonna rambo with this time?" It's more like "These are my options, now what am I going to do with them?"
-The physics are great and really consider a lot of important factors such as center of mass and thruster location.
-The music is astounding. Gives a nice space-y feel and also compliments the actual gameplay quite well.
-Buildup from small to large ships doesn't feel grind-y and boring. It's just a different phase of the game, where instead of taking on giant death machines you go around activating stations and collecting resources from easier sources.
-Ships made by other players spawn in your world, so you get a lot of variety.
-The graphics are great. Frankly, I'm sick of repeated textures and copied/pasted environments. The basis on particles makes each game experience unique both visually and in regards to gameplay.


However, this game feels like it never left alpha/beta phase. There are insane numbers of holes in regards to instructions/development. A minor example (that still bugs me quite a bit) is part tool-tipping. Many have descriptions while even more have no real explanation whatsoever.  The number of typos is also embarrassing.
The number of general options is also a joke. Why do I have to turn autozoom off every time I start the game? And why do I have to deal with that stupid tutorial every time I start a new file? There's no skip option! And don't even get me started on those quests that never go away (why should I have to minimize the HUD just to sweep the pathetic tutorial under the rug?)

The biggest issue has got to be the bugs, though. So. Many. Bugs.
-The game crashes frequently during ship construction or even just flying around. Or sometimes it will freeze for 2 or 3 minutes just 'cause.
-Sometimes I catch allied ships desperately trying to kill themselves on asteroids. I mean, just slamming into them and then keeping thrusters full speed ahead until they finally explode.
-Sometimes the above happens to me and gives me no control over it. Even if I'm holding "X" to stop the freaking ship.
-Lag lag lag. I know this is a particle-based game, but come on. Going through Spiky Plant territory means sending the game into slow motion (about 1/2 time, maybe slower).
-Weird glitches regarding exploring. Sometimes my territory goes from my ownership to "unexplored" or no-ownership unexpectedly. Even if I'm sitting in the middle of that territory with a few stations and a fleet of 50 ships. There are other similar glitches, such as arrows pointing to stations that don't exist.
-Lots of glitchiness surrounding drones/missiles. Particularly during ship construction. Sometimes the parts just do really weird things like spawn a missile inside of the ship, which leads to all kinds of glitchiness. I once had a ship I was working on explode into a few pieces IN THE EDITOR because of a stray missile.

There are a few non-bug-related issues with the game IMO, but those are actually pretty minor. Compared to the bug issues, I often forget they're even issues at all.
I could go on and on about all the glitches in this game. It's insane and needs to be addressed more immediately. I love this game for the ideas/concepts and gameplay. It's really fun and has a lot of awesome mechanics. The brilliance and creativity that went into making this work of art are just enough to overlook the pile of crap that is the coding/attention-to-detail.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994588681', 'num_games_owned': 270, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 947, 'last_played': 1438333678}
review:
Absolutely fantastic little indie game, would without hesitation recommend it to anyone who enjoys things like S.P.A.Z or StarSector. The way that ship design works is near perfect.

My only negative thought about the game is that the AI could do with a little polishing, its a bit rusty in places, but I fully expect that to be either fixed by the dev, or a mod given the workshop integration

author: {'steamid': '76561198005923854', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 305, 'last_played': 1698639335}
review:
I see the appeal of this game, but once a-freaking-gain, it's a title that shipped long before it was finished. 

I LOVE these types of games. Build ship, gather resources, build bigger ship, smash enemies. That part of this game is fun. However, it's a broken PoS. Half the things don't work properly.

List of broken stuff:
-Drones fly off without reason into space and die.
-Missle targeting flys around in circles for no reason.
-Auto-target turrets don't auto-target 75% of the time. They sit there idling.
-Auto-fire doesn't auto-fire when enemies are nearby 75% of the time. They sit there idling (noticing a pattern here?).
-Ship re-building randomly doesn't work. Once, I was half-dead, went to allied territory and went to take a leak. Then I made a sandwich. Came back 5 minutes later and I still wasn't rebuilt. I had to exit and re-enter the game.
-Sheilds randomly malfunction . No, there was not an EMP, the sheilds simply didn't want to turn on so I had to go kill myself to get them to work again (even though dying in this game isn't much of a consequence, it's still annoying!).
-Thrusters on the side of the ship do jack-all. No matter what angle I put them at, strafing is a hundred times slower than going backward and forward. I put LITERALLY 10 times more thrusters on the sides of the ship than on the back of the ship, and no change. Barely any strafing at all. A thruster on the side of the ship does 1/100th the power of a thruster on the back/forward of the ship simply for the fact that it's on the side. I'm not sure if this is a glitch or if it's designed to be like that, either way, it's really damn annoying.
-Half the time, the ship I'm currently flying either wants to go forward, or turn. Never both at the same time, but one or the other, exclusively.
-Entering or exiting a menu resets the volume of the music to MAXIMUM. I play with my speakers pretty high up and turn most of the in-game volume down. This usually isn't a problem except in this game. Every time I go into the menu to change my ship, my fleet's ships, check the map, or pause the game, the volume for the music cranks all the way up to 100% for about a second, deafening me. This is more of a personal problem, but it's just another glitch that shows the game released too soon.
-Every third game, my base spawns in the middle of god damned no where. No enemies within a hundred miles. Just dead, deep space between me and them. At the beginning of the game, you're especially weak, so you rely on your allies to help significantly, but it's impossible in these games, so the best advice I have is to just remake it. Another annoyance.
-Every few minutes more I play this game I find another glitch/bug/thing I don't like.

Positives:
-Music is awesome. It gets my blood pumping at times and at others it makes me sit back and relax to the joys of the graphics.
-Looks awesome. The graphics of this game are amazing. Beautifully done.
-Ship building is simple, yet deceptively complex. You can't simply stick a massive shield on one side of the ship and have it work properly. You need to counter-balance it with another shield, or something with similar mass. Center of gravity of the ship actually matters and you can easily build a ship by accident that can only fly in circles. I love that!
-Individual part destruction. When a part gets hit, you lose it, simple as that. If you lose your left aft engines, then guess what, you're flying in circles 'till it regenerates buddy. 
-Individual part regeneration. After a short period (dependant on the part), it regenerates, free of cost, without having to go back to a station to repair and refuel.
-Unlock a part and you can use it as many times as you like.
-Free ship re-design. Re-design your ship over and over and over aaaaaand oooooooveeeeeeer again all you want, it's free. You're gonna need those remakes to create a good one. You don't even have to enter a spaceport and whatnot.

Once again, I'd love to love this game, I really would. There's a lot of great features and design aspects of the game I really love, but it's just not finished. It's just yet another game released before its time.

review: An extremely entertaining spaceship construction and combat sandbox where you collect purple orbs and build new ships of your devising which can self-replicate ad infinitum. Game is a work in progress but already fully playable with no annoying bugs. It is single with a sort of asynchronous muliplayer where you upload your fleet to be encountered by other players. Amount of different components is quite big, a couple dozens for each of seven playable factions and there are already thousands of designs made by players. 9/10, would be 10/10 when it is complete.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091892821', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 48389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32244, 'last_played': 1669672789}
review:
A fun enjoyable game with endless playtime, although it can be grindy at times if you play your cards right (easy) grinding will only take 1-3 minutes, just add more time to that for the extra currency or resources you need.
Graphics are simplistic yet easy to get around, nothing overly high  1800x1800 pixel sprite sheets like most other games out right now so performance shouldn't be an issue at all and viewing the game is easy.
Ontop of that it holds a good engine so even when there's spam everywhere the game will run smoothly.
Reassembly also inspires creativity, even if you aren't creative and bad at making things look good, the game still  assists you, and if you can make good looking machines the game makes them look even better out of the editor.
Gameplay is something not many use but regardless even if you get 5+ capitol mega ships you will still find something which will scare you and hunt you down followed by killing you.
However the best part by far in my opinion is the fact what you make, is whatever ships you make and add to your fleet design, will be randomly spawning and recreated which always gets me hyped when I see my own creations in use.

Generally i'd give this game a 10/10
Graphics - 10/10, Simplistic and easy to understand
Sound/Music - 10/10, Clear and easy to understand along with always being interesting
Gameplay - 10/10 Allows creativity and is in good balance

author: {'steamid': '76561197969620207', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3023, 'last_played': 1701532757}
review:
Great open-world shoot-em-up with a fantastic modular ship design system. I could (and probably already have) spend hours just designing and testing out different ships. I've played it for hours and there are a number of things I really like, but I'm going to focus on the areas that need improvement for this review:

My biggest complaint is the lack of end-game goals. Once you reach the upper limits of ship size and amass a big fleet, there's pretty much nothing that can stand in your way and the game becomes trivial. At that point, even if there wa s a win condition, there's no real reason to keep playing.

One of the other areas I'd like to see improvement in is the various factions. The first faction, Terran, has a lot of different technology to play with, but most other factions only have a few different weapon types, etc. This made playing the factions I'd unlocked less fun than I had hoped.

Finally, the ship AI leaves a bit to be desired, specifically their ability (or lack thereof) to navigate around obstacles. For a game set in space, the world is densely populated, and I've frequently had issues with AI ships getting stuck behind asteroids or accidentally getting latched onto other ships (the more irregularly shaped ones). Even trying to turn your own ship around in similar situations can be difficult with the default control scheme (mouse rotates ship).
