author: {'steamid': '76561198030055965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 3929, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3193, 'last_played': 1480750144}
review:
[b]TL;DR[/b] Reassembly is a game that won't let you go even after dozens of hours, keeping you busy building your own Death Star and then sending a fleet of those to ruin someone's day.

[h1]The Spacetacular Spaceventure.[/h1]

Reassembly is all about space and freedom of it. There are seven factions available, each with their own unique playstyle. You can peacefully grow plants and extract energy from solar panels, or you can set up your own fleet of doom and plunder the galaxy. You can take things down with precise lasers, continuous beams, play a pew-pew-em-up with plasma cannons and if that doesn't help - spam them with missiles until they die. For those who desire exotic methods of space annihilation, make your own sawblade of death. Choices are limitless.

[h1]Right [strike]in[/strike] from the childhood.[/h1]

There are just three resources in this game: R(esource), C(urrency) and P(ower), each made to limit or unbind your possibilities. The cycle seems to be simple - R is traded for C, C is spent on P, and P is how many hardware you can put into your ship to earn yourself more R. But it's harder than it sounds. You don't just buy hulls, glue cannons on them and go gunning things down. You build your own ship piece by piece, and that's where LEGO nostalgia hits. Space, energy and Power efficiency is what makes it hard and beautiful. You can put tons of armor and guns on your ship, but thrusters just won't carry such mass. You can be tanky and quick, but with little to no offense available. You can put powerful guns and quickly execute hit-and-run tactics, but two shots will annihilate your little scrap piece of death.

[h1]Spiky plants.[/h1]

You'll find out soon enough.

[h1]Dark spirit fleet has invaded.[/h1]

So, you've made your bulky space cannon of extreme vengeful execution of space heretics and conquered the whole galaxy. And that's it? No, of course not. There are wormholes and agents.

Wormholes is what gives Reassembly infiniteness. When you approach a wormhole you're offered to either pass through to a newly generated galaxy, or to send your current fleet to other worlds in form of agents.

Agents are what slows you down. They are well-equipped fleets made by other players, and they are extremely hard to defeat. There are usually 6-8 fleets on the galaxy map, and they're moving towards you. Slowly. But when they reach you, they start plundering your stations and ships. Until they are defeated, they'll find you and destroy you. But the reward for killing them is worth the trouble.

[h1]Boooooring![/h1]

Well then, recently there had been added Steam Workshop support. Test out all the new player ships and factions, unleash their power on others or get wrecked by their overpoweredness. I'd say that the choice is yours, but you don't really have any choice. The galaxy's cruel.

[H1]Conclusion[/h1]

The best singleplayer experience I had in a while. For how much this game already has, I give it 10/10. For me, this is the indie Game of the Year.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992766764', 'num_games_owned': 374, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1209, 'last_played': 1511991261}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025724769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 135, 'playtime_forever': 1759, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1759, 'last_played': 1426609701}
review:
Fascinating in concept, a lot of fun to play, and completely unique. Other games have you utilizing your own designs, but the sum total of Reassembly's parts produce something that I haven't found anywhere else. 

For better or worse, this game is almost too addictive. I've been avoiding it since it was released, because I spent all of my free time for at least a week just playing it constantly, to the detriment of both my work and sleep schedules.

I was sold on this game back during the kickstarter partly by the number of times the designer said the word 'spaceship' in describing it. You design your own spaceships, and fight other spaceships, while your spaceships give birth to other spaceships, then mail your spaceships to other players through wormholes to fight their spaceships. spaceshipsspaceships

author: {'steamid': '76561198141231864', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 17190, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3332, 'last_played': 1703322529}
review:
I like this game because of the deceptive simplicity, overall aesthetic, and also the progression. The ships you make gradually get larger, limited by your "pee" or, ship points, as I call them. you start by getting resources from plants, turn them into credits, then start making a massive empire of ships with a factory. the simple building blocks look great and most of the time just, fit! but I have some suggestions.
1.make more factions function correctly.
2.make the red faction's blocks fit more nicely/give a little more budging room. I often find myself building mouths and finding that they just won't close, and I spend hours trying to work around that.
3.steam workshop files.
4.give us block learning. a good way to do that would be to destroy thousands of p worth of that block in order to get it.
5. let us teleport as the fly!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025153924', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 84, 'playtime_forever': 3185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1989, 'last_played': 1687605147}
review:
Was surfing through steam games and found it. Bought it on a whim. Talk about a hidden gem!!!

Your space ship is made of parts. Just like legos. And they fight other ships the devs made or other players made. Thruster position and mass are a big part of how the ships work. Lots of 'armor' means more mass which means thrusters will not be as effective. And WHERE the thrusters are placed are so important too! Its just so much fun to build ships and fly them... or spawn them to make a good little attack squad against really well made player made ships. Errr just understand its just their designs. Its not an online game with PvP.

4/5 but will easily give it the extra point if more is added besided building/ fighting

author: {'steamid': '76561198088085449', 'num_games_owned': 304, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4727, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 926, 'last_played': 1672202184}
review: Amazing game! Taking an old concept, and making it incredible. The ever changing world is gorgeous, and the game feels so effortless. Controls A+ VIsuals A+ AI A+ Although the game doesn't have rediculous depth, the game concept is portrayed PERFECTLY! This is the most well designed game I have ever seen. Yes, there are better and more complicated concepts to games, but this one executes its concept incredibly. I have never seen a game so well made.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008531367', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3544, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1681, 'last_played': 1569708895}
review:
Pros:
-Appealing art style
-Great soundtrack
-Endless possibilities of ship design
-Numerous playable factions with their own unique play styles and ship designs
-Moddable factions with steam workshop support
-Moddable ship parts, potential for completely custom ships
-Player made fleets appear in your game
-Ability to upload your ship/fleet to the cloud so they can appear in other players' games
-Good graphics
-Newtonian physics, it's like you're actually flying in zero gravity
-Interesting AI differences in factions, some npc ships will actually salvage parts from downed enemies and use them to upgrade their own ship.
-A sandbox mode where you can simulate battles, take control of ships you spawn, and write scripts. Great for testing your custom factions and ships.

Cons/Suggestions to devs:
-The ship editor lacks a symmetry mode, which would make ship building a bit more streamlined
-When you run into stuff, you take damage. I feel like there should be an option to disable this for new players, however this feature grants the ability to create ships that ram when in combat, which is always fun as hell.
-There needs to be a better way to quickly check how damaged your ship is. Perhaps a bar on the hud that shows what percentage of your ship is damaged. Sometimes the screen gets so busy you can't see how much of your ship is left and when it would be a good idea to turn tail and flee if things get too hairy.
-Sometimes it's hard to travel quickly from one place to another because you can't see far enough in front of your ship to see obstacles like asteroids and stations. Space high ways or warp gates would be an excellent addition to the game.
-There is currently no way to tell how much of your shields are left. A way to monitor that would be very convenient.
-The sandbox mode lacks a tutorial on how to use the command line.
-An interesting addition would be factions that have more than just 2 colors in their color scheme. I sometimes feel limited when attempting to create more flashy and appealing ships. Maybe the ability to paint your ship or add decals would work.
-There are no planets. Holy shit it would be awesome to blow up a planet.

tl;dr

I bought this game after reading the reviews. They do not lie, this game is extremely fun and addicting. You will not regret spending your money on it. Amazing game and amazing community. If you're on the fence about it, I'm telling you to buy it. It's great and you'll really enjoy it. 9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198063863283', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 8799, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4877, 'last_played': 1631588998}
review: This is one of the most addicting games I've ever played. No matter how much you do, there's always another idea for a ship that pops into your head.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046533401', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 2692, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1489283870}
review: take the very beginning of spore, the cell stage, upgrade that ten-fold,  use a spaceship asthetic, and you will get a good idea of what reassembly is. this game is really a lot of fun, especially if you like building things. there are different races you get to play, each with their own style, weapons, and blocks to use. during the game, you float around killing other ships and collecting resources. you take those back to stations and factories that can make more ships, and blob out from there to occupy more space. the more resources you collect, the more you can upgrade, and the size of your ship will progressivly get larger and larger. one fun side part of the game is just designing ships and having tournaments with them. finding out what designs work in different situations and adjusting your current blueprints to fit within a certain size can be very addicting. do you want a slow chugging armored beast, or a superlite speedy sniper? in the end its up to you, and the amount of designs that you can create are literally endless.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065752770', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 523, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 523, 'last_played': 1435319790}
review:
Reassembly...a game where you can build you very own fleet piece by piece.  A very interesting and fun game that I would reccomend to anyone and that I think anyone could get a kick out of. The only thing is how long you'll stick with it. Now, I've only played this game for about 9 hours, so this is more of a first impressions, so take everything Isay witha grain of salt if you wish. 

This game is certainly an interesting idea that was executed rather well. They made the building system rather intuitive, but it is a bit difficult to master.  I did enjoy when I had my fleet and I was just cutting a warpath through my first world until I got to the wormhole and sent my fleet to other worlds and logged off for the night. It's a game you think you'll for an hour or 2, only to find yourself walking out your door screaming "WHAT YEAR IS IT!?!?" However, my only real problem with it is that is all you can do. To me it feels like a game that will get repetitive instantly.  

Again, only played for 9 hours myself, so take what I say with a grain of salt. I would reccomend this game to anyone to give it a go. It is certainly worth the 20 dollars, especially if you get real into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071037217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 927, 'last_played': 1644635649}
review:
I've always been a sucker for customisation and Reassembly offers the one of the best ship-building experience that I have ever had. It's nice to see a game where ship design, thruster placement and mass distribution directly affects performance. Seven playable factions each with their own unique weapons and playstyles. Depending on your combat preference, some factions are easier to play than others. You kill things, research new components and increase the point limit for your ships. 

I bought this game during a sale but after playing it I can say that, for me at least, I would have been happy to pay full price.

The only things that I would change in this game would be an option to disable tutorials when you start a new faction and perhaps a few more components for some of the factions that only have two different types of weapons. 

Quick edit since I started playing the game again: The only feature I feel could use improvement is AI targeting. The bots (and missiles) do not lead their targets AT ALL which can be a big source of frustration as it causes them to them miss most of their shots, depending on the weapon. Charge-up weapons also don't seem to fully charge when they are on automatic or bot controlled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053598179', 'num_games_owned': 285, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 10349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5701, 'last_played': 1638380929}
review:
Reassembly is a space combat game, in which you build your own ship, and can also design all the ships your faction spawns.

The ultimate goal is to conquer the galaxy, eliminating all other factions (I've never managed [EDIT: yes I have c:]).

It's got a great atmosphere, the galaxy really feels alive, with plants shooting their spores from one asteroid to another, all the different factions doing their business, battles raging, quiet stretches of space littered with the remains of destroyed ships, asteroid fields and wormholes.

It also has a sandbox mode (with command line and all), and a tournament mode, where you can organize battling championships.

All in all, it's a great game! As you can see (or not, depending on when you are reading the review), I sank over 92 hours into this game in two weeks. That's quite a lot - and for good reason, it's super addictive. It felt quick because I sank so many hours into it in a short time, I think, but it's got great replayability, I still play it occasionally.

Slightly dissapointed with some unlockable factions, and the UI isn't great (no way to save individual ship weapon bindings?), but I don't regret buying the game at all, it was (and still is, to be honest) a blast.

[EDIT (Feb 2016)] - Binding issue seems to be fixed! Devs are still fixing bugs and facilitating modding! :D

Most people should be comfortable with full price, it's not an expensive game at all.

Go ahead and buy it! :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198095670575', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 943, 'last_played': 1451503770}
review: very creative

author: {'steamid': '76561198114051864', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 15610, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6323, 'last_played': 1683834414}
review:
I must say, I don't come back to games that often.
But this is one of those gems that I can't leave alone for longer than a week or so, it's a masterpiece.

The idea? Make a ship, blow up other ships, farm resources, make an army, use the aforementioned army to destroy other ships and make your faction inevitably powerful and build super destroyers, for the sake of entertainment.

But it's so much more than that, it has beautiful graphics (even on lower settings), doesn't destroy your framerate, allows free building of pretty much whatever you want, in terms of ships / stations, the only part of this game that I feel is lacking is in both the modding and sandbox areas.

They could use a little work, not for me, but for those inexperienced in the usage of command lines.
Aside from that, if you like action/exploration, then take up this game, i've had 90+ hours on it and I'm still not bored.

^^

review:
Very addictive spaceship building, battle and capture game.

It's a constant challenge even later on in the game - just because of the infinate possibilities of the spaceship builder. This is an easy to learn yet very deep game with a lot to offer.
Don't be put off by the simple 2D visuals, the gameplay and building will suck you in. Give it 2-3 hours and you'll be hooked for weeks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059822891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2579, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 553, 'last_played': 1635986725}
review: dont get this game, just fucking dont..sure the game has some good points like its ability to let you build ships and the factions which i honstly love..but everything else is SHIT. ok, so no matter what you do, and im not fucking jokeing, no matter WHAT YOU DO, your going to die to 3-4 T-minion ships.. the game wont give a fuck if you have shields..or armor..its just going to make you have empathy for flys that cant get outside even though the windo is wide open..and the way you move your ships is TO FUCKING REALISTIC, you can never acctualy halt your ship, it allways drifts to some random direction. and the part generation makes you fly 6000 miles into space because it couldnt load one thruster, and asteroids somehow have invisible arms that they use to smal you into themselves nomatter what direction you head in, makeing you lose your shields or your railgun, so your renderd useless untill the next 20 fucking hours, or untill you die. and the world generation IS JUST FUCKING HORRIBLE, SERIOUSLY. you spawn at you spawning point..ok everything seems fine untill you look at the minimap, you realise your surrounded by the flame red AI fucks that will soon be dominateing you once they finish drinking the blood form the skull of your previous ship character..all in all, dont get the game..just fucking dont..

author: {'steamid': '76561198079785505', 'num_games_owned': 47, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 817, 'last_played': 1473244738}
review: This game is epitome of everything I tried accomplishing in my early childhood imagination. Building as you would with lego's is a small aspect to this game. The ability to create magnificent creations, throw some lasers, hundreds of missles and guns on it, is very fun. Just having a sandbox game with these features would have been good enough for me, but it goes on to provide an engaging universe full of objectives and threats. This game also has a very unique difficulty, where you have to experiment and use your imagination in order to be successful. I truly can't wait for this game to grow and reach great heights.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052277700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 2857, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1773, 'last_played': 1648929279}
review:
Wow.

This game is phenomenal. A true gem. It's like a rabbit hole that goes far deeper than you would assume at face value.

There is a lot of hidden depth in this game, from the simplistic yet very rewarding ship construction to the different ways varying races specialize, such as farmers who can cultivate plants into resources as opposed to annihilating all who oppose them with gigantic rail guns.

The game also boasts aesthetically beautiful fully destructable ships and environments, and a gorgeous soundtrack to boot.

In a lot of ways this game has me thinking this is what Spore should have been. Only with living spaceships.

Buy this game. Support awesome developers.

author: {'steamid': '76561197974008645', 'num_games_owned': 814, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 4150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2378, 'last_played': 1681239730}
review:
I started playing and before I knew it, 5 hours had passed. This game is fun & addictive. It's a strange mix between bullet hell shooters, real-time strategy and Spore (the species evolution game).

Build & customize your ship, research new building blocks, add on a factory, start producing ships for your fleet, build space stations, conquer the map. This last bit... tough!

The ship builder/designer is a game unto itself. Construct a ship by taking your command module and attaching blocks to it. Armor blocks, engines, power generators, harvesters, automated turrets, manual fire weapons, missile launchers, drone launchers, etc. Then press the test button and watch the AI duke it out in an arena against 5 different ships with similar construction cost in 1 vs 1 battles. It will highlight strengths & weaknesses... and it'll give you more information on how to further tweak the perfect ship.

I think I spent over half of my time with this game in the ship builder and battle simulator. It's just so much fun!

author: {'steamid': '76561198048708695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8385, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3448, 'last_played': 1678905947}

author: {'steamid': '76561198009126073', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 8251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3471, 'last_played': 1570734120}
review: It's great.  Less than a week by this point and over 55 hours clocked.  If you like desiging ships, be them silly or serious, this game will reward you.  It's fun to design and test each vessel and all while your faction adapts your designs and tweaking designs is easy and intuitive.  The AI is okay, but it's major strength is your own customization.  It has high replay value and if you want 100% completion on any one game it's tough as nails.  It's exactly what I look for in a video game.  You get out of it what you put into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069896504', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1854, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1100, 'last_played': 1675997960}
review:
If you are hesitant on if you should buy this game or not. Buy it! I've owned the game for a week and have already play 16 hours. As many other reviewers have said this game is very addicting. Starting as a small ship the size of a VW Bug, and then destroying other faction's ships and harvesting resources to become a ship the size of an aircraft carrier or 5. On top of that, your main ship can shit out other ships that you've designed, which will attack what you've locked on to. 

And once you've had enough with one faction, you've unlocked others you can now start a new campaign with. Other factions have different strengths and weaknesses. Buy it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056371053', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 543, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 543, 'last_played': 1435164717}
review:
Reassembly is a 2D vector graphics based space shooter where the only objective is to conquer and destroy everything else. You start in a small ship in your own faction with only one station to your name. You gain resources by destroying enemy faction ships, collecting resources from nearby asteroids, and expanding your territory by activating unused stations. Once you have enough resources, you can design your very own ships to the fullest degree as they are no mandatory templates or spaceship hulls to work off of. You can build ships that can build other ships on the fly and command a fleet of your custom made ships. All the blocks that make up a ship must be researched first, and the only way to gain blocks to your "datastore" is to destroy enemy ships with said block. 

*** Pros ***
Vector graphics and particle effects mean zero load times and small game size (~100 MB)
Custom build all ships from movement to weapon systems
Extensive tutorial to teach the games mechanics
High replayability as you can unlock other factions ships
Good soundtrack and sound effects

*** Cons ***
Large battles can get confusing because of particle effects

author: {'steamid': '76561198167489046', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1463, 'last_played': 1577898505}

author: {'steamid': '76561198002599817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 2361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2132, 'last_played': 1617061631}
review:
This is a simple sandboxxy space combat game.  Focus is on design and some very arcade style combat.

NOTE: I haven't played past the first 'race' - and the playstyle of other races are different - but in a limited sense.

In theory you could do economy building, but you only control one ship (effectively) so actually building a economy to produce masses of ships appears a distant dream.

Complaints about the balance are justified.  Ships designed by other players will inhabit your world, and they run the gammut from harmless to ... very challenging.

I'm continuously annoyed by 3 things.

1 - Economic development is unmanageable, and resource farms are often eradicated by combat.  It's not merely a re-seed problem - you can actually destroy asteroids - the 'ground' on which you plant farms.  Only one faction can effectively generate farms. Humans can push asteroids around and then hope that seeds spawn before the plants / asteroids are destroyed by combat.

2 - The blocks aren't quite standardized.  The slight differences in size and connection point locations are amazingly frustrating.  75% of my ship design time is spent trying to find a way of connecting blocks that are off by a few pixels.
As a bonus sometimes the order in which you assemble the exact same shape can allow or disallow a connection.

3 - Progression is very shallow.  You can spend your 'money' on: 
- new weapons / modules (but nothing outside your faction and there is no 'tree' or research time, just a list of items and prices).
- AI ships (like one of your faction's ships?, you could make one or just buy it)
- Size limit increases. (your personal ship is 'free')

'Size limit' is the only thing that prevents you from making collossal ships at the start.  Modules and Weapons (but not hull) have a complexity cost, and your complexity limit starts at 300.  You simply spend 'money' to buy a larger limit, and 2000 appears to be a good target for a good combat design.

You also have resources which are used to produce new ships.  You can trade resources for 'money' by dropping them off at a station.

Overall: 
 If you want a sandbox for designing blaster ships, this game isn't bad.
 Advanced stuff isn't possible due to the AI and mechanics. (AI can swarm - but you can't)
 The game quickly devolves into a deathball mopping up the galaxy - which becomes a chore awfully fast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023785211', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 18758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5859, 'last_played': 1688435269}
review:
Great game. Simple mechanic yet very addictive: you can create any kind of craft you want. Be it a big and slow heavily armed cruiser or a fast and nimble smaller fighter, the combination are seemingly endless.

+ A free roaming procedurally generated "galaxy" populated by different factions that fight each others for sector control.
+ Attractive but simple graphics with lots of different particle effects.
+ Greatly optimized resulting in perfectly fluid gameplay and rigid body physic despite the hundreds of objects interacting simultaneously.
+ There is a strange but appealing organic, underwater feeling to the game.
+ Soundtrack fits nicely with the game ambiance.
+ Incoming MODs support via Steamworks.

- Some factions could have been better balanced and lack variety in spacecraft design.

If you like old school 2D space shooters, give this one a try. The ship designing aspect adds a nice touch to the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198102364510', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 1466, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 681, 'last_played': 1519266737}

author: {'steamid': '76561198089447328', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 15814, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1584, 'last_played': 1629167935}

author: {'steamid': '76561198045583199', 'num_games_owned': 215, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 8156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1622668261}
review:
The game I've been looking for. Reassembly is easy to understand, rough to master, with multiple different ship construction strategies that may or may not work, whether alone or together.
Your objective is to collect resources to upgrade and build your ship(s), eventually providing your ship with a factory block that can spawn a fleet for you. Enemies are generated off of other players' designs, copied through the use of wormholes, keeping you however from ever encountering real players, just AI versions of their fleets.

Pros:
-No frame drops, I've rarely been lowered in video quality throughout my time playing
-Expansive maps, plenty of sectors generated swiftly with new stations to capture and factions to fight
-Comfortable building interface, with useful tools like mirror and copy and paste to make everything much faster to build, putting you in the fight sooner, plus a lot of weapons and tools to make specialized ships like drone swarm spawners, rocket carronades, snipers, etc.
-Nice artstyle. Very minimalistic, but it is still nonetheless fun to watch your ships "reassemble" as the new parts are traced and come to life in the middle of a battle
-No loading screens. Literally none.
-Test feature, which pits your newly made ship against another of the same value to test its strength in a real battle, before you try and fly a space dumpster into a battle and waste time

Cons:
-Slightly repetitive soundtrack. Good music, but it seems to loop a lot. Maybe I'm just playing too much :P
-Instructions and controls must be looked up a couple times to learn how to do everything (ie Toggle hud, commision fleet ships, set child cycles for your fleet's ships, etc)
-My biggest problem: Ship control. Most games like this have the WASD keys stay in a locked position of North, West, South, East. This game, however, orients control around your crosshair, meaning you have to constantly check which way your shape is facing and reorient yourself to fly properly. Very hard to get used to.

All in all, I'm giving it a 8/10. Fantastic game, and I highly recommend it, I would just like to see some new features implemented and that movement control thing given a second option.

Things I want to See Implemented:
-Co-op multiplayer. Allow a friend to join you in your faction and grow alongside you. Perhaps a combining force of an intelligent gunship and bot spawning mother-ship, I thought this would make a fantastic duo.
-New music
-New weapons and hull parts/utillity pieces, some ideas are:
     > Repair drone. Accelerates rebuild speed.
     > Cloaking system
     > Repulsion/Attraction blocks, for pulling in enemies into short range weapons or pushing them away from a long range ship
     > Kamikazee drones. Name says it all
     > Barrier construction. Some kind of attachment that uses resources to build walls for defense, or maybe even dispense some kind of acid or magma to ward off pursuers.
     > Parasite drone. A drone that embeds into the core of a ship and changes its faction, rebuilding it and putting it in your fleet, maybe even copying the schematic into your inventory


So those are my ideas and reviews of the game, hope it helped and you agree!

author: {'steamid': '76561198021798089', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 3501, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1521079216}
review:
Ever played Bubble Tanks? Well, imagine a universe in which
1. It was Polygon Tanks instead of Bubble Tanks
2. The series continued past number 3
3. Number 3 didn't suck

This game is quite a lot like what Polygon Tanks 14 or so from this hypothetical universe would be like.

If you want a more detailed description, there are tons of other reviews which sum up everything about the game far better than I ever could. Basically, if you think there's a chance you might enjoy the game, just buy it.
There's only one thing that bothers me. There should be an option in the editor for auto-symmetry, a lot like... well, Bubble Tanks 3. Everything else about the editor is astonishingly intuitive, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971228638', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 10947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2633, 'last_played': 1666306414}
review:
Taps straight into my need to tinker/experiment and refine, without dissolving into the usual option-paralysis that build&fly games usually have with endless numbers of components or useless decoration.   Love the simple artistic style, the ambient music and mostly intuitive building interface.   I still need more practice with flying.

The only negative I can think of is the over-zealous 'auto-zoom' feature, which is easily disabled.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117034991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 643, 'last_played': 1611076895}
review:
*AMAZING*
This is a beautifull game that makes you rage when the other factions kill you brutally and joy when you destroy their cities to death.
Ok now to the true review.
CONTENT:
This game is full of content:from giga weapons to strange asteroids that explode on contact,every faction has its own weapons and parts that makes you feel you are playing a different game when you switch faction.
The map is HUGE and every time different with tons of biomes.
GRAPHICS:
The game graphics are extremely simple but beautifull at the same time,they are very clean and outlined with lit colors.
CHALLENGE:
You'll start with a small weak ship and you are going to build your way up to a powerfull mother ship with hundreds of drones...
at least if the other factions don't destroy you first:every faction is hostile,no one will help you except some ships and some stations that are from the same faction as you.
So the game is very hard at the start but in the end it's easy as eating a piece of cake.
ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE:
While in combat the ai is formidable,3 ships can kill you in no time dodging all of your hits,into  the travel factor they often crash in to asteroids.
Multiplayer:WARNING MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS.















I'VE WARNED YOU.





















Ok now i can talk.
The multiplayer factor  is divided into two parts:wormholes and tournament mode.
Wormholes:
While exploring your world you could find worholes ,with them you can do two things:send your fleet in the world of another player(it's random),the sent fleet will spawn as an "agent" that whill destroy the players stations,or you can travel physically in to another world that is different from the one that you were in.
Tournament:
In tournament mode you can challenge other players in a fight between fleets(you can select the ones that you have built in single player).
Final vote: 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198010242470', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2322, 'last_played': 1625651193}
review:
5/10. Game runs well and controls are feel a bit odd, but manageable. There are factions, in the general scheme of things, they are the same. For a game about modifying and tweaking your ships, it shoots itself in the foot with combat. Combat has the depth of a kiddy pool. Which links back to the factions being similar. There is no cloaking, emps, damage differences between shield and armor, and no afterburners. Just to highlight a few things. Balance is questionable. No real economy outside of combat, trade maybe? Docking for stations? A campaign? Those don't ruin the game just felt missing. 

Bottom line for around $12 it should give you a good few hours of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039354265', 'num_games_owned': 380, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 3665, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1928, 'last_played': 1565657211}
review:
If you're a sucker for design-it-and-fail kind of games (like I am), then this game will be the crack to your addiction. The simplistic parts that you get to design your ship with is all you need to create the coolest looking space-ships this side of the galaxy. It's not as simple as "plug the device on and go", you need to build your ship CORRECTLY or it won't maneuver through space! Don't have enough retro-thrusters? You better hope you can back off the enemy fast enough by turning (and not dying from losing your back end). Didn't think you needed thrusters to turn? Guess you're going in one direction infinitely. It's a constant failure zone, and I just LOVE IT!

It's a very grindy game, so if you don't like grinding, I would certainly stay away. And the sandbox mode isn't very intuitive either. I tried to build something in the constructor (in the sandbox mode), and I didn't even get things to build with. Don't get fooled with sandbox mode, it isn't a free build-any-ship-for-free mode @.@ If you don't mind grinding as you play different factions (have to unlock them), then you'll find HOURS upon HOURS trying new designs and seeing if they stack up with the best.

[b] 24 hours of Gameplay later: [/b] This game is even better!  Again the game is grindy, but the different factions (without mods) force you to build your ships in different patterns. Have a good design for faction 1 (Terrans)? You're not using it on Faction 4 because there are no long-triangle blocks! The only downside with ship-building, is when you test your ship against others' you need to fight these really cheap min-maxed ships that do nothing but fly backwards when your ship catches up with every default ship in the game; actually it's the CPU attacking the other ships, but it's still cheap tactics that win.

Also, the sandbox mode isn't as convoluted as I first thought. I can create any ship I want with the right commands, and even see the default ship palettes for each faction. Unfortunately this isn't explained very well and you need a tutorial outside of the game to understand which commands do what (and that Faction 1 is actually Faction 8 for example). You can still build any ship you want in your save game, but the sandbox is very misleading (not much of a sandbox :/ More of a programmer's blank sheet of paper). I'm still getting my money's worth out of the game; Time to conquer the galaxy!

author: {'steamid': '76561197979698239', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1434591278}
review: Honestly I was intrigued by the video for the game, but I quickly realized this isn't for me. The beginning gameplay wasn't fun, fighting wasn't satisfying and I was dying a lot. I didn't feel compelled or incentivized to attack other ships, it was pretty much just chaos. A more directed experience with goals and sense of progression would help this game a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006754898', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 1540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 874, 'last_played': 1500823408}
review:
This game is great. Sandbox Singleplayer space game in which you create your own ships, your empire slowly expands with or without your assistance, and allows you to feel like a cog in a machine, playing nameless warriors as opposed to overpowered super characters.

Creativity Toggle: [ON] OFF.

9/10

+ Creativity.
+ Open Sandbox/No Narrative.
+ Build your own adventure.
+ No quest givers, achievements, or set goals.

- Not a TON of items to build with, though he'll probably add more over time.
- Only 4 months old, has room to grow.
- AI has a tough time once in a while.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013132245', 'num_games_owned': 419, 'num_reviews': 316, 'playtime_forever': 6281, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1752, 'last_played': 1578370775}
review:
Arcade-style graphics.

Design your own ships.  The part shapes are just occasionally odd enough that getting things to line up becomes part of the fun.

Test designs by letting them autopilot versus random other designs.  Center of gravity and healing rate are important.  Some ships are practically a huge gun with a seat and thrusters strapped onto it!

I spent hours not even playing - just designing a ship and watching it play against other designs in the test phase.

Once you are happy with a design (or just want to shoot something yourself) go in and harvest resources where the bad guys are, which also allows building up a fleet to team up against opponents.  Building a fleet is pretty cool - although they are something like a herd of cows...  not too smart and they get stuck in the weeds sometimes.  Playing the fleet dynamics is a whole game by itself!

The flight is very space-like where you have to oppose thrust to slow down, which makes it feel very swimmy (I think why they say welcome to the tide-pool).  In that regard it feels a little like Spore's bacterial stage, only flying takes much more concentration.

Replay value is sky-high, as optimizing ship designs at all size allowances allows starting over and trying new ideas.

Also, the game feels very different than other games because you have complete control how your ship handles (although once it's damaged and your engines have fallen off it will handle very differently until it heals again over several seconds, relatively fast).  Trying to control a damaged ship reminds me of Robocraft, though this game is much more twitchy.


TLDR:

If I had to pick a favorite game so far in 2015, this might be it.  The gameplay is straightforward.  There are always more things to want to try out, which takes time to get there and try them.  And Space feels alive.  This is more of a tadpole simulator than a space game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057346348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 724, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1437959318}

author: {'steamid': '76561198023888074', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 959, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1626034865}
review:
Build a ship
test the ship
cheer the ship as it fights a bot
be sad when it blows up
build a better ship
cheer as it fights a bot
be happy when it wins
take your ship out into the galaxy

author: {'steamid': '76561198068534122', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 8717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5035, 'last_played': 1682950683}
review:
So I've got about 100 legitimate hours of playing this game. That's split between playing the singleplayer, building ships for tournaments, watching my ships compete in tournaments, and sharing and battling ships with friends.

This is, in all honesty, one of the best space-ship games I've ever played. The game itself is built on very simple components: simple physics, simple graphics, and simple 2-D exploration. However, it is the way these parts fit together under the fantastic music and brilliant vector-based combat that just draw you in. Very immersive, very fun, very addicting, and by far the best ship builder in any space game I've ever played. The ship builder and sharing tools are really the highlights of the game.

What there is to do:
-Build ships from scratch
-Fly ships in open 2D space
-explore procedurally generated content (As with all games that rely on procedurally generated content, the wow factor goes away pretty fast. Thankfully, this isn't what the game relies on to stay fun)
-Unlock new ship pieces and build better ships out of the scrap of your defeated foes.
-Build a factory and begin constructing a fleet
- Battle fleets made by other players at hotly contested wormholes (There is no multiplayer, but the AI is VERY good and it pilots the fleets that players themselves upload. It priotizes the fleets made by steam friends)
-Enter the wormhole to upload your fleet
-share ship.lua files with friends and pit them in 1v1 battle in tournament mode to see who can make the best ship.
-7 playable factions

That's about it. One last note, it seems that the developer is pretty much done with the game. There haven't been any major patches since the launch and the forum activity has died down quite a bit, but I believe the last thing that's being set up for this game is compatibility with steam workshop so that all future content will come from the game's players rather than the devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139641420', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3055, 'last_played': 1439536851}
review:
If you like construction and customization, building a fleet of ships, leading your fleet into huge battles with other players' fleets for the sake of expanding your galactic empire, buy this game.

Don't let the 2d vector graphics throw you off. Reassembly is a relaxing game with a great soundtrack, infinite creativity, and great battles.

Several different factions, all with a different selection of weapons and hull blocks, gives much more replayability and keeps the gameplay from getting repetetive. The real fun is the ship building, though. Test your ships in simulated battles against other players' designs, and then use them in the game.

Basically if you ever dreamed of building and commanding a fleet of spaceships, you will love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046229246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 21374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15169, 'last_played': 1663883476}
review:
Remember those little fridge magnets you used to play with pretending they were space ships? That's this game, but better.

Of all the space, building, sandbox, and customizable games I've played, this one is way up in my top favorites. For those who love to be creative, this game is a must-get.

PROS:
+ Full customization of ships and stations, shape by shape. This is a huge plus for those who love to build things from the ground-up.
+ Ship building is very well structured and stable. Rarely are there frustrating moments where blocks don't do what I want.
+ Semi-open world (the world loops, but you can travel to new maps too.)
+ Nice graphics & well-built. Nothing too fancy, but still fitting. This game isn't too demanding in general, in terms of hardware.
+ Easy to get the hang of. It doesn't take too long to figure things out.
+ Forgiving gameplay. If you die, you lose all your resources that you were carrying, but if you're nearby enough, you might be able to rush back to pick it up.
 CONS:
- Frustrating at times. There will be times when you have those "BS" moments, and indeed, it gets rather annoying sometimes.
- Trial-by-fire learning curve. I advise against going to the center of the map until you're at max build limit...
- Full customization. For those who aren't able to commit to building your entire ship, there are only a few pre-made ships available at the start. Again, for me, this is still a Pro, but it depends on what games you're into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027792321', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3375, 'last_played': 1624059775}
review:
Where to start-

Reassembly is a top down 2D action spaceship building/ combat game. Sadly thats all it is though. This does not mean the game doesnt have some fun in it! You can encounter other players ships and send your fleet out for others to find. You will fly through space collecting resources and fighting other ships. It reminds me alot of first stage of SPORE. Ships out and about everywhere, collecting to power up.... Then some behemoth comes along and kills everyone. 

Pros-
- Easy to use builder. Doesnt take long to build ships.
- Decent combat. Sometimes the AI is wonky but all in all good.
- Huge areas to explore. Though after a couple times it feels the same.
- Neat factions each with their own strengths, except 3. Faction 3 is wet tissue paper hanging on toothpicks. Dont hit a rock too hard or bye bye ship.
- Good ship physics. How you build your ship completely affects the way it moves. Only complaint here is the seemingly never ending drift.
- General fun gathering. If you like the first stage of the game SPORE you will enjoy this.

Cons-
- Ship building is somewhat limited. You cant make really huge ships. This is limited by the max 8000P also once they reach a certain size the ether have no speed or no guns.
- Combat is decent but thats all there is to the game. Collect, size up, fight.
- Agents. I love the fact I find other peoples ships, I dont love that sometimes I run into massive fleet 10 mins in that destroys me so hard space rips a new black hole!!
- Some factions are unbalanced. Faction 3 is so soft on the hull that most my deaths came from hitting something too hard. I know it says hard mode but come on now tissue paper is not hull material. Faction 1 and 2 have the most building options. 4 can become really strong really fast. Like cut ships in half kinda strong. After playing all the factions I find 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 left me feeling let down. They didnt have as much to work with as 1 and 2 or were just 1 trick gimmick factions.
-Not all factions are playable. While you can mod to make them so, they are incomplete. I would love to see the borg like faction become playable or the plant type.
-Nothing but combat. I already mentioned this but it really is the biggest issue. Litterally all you do is collect, size up, fight, repeat. The game needs something.

All in all id say 4/5 stars. Sure it has alot of downs but that did not stop me from spending 40 hours surfing the stars. I recommend this to anyone who loved the first level of SPORE. If you liked that you will like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146413967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2454, 'last_played': 1628118791}
review:
This game is just too addicting! I can't seem to get enough!

Reveiw:
This game is basically Space engineers on Steroids. Where you design a ship and die a lot of times ( if you're me) or succeed greatly and gain resources and currency to spend on your upgrades and your ship. The ships are completely buildable and you have a large selection of guns to choose from and use (or abuse) on your ship. The map is randomly generated and people are able to upload there fleet of destroyers to your world in the form of agents. These agents are few in number and provide a challenge when you have made your ship so overpowered to the point where you raze other small ships. You can also hire and build allies, and there isn't much of a penalty for death.

11/10 would die 1,000,000 times and kill everything again

review: Very good game, I've played around 500 hours of it and it is still fun. At first everything will kill you, but later almost nothing stands a chance besides agents. A lot of diversity in the different factions. Every faction presents a new way to play, and a new goal to reach. Very easy to learn, very hard not to get blown up by bigger ships and not crash into random things. Only problem I have found in the game is the indestructible faction 1 station cores that sometimes agents are made of. 9 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210178768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 155444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12631, 'last_played': 1710462954}
review:
I guess I should update this review since it was so long ago. It's now almost 10 years since I made the original review and I have over 2,500 hours in the game.

[b]Why do I like Reassembly so much?[/b]
The base campaign is pretty simple and easy to complete. Where have all these hours come from with a tiny indie game?

Basically Reassembly is an engine that allows you to create what you want.

[b]Is the campaign too easy?[/b] - Make it harder by adding your own ships, more agents, or mods.
[b]Tired of the main faction?[/b] - There's six other factions to try out and each has it's own challenges. 
[b]Tired of the vanilla factions?[/b] - There's about 1,000 other factions people have made in the workshop.
[b]Still not happy with how things play?[/b] - Make your own mod and have it play the way you like.
[b]Wish there was more interaction with other player's design?[/b] - Try participating in tournament events, which we do a few times each year.
[b]Tired of building flat 2D ships with a set structure?[/b] - The game allows you to 'stack' blocks to create new design challenges.
[b]Still not done with that?[/b] - Take stuff you previously made and find ways to make it way better now that you know more building tricks.

^ This is how you get 2,500 hours out of a $15 indie game I bought 10 years ago.
10 years from now, I'll probably still be messing with Reassembly as long as I can find a computer to run it on. ... And you know what? The graphics will still be fine because it's all vectors.

Cheers  :D

============
Have a new idea for a ship.
Build it.
Make it better.
Test it.
Make it better.
Fly it around, shoot stuff, build a fleet and commit genocide.

It's now 5:00 am and I'm not sure what day it is.   .... but I have a new idea for a ship

author: {'steamid': '76561198118995407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1376, 'last_played': 1640200753}

author: {'steamid': '76561198160805988', 'num_games_owned': 142, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 28408, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4555, 'last_played': 1679546214}
review:
Very nice game, love the idea, love how it was all works, and the amount of players on it. It's also addicting, because you can just make a hole bunch of unique ships and get a big difference in each ship. Add a bunch of factions to it, and you get a huge variety of ships that you can make. The games environment is also beautiful. 
     The only problem that i have with this game, is the price. Its not bad, but it could be lessened to 10$ tops.

All in all, the game is worth the bucks. 9/10
(would recommend getting it on sale tho :P )

author: {'steamid': '76561198032231384', 'num_games_owned': 106, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 7003, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2922, 'last_played': 1539620619}
review: If you loved playing with or building lego space ships as a kid, then this is probably your dream game. It's a little hard to get into at first, but once you understand the mechanics of what is good/bad on ships, and how to maintain growth within your faction, then the game becomes a joy. Also if you're a perfectionist you can spend hours upon hours just building and testing ships. I know I have.

author: {'steamid': '76561198193483626', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1308, 'last_played': 1567461988}
review: Honestly one of the flat out coolest games I've ever played. The whole feel of the game, how it's organic yet futuristic and simple yet extremely complex is just awesome to me. It's a game that invites you to show off your creativity and ingenuity, and really makes you proud of your progress and what you've achieved no matter how far into the game you are, even if you're already been there in a previous save. Easy to learn, hard (but extremely fun) to master. Well worth the 15 bucks, would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970533652', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1666724181}
review:
This one is pretty original and addictive.

Its a 2D space shooter with RPG / progression elements.

The original part is that the RPG elements are all in the design of your ship.  You'll progress by designing better shaped and more capable craft as you go, and the designing mode itself is a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017871005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2495, 'last_played': 1664744421}
review:
I like this game, but it gets stale very quickly and the developer didn't deliver on the promises made during early access.  The game is exactly the same as it was when it came out on Steam, with the only major addition being a "tournament" mode where you plop a couple ships into a ladder to see which one wins out.

The aesthetic is interesting, but ultimately the actual game is shallow.  Most of the gameplay comes from designing your ship and seeing how it fares in combat, but the combat is doesn't have strategic depth other than ramming or kiting.  Your design slowly moves away from what you'd call an actual spaceship and more towards a geometric shape with internal engines.  A basic square filled with as many weapons and shields as possible is simply better than trying to create anything that's actually interesting.  Ship combat, therefore, devolves into a blob of shields mounted on a square careening through space and slamming into other blobs of shields in an orgy of lasers and missiles.  It looks nice, but carefully designing a ship isn't worth the effort.

The design system is simple and easy to understand, but in practice it just falls flat.

The "living world" is also not really what you'd expect.  Capturing territory across the galaxy becomes an exercise in Exterminatus from Warhammer 40,000.  You bring as many ships as possible and cleanse every single enemy ship from an area of the map, which then switches colour to your faction.  That's it.  You don't get any resources, your own ships don't start to spawn there, not even a message appears on screen.  A part of the map changes colour, and you move on to the next area.  Eventually this devolves into chasing one tiny little gnat of a ship that can't even hurt you across your territory because it keeps reclaiming tiles.  It's tedious.

Don't get me wrong, I liked this game, but it is very shallow and the replayability just isn't there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088214485', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2222, 'last_played': 1582444741}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998391180', 'num_games_owned': 3439, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1127, 'last_played': 1689102115}
review:
Creativity in video games has always been a standard. How do you beat this next boss? How do you navigate past this obstacle? In the past, the solution usually had a few different answers, but today the answers offered really do seem endless. Reassembly demostrates this by placing you in a gigantic galactic sandbox. You will start as the little fish, and work your way into becoming a devastating war-machine. Do you prefer anti-matter cannons, or a nice simple plasma beam? Maybe you will swarm the enemies with missiles and drones. Maybe even all of the above! Eventually you will also get the opportunity to design and produce your own fleet with a factory attachment. Each ship can be given a â€œchild orderâ€ in which they will spawn their own new ships as long as they too have a factory attached. A war-machine and a loving mother? Oh the duality of manâ€¦ Er, womanâ€¦ Errâ€¦ Spaceship. This isnâ€™t going well. Anyways, letâ€™s take a closer look at Reassembly.

Upon killing an enemy ship you will start to gain â€œRâ€ or resources, which can then be traded in for â€œCâ€ (currency). The currency is then used to buy new parts that can be used in any new ship design, this means you will probably redesign your ships fairly regularly to keep up with the latest, greatest weapons in attempts to conquer bigger threats. Your mothership has a â€œPâ€ limit, I assume P is for power, which can be upgraded with the currency. The power limit of any ship designs constructed will translate to the resource cost once you eventually unlock the factory. While the basics can take a while to master due to the needlessly abbreviated names, eventually your mother-ship will be ready to take on anything. You will scoot around repairing damaged stations, which are actually destroyed by your enemies in real time! There are 7 factions, which means 6 different races to destroy! While you might enjoy feeding on their little guys, stay on your guard because there is almost always a bigger fish. Then again, it might be worth the risk because destroying one of the gigantic capital ships among their allied swarm is extremely thrilling!

Maintaining control of an entire galaxy is tough work though, and opposing factions arenâ€™t the only ones out to ruin your rampage. Agent fleets, which are created and uploaded by other users (via wormholes) will relentlessly hunt down and destroy your spawning stations. When you finally find your way back to try and repair it, prepare for one hell of a fight. Flight and weapons are wonderfully dynamic, both in combat and out. Navigating an asteroid field takes a lot of foresight, unless you just have a set of lasers mounted to burn through anything that gets in your way. Some weapons are able to follow your cursor, while others are mounted firmly to the ship. Finding the best combination for your race, fleet, and strategy is absolutely imperative. Each of the seven races offers a completely unique set of parts for their ships so even after youâ€™ve cleaned up the galaxy as one team, there is still tons of incentive to go back and try the others. The AI is pretty intelligent as well. You wonâ€™t see a drone ship (yours or the enemyâ€™s) rush into the fray, and even the combat fighters know when itâ€™s time to retreat.

There is very little criticism Iâ€™m able to find for Reassembly. It does lack a story, and the level generation seems completely random which doesnâ€™t lead to much strategy regarding which colored enemies to go after until later in the game when territories have more or less been established. Overall, I found Reassembly to be an endlessly replayable treat, with a learning curve much higher than one would perceive at first glance. There are so many little touches that put this game over the top, such as the ship building battle simulator, in which you can test your newly constructed ship against enemies of around the same cost. This helps immensely with knowing how the AI will handle the many ships you spawn for it. Paired with the amazing construction, and as many galaxies as there are wormholes to crawl through (read: ENDLESS) this game is a fantastic indie gem that has truly blessed my library. Big thanks to Anisoptera Games and Indie Voyage for the review copy, this game is a jump away from absolute perfection. Fantastic work!

Gameplay:

    Controls- 9/10
    Fun Factor- 10/10
    Difficulty- 9/10
    Replayability- 10/10
    Innovation- 9/10

Aesthetic:

    Graphics- 9/10
    Music- 7/10
    Sound FX- 8/10
    Story/Lore- 5/10
    Level Design- 6/10

Final Score: 84/100 for fun factor, replayability, and graphics.
Summary: A gorgeous space-sandbox which allows you to design your own fleet and strategy.
Verdict: Reassembly will please anyone with an eye for construction and customization.

Gameplay/Review video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GO65vyQ9IVQ
Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-reassembly/

author: {'steamid': '76561197974575672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 8754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4013, 'last_played': 1698889069}
review:
This game is a lot of fun.  I still play it on occasion.  I have played all of the races to their max, and I still find some fun stuff to do.  

You build your ship out of geometric shapes and weaponry, and can build a fleet of your own ships.  As you build ships / stations, the randomly generated galaxy will start to incorporate them.  As far as I can tell, this works across save files as well.  I built a great ship with one race that was pretty much unstoppable and it showed up when I was playing another race as an agent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064584233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2799, 'last_played': 1470473735}
review:
I made a ship that's also a giant mouth, with plasma guns on the teeth. I used it to conquer a huge swathe of the galaxy, devouring all who crossed my path. None could stop me. Then I met my match. A huge, blocky warship covered in enormous plasma cannons. So I upgraded my ship. I went up to the level of battlecruiser. But I still couldn't destroy it.

Eventually, after much fighting, I worked out that the command module was vulnerable at the back. I downgraded to a tiny corvette and flew up behind it. I started firing my weapons, staying out of range of the heavy plasma cannons. My beams gnawed away as the other battleships approached. Then I got through the armour. I smashed the command pod.

I had won.

So yeah, it's pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002688923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1599188371}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020162488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 113108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13757, 'last_played': 1710202698}
review:
Simply put, this game is amazeballs! Seriously, buy this game. I would never have imagined someone making something like this or me going apeshit over it and yet here it is; At it's core just a handful of basic ideas, geometric building blocks, and one giant helping of awesome-sauce slathered on top to drown the whole thing in.

Here's what to expect:

1. A Procedurally generated space sandbox so the game is literally new every time you start a new game.
2. A palette of glowing geometric blocks with which to build your epic spaceship/station heart out.
3. Your own fleet lovingly mouse-crafted by you from one of 7 factions unlockable by playing the game and dominating your enemies.
4. 100s of stock ships from the 12 (or 13?) distinct in-game factions populating your space-box (that's "space sandbox" for those of you catching up).
5. One of my own ships showing up in your space-box bent on dominating your universe via the "Wormhole" system that allows AI controlled versions of other Reassembly player's ships to appear as "Agents" and lay down some good ol' fashioned obliteration on your ass.
6. Out of control radiant geometric space-plants growing on  nearby asteroid fields that SEEM to not pose a serious threat compared to the other guys with plasma-cannons and burst-lasers but just wait....just wait...
7. Moddable factions (currently in beta) where you, yes YOU! can create your own block palette, ships, and other faction goodies to inject into your game or upload to the Steam Workshop and let others play with your wonderful (or evil...) creations.
8. An awesome in-game soundtrack by recording artist Peaks.
9. Hours to fly by as you have an amazing time playing one of the greatest games there ever was or is or will be in this dimension or the other infinity of them. Seriously, buy this game. 

What not to Expect:

1. True synchronous multiplayer....sorry folks, this doesn't seem to be a thing in Reassembly but who knows about the future? *wink wink Arthur wink wink*
2. Boredom. In fact, kiss that asshole goodbye because Reassembly will be filling his usual spot from now on.
3. Buyer's Remorse. "This game is good. This is game is very good." - Everyone

author: {'steamid': '76561198015740903', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 24934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3375, 'last_played': 1509951192}
review:
This is THE definitive lego game for lovers of space and starships.
       It always surprises me when developers are able to boil the concept of 'fun' down to such a simple, gratifying level. And that is exactly what you get with this game; an intuitive fleet building experience where the fun doesn't stop when you hit the building menues. 
       I'd argue it starts there. Though admittedly half or so of my game-time was spent afk (as with most games I play), I have spent roughly 20 hours building ships, and maybe 5 actually cruising around. The 'tournament' style mode you can throw any ship you've been building into is incredibly rewarding, and oddly relaxing. Sitting back and watching the Dreadnaught you've spent an hour on go ripping through other people's lovingly crafted creations is a great system that both allows you to test out your ship against a variety of other players' designs, and serves as eye candy to the nth degree.
   
       The game has a concept of 'agent' fleets, in which a fleet designed by other players invades your world. There is a peculiar feeling I get from this game that stems from this idea, and not even necessarily when I'm playing it. The fact that some poor player will at some point accidentaly have a run in with my fine tuned, massive killing machines gives me a sadistic pleasure that I would say is almost entirely unique to this game.

A gem of a game for people of all ages, and now that it has modding support added, who knows what can come out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025582931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 3823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1344, 'last_played': 1603526361}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075360983', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1616196115}
review:
Dans Reassembly, il y a tout ce qu'on aime dans un jeu d'exploration spaciale...

C'est beau, c'est trÃ¨s fluide, c'est colorÃ©, c'est gigantesque ! 

On commence basiquement avec un vaisseau trÃ¨s limitÃ© en Ã©quipement, puis en dÃ©gommant les petits vaisseaux qui trainent on Ã©volue gentillement, on se fixe des objectifs sans s'ennuyer. Le monde est vaste, les ennemis divers et les factions fÃ©roces. Une fois atteint les 8000P de vaisseau, lÃ  on prend plaisir Ã  optimiser son escadrille !

 [b]Points positifs : [/b]
[list]
[*] La musique, vraiment dans le thÃ¨me (ma chÃ©riiiiiiiiiie) et entrainante ! 

[*] Les graphismes:  somptueux, on ne peut pas rÃªver mieux pour ce genre de jeux. Lorsque le jeu peine Ã  afficher les 300 vaisseaux, 4000 missiles et 2000 drones sur l'Ã©cran, il baisse la vitesse du jeu sans jamais sacrifier le framerate: un gros point agrÃ©able!

[*] Les factions : on les pense similaires mais elles ont toutes des points forts et des points faibles. Du gÃ©nÃ©rateur de bouclier taille XL en passant par le Missile nuclÃ©aire jusqu'aux Ã©pÃ©es laser devastatrices Ã  courte portÃ©e...

[*] La personnalisation : mÃªme si certains prÃ©requis demeurent (les propulseurs doivent Ãªtre rÃ©partis uniformÃ©ment dans chaque direction pour avoir un vaisseau assez mobile), Ã  vous de crÃ©er le vaisseau qui vous semble le plus efficace et le plus resistant. On passe d'abord aux vaisseaux cubiques pour aller vers des formes plus variÃ©es, souvent optimisÃ©es pour le combat selon nos prÃ©fÃ©rences.

[*]La possibilitÃ© de tester vos vaisseaux en 1v1, l'IA du jeu s'en occupe mais Ã©tant bien developpÃ©e parfois on est scotchÃ© quant aux resultats. Ce n'est pas le plus gros qui l'emporte (pas tout le temps) !
[/list]
 [b]Points nÃ©gatifs : [/b]
[list]

[*] Certaines factions rencontrÃ©es en jeu ne sont pas (encore?) jouables... C'est dommage on aimerait bien essayer!

[*] Le multijoueur n'existe pas encore (ou pas trouvÃ©..). Pour l'instant, votre flotte est sauvegardÃ©e sur les serveurs et vous rencontrez alÃ©atoirement dans votre galaxie la flotte d'un autre mais toujours contrÃ´lÃ©e par l'ordinateur...

[*] L'Ã©quilibrage entre les factions est Ã  mon goÃ»t encore Ã  travailler... Surtout la faction rouge-orangÃ©e qui malgrÃ© un arsenal dÃ©vastateur n'a aucun moyen de protection et croyez moi, mÃªme les plus gros vaisseaux sont facilement dÃ©truits...

[/list]

Je vous recommande vivement ce jeu. Car Ã©tant en dÃ©veloppement Ã§a ne peut que s'amÃ©liorer et les idÃ©es sont lÃ .

L'Ã©valuation est donc susceptible d'Ãªtre modifiÃ©e.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115092745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2410, 'last_played': 1589375758}
review:
Ich liebe dieses Spiel! Es macht extrem viel Spass mit verschiedenen Schiffsdesigns und Fraktionen rumzuspielen. 
Da man sieben verschiedene Fraktionen , die sich alle anders spielen ( z.t. sogar extrem unterschiedlich ) und eine enorme Gestaltungsfreiheit hat sind auch viele Spielstunden rauszukriegen. Ich habe jetzt 30 Stunden gespielt und das GefÃ¼hl die Anzahl der MÃ¶glichkeiten noch nicht annÃ¤hernd ausgeschÃ¶pft zu haben.
Es ist auch mÃ¶glich eigene Schiffe ,die man konstruiert hat, in seiner Flotte mitzufÃ¼hren um noch mehr Feuerkraft zu haben.
Die Stationen, die man eingenommen hat bauen auch neue Schiffe, die auch Spielerdesigns sein kÃ¶nnen, was dazu fÃ¼hrt, dass sich die Welt sehr lebendig anfÃ¼hlt. Die Flotten anderer Spieler, die oft schwer zu besiegen sind kÃ¶nnen allerdings auch problematisch sein, falls es nicht gelingt ihnen zu entkommen solang man noch nicht stark genug ist sie zu zerstÃ¶ren. Das passiert aber nicht hÃ¤ufig und die Spielerflotten sind spÃ¤ter im Spiel eine wilkommene Ablenkung wenn man sonst herÃ¼mfliegen und alles zerstÃ¶ren kÃ¶nnte. (Das macht aber auch wirklich Spass)
Riesige Raumschlachten mit vielen Schiffen, die wirklich chaotisch und lebendig aussehen trÃ¼ben den Spielspass auch nicht gerade.

Das Spiel lÃ¤uft sogar in grÃ¶sseren Schlachten recht flÃ¼ssig, dabei ist mein PC nicht sehr gut. 

Ist die 15 â‚¬ meiner Meinung nacht wirklich wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093651616', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1578121016}
review:
I have to say that before I purchases this game, I was kind of nervous about how it would be, though it had some really good reviews. I soon found out that those reviews lived up to the positive nature.

Starting out as a single faction to pick, and a basic little ship, you start out a bit causious, trying to gather resources to build your ship up and try to take control of the map with a fleet of your own design along side you.

I have to say that one thing that really impressed me is how optimized this game really is. It might seem like the simple nature of just polygons and other shapes would run smooth, but the effects and lighting that can take place during a large battle between many ships can cause your system to lag. Surprisingly though, it takes several hundred ships in that battle before it really starts to take any effect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030688533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2038, 'last_played': 1701713981}
review:
Bon, un petit commentaire en franÃ§ais afin que les francophones puissent s'intersser au jeu car il en vaut rÃ©Ã©llement la peine. 

DÃ©jÃ  le jeu est beau. Magnifique, splendide. Sur Mac le rendu est superbe. Sans parler de l'OST qui est Ã  tomber et qui met vraiment dans une super ambiance.

Mais bon, c'est beau machin machin, mais qu'en est-il du gameplay ?

Reassembly est un jeu oÃ¹ l'on contrÃ´le son vaisseau spatial. Ce vaisseau est modiafiable et amÃ©liorable grÃ¢ce Ã  des piÃ¨ces d'armes, de propulsion et j'en passe. Et toutes ces piÃ¨ces sont diffÃ©rentes en fonction des factions qui s'Ã©lÃ©vent au nombre de 7. Car une des forces de Reassembly rÃ©side dans la personnalisation.

Votre but va Ãªtre Ã  la fois de controler un espace plus grand sur la carte et d'avoir un meilleur vaisseau au fur et mesure du jeu. Il faudra donc jongler entre vous et votre faction.
Reassembly s'avÃ¨re surprenant dans l'intensitÃ© de certaines batailles spatiales et dans la physique du jeu. Reassembly dispose d'une physique superbe ce qui oblige a faire des modifications necessaires sur le vaisseau (Ex: si vous n'avez pas de systÃ¨me de propulsion sur les cotÃ©s de votre navire, il ne pourra qu'aller en ligne droite). Cala peut paraÃ®tre comme un dÃ©tail mais vous comprendrez en y jouant.

Un petit coup de gueule : le jeu n'est qu'en anglais (pour l'instant !) ce qui rend le tutoriel assez complexe au dÃ©but, mais les mÃ©caniques s'assimilent au fil du jeu.

J'avais achetÃ© Reassembly sur un gros coup de tÃªte, et bien je ne suis pas dÃ©Ã§u et si vous hÃ©sitez, n'hÃ©sitez plus et foncez. Le jeu est sorti il y a deux mois, il y a eu une MÃ J en Mars et il y en a une de prÃ©vu en Avril. Autant dire que le jeu s'avÃ¨re TRES prometteur.

Amusez vous bien !

----------

EDIT :

Un an plus tard...

Reassambly est devenu une perle. Le jeu n'a plus rien Ã  prouver.
Il a Ã©tÃ© rendu compatible avec le workshop ce qui l'a rendu encore plus diversifiÃ©.
De nouvelles armes et pieces de vaisseaux sont apparus laissant place a de nouvelles stratÃ©gies de batailles. Un grand bravo et merci aux Developpeurs.
