author: {'steamid': '76561198046836741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 32847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 10842, 'last_played': 1712302569}
review:
This games has essentially redefined the "build your own spaceship" kind of games. Sure, it's only 2D - but that gives the modding commuity much more room to push the boundaries! In terms of goals there are basically three:

Destroy all hostiles (thus stay alive)
Design awesome custom ships
Have a relaxing cruise through space to the games sweet soundtrack.

In a bit more detail though; some people dislike the deliberate inaccuracy with space physics, but I think it helps to simplify the playing and strategising. Having blocks with different features (such as ncreasing thrust/torque, beam weapons, cannons, missiles, resource generators) the creative potential is only really limited by the block limit and the RAM of your PC (I play this on a 8GB RAM laptop and it works OK, but best results come from higher RAM).

All in all, I cannot praise this game enough!

review: after over 100 hours of playing reassembly i can say i really like it. it could use some extra building blocks, more interesting weapons and stuff, but it is a solid and fun game. if you dont care much about gfx and just enjoy a good gaming experience in an old school design, this is something you will like.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049078901', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1951, 'last_played': 1556497854}
review:
[i]It's Reassembly:
Customizable Spaceships,
Maybe look at guides.[/i]

   Reassembly is an interesting 2D sandboxy game where, simply put, you make spaceships out of varying sets of shapes and modules in an attempt to devour all other living things in the galaxy and unleash an age of your own reign. Or you could just get the second playable faction and make giant solar panel stations. Doing that also works.
   Anyway, I would suggest playing Reassembly if you like to create pretty things, functional things, or just spacey things in general. I personally like it for the large amount of customization which can be expanded even further with (apparently) easy modding that I have yet to dip my toes into.
   One of the few downsides I can think of is the fact that the various "factions" are limited to specific sets of blocks instead of it being all blocks at once, but that kind of makes it more balanced, otherwise you would end up having giant solar panel stations with nuke all over them.

As an added note about the last line of that haiku, I would suggest reading through some guides if you're having trouble at first. Unless it's just really not your cup of tea, it will probably get fun eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964696375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2330, 'last_played': 1487295121}
review:
Extreamly addicting and fun game.  The ship designing system and balance is brilliant, as is the economy and ship-reproduction system.  Good for about 40 hours of intense gaming. WOW.

My only gripe is that after playing the game as the starter race for about 40 hours and hitting the part cap, I hit a wall because I got the feeling I'd expereinced everything in the game.  In my opinion, the other races and the "clean out the entire universe" tasks aren't as compelling as the development of increasingly complex and dangerous ships as you "level up".  The honeymoon ends once you hit the part cap. 

In my opinion, if there were no part cap, i would probably play this forever making like deathstars at some point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198100944461', 'num_games_owned': 160, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 4896, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 640, 'last_played': 1572794501}

author: {'steamid': '76561198125254167', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2325, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1114, 'last_played': 1506118642}
review: It's a top down space shooter sandbox, and what an impressive sandbox it is.  The construction element of the game is really impressive.  My hat is off to the developers, they have accomplished something really impressive with reassembly.  I hope that it inspires developers everywhere in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000425817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3028, 'last_played': 1489440286}
review:
I love this game. Spent hours, no days building and optimizing spaceship designs. This is a designer's game.

Pros:
-The controls are flexable so you can fly however you want, a very welcome feature in these top down 2D games.
-The attention to detail in physics is incredible, e.g. if your ship has no off-axis thrusters, it turns really slowly.
-Open ended - no one strategy to dominate. You can go for speed, armor, shields, range, or build cost. Or you can just be a farmer or a gatherer.
-Multiple races - just when you think you've optimized a ship series for a particular race, you can play a different race with different abilities and different parts!
-Really pretty
-Self-building ships: the trouble with other building games (e.g. StarMade) is that you always have to rebuild your ship after a battle. In this game you don't worry about that, although there are design strategies for having your ship regenerate faster.
-Good combat AI, so you're not frustrated with the AI pilots being idiotic which breaks many other games.
-Ability to customize the build sequence of allied ships and stations

Would like to see:
Fleet vs fleet battles with the asynchronous mulitplayer! There are ways to do this with the sandbox but it's not very accessible.
Better (maybe customizable) combat AI: e.g. turning the ship to hide damaged armor or shields from enemy fire while it regenerates, or maybe being able to specify a preferred range of engagement.
Better non-combat AI: Having AI ships being more exploratory would be nice, otherwise they exhaust their local resources and just end up sitting around.

My dream is to build an agent fleet that can go into someone else's universe, replicate like crazy and be hugely successful, and completely take it over. Muhahahaha.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111217446', 'num_games_owned': 135, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 15420, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5088, 'last_played': 1671573365}
review:
Reassembly. 

A game about building spaceships and fighting against AIs In a open galaxy.

You can design your own ships completely form scratch out of different parts.

There are 7 playable factions each with different parts to use.

If you like captain forever you will almost certainly like Reassembly.

You can collect resources from plants and build a fleetof your own to fight along side you.

Overall A very good game.

Definatly worth buying!

author: {'steamid': '76561198213602552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2207, 'last_played': 1684629575}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041108753', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 16588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4073, 'last_played': 1662812445}
review:
Sometimes, two children building spaceships out of LEGO will be in the same room and without adult supervision. They will probably start by dogfighting their plastic creations, but sooner or later they will be taking turns to throw each spaceship into the other. This is the game of those models.

Reassembly's ship creation is simple but pretty intricate in its outcome - you strap 2D weapons, components, inert hull pieces and engines to your command module until you're happy with the result. Ships can be any size, shape, scale (ships can be worth 50 points or 8000), tactical role and degree of effectiveness. You could build the Serenity, a Star Destroyer, a butterfly, a cartoon house with drone launchers in the windows, a space station shaped like Dover Castle or even a sniper rifle with a spinal death weapon for the barrel and a point defence laser for the trigger.

At any time during the customisation you can press the 'test' button, and the AI will fly the ship against available stock designs in a 1v1 arena battle. You can also use the tournament game mode to watch battles between selected designs from any of your save files, any of your friends' save files and any .lua files someone has shared elsewhere on the internet. The devs run occasional open tournaments for ship designs, as do some youtubers.

Single player is utterly devoid of story, it's basically a sandbox galaxy in which various mutually hostile factions hold territory. Kill things and provide R (the production resource) to your factory ships to gain C (research resource). Use C to increase your ship's build limit and unlock new components to play with, or to hire friendly ships to follow you around. Install a factory on your ship to be able to spend R on your custom escort ships, which you can release for more C. Conquer and comsume the galaxy, find a wormhole, travel to the next galaxy and start over. The visuals are pretty nice, the opposing factions are diverse and the fact that your escort ships are ones you yourself have designed makes the campaign feel more exclusive and personal in a 4X-ey sort fo way.

The 7 playable factions generally handle differently, which adds some replayability. Some factions have diamond or rhombus hull pieces, changing their look and design priorities. there's a faction with really cheap shield generators and sniper cannons that can spawn resource-generating space-plants, there's a faction with cheap high-damage weapons and deadly beam drones but very little effective armour, there's a faction whose only direct weapon is a spinal plasma launcher you build by stacking modular components on top of each other. There's one faction that gets nuke launchers and melee spikes.

On the downside though, some of the factions get their playstyle from a lack of versatlity and a poor choice of components. It's pretty demoralising to look at a new faction's full array of hardware and think 'is this it?' Tournaments can be dominated by Faction 4 (the modular plasma cannon one) and by 'spinny ships' (that exploit the AI's ability to lead targets, making them impossible to hit), the music is good but can be intrusive and gets repetitive after the first dozen hours or so. The campaign has almost no ships bigger than 3000P, meaning a player with the cap of 8000P gets to stomp everything with little effort or interesting events. They are small complaints but they do add up sometimes.

To finish, I'll say that Rassembly holds its players' attention not with a scripted or even emergent narrative, or with a great challenge, but with the promise of having something to tinker with. Working out the strengths of each weapon or design, using those extra 200P to give your flagship a little more punch, and reverse-engineering a design you saw on youtube that one time, are what contributes to an addictive and engaging experience that's well worth the Â£11 it asks for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982567490', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 324, 'playtime_forever': 4652, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1486, 'last_played': 1555432971}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035283552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6706, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3577, 'last_played': 1622422499}
review: This is a fun game that can be played casually while still offering some intense moments. The choice of different factions offers some degree of gameplay balancing: for a difficult play choose race 2, or for easier gameplay, race 4. Tons of fun building and testing my creations against community builds and those of my friends, and when you unleash an armada of ships through a wormhole you will chuckle right up to the point that you run into someone elses death fleet and get hammered. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1428434816}
review:
Reassembly puts you in command of not only one ship but an entire fleet of customizable and player made ships. 
The beauty of Reassembly lies in its freedom. From experimenting with ships to exploring the galaxy, as you pass by gargantuan space battles happening around you. 
However there is some blackholes in the beautiful universe that is Reassembly. Controls and lack of tool tips can make the game a little bit frustrating at times. Experimentation is required to figure what does what. Also combat ends like a flash in pan. Either you or your enemy will usually over power one another and it will end rather quickly. Not to mention the computers pin-point accuracy that simply a human couldn't replicate due to the camera. Leaving all your best laid designs to ruin. Graphically and musically Reassembly hits the mark. With a space themed soundtrack that is enjoyable to listen to and vibrant colors that fill out the galaxy. Reassembly givens you freedom to make what you want and do what you want. Long as you don't mind a little inconvenience here and there.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/YfyDepRbQnQ
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

author: {'steamid': '76561198019355296', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 3984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1659141736}
review:
Great game, I'd even go as far as to call it superb. Basically you start as a small ship being part of a faction. You go around collecting resources and fighting enemy ships, bringing the resources back to your base or to motherships to be rewarded C (the "money" currency in the game). C is used to upgrade the max points you can spend on your ship, meaning you can create bigger ships with better guns and upgrades. C is also used to buy new weapons and things like shields you can put on your ships. You can recruit other ships also with C but it's a stupid thing to do since you won't really earn any C if you spend it on getting allies.
So you go around the galaxy, restoring your faction's stations and earning C and resources by doing so, destroying ships and their stations to enlarge your territory, but the enemy factions do the same thing to you. They destroy your stations and your hive ships and as you are expanding your territory in one direction, it's easy to lose your grip in another part of the galaxy meaning you have to upgrade all the ships in your faction as you unlock more total points to spend on ships, otherwise they will be too fragile when the enemies attack your base. You personally customize all the ships in your faction any way you want to, mixing functionality with design or just going flat out functionality with ugly ships.
After a while when you've earned a ton of C, upgrading the total points you can spend on ships, you start to build hive ships which can create new ships. You get to choose 4 ships that you can create but you can replace those ships whenever you want to without replacing the already built ships, meaning you can build 4 ships of a certain type then switch them out and build the next 4 while keeping the ones you already built so you can basically have a whole fleet of all the ships in your faction. This is when the game becomes fun for me because now, you're basically free to do whatever you want to. You started as a drone for your faction and now you have become a moving station, building ships from the resources you and the ships you produced gather for you, growing your fleet larger and larger all the time being able to take on more difficult enemy factions. Or you could just stay as a fighter ship if you're into that, collecting resources for your faction and letting it expand on its own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079307571', 'num_games_owned': 1549, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1571950781}
review:
This game is an awesome starship building/destroying sandbox. It is open ended, there are no goals. You build a ship, kill ships, gather resources, unlock parts, raise your ship size limit, build bigger ship, kill bigger ships, build something insane, die, try egain :-D Killing an enemy capital ship unlocks that faction for you and you can use it in your next save.

Graphic style is simple but looks very good. It is colourful and trippy. I would describe it as a space Lego on acid.

Sound design is ok. Nothing mindblowing, nothing bad - it works and doesn't pull your attention too much.

Music is great. It helps you to immerse yourself into this space madness. It will get you into some kind of trance and then you realize, that this game managed to devour your whole evening :-D

If you need story and goals, this is not a game for you. But if you like to build crazy things and test them in combat + you like 2D space combat games, you will love this thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009384224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3515, 'last_played': 1662575032}
review: The LEGO-style ship-building process that has "realistic" impact on how good your fleet actually is compared to others is addictive. At least to people like me who grew up building LEGO spaceships and always wished that they could actually mass-battle them against each other. The sound track is mesmerizing, I just wish (after 40+ hours) that there would be a few more songs for variety. But it's still far from boring, very inspiring in fact. The graphics are stylishly abstract and big battles are amazingly beautiful. This game really is a treat, and I am glad I backed it on Kickstarter last year. Thank you so much to all the developers, I'll certainly keep playing this for years!

author: {'steamid': '76561198086554974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1701148347}
review:
The game is fun, and I love the customization. You have to build your ships to match your environment, and play style/skill. The battles are intense, and very frantic at times. 



But then there are agents.



An agent in this game is another player's fleet, uploaded and ugly. The problem with agents is two fold:

a) They are usually better equipped than you are.

b) They actively destroy your stations/territory.



Agents suck. Make it a priority to destroy them. Leave, harvest, min max, eradicate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072768799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 30775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23575, 'last_played': 1697078996}
review:
[h1] This. Beautiful. Game. [/h1]

For those who enjoy having the ability to build literally almost EVERYTHING for yourself, this is very, very, very welcoming to the creative minds out there. Every single aspect of the ship is COMPLETELY up to you, as you build your ship (and soon) fleet; not just build, but evolve.

At first, you might get lost real easily by how the game starts out, dropping you in the middle of the game, letting you get your hands in the thick of it with no real instruction. EXPERIMENT! This game is literally endless, with no real, true penalties to stop you from doing whatever you want. From a few simple polygons, you clump it together slowly, piece by piece, and learn what YOU enjoy, and find to work, and improve off it. Not only that, but this game can conform to the way you wish to play easily, so there is NEVER any one, right way to play. 

Wish to go in hard and heavy, with a giant, bulk-head cruiser? Go ahead, and charge at enemies with a hailstorm of laser beams. Or stay it safe, and strafe your enemies and snipe from afar with powerful missles and energy shots to obliterate the enemy. It is entirely put into the hand of the creator: You. 

I bought this when it was at $30; I would do it again and again. I found it good enough to actually post a review for the FIRST TIME. With a lovely $15 price tag, and with how well sewed this whole game is, based on such a simple concept and turned into something limitless, I could nearly argue it's the best game I've ever played in my life thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049200072', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 124997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18089, 'last_played': 1609960164}
review:
Reasembly. It is more than a vectored spaceship-building sandbox game. It is a game of infinite possibilities! It is an extrememly addicting game should you have a creative and boundless imagination. With seven highly modifiabe factions to play as, [spoiler] and three more playable factions when modifying the game's cvars.txt [/spoiler], explore an ever-evolving galaxy full of wonders, dangers, and plants [spoiler]that are more than welcome to slice you to ribbons[/spoiler].

[spoiler] You also have access to a sandbox mode, which you can use to create literally any ship.[/spoiler]

[spoiler] Press \ in the main game to access sandbox abilities, too![/spoiler]

Imagine the tidepool of "Spore"'s Cell Stage, combined with the role-playing aspect of "Faster Than Light", and the simple ship-building mechanics from the flash game "Captain Forever", and the theme of the Space Stage of the aformentioned "Spore". This is basically Reassembly in a nutshell. Or is it?

author: {'steamid': '76561197989499070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 17970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11800, 'last_played': 1671241837}
review:
This game rocks. It sucked me in completely for a couple of weeks. I'd look up at the clock and think omg it's been 6 hours! I'd go to work the next day on 5 hours sleep. It stirred my gamer blood! The ship building freedom is top notch. You build any kind of ship you want particle by particle and there are lots of smart, handy features in the ship building editor to save time. You can hold down the mouse and drag it across an area to select multiple components or you can just double click one piece and everything attached to it will be selected. 

A quick ship building tip is to just build one side of the ship, say a wing, select all the pieces then hit c to copy. Move the cursor to a blank part of the screen and hit v to paste, then hit m to mirror (to invert the selection). Now you can just attach that perfectly mirrored section onto the opposite side of the ship if you need symmetry like for wings.
Symmetry is also important in placing your thrusters. You are in space so your ship isn't going to stop moving unless it crashes into something...or you put thrusters pointed in the opposite direction to the direction you're traveling in so you can break!
Also each different playable faction has some unique pieces to build with. Sometimes the minor differences aren't obvious, like where pieces don't have as much mass as other factions or they have slightly higher armor, but when you stack all those pieces together into a ship then the net values really make a difference in speed, toughness, or resource carrying capacity. You'll want to look at the stats on the ship pieces closely if you're into ship building.
If you're not into ship building there are premade ships available with each faction that you can use and just modify to your taste.

The game is beautiful to look at and very organic. To me it looks more like the world under a microscope filled with living, evolving organisms than it does a space frontier. Much like organisms, the ships actually create children. You can set a creation queue for yourself once you have a factory as part of your design. But you can also go into command mode by hitting tab and click on an allied vessel that has a factory and drag child designs into their queue so you begin to shape the future of your factions expansion without actually managing the execution. Just hit tab again to go back into pilot mode and go on your way. The allied ship you just programmed will now create what you set for it via the AI. 

Once you've got your perfect fleet together you can find then fly into a wormhole. You will be given an option to follow it or stay. If you stay a parallel version of your fleet will upload to infect another player's galaxy through one of their wormholes while you remain where you're at with your original fleet. I just really wish there was some way of knowing how successful these invasions were, like a scoring system players could access to get some sense of how good your designs were.

The tournament mode doesn't pit you against other players. It just lets you test your own ships against your own designs and a small selection of premade designs. I would love to see a true tournament mode where you download player agents and test your ship against theirs with scoring. The game lacks true player interaction in real time but atleast we can see other player's creations as they come into our own galaxy as enemy agents controlled by the AI.

Unfortunately I do think there is a balance issue that needs to be addressed with faction 4. You will eventually find certain enemy agents that are typically oblong, travel at high speed, and shoot enormously long particle rays at you at range even from off of the screen! That's faction 4. They almost made me rage quit because they really get too many advantages, but I perservered and went back to the design editor. Their weakness is maneuverability. Their big bad weapon of choice is not turreted so the whole ship has to turn to target you with the death ray. This is not a huge disadvantage because their ships are inordinately fast but if you build a ship that can quickly side step their line of fire and either swarm them or ram them so that they can't turn into you then you can take them down...if you can catch them. Trapping them against asteroids is a typical ploy. Really though, no other faction gives nearly so much trouble...

The only other criticism I have is lag. No it's not really just a hardware issue. I play many other games where it's not an issue. The devs themselves have stated that they've worked really hard on the optimization but the fact is there comes a point where there are so many collisions going on in the galaxy that it can be taxing. I have an i5-4670, 8G ram, nvidia GTX 780 so my hardware is good. But I like faction 2 whose strength is cultivating resources and building up a fleet really quickly. Once I push out a bunch of ships that then create their own AI controlled child ships, the game has alot to track. The devs said to go into options and lower the physics updates per second value so I'll try tweaking that more. But it kind of makes me want to put the game aside now and come back later, maybe playing a different faction and not use a swarming strategy. If you get lag you can also follow a wormhole to a fresh universe, but that too can start to get repetitive.

The fresh content is really about fighting other player designs as enemy agents enter your galaxy. I hope the devs continue to work on the lag issue (maybe instancing parts of the playing field to lower the amount of AI activity needed as the game progresses). I'd also like to see them expand on player interaction by scoring invasions, and maybe add some simple tiered goals with rewards for flipping sections of your galaxy to your faction. I think those things would add alot to the game's longevity for me. Regardless, this is a really creative game. I love looking at it and playing it. It was worth every cent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042065562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2932, 'last_played': 1680550222}
review:
The level of enjoyment you get out of this game will depend on two things, how much you like starships, and your level of creativity.

If you don't like sci-fi and disliked art class when you were young, there is a fair chance you won't get much traction with this game, but if you are creative, imaginative, and love sci-fi, this game is a splendid creativity tool.

It could use some more parts admittedly, some factions have close to 40 while others have only 17 or 16, and it has a few factions that aren't playable at this point, both things I hope will be rectified in the future, but despite a few flaws, this game is undeniably a jewel, a unique and interesting concept.

In the end a Review is about one thing, is the game fun, and for me, and likely for those others who enjoy science-fiction and creativity tools, this game is definitely fun, prepare to sink hours into tweaking the designs for your fighters, capital ships, and stations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025872420', 'num_games_owned': 511, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1494, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1666392186}

author: {'steamid': '76561198016887117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1870, 'last_played': 1664572770}
review:
â€œItâ€™s like watching Battlestar Galactica through a kaleidoscope!â€

This is one of my favorite 2D games at the moment and WHY I SAY THAT YOU MAY ASK? Let me start with the basics: Reassembly is an action oriented spaceship building game. Created by Anisoptera Games, an independent studio based in Los Angeles. Mainly inspirited in Lego and insect behavior in a world where everything is modular.

Reassembly

You start to build your very own ship piece by piece (ships are assigned a specific value based on their size) and most of the factions will cap out at 8,000P. Obviously it will take some time to get there ;). There are 7 factions in this universe and all of them play and work differently (insectoid, angley, squarish, plantlike or cristal like are some examples). One faction prioritizes high damage while other will get armor mostly. All of them have specific tactics and this will impact in their weapon choices.

You can also unlock most of the factions by killing large and valuable ships aligned to them. Once you destroy an specific amount (or, in other words, you make that faction lose an specific amount of value), you unlock that faction to play with.

Combat

Wield a wide variety of projectile and beam weapons, missiles, rockets and torpedoes, drones, and more against your enemies. Defend yourself with shields, armor, point defense systems, and pure maneuverability. The combat is a mix of skill, tactics, and preparation â€“ an expertly piloted fighter can take down an enemy fleet, but having a well balanced arsenal helps. I canâ€™t explain this better.

Art & environment

Maps are beautiful and the music flows with it. Procedural generated open living worlds where each faction fight for survival and evolution travelling though wormholes. There are usually a lot of â€œagentsâ€ (player fleets) spawning in the universe defending the sectors and spaceships, in Command mode you can pay them to join your fleet and seek you places to emerge. You need to conquer specifics zones to make spaceships emerge or grow your bases. But be careful, the big enemy fleet is looking these places to destroy them. Scavenge for resources, investigate disturbances, self repair, reproduce and take your fleet to the next stage.

 Reassembly Reassembly
 Reassembly Reassembly
 Reassembly 
Artificial Intelligence

AI is incredible. When you have a decent fleet of spaceships including your motherfucking leadershipâ€¦ YOU WILL DIEâ€¦ A LOT. AI ships can retreat if overwhelmed because they know how to measure the incoming attack. You need to plan how to attack and how to approach the battle and maybe take advantage of impromptu battles between rival factions to recover objectives, or run away after your opponent calls in reinforcements. In screen there can be around 150 ships in crossfire (it will run smoothly and at a decent framerate if you have nice hardware, otherwise you will be laggy).

You can only target 1 enemy at time with you entire fleet and that is a questionable design choice. A small system to target different ships would be nice in Command mode. The overall gameplay is very nice. Sometimes maneuvering big ships can be frustrating in places with a high amount of ships and planets, but is not that bad. We have three control types: Keyboard Only, Mouse and Keyboard, and Gamepad. This is very nice and completely user configurable, from colors to buttons, keys, even control schemes.

And well, we canâ€™t have it allâ€¦ No true multiplayer mode(canâ€™t fight other players in real-time) the AI takes over other peopleâ€™s ship designs and places them in your worlds. Obviously, you need to upload your fleet when you go through a wormhole. Last time a tried that Steam completely crashed, so some additional work towards multiplayer would be appreciated. PLEASE LET US PLAY IN REAL-TIME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044198715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1425213138}
review:
Poor instruction. Poor UI and poor gameplay.

Every ship drags out and drifts so much that thrusters are really only to propel and fling you in one direction while you wait to crash into something constantly. Simply put, the inertia is very poor.

Haven't played much, and I'll have to play some more to justify blowing 15$ on this mediocre game.

Game feels heavily like an early-access (ie bad) than something that is classified as complete and released.

You bascially throw together some ship with thrusters and weapons on it and fly around and shoot stuff. The end. Every ship looks the same (a chunk of material together with random projectiles coming out of it)

Certainly a regrettable purchase. Legitimate buyer's remorse. Don't let the trolls saying it's good and downvoting anyone saying otherwise tricking you into buying this poorly made and hollow game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985187860', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2361, 'last_played': 1599513755}
review:
Reassembly es un juego de exploraciÃ³n, construcciÃ³n y batallas espaciales.

Me recordÃ³ vagamente a la fase inicial del SPORE, en el estado de cÃ©lula. Vas recolectando recursos o destruyendo otras facciones para ir evolucionando tu civilizaciÃ³n y mejorando tu flota de naves. Al igual que en spore tus diseÃ±os ademÃ¡s de usarlos tu, tambiÃ©n los usa la IA, cosa que me gusta.

La forma de construir es muy intuitiva y fÃ¡cil para cualquiera, la variedad de las partes y armas es buena y permite mucho juego. El mapa es amplio y la IA enemiga es habilidosa.

La secciÃ³n de construcciÃ³n tiene un aliciente, y es un test de tu nave mientras la fabricas en la que son dos IA, una con tu nave y otra con rivales de presupuesto similar luchan al mejor de 3 y asÃ­ ver donde flojea tu diseÃ±o.

Lo mejor de este juego es que tus diseÃ±os se comparten como enemigos a otra gente. Existen unos agentes (diseÃ±os compartidos por otros jugadores) que suelen ser flotas dificiles que invaden tu galaxia, una delicia.

La cantidad ingente de elementos en movimiento en pantalla sin notar bajar el rendimiento es muy buena, esta muy bien optimizado, al igual que las fisicas, en definitiva es un juego viciante muy recomendable!!

9.1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197965153857', 'num_games_owned': 829, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1425439536}
review:
A great 2D space game leveraging a simple but versatile geometric ship-building system. You and your fleet blast and farm your way across the expanses, which are densely populated with both dev and player-made hostiles. It's not multiplayer, but the opportunity to share your creations with others, and pit yourself against theirs gives great replayability.
With a bunch of playable 'races', each with their unique build palette, and a spot-on musical accompaniment, this is a game you'll enjoy sinking time into... A lot of time.[7.0]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998629627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1096, 'last_played': 1427010253}
review:
Bought the game yesterday. 18 hours later I can say I've gotten my money's worth. Reassembly is compelling and addictive as you try and work out how systems function and such. The combat feels good although sometimes I get caught on an object and destroyed for my weakness which is lame but doeasn't feel cheap. The ship editor is fantastic and works very well and mostly does what I'm trying to do. I have only encountered a couple of minor bugs so far. Overall I would recommend and heartily encourage everyone to try this game. The ship editor and AI arena are by themselves worth the $15. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198214703568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1523770472}
review:
What else should I say about this game?
Basically it's a 2D space game where you have to make money by kiling other space ships, simple huh? Not really, because you get to make your OWN spaceship using different blocks. And because you do, so do other people, and their ships shown up in your game and destroy you. Boom. Unless of course, your spaceship is good enough to make theirs go boom.

Pros

Build you own spaceship
Blocks of stuff running around, how can that not be good
Beautiful textures
Fight the ships other people build
You get to waste too much time

Cons

Nothing, ok but the dev needs to add bigger maps and multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072402725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4083, 'last_played': 1700122287}
review:
First part is only for in-depth explanation, also may contain SPOILERS:

Scroll past for basics

[spoiler]I have been playing this game a lot recently, and I love it.  I'm usually a little worried when I look at an alpha stage game because I have a few that I have bought in the past and never play, not because it was necessarily a bad game, or that the devs were bad, but because I have a very short attention span, and a lot of games.  The games that I tend to focus on are ones like reassembly, because you can take it as seriously as you want and the gameplay is ongoing, as in, you can go through wormholes and either upload the fleet you have currently in your saved ship designs chart, or you can actually 'go through' the wormhole and end up in an entirely different universe.  This is actually the part that I like most about the game, the first time I ran into a wormhole I decided to see what it did, after I went through my computer crashed and it deleted my whole save, which made me kinda sad, mainly because I thought my fleet just leaft me wouldn't come back, but ever since it has worked great.

Other than it crashing that one time, this game is spectacular, you are provided with 8 factions to play as(I think there are 8 playable one's anyway), and each faction has loads of powerful weapons and methods of defense.  The game makes it feel as though you are actually the commander of a whole race(being able to change the production of any factory weilding ship or station), and a power limit that allows you to construct massive ships bristling with weaponry.  The graphics are 2D, but that seriously doesn't matter, the visual effects are stunning, and the sound effects are also top-notch.  The ship crafting system is just like they promise, you can build anything you want, given you have ingenuity and know how shapes work.  The soundtrack is surprisingly good for galactic domination, and has a very spacy, electronicy feel.  The A.I. is pretty smart, not human smart, but it will use it's advantages against you, especially agent ships, cuz remember, they could be made by me, or you, or anybody.  With all that other stuff in mind, I have a pretty nice computer and a really old and outdated monitor, so i run most games on ultra, except crysis, or that type of stuff.  Most of the time this game runs fine, but if i have a big fleet, and im fighting a huge battle with hundreds of ships, it gets quite laggy until everything is dead.[/spoiler]

The basic facts are as follows:
Pros:
- Gameplay is fast paced and fun
- Makes you feel like the king of a space empire
- Ship-building system is perfect
- Graphics yo
- Sounds great
- [spoiler]Agents add tremendous difficulty[/spoiler]
- it's quality shit, buy it

Cons:
- Large fleet battles can cause lag
- crashes are few and far between, but excpected, cuz beta

author: {'steamid': '76561197993082660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1511289534}
review:
Really funny game, unluky there is no increase in difficulty level and no real multiplayer, so it gets a bit repetitive over time.

The concept itself is so beautiful that the game really deserves to be bought.

The only pity thing is that it is soo close to become a must, few changes, don't know if the author will implement this few changes.... then the game would be worth much more then the actual price.
Would be great to see more parts introduced to build ships, a really aggressive A.I. that actually kills your small fleet... but no... u re safe and able to explore really similar universes. Nice the idea to introduce agents (fleets from real umans A.I. controlled).

The in game musik is amazing too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059880635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 21938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5808, 'last_played': 1563325228}
review: This is the game I have been waiting for to play for years, If you enjoy open ended design this puts other games like MOO or SPORE to shame, you have true freedom to build great ships of all different shapes and sizes and then to fight them. The biggest things missing are pvp and perhaps a large strategy multi sector type of modes but as of right now in its current state the game feels very polished and will waste hundreds of my hours :) I would reccomend this game to anyone who loved playing with legos, and likes to create things then blow them up!! I would just wish for more races and some sort of pvp.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053778973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4356, 'last_played': 1602080098}
review:
Love this game, all of the people here can simply explain how great this game is but a few things I must point out just to help you:
-Don't go into the wormhole until you are powerful enough; the first world is designed to have agents (player made fleets) to be weak power levels, stronger than you from the start but still relatively weak in general. The moment you leave to the next world, you'll be fighting random power varieties of fleets so be warned
-Objectives don't need to be done right away, take your time, agents don't need to die immediately and if you lose, go somewhere else, gather and build and become stronger
-To make REALLY GOOD SHIPS requires a lot of time building, to where I spend 50% of the time building and fine tuning and 50% of the time playing. Not all good ships are required to be blocky and ugly.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997172478', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1013, 'playtime_forever': 135, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1426107641}
review:
[h1]Fly,shoot,steal[/h1]
Reassembly offers two-dimensional graphics, within which you explore a procedurally generated universe in a ship you design. All in order to create the best, most agile and powerful ship possible to fight the alien race. Over the course of the game, the ship will get bigger and bigger, but at the same time it will face more and more powerful challenges.

At some point, the player will be given the ability to create a fleet of minor ships, and later each minor ship will reach a level where it will be able to create a fleet of its own ships. All this in order to be able to fly further and further towards greater dangers.

The developers boast about the mapping of physics, particle effects and the soundtrack, for which Peter Brown is responsible.

Reassembly also offers online gameplay, where the game world is also inhabited by other players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012655578', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6243, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2577, 'last_played': 1648765324}
review: I'm changing this review to a recommend; I still feel that more explanation of how the game works would be nice beyond the bare-bones tutorial, but I feel that the other qualities of this game make it recommend worthy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060982023', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2332, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1688, 'last_played': 1588538982}
review:
Very deep, deep game. Usually takes me about 30 minutes to "figure out" a game. This one took me close to 20 hours, and I would still say I've only scratched the surface.

Only serious problem I've run into:
Incredibly frustrating manuvering in tight spaces, especially with larger ships (but this is 80% my own fault, better placed thrusters would help this dramatically).
Game crashes every few hours of gameplay, which doesn't do much but force me to start my fleet from scratch (still very annoying).
Lacking a bit of personality due to the game having no characters. More of a personal problem for myself, I suppose. Some people might enjoy this aspect.


8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198042106251', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 8164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1779, 'last_played': 1663980238}
review:
In my opinion, this is the best purchase I've made all year.

Synopsis: 

You fly ships and blow things up, exploring new sectors and conquering the universe. You collect resources.  You upgrade your blueprints and your "power level" to build bigger, better ships. 

Eventually you can build "factories" on your ships, which allow your ships to produce even more ships. These ships become part of your "fleet", allowing you to get into bigger, better fights.

Upgrades are permanent. Possibilities are almost endless.



What I love:
1) Few restrictions are imposed on designs. Making ships is a blast. Learn the shortcuts.

2) Factions and weapons vary well. Each has strengths and flaws. There is no magic bullet.

3) The learning curve to designing ships is rewarding. You will quickly discover what doesn't work.

4) Making mistakes is okay. Your flagship is basically free. You can recover from losses easily.

5) Fights are exciting, managing your fleet is addictive. This game is fun for me.

6) The objectives aren't super important. My goal is to conquer the universe.


Cons, which I hope to explain away:

1) The music became repetitive. I replaced it with my own, no big deal.

2) The building interface is tricky at first. Learn the shortcuts.

3) Controlling ships is tricky at first. Don't neglect propulsion in all directions.

4) Rarely, I will get "stuck" on things on collision. It may be a bug, but I try not to hit things.

5) [Related] an "impending collision indicator" would be awesome. Seriously.

6) I feel like dismantling ships you don't want for money/scrap should be a thing you can do.

7) I hate tutorial popups. 
Give me a help window to explain the controls in full, I'll refer to it as needed.
Don't interrupt me while I'm destroying the universe. 
This problem is a minor annoyance at the beginning of a new campaign.


I really feel like this game outshines. It is definitely worth the $15 for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074768278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1122, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 761, 'last_played': 1646980986}
review:
I stayed up until 2 AM playing Reassembly, designing ships and then testing them against the AI.

The action is fast and furious, but you can slow it down to 1/64 speed if you want, making the battles occur at a pace that makes a lava lamp seem frenetic. It's mesmerising and beautiful on a level I haven't seen since dropping acid during an ice storm. 

The whole time I kept thinking I should tab out of the game and check to see what track was playing on the radio and then remembering that this perfect music is actually the game's soundtrack.

100,000/10 would have spiritual epiphany again

author: {'steamid': '76561198129101111', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 25685, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4079, 'last_played': 1705610981}
review:
A surprisingly simple to grasp, yet complext mastery system for such a fun game.

Space combat with geometry designs, in a fun atmosphere of grinding. No real story or concept to grasp, just build, expand, explore and repeat. Surprisingly gripping for such a simple dynamic.

The system works well with just basic resources to collect by destroyed ships or slowly harvested from a strange organic plant-like space stuff, convert it to credits for the faction you play as to grind and level up to unlock new parts and materials to build and design with.

Graphically its surprisingly impressive for such simple mechanics, and I've only had a few sparce occasions of which there was too much to render at once, slowing my rig down.

All and all, a worthwhile game if you are into building and designing your own spacecraft in a simple 2D top-down shooter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023888448', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1425947616}
review:
I had some high hopes given the video, and I'm going to put more time into this, but there are games that do this better. 

It is much too hard to distinguish between allies and enemies.

There is definitely a steep learning curve, so casual gamers be warned.

I'm not going to say avoid this game, because it's clear that there's a lot of fun to be hard here by a person who has time to get over the learning curve. I would also say that the premise behind the universe is excellent too.

Gimbal is a similar game with better ship building mechanics, so I recommend that if you're looking for more casual play. It is a multiplayer game (singelplayer with bots) and the community is friendly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035689376', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 17148, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10366, 'last_played': 1579462057}
review:
Unsustainable game.

While certainly a gem above a mountain of garbage games released by the truckload, the way this game is structured is going to kill itself, due to lack of meaning and arbitrary limitations.

You will have satisfaction from the mechanics of building, flying and shooting ships, but those will be cut short by having to grind for points to actually build anything remarkable and combat will be outright impossible when your weapons deal less damage than how fast the enemy shields can regenerate, forcing you to grind before the game actually becomes viable to play. And when you do finish grinding, there is no challenge or meaning left to play.

Wasted potential, but worth a few hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022866923', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 6320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1411, 'last_played': 1589821765}
review: This game has a really nice meta singleplayer feel along with the feel of struggle that I have come to love in rpgs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067692156', 'num_games_owned': 1507, 'num_reviews': 127, 'playtime_forever': 2946, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1619, 'last_played': 1654207046}
review:
Design magnificient 2D space ships in a great and efficient editor that's better than most of vector graphic editors I've used. Your civilization is using the ships you've designed so you can see the progress throughout the galaxy as you iteratively upgrade your ships to be bigger, better, faster, stronger and annihilate all opposition in an extremely satisfying way.

Thanks to wormohles (author calls it async multiplayer), you wage war against other players' creatinos and send your warships into other people's universes to do the same! This is a [b]fantastic way[/b] to deliver user generated content directly in the game without hassle and reward you for contributing - sending your creations to wreak havoc in parallel universes. How cool is that?!

I love space games, especially 2D ones like Space Pirates And Zombies and I also love engineering games where I build vehicles myself for efficiency (Robocraft, From the Depths, Space Engineers) and this game brings so much to the table I sit here with my mind blown. 

Did I menion one of the 7 playable races is using bloody penrose tiles? What the... just wow!

I think there is space for more user content awesomeness like player designed races (from the tiles already available) that would increase the already huge replay value to unseen levels, but you could call that a greed as the game is great already as is. And imagine downloading new races (tile sets) from workshop... yeah, greed... hmm...

This is a very special game and I deeply thank the dev for creating this masterpiece!

Few highlights:
 * ships are damaged piece by piece
 * ships [b]reassemble[/b] themselves piece by piece
 * ships with factories can spawn other ships (with factories...)
 * maneuverability is decided by the placement of engines ([b]finally[/b])
 * 7 playable races are unique and many strategies and designs are available
 * you can test your ships against other ships and even against each other across save files
 * galaxy feels alive, almost like Spore
 * user generated content integrated into game with 0 effort to both consume and create (just fly through wormhole and even get reward, yay)

I bought this at full price and I regret nothing. I can't say that about many Steam purchases I did :-p

author: {'steamid': '76561197972335748', 'num_games_owned': 536, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 9793, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3651, 'last_played': 1542280820}
review: Build a ships and pit them against the AI. Simple game that twill eat time like crazy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198112703748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 8307, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4703, 'last_played': 1704616273}
review: A must try. My newest favorite, just can't stop.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975412350', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1461, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 373, 'last_played': 1494642837}
review: A couple of things that have influenced my life reappear when I play this game. Stratosphere for the PC, Legos and the joys  of a summer backyard.  In this game you design a ship to participate in a large open world ship combat ecosystem.  You'll find joy at upgrading your ship and will look back on early designs and laugh at your lack of ambition.  It's satisfying to create a ship that fits a certain combat style.  Ship designing utilizes a clean workspace that is powerful. Amazing, coloful visuals and an epic electronic/ambient soundtrack also make this a great experience.  Pick up your destroyed pieces and get back into the war. 10/10. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026037706', 'num_games_owned': 266, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 3645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 734, 'last_played': 1660351403}
review:
Thought about it a bit more, the game is all there. It's really intresting at first but loses some of it later, once you know how to make ships and how the factions work, everything loses alittle bit of speciality. 

It's very pretty, has alot of content, and has some neat features im not going to type out

recommend/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197966671379', 'num_games_owned': 1018, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 203, 'last_played': 1561261792}
review:
Very excellent top down shooter. Attractive graphic style, atmospheric music, interesting color schemes. Everything in the game, from the sound effects to the ship blocks, reflect a minimalist style that is really appropriate and builds a very well rounded experience. In Reassembly the basic mechanics are: gather resources, turn them in for credits, use those credits to buy upgraded blocks for your ship, and use your more awesome ship to expand your territory. 

Modifying your ship is a pleasure, the editor is clean and inuitive, and the block point snapping is extremely helpful. I find myself spending about 50% of my time in the ship editor just because I enjoy it so much. A really cool feature of Reassembly is it's test mode, where the AI takes over your creation in a "Best of 3" battle vs. other similar cost ships of varying styles. It really helps you see how your changes affect your matchup against different style ships before taking it out into your world. 

The only downside is that since this game is all about making really awesome ships, you are left wanting a ton more blocks to expand your options. I feel that there is a good amount of variation, but after a few hours of diligent resource collection you seem to have them all. However, there may be more blocks further down the chain that I cannot see yet, will have to update when I get deeper in the game. 

Overall, I am having a ton of fun in this game and its extremely simple and yet satisfying mechanics. I would recommend this very highly.

review: Interesting game. Very fun to play and progress in. I do think the wormholes are a bit stupid tho, because they just start you over pretty much. You lose all footing in the previous world. Whats the point?

author: {'steamid': '76561198112482554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1147, 'last_played': 1483292051}
review: Simple and addictive! Love it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198125312365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1176, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 825, 'last_played': 1680139613}
review: Reassembly is a brilliant game. You can either play it in long marathons or short periods to get enjoyment out of it. Just when you think you're done, there is another faction, wormhole, or achievement to explore. I would like to see some kind of multiplayer (coop or vs) implemented, but it is still amazing in its current version.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990689230', 'num_games_owned': 85, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1815, 'last_played': 1519550480}
review: Incredible game! Unique and very polished.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976760047', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 15661, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13365, 'last_played': 1621187955}
review:
It's a good game that has a classic styly of gameplay. It has the added bonus of allowing you to build your own ships and perfect them.

 The worlds you play in are procedurally created, but I wish there were more of a  variaty of obstacles and hazards in the game.

I like the various factions you can fight and play, but I long for more varied ship designs.

No story mode, but it really doesn't need one.

No multipleyer, but the single player game work just fine.

The keyboard layout ssems a bit spread out, but I use and older Nostromo N52 speed pad and it makes this game play nearly perfect.

The AI for both your own faction and the enemy factions could use improvements.

There are mods that fix things, and sometime ruin them.

In conclusion:  The game is not perfect, but it's still a fun time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198104799517', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 5119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3122, 'last_played': 1662923554}
review:
BUY THIS NOW!

I jumped in to this game blind and was so pleasantly suprised.  This game will suck your time away. 

 I bought it when it popped up on th epopular new releases. I happened to have two days off... i put in 32 hours with no regret.  Its not a new idea but it is perfectly executed.  The atmosphere is amazing! Gameplay is rewarding and the soundtrack is spot on! Tons of replayability, multiple factions to create with and take over the galaxy in so many ways!.  

11/10 Tell your friends!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992223231', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 8950, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2882, 'last_played': 1450579288}
review:
This game totally sucked me in.  The last 5 hours are a blur.

I would like to see more depth in the upgrades, but maybe I just haven't played enough to get that far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051152038', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 6323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2026, 'last_played': 1569394958}
review: This game is incredible... You can easily lose yourself in the gameplay; Modifying, upgrading, multiplying, and conquering, you can grow your modest little crafy into a deadly battleship bristling with lasers, missiles, drone launchers, and cannons, and go on a crusade to destroy all those who stand in your way (Especially the plants). This game is well worth the price, if you like building armies from scratch to obliterate your enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079433900', 'num_games_owned': 233, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 247875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 180002, 'last_played': 1711245904}
review: it's ok

author: {'steamid': '76561198035450493', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 6768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2493, 'last_played': 1454625255}
review:
There are fun games, than there are absolutely mind blowingly super intelligent games, and there are games that are simple on the surface. This is fun, intelligent, simple, and as complex as you want it to be. 

Its a masterpiece. Anyone who likes arcade games or grew up playing asteroid but wanted the grown up version of it here you go. I probably put in 20 hours already and I could play it for 1,000's because of the reconfigurability, stability and just calm joy it gives you when you play. Its also good for your brain, I swear sometimes games like this are like puzzles that clean your brain and help you focus on real world tasks. The only thing that is lame is the name Reassembly, its just not sexy enough for a title this good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983571471', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 8333, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1, 'playtime_at_review': 1155, 'last_played': 1711825948}
review:
This game is good for the money, No gimmicks, No skilltree grinding, All the progression feels genuine and intriguing, Atmosphere is living and with a great soundtrack to boot. Great visuals and particle effects.

Overall, Amongst the crap-fest of recent games being shoved out, This one is a gem that feels, looks, and really sounds overall polished and smooth.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966610978', 'num_games_owned': 1163, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1968, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1143, 'last_played': 1477846786}
review:
Awsome Game!
I like building stuff and i like optimizing.
With this game i can have both.

Game has some minor issues.. but as long as there will be patches .. it will keep improving.

Totally worth its money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198042725855', 'num_games_owned': 650, 'num_reviews': 121, 'playtime_forever': 1640, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1325, 'last_played': 1458876007}
review: A big old box of toys to play with in a huge, endless sandbox. A hell of a lot of game here if you like building and blowing spaceships up. Looks simple on the outside, but there's plenty of experimentation and customization at your fingertips. Exceptional title, I bought it on a whim and have been hooked since. The 'agent' system just adds to the fun, as players can upload their ships to spawn in other players' games, and it's these agent fleets that will give you the most trouble, and possibly the most inspiration in designing your fleet, which you will undoubtedly send into a wormhole to bring hot death to others. Fun stuff.

review:
a fantastic sandbox space rpg anyone who likes minimalistic artstyle a great chiptune/dark techno soundtrack and fantastic sound design would love this 
the multiple factions wich play in compleately different ways to eachother bring already enough variatio to the game and the fact that other than creating your ship you can make a lot more to make your fleet rule the galaxy adds great deph 

the only problem is that there is some grinding involved to reach the apex of your abilityes in game but fortunately this grinding is not repetitive.

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198030976461', 'num_games_owned': 103, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2744, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 806, 'last_played': 1679207007}
review:
In Reassembly, you start out as a little ship which is just a minion of the station or carrier which spawned you. you collect resources and bring them back to the station in order for the station to make more allies to fight with you. each time you do this, you get credits which you can use to upgrade your ship and buy new part. Once you get big enough, the roles switch. You get to a point where you get a part which lets you spawn ships. your resources now go to making your own fleet which follows you and fights for you. Those ships will also bring you the resources they collect, allowing you to make more. If you put enough storage on your ship, you can even spawn the massive stations which intially spawned you in the begining.

I love the game and it never gets old. There is always a new ship or even fleet to fight. Just as you think you have built the most powerful ship, an agent comes in and kills you and your fleet in seconds. This makes it so that you have to tweek your own design in order to compete with the new foe.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970818678', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 3285, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2974, 'last_played': 1555833347}
review:
This is a surprisingly addictive game.

Pros:
- Cutting enemy ships CLEAN IN HALF piece-by-piece with my massive laser array and watching the remaining pieces tumble through space gives me a warm fuzzy feeling.
- The ship designer is probably the best one I've seen in any game that lets you construct vehicles.
- There are several unlockable factions which have completely different ship components for lots of replayability.
- There are occasional bugs, but so far they're minor and don't detract from the fun.

Cons:
- The friendly AI ships currently don't do a very good job at following you or fighting.
- Some obscure parts of the interface aren't very well explained or are kind of 'hidden' (but aren't hard to figure out once you find them).
- Factions don't have names (just numbers - which are easy to mix up), which makes them cumbersome to discuss with other players.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012403435', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 3618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3021, 'last_played': 1446490895}
review:
This game was a weird experience. It looks like a RTS, but plays like a 2D action game. It gives you the feeling of an ant in an anthill, fighting against the minions of other swarms. But also you grow and evolve and start to get your own swarm, that follows you.
All in all, beside being a space shooter, it really has some organic feeling. It also could be on the bottom of the ocean. Or maybe small microorganisms.

Your ship is made of different shaped geometric objects. Hull parts, interior and weapons. Zoomed out, they give surprisingly good looking shapes. After you design your first ship, you are thrown in a crazy living 2D world, where everything tries to kill you, that has a different color than you. This isnt always user friendly. Flying too early too far out of your territory you face enemys, that are 10 times the size of you. While you explore, you unlock commando points, that give you new weapons or upgrading your ship to be able to use more parts to be bigger. Also your surroundings generate ressources. Everyone is gathering them. If you kill an enemy, he will drop his ressources, if you die, they will also loot you. You can turn in those ressources on allied bases to get more commando points, also that station will generate new allied ships. That way, every faction on the map is constantly growing at attacking the borders of the other faction.
As the game continues, you will find more and more ressources, unlock new weapons, until you are that big, that you stop selling your ressources but generating your own minions, that follow you. If they are big enough and have a factory, they also will be able to gather ressources and build ships. 
If you are bored with your universe, you take your fleet and go to a new one (reset the game, like a new game+).

Every enemy faction has unique weapons, buildings, ships and tactics. Some of them can be really annoying, most of them are playable, after you once defeated them.

While working perfectly (I only had one massive crash), the game has a lot of flaws that bug me:
- there is no real war: The world only moves around you. If you arent present, the areas arent loaded. That way, you only have the illusion of a living world, but the only acting thing is you.
- enemy AI is korean like, allied AI is on drugs: Having some maxed out follower ships, then seeing them flying into an enemy fleet like idiots and dying like idiots makes you question the game. Seeing the enemy flying player designed ships better than the player is capable of, makes you rage a lot. It is no fun fighting the AI. They will dash forward, attack you and retreat like cowards, when you fire back. That way, a lot of small ships are capable of slowly poking you to death. If you manage to hit them, they will run away, like on crack, never giving you the chance of actually destroy and loot them. Some ships, even split in half and totally destroyed managed to escape me with 1 or 2 remaining thrusters and the commando bridge. A strong AI is cool and challenging. A perfect AI, that plays safe and never do mistakes is frustrating. A lot! Its not about them being OP, its about them always fleeing a fight.
- Charging my lazerz: directed beam weapons > everything. You can defeat 90% of the map by using massive amounts of the charge beam laser. Then put it on point defence. Then laugh like an idiot watching those skirmishing ships flying towards you to do their stupid hit and run, seeing them exploding because your point defence automatically targets and destroy them. Your other weapons will be massive amounts of plasma cannon to melt down everything that cant move away, or, if you like it with more precision, gaus rifles to shoot those poor bastards without them even knowing from where you hit them.
- After reaching max size, the game is over. There is nothing to do. Even the big ships, that chased you in the beginning, are small fishes now. I even managed to cut one of them in half with a single salve of gaus shots. Since you have the lasers, you dont have to care about the small ones ether. Simply ignore them. They will come in weapon range, then explode.
- If you are bad at designing and crafting games, just dont.

Reassembly is not a decent game, it is an awesome game! But has major problems with balancing, AI, mapping and simply has no endgame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043883644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2268, 'last_played': 1580672193}
review:
I haven't picked up a game and actually played that game in probably over a year. This game has got me hooked. There are enough RTS elements (but it's not a traditional RTS), and customization features in this game to last awhile.

While not there yet, there are potential entertainment issues once I get to a point where every ship part is unlocked. This game is kind of both relaxed and intense, and depending on your play style you could play it either way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976366991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 204, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 204, 'last_played': 1425139269}
review: Fun for the ship building, exploration, and further customization. Not so much for the controls, which feel extremely wonky unless your ship is super nimble, and time you'll spend 'farming' to actually put your fleet together so it's not 1v10, where any one of them can melt you very quickly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003518140', 'num_games_owned': 2824, 'num_reviews': 361, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1425606979}
review:
Very interesting game. I picked it up on the recommendation of a Steam friend of mine who has similar taste in games.   I wasn't sure what to expect but I can say the game is addicting.  I started it up with the intention of playing for 5-10 minutes just to see what it was like and the next thing I know it was three hours later.

Graphically the game has style, though it is somewhat hard to tell from the screenshots that I have seen.  I personally like the vector graphic look and reminds me of Asteroids which I played the heck out of in my younger years.  The game is a bit hard to get into and I am sure I am going to have to watch a number of vidoes to understand all the concepts but it is easy enough to play with and pick up enough to enjoy.

This is one of those games that you just have to play for ourself to see how addictive it is.  

10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198005216657', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 10764, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 799, 'last_played': 1666072411}
review:
Truely a fun game, and great for those who like to construct your own spaceships and watch how they perform.  Go back and tweak, or start all over again!  Go against many different factions, as well as other player's fleets.  Easily a time sink, making you itch for that "one more tweak" to your ship to see how it will fare. I'm so happy to see an Indie studio produce a game of this calabur.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Indie Game Studio
[*] Compatable with all three platforms (Windows, MacOS, Linux)
[*] Three control types: Keyboard Only, Mouse and Keyboard, Gamepad
[*] Vector Graphics!  Pretty beams and explosions!
[*] Completely user configurable, from colors to buttons, keys, even control schemes.
[*] Spaceships, Spaceships, SPACESHIPS!  Tons to fight, and design your own!
[*] Control fleets of ships!
[*] A-Sync Multiplayer... kinda (The AI takes over other people's ship designs and places them in your worlds)
[*] Consistant world, which keeps changing due to different factions warring with each other
[*] Unlockable factions with their own tech and designs.
[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*] Not all factions are playable
[*] No true multiplayer (can't fight other players in real-time)
[*] Slow on older / minimal hardware, especially with many ships on the screen
[*] No touch controls for tablets
[*] Fleet commands are basic, only one target at a time
[*] Linux install maybe a little difficult for those who don't know command line
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561197974781318', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 8728, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 800, 'playtime_at_review': 3100, 'last_played': 1711445616}
review:
This game is simply phenominal.  It's so good and unique, it's kind of hard to wright a review.  The shipbuilding options are phenominal and limitless. The controls and control mapping are fantastic, though it might not seem like it if you build a wacky ship. The environment is pleasent and very diverse. Performance is solid. All the factions have some very unique abilities. The music is nice, though could use a bit more diversity. 

The only negative might be is that it is a bit confusing at first. Though honestly, figuring it out is even pretty fun. Probably the best $15 you could spend, on anything....

author: {'steamid': '76561197994007173', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 14422, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3381, 'last_played': 1568072350}
review:
Additctive fun, but don't forget to set your alarms since you'll lose track of time!

With a screen full of particle effects the game runs smoothly.

You can design any 2D shape you can think of given the limitation of the pieces per faction. Practically any design is possible with enough pieces.

Ship design is done by you.  You shape it's toughness, layout, engine placement, maneuverability, weaponry, and other things related to each faction.

There isn't much direction, but the game is simple, shoot everyone else.  There is a simple tutorial to get you to realize some things that might not be apparent.

Some achievements are weak, but others actually take time and effort.

Other player's ships show up in your universe to battle against.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971568340', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 1054, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1006, 'last_played': 1482264964}
review:
I cannot BELIEVE how addicting this game is. It's so simplistic yet complicated enough not to ever get boring. Last time I was anywhere near close to the addiction level of this game, was when Terraria was released (Though I have to admid Starbound has been a blast also). This game's store page simply does no justice to this game. I higly recommend you at least watch some Let's Plays about this game. You'll get some idea why you just keep telling yourself "just a little while longer".

This is some Indie gold right here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028502430', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 4134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1087, 'last_played': 1651940649}
