author: {'steamid': '76561198038034232', 'num_games_owned': 151, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2146, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1593801040}
review:
Let be break this down into a few categories. Graphics, Sound, Story, Controls, Gameplay. I will end this review with my honest opinion after just about 30 hours in game.


Graphics:

The Graphics for this game are simple. And that is what this game's charm is riding on. 2D. It is simple, but because of this, this game has a very good feel to it. Like games of yesteryear. The game, with it's simple graphics. also has much diversity in the way it presents said graphics. From lightly colored tints, to bright shades. With the geometric shapes, the games has as much variety as you give it. And if you allow yourself to become immersed, the game will provide the rest.

Sound: 

The sound in this game was surprisingly not what I was expecting. I was expecting simple, "Pyew Pyew ZZST" sounds for the weapons, and the classic "Rocket Burn" sound for the engines. No, Certain weapons all have a different sound. And the further you are from the source of the sound, the softer the sound will be. Zoom out fully, and the sound is just a whisper. Zoom in fully and you get the full range of sound. Do not expect huge Orchestral themes with this game. It keeps it simple, and does a great job at it. 

Story:

Story? Simple. You own part of a Galaxy, and you conquer other sections. How, and when you do this. That is for you to decide. Not much else to it. Simply put. Your story is your ship. It is what you make it to be.

Controls:

Control are simple. Mouse cursor to aim. Or, if you like, Hit the "R" button to change controls. Personally, I go for the Mouse to aim, and W, S forward and back, A and D to turn. Gives it a more of an old school vibe to it. Makes the game feel more fluid on my end. 

Gameplay:

Gameplay. Oh so simple. Anything shoots you, shoot back. You died? Well then. Try out a new build. In my honest experience, going for pure SP from the very start, helps. Once you reach Max (8000) then you can have some fun. I went for a build similar to current day Naval ships. And let me tell you. If you build to win, using your own creative imagination. You will have some deadly ships. And When you get to build huge huge ships, you become a force even to  other players ships. And, like many others have said, there is no multiplayer in this game. Instead, you get to have other players ships, ported to your game. And, depending on how good they are. You get to feel their wrath. 

Now, for my Impression of this game. I have to put it in a few simple words. A breathe of fresh air. Why? I encourage you to see how many good, space sandbox games are out there, that have a flow to it. Yet do not take endless hours to fully experience what this game has to offer. Yet the deeper you dive into this game, the more layers of strategy it takes to overcome. Though that is not to say the game will endlessly become more challenging. It is, as I have said, as you imagine it to be. And that, folks, is where this game has it's core. Some, like me, will find this game charming. And others, will of course, be left feeling a bit empty inside. That is entirely okay. So in the end, You can give this a try, and find out for yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052333663', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 97, 'playtime_forever': 384, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 384, 'last_played': 1424987193}
review:
I enjoyed this game. It has it's limits, but is definitely fun.

Video review:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5dDObkYTzJE&list=UURPe3hzgc7y8NTczf8AffDg

What is it?

Reassembly is a ship building game. Your goal is to design the most effective warship and conquer the sector. Of course, you're not alone here. There are factions that control territory in the sector. You belong to one faction and most others are hostile, although there are a couple neutral factions.

Gamplay consists of designing your vessel using preset parts. In the beginning of the game, you'll most likely spend your time gathering rescources that are generated by the local fauna and bringing it back to your factions stations. You will exchange the rescources for credits that allow you to purchase new ship parts and also alow you to build a bigger ship. Later, you'll likely build a warship capable of using the resources you collect to build your own fleet and wreak havoc on the opposing factions.

Your faction will grow and expand out into the sector and become stronger and you design ships to be put into your fleet. Once your done with one sector, you can enter a wormhole and enter a whole new sector.

Pros:

-The ship building system is simple and easy to use. Putting together a ship is as simple as a drag and drop experience. 

-The graphics look amazing. Despite being simple polygon graphics, they really are captivating. The light show that a large battle creates is quite a sight to see.

-You have choice about what you will do. You can choose to be anything form a simple harvester to a fearsome dreadnaught.

-Competition within your own faction. As you bring back rescources, your station builds ships. These ships then go out in search of rescources. This will force you farther and farther from the safety of your station. I find that interesting.

Cons:

-Despite what the devs may say, there kind of is one way to build a good ship. The armor plating pieces do not count towards the size of your ship. The best way to build a good battleship is to slap on as much armor as you can.

-There is no interaction with the factions. There are no quests, no diplomacy, and no alliances. The only path to victory is conquest.

-Grinding. In order to build a large ship, you will have to harvest a lot of rescources. If you don't build a big ship, you will always dies. Put two and two together.

Really, this game boils down to trying to build the most powerful ship. That's enjoyable, and the exploration (at least before you've seen everything there is to see) can  be quite interesting. I doubt that I'll play this game far into the future, or that (in this current state) it will remain a big thing for long. However, it is still a good game and I've definitely enjoyed playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978534278', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 5996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4116, 'last_played': 1503675621}
review:
I have loved this game since I got it.

The game is a simple and fun top-down space shooter with the ability to design and fly your own space ships, and even design an entire fleet with ships ranging from small shuttles and fighters to large destroyers and frigates.

There are several different races (some of which you can't play) that unlock while playing (and destroying stations from a race you haven't unlocked before), each with their own technological pro's and con's, but they are all (reasonably) evenly matched, and where one race falls short in say shield technology, it makes up for armor or speed.

The universe is generated in sectors each controlled by the majority of whatever ships are in that sector, so it can at times be hard to claim a sector completely when there is just 1 little core still floating about. The universe is limited in size, but thats alright since flying over one edge of the map puts you at the opposite side without a teleport or cheap backend trick. Watch out for pirate fleets though; These are, from what I gather, uploaded by other players and are randomly selected, which means that in one universe you may find ships you won't encounter in the next. This uploading is done through anomalies called wormholes that allow you to upload your fleet (designs) or fly to another universe. The latter will generate a new universe for you while you keep your resources, credits and ships.

The only downside I experienced so far is not being able to destroy core blocks from certain stations. Usually this happens after a few hours of playing and may be memory related, but other than that it plays like a dream. The thing about player created content worries me a bit though, but we'll see how well balanced the game is over time.

A definate recommendation and big thumbs up for this gem.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095232981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3672, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1296, 'last_played': 1617828011}
review:
This is a simple game.
That is not to put it down, out of a lot of games this is by far one of my favourites, some of the factions are a bit limited, However that does not take away from the unique experience that this game offers.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016548618', 'num_games_owned': 198, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 2217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1317, 'last_played': 1595404246}
review:
This game exceeded my expectations by far.
The way it does ship creation makes it similar to StarDrive, except way better, in everything from the possibilities to the quality of the editor.

The camera pans with a weird delay, sometimes your ship wont be anywhere near the center of the screen.
Friendly AI really likes to ram you head on, sometimes they dont even attempt to avoid.
Asteroid fields are too dense.
The game generally gets bad due to crowding when theres too many ships, although the efficiency of the engine is very impressive and it takes a lot to make it lag.

But despite those things, if it gets an FTL mechanic and multiplayer then I'd give it a 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002502979', 'num_games_owned': 179, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 1645, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 790, 'last_played': 1676140105}
review:
[h1]Reassembly is an extremely fun, addictive game.[/h1]
 It has a pretty unique concept that was executed really well.
If you like spaceships, expansion, customization, dogfights, big ass (faction) battles, factions, or just nice things in general, you should get this game.

[u]Pro's[/u]
+ Addictive
+ Infinite customization
+ Expanding is fun
+ Massive battles
+ Several unlockable factions
+ Asynchrous multiplayer 
+ Has more depth than you think
+ You can make your faction exactly how you want it to be


[u]Cons[/u]
- Once your faction is unstoppable, there's pretty much nothing left to do
- Other players sometime make huge spamming death machine ships which they then release into the wild, meaning they can pop up in your galaxy too. Might take over your galaxy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198015043797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 3164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1860, 'last_played': 1526190359}
review:
In theory the game is about 2D space battles.

However I spend most of my time designing and building my ships - and that involves a great mix of planning, experimentation and working with the different fleets strenghts/weaknesses & shapes.  That part of the game feels a lot like the board game galaxy truckers to me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013835180', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1630740279}
review: Awesome game and suprisingly tight soundtrack

author: {'steamid': '76561197990130383', 'num_games_owned': 352, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3966, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1565803951}
review:
Beautiful and deep.

The designer did a good job making the exact configuration of your ship very mechanically relevant.  You can spend hours thinking about where to place your thrusters, armor, turrets, ect.

The progression isnt bad either- there are 12 factions, each with many parts to unlock.  Its hard to describe how different it feels going from a faction that lets you make things out of squares to a faction that forces you to use rhombuses instead.

Fighting player made fleets is also pretty awesome.

The minigame of "Can you make a ship for X points that beast everyone elses ship that they spent X points on" is actually really interesting and deep as well.  Watching the AI pilot your ships is quite interesting (though its a shame there isnt a more formalized way of pitting your designs against specific friends' ships).

This game is basically a better, more fleshed out version of the spore cell stage.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072595407', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3493, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 934, 'last_played': 1651658246}
review: I bought this game a couple days ago, and am having a lot of fun with it. I especially like the idea of being able to send my fleet into another persons game (of course you have no actual control over them while they are in there) I find that interesting, seeing another person's set of ships while exploring. That's just the one thing though, the gameplay if extremely fun, and despite me dying over and over (hey i'm not that good okay?) it is just so entertaining. I would definitely reccomend this to anyone who enjoys something that's sandbox/arcade.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966224667', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2884, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1948, 'last_played': 1425519205}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993321894', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2275, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 853, 'last_played': 1442526626}
review:
I think I actually really get into one out of 5 or 6 games that I buy so I am pretty picky.  This game is my new addiction for sure.
1)  The ship building experience is easy.  Think Visio, only you get to go out and blow stuff up with what you draw instead of present to boring people with it.  It is such an intuitive experience building your ship.  I spent an hour or two builing before blowing stuff up.  And the detail in how you have to think of your ship is great to, you have to place your thrusters to ensure you can turn well... totally fun.
2) blowing stuff up is great.  The game plays well and you can start playing but you keep getting better. 

The game that really keep you into them are the ones that are fun right away but have the depth to keep you coming back to learn more, this game has it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990920529', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 709, 'last_played': 1440012821}
review:
Auch wenn ich sonst eher kein Freund von 2D/ Side-Scrollern bin, so hat mich Reassembly schon im "Early Access" Ã¼berzeugt dass es auch SpaÃŸ machen kann in einem 2-Dimensionalen Universum auf Entdeckungsreise zu gehen.

Besonders wer als Kind gerne mit Lego Raumschiffe gebastelt hat, der wird hierbei schon leicht in Nostalgie schwelgen, denn genau so fÃ¼hlt sich der Raumschiffbau hier an: alle Teile haben bestimmte Verbindungspunkte und nur an diesen lassen sich andere Teile anstecken.

Die Teile-Vielfalt ist ganz ok, nicht Ã¼berragend aber auch nicht zu klein, aber da es noch "Early Access" ist wird sich da sicher noch was tun.
Aber: fast alle Waffen spielen sich auch unterschiedlich: Railgun, Plasma-Kanone, Raketn, Minen oder Torpedos, alles ist dabei und alles hat seine Daseinsberechtigung.

Raumschiff-Teile lassen sich hierbei grob in 4 Kategorien teilen: HÃ¼lle (quasi die Panzerung des Raumschiffes), Waffen, Antrieb und Gagets(z.B. Schilde, Generatoren...) aus denen mann dann nach belieben eigene Raumschiffe bauen kann.

Alle Teile (auÃŸer HÃ¼lle) haben eine gewissen Wert an "P", quasi das maximal Level dass das Schiff erreichen kann.
Dann beginnt auch schon die Sandbox und man versucht neue Teile freizuschalten und den "P-Wert" zu Upgraden so das man dann zum Schluss auf den maximal-Wert von 8000p kommt.
Hinzu kommt dass alle Teile eine gewisse Masse haben, die dann den Schwerpunkt des Schiffes bestimmt.

Die Steuerung ist je nach Schwerpunkt und gesamt-Gewicht von sehr schnell bis ultra trÃ¤ge, sehr unterschiedlich aber wenn man sich erst mal an das akutelle Schiff gewÃ¶hnt hat macht es extrem viel SpaÃŸ gegen immer grÃ¶ÃŸere und immer mehr Gegner anzutreten und sein Schiff immer weiter zu verbessern.

Ein weiterer Aspekt sind die "WormlÃ¶cher" die ich auch nach ca.10h Spielzeit noch nicht so ganz verstanden habe: es gibt dort nÃ¤mlich 2 MÃ¶glichkeiten: 1. man fligt durch das Wormloch und gelangt in ein neues Universum oder 2. man schickt quais einen KI-Klon seiner Flotte hindurch, der dann in einem Universum eines anderen Spielers als Feind auftaucht, zumindest sollte es so sein.
Diese Mechanik wirkt etwas Dark Souls inspiriert ist aber immer noch eine gute Idee, schade nur dass man nicht selbst/ aktiv ein Universum eines Anderen attakieren kann...


Alles in allem lohnt der Kauf von Reassembly sich schon, aber fÃ¼r Leute die eine ultra komplexe 2-D Raumsimulatione mit Schiffsbau haben wollen, ist es doch eher ungeeignet ;)


Zum Schluss noch:
Was ich mir noch als Verbesserungen wÃ¼nschen wÃ¼rde?
1. Coop und PVP
2. mehr Teile
3. hÃ¶heres P-Limit

author: {'steamid': '76561198013536111', 'num_games_owned': 502, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 7399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2112, 'last_played': 1666582514}
review:
I don't write many reviews, but when I do I like to write them for games I like. This is one of those special games that I will take the time out of my day to write a few words about.

First: off I love how there are three different control schemes for the game, you don't realize how important this is untill you try all three. It is exceedingly useful because not all ships will work with one control set up. 

Second: it's an interesting idea to have the universe populated with other players ships. It makes the game fresh. There are some problems with this system, for instance if you make a really weak ship and it is put into someone else's game it's pointless, but for the most part it's good. 

Third: the building system, now this system has some major problems, mainly because I have not used it enough to completely understand the logic behind it. I will try to explain the good things it does and the problems it has. It functions like the builder in banjo and kazooie nuts and bolts the difference is it's two dimensional and you have a keyboard and mouse so it isn't frustrating to manipulate It for the most part its balanced, I think it would help if the basic blocks had a cost, for instance I made a cube with the faction you start with and though it's slow it is almost unbeatable because it has so much armor. This could be fixed if the basic parts had a low cost, maybe raise the cap to 10k and make the prices on the other parts higher so it evens out. The biggest problem with the building system is the blocks have to be exactly aligned for them to snap together, basically imagine legos but the pegs are the sizes of needles and you are making giant ships. This ends up with blocks that are a few pixels off of being perfect, this bugs me to death, it's probably the biggest problem with this game. 

Fourth: The plant faction is too op, it is too easy to make a swarm of ships and to overrun any opponent you may have. 

Fifth: Another amazing thing this game does well is the different factions have different base blocks, for instance there is a faction that is focused on triangles, this forces you to build intelligently.

There are many more things in this game that are worth a mention but if you made it to this point I will sum up my opinion on this game with, a resounding recommendation. All though it has it's problems the game as a whole is fun and for 15$ there is almost no reason not to buy it, I have played almost thirty hours of it at the point of writing this reviews, thats fifty cents and hour I have bought triple a games that are less enjoyable than this( looking at you tomb raider, Shadow of mordor, farcry 4, and many others).

author: {'steamid': '76561197980174344', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 17260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1696346468}
review: Reassembly and Gimbal are my two favorite 2D arcade shooters where one can design their own ships.  The moment I saw this game I thought of Gimbal and knew I had to have it.  Graphics-wise Reassembly is not quite as detailed, but the particle physics are beautiful!  Reassembly makes is very easy to design one's own ships on the fly, and offers procedural content that keeps things fresh.  This game is certainly worth the price and I highly recommend it to any gamer that enjoys a 2D space shooter with almost endless customization!

author: {'steamid': '76561197996235457', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 6917, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3313, 'last_played': 1656339699}
review:
Built a spaceship that has two giant dragon heads with flames coming out and lasers for eyes.

11/10 would shoot lasers out of my dragon eyes again.

Silliness aside, I play a lot of computer games and love this one.  I rarely write reviews, that's how much I enjoy this game.  So let me help you decide since you're still reading because you're too lazy to watch a video clip of it on youtube (j/k, i read reviews of games before I buy too).  Do you like:
- sci fi games?  (Starcraft, EVE Online, Alpha Centauri)
- building characters in RPGs, building empires in 4X games, or creating custom units?  (think Armored Core, Alpha Centauri's unit editor, etc.)
- 2D arcade shooters, or people who like shooting things in general?

This game has elements of all of those.  Has a fun difficulty to it too, learning the mechanics, and being caught offguard by something new because you fight other people's spaceships in space sometimes, lol.  Testing your shapceships in automated AI duels against other player's spaceships is entertaining too, like watching a tournament in eSports.  Very entertaining game, excellent graphics, awesome soundtrack.  Music is the kind of rare video game music that you can listen to for hours and still enjoy.  The music reminds me of the PC game "Shatter" soundtrack - a game which I've never played before but love the music of (look up Shatter OST on youtube).  Highly recommend Reassembly.  So wow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021179677', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1718, 'last_played': 1707414274}
review:
This game is great and all, unless you either
A. Hate uneven ships (You know what im talking about *cough cough the damned triangles cough cough*
B. Have OCD, or just like to keep things even.
C. Have no creative ability (The game is still fun, you just have terrible ships.)

Other than that, from a person with no creative ability who also hates uneven ships, I love this game, until i used the triangle blocks, damn you!

But all jokes aside, this game is one of the only games I can truly spend hours on without knowing, I get so engrossed with the ship building and testing that hours go by... And the combat is even worse, I could probably spend a few years just fighting if someone didn't snap me out of the game...

author: {'steamid': '76561197972469536', 'num_games_owned': 500, 'num_reviews': 92, 'playtime_forever': 1031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1031, 'last_played': 1425086857}
review: very fun game.  Lots of creativity and ships that you can make.  I love that the ships you make are used on other people's maps and that other people's ships are seen in my maps.  Some of them are awefully hard to face against. It's a whole lot of fun designing and flying ships that you have made.  Buy it, you won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020427560', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4983, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1684, 'last_played': 1667904264}
review:
A game that has been stealing my sleep hours as of late.

The good:
Excellent game mechanics, stylish and has a distinct feel to it. Watching your newest design come to life on the screen and actually make a difference in efficiency is something that not too many games can boast with.

The bad:
Not really much bad there, but even with all the opened playable factions, I still wouldn't mind more content. Also the differences between factions could be made even more distinct with some effort in balancing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005510709', 'num_games_owned': 1100, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 2596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1315, 'last_played': 1611346546}
review:
Reassembly is a fantastic game. In practice its very much a twin-stick-shooter, though it retains a surprising amount of depth for a game which is so simple at its heart.

There are many things that make this game great, but to simplify things for this small review, and to add information to anyone on the fence on weather to buy it or not, i will put these points into separate short sections.

1) Ship Building.

The core mechanic of the game, building your ship is both rewarding and a time sink. When building the largest ship in my fleet, i spent 40min before i was satisfied with the end result. But when i was satisfied, i was very satisfied. I glowed with pride as i flew my behemoth through space.
The fun doesn't stop there. The ship is made up of lots of different parts, as you can see from the imagery. At first you would be forgiven for assuming that this is simply a method of allowing design flexibility. While this holds true, it opens up an interesting mechanic. You see, every part of the ship is a separate entity. A finished ship is less a single unit, and more a collection of blocks stuck together. In practice this means that slapping hull plating to your ship doesn't simply increase health, but creates an armored point wherever you placed it. Weapons have less health, so placing them in your ship created areas of vulnerability. If you gun is destroyed, you cant fire. If your jets are destroyed you cant move. This means that the layout of your ship is as important as what you put in.
Equally, your jet engines work as individual units, rather than just giving your ship '+movement speed'. So, if you don't have any jets placed at an angle, you cant turn. If you have no jets on your sides, you cant strafe. No jets facing forwards means you cant reverse. In this same vein, the more boosters you have, the faster you move.
All these points turn ship building into a sort of puzzle game. Though one in which the answer is what your preferred gameplay style is.

2) Combat.

While general space exploration is a big part of the game, combat is the fly in the soup of game mechanics here. (Not in a bad way, as everyone will want one). Combat is simple as it is deep. At its heart, you pick your target, align guns, and fire till dead. But on a deeper level there's alot which goes into combat. Every ship has a 'core'. This is your command bridge, your heart. When this goes, you die. Until it goes, you will regenerate parts slowly. So when approaching an enemy you look for the quickest way to take out this heart. With the variety of ships on offer, this never gets old.

3) Pacing.

The game is fantastically paced. Tutorials are done on the fly, so you learn by playing. At the start, you have a small ship. You gain resources by exploring, with small dogfights along the way. You use these resources to improve, and eventually you have a medium ship. Now you start fighting abit more and getting a better income from doing so, whilst supplementing you income with exploration. Then you get a big ship. Now exploration becomes the back seat. Combat is your bread and butter. You fight and fight. After abit, you enter the forth stage of progression. You may have dabbled, but until now you've been focused of improving yourself. Now you build a fleet. Soon your at the heart of a 30 ship strong armada, and fights take on a whole new focus.

The fantastic thing about this formula of progression is with the unlocks. There are alot of races (8?). You start with only 1. To unlock others you must locate and destroy a ship worth 1000 points (you start with around 300 and grow to 8000 so i found i was doing this around the second / third stage). Each race has some unique items and generally some sort of separate theme to its shared items. This allows great re-playability.

---------------------------

So, the review summery. This is a great game. Part Space exploration, part space combat, part lego. I'd advise this to alot of people, as there is something for everybody. In particular i'd point people to it who enjoy games with creation elements, such as Spore. If creation isnt your thing, but you like space combat sims, i would still advise this game. The races come with pre-made ships, and the game has the ability to export ships as code. So you can always trawl forums to locate ships.

I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197965777212', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1214, 'last_played': 1426828315}
review:
This is a mesmerizing and addictive game.  The idea is not new: design a spaceship, battle other spaceships, mine resources in order to buy ship upgrades, repeat.  But this game stands out for a few reasons.

First is the realism of ship design.  You assemble your ship out of a stock of components in a editor reminiscent of Microsoft Visio (but better; MSFT ought to hire this guy).  In most games like this, you might, say, upgrade to Engine IV, which makes you move at speed 8.  In Reassembly, your ship's behavior is instead calculated as a consequence of your design.  Speed, for example, is a result of your thrust and mass, but in addition, maneuverability is a result of where you put your thrusters, how they're angled, your ship's center of gravity (which is indicated in the ship editor), etc.  If your ship doesn't handle the way you like, it's your fault, and you can easily fix it.

Second is the AI behavior.  All ships seek resources which grow on space rocks.  Lots of small ships hover around these rocks harvesting what they can find; a few medium-size ships prowl around the perimeter hunting the small ships; and occasionally capital ships arrive and destroy everyone.  It feels rather like an ecology simulator, with minnows nibbling at coral reefs, big fish eating the minnows, and so on.  Since the universe is dynamically generated, I assume this 'ecology sim' behavior isn't hard-coded, but is emergent behavior of the ship AI.  Anyway, it makes you feel that you're inhabiting a living world.

It's beautiful, too, with a minimal color palette standing out against stark black space.  Hundreds of ships can be onscreen at a time without the game apparently breaking a sweat (thanks Reassembly developer, for actually caring about performance).  And the trance-y music complements the minimalist esthetic nicely.

If you built Lego spaceships as a kid, or you have scuba dived in a coral reef and liked it, you should play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076600299', 'num_games_owned': 214, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 3541, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2159, 'last_played': 1457569847}
review:
Its really orginal, never played a game this good. The building of ships and their possibilities is almost limitless "almost". The way you gather resources isn't exactly boring at all, I was worried that it would be a slow game that takes loads of time to build up to better tiers. But no, there is some time needed for gathering resources but more than half of my time I put into this game consists of me making up ideas of ship designs and models of ship from great sci-fi games and movies. 

This game has tactics that gurantee victory like other games allowing this much building freedom. One obvious one is weapon spam,  which does get nerve recking, especially since the game allows other built fleets to attack you. Which is an awesome element though, it really keeps you on the edge of your seat which makes there be no dull moment at all during gameplay. Although don't be worried about this as a huge issue,, one way to counter it is by making a bigger fleet or have bigger guns than you enemy. ( thats one that i have started using)

Overall great game, worth the money i payed, and WARNING GETS EXTREMELY ADDICTING!

8.8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197994059145', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 5075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4396, 'last_played': 1582464944}
review:
This game...my god..is fun.
I was not expecting much, just wanted something to play around. So I got this.
Man..I was hooked...I spent hours on getting my ship design right...
The control of the ship do take sometime to get used to, but you will just get familiar in time.
And you can upload your ship design online and let other player fight against it.
One thing you can also do is you can design your own space station and deploy them anywhere you want. it is exciting to see your station against other player's fleet and destroy them.
And there are a lot of factions you can unlock and play, each factions plays differently.

I highly recommend anyone wanted an space action rouge like game to get this. It is a good buy

author: {'steamid': '76561197985561027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1034, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1034, 'last_played': 1424961856}
review:
Her er et spil som jeg ikke regnede med at det ville stjÃ¦le 10+ timer af min tid. Et spil der pÃ¥ overfladen er ganske simpelt men er svÃ¦rt at mestre, dog uden at det slÃ¥r dig fuldstÃ¦ndig ud pÃ¥ noget tidspunkt, da der er et fornuftigt respawn system i spillet.

Her er en kort liste over plusser og minusser i spillet.

-Ingen multiplayer, kun mulighed for at dele sine konstruktioner med andre ved at sende dem ind i ormehuller, hvor de sÃ¥ dukker op i andres singplayer spil som "agents".
-Du skal gennemfÃ¸re spillets tutorial HVER GANG du starter et nyt spil. Det kan ikke springes over, hvilket kan vÃ¦re irriterende hvis du ender med at vÃ¦re en rutineret spiller som gerne vil springe newbie assistancen over.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994236983', 'num_games_owned': 1096, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1989, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1063, 'last_played': 1513907961}
review:
If you like Battleships Forever or Captain Forever, this game is for you. (They're both freeware so go try them if you're interested in this.) It takes the concepts of both, and throws in a bit of Starsector (namely the fleet mechanics) for good measure to make a game I've poured hours into already. (As of writing, I've played it for 10.8 hours. I bought it yesterday.)

While some have also compared it to Gimbal, I'd say only at the very start. The comparison starts losing ground once you get the bigger ships.

Where this stands out is the.. well, game. BF and CF are both fun for a short play, but don't have many backing gameplay mechanics. Reassembly gives you economies, waring fations, fleet control and quite a bit of variety (Though I'd like to see mod support in the future for even more pieces/factions). Each faction also plays differently in various ways, for example, one can plant and grow their own resources, but seem to be lacking in firepower, another has literal nukes, but no shields, and so on, it forces a change in tactics when it comes to ship design that keeps things fresh. With all that in mind, it's still a sandbox, outside of the tutorial, what you do is purely up to you with zero guidance, I personally like that, some might not.

It should also be noted it seems to run superbly. I have a fairly powerful machine, but any game with 1000s of ships/particles will slow it down some. This doesn't, I've had fleets of hundreds of ships facing off against each other, and it has stayed at a stable 60fps. 

All in all, one of the best games I've purchased in a very long time.

EDIT: Apparently mod support is already somewhat in the game. I got ahead of myself.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971141931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 2365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1304, 'last_played': 1697502045}
review:
Everything I wanted Stardrive to be.
10/10 Ship building.
8/10 Space battles.

0/10 Story - There is'nt one!

Overall a really really enjoyable game. Fingers crossed the Dev pumps more content into it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030212795', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 4733, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2647, 'last_played': 1439437717}
review: actually making effort of typing words because this game deserves a full recommendation. do not hesitate, buy now

author: {'steamid': '76561198026081304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1642658590}
review:
Great game, if you like building and improving spaceships and and simple gameplay, don't hesitate and get this game. There's enough variation in the spaceship building blocks and enemies to make you think. You've got to experiment with the various builds and styles of play to get a winning combination. Also, you can design and add ships to your own fleet, adding more strategic combinations of missiles, rays and drones. Great fun and will eat hours of your life. 
Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044758616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2515, 'last_played': 1434604237}
review:
This game has been a pleasent surprise. Noticed only a couple small bugs so far. Half the time I'm just plotting my next ship or a counter to something that tore my last idea in half. Needs more factions and less skating on ice feeling when flying. Otherwise definately worth it.  

Pros:
~ Easy to learn controls and UI
~ Game mechanics/speed is more or less controlled by the player
~ Different factions with different building materials offer a different feel.
~ Custom colors, I hate when you have to look a certain way.
~ So many different ways to build your fleet! I felt like a kid again watching my legos come alive haha.

Things I wanted to mention that aren't so positive:
~ Ive noticed some of the stations don't build themselves after capturing the node. They sit idle until I edit them, after I edit they will grow and start to function.
~ I mentioned the feeling of skating on ice. even with well placed thrusters its still hard to control your ship.
~ In ine point of the tutorial the game asks you to build a ship with a ship with a factory and then have that ship produce another to complete the cycle to grow your fleet. I love this idea but after you've made the first one spawn they dont really expand they all kinda stay in the same spot :*( I gave them thrusters to move! go kill stuff! Anyways.

8/10 Great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043221198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 6649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1743, 'last_played': 1601592772}
review: I do like the game but the in game different factions are radically unblanced and the ultimate ship is essentially a cube or rectangle with a bunch of weapons and engines.  There are some creative powerful ships out there but they are few and far between.  In specific i am almost constantly up against an agent called the lasercube, and its fucking boring as hell because i essentially have to break out a long range super fast sniping ship and kite it to death or make a clone of it, produce several of them and just out laser cube the laser cube.  This is also annoying.  Of course some faction arent even able to snipe things.  The faction that is orange red yellow has such weak hulls that the laser cube destroys them on sight, and with no long range weapons, and no shields the ROY (red yellow orange) faction is weak as balls against the others.  Its really annoying when my fleet of 7 or more 4000 cost ROY ships just get blown to shit by an agent looking at them the wrong way.  In short its a cool game, i do enjoy it, it just frustrates the crap out of me because the factions are unblanced as fuck, all the agents i see are basically cubes or rectangles, and I purchased the game right before the price dropped to $15.  As it stands if the price drops again, or if the game is somehow rebalanced to make cubes and rectangles not the most effcient ship design, or to somehow award ships with greater aestetic appeal more functionality, or really just something to balance all the factions and make them all equally capable of fighting with eachother, then I can recomend the game.  As it stands I would say buy it if you enjoy playing with legos a lot, and if legos weren't one of your favorite toys then this isn't for you as of right now.  I also noticed a lot of reviews talking about crashing and deleting save files but i never had those problems.  Not sure why, but those need to be fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964234833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2172, 'last_played': 1510802661}
review:
Get this game!  It is nearly perfect!  If you are wondering "Will I like this game?"  The answer is yes!  Ship design and building is flawless.  Handling and combat are satisfying and responsive to what you design and the changes you make.  If you like Lego (building blocks not games) or buildy games like Terraria, Minecraft, Gratuitous Space Battles you will loves this.

Endless replayability, like a bucket full of Lego bricks.  The last two games that made me feel this way were FTL and Terraria.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007644974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1433466053}
review:
Fantastic little game, but of course it has its flaws too.

First off, basically everything about this game is something to love, the graphics are really simple but work so damn well, the framerate NEVER drops below 60, the sound and music are also simplistic but lovely and the gameplay is some really incredibly fun stuff!

At the start, the game throws a ton of mechanics at you. Once you either get a friend to explain it to you or re-read all texts a few times, you'll get what the different terms mean, get used to them and be able to work with them.

While I imagined the gameplay to get repetitive at some time, it actually stayed incredibly fresh and fun for all this time. You keep getting new ideas on what to do, new things to try out, you can keep expanding and if all's boring, just start a new game in a different faction, changing up the gameplay a TON.

The other thing is: you NEED a good upload speed to play this game, because once you close it, it has to sync about 20MB of data (the world and ships) to the Steam Cloud, stopping you from playing other games during that time, and is just plain annoying. The even worse bit is that DISABLING Steam Cloud syncing seems to erase all ships you've created (it at least happened for me, not sure if that's exactly the cause), so you gotta deal with it somehow...

EITHER WAY, this game is so damn awesome, please go play it, I'll tell ya, once you get used to the mechanics, it'll be an enormous time sink!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060408607', 'num_games_owned': 649, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 6170, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1025, 'last_played': 1549094420}
review:
Game is in early access and some bugs need to be worked out, along with some UI stuff in my opinion, but for the most part this game is SUPER fun. It's best moments are when you have a giant fleet of ships and ram it right into another one, and at that point just sit back and watch the lasers and explosions and parts of ships flying everywhere.  
10/10 would space again

author: {'steamid': '76561197972361802', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5414, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2054, 'last_played': 1579750879}
review:
A lot of hours in the last few days into this game.  Basically its a top down shooter that you build bits and pieces if your ship.

Its oddly satisfying to cut your opponents ship in half, through an asteroid.. ;) 

I think there's a lot to offer in the game, though it could use a bit more content, maybe more/different pieces.  Multi player would be killer, even if it was a wild sandbox.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005949347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1426030475}
review:
This game is beautiful. A physics-based WASD space shooter nestled in the most enjoyable sandbox builder I've ever played.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
  [*] Your ship is constantly rebuilding itself - leading to great gameplay moments like sniping enemy cores, narrow escapes, on-the-fly hull redesign, etc...
  [*] Instead of being a solo ship, you are part of a faction. You gain acess to new tech and bigger ships by advancing your faction's power which does a great job of making you feel integrated into the game world.
  [*] Each faction is very diverse, with its own unique attributes and building elements. These constraints help shipbuilding to stay fresh and encourage experimentation.
  [*] Fantastic ship editor makes it fun and easy to make your designs real.
  [*] Good tutorial to get you started with the core mechanics.
  [*] Community content - at any time you can approach a wormhole and upload your fleet. These fleets can then spawn in other players' games. What makes this awesome is that you don't just encounter single ships from these fleets, but whole communities with multiple ship styles from the same user.
  [*] A sense of progression. I typically lose interest in sandbox builders where you have to collect resources to use in crafting. Reassembly uses point-based ship construction, so you don't have to collect resources to build your ship - just to expand your point cap. This gives you concrete goals to work towards over time, while again providing constraints to motivate continual re-design of your fleet.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
  [*] You haven't purchased this game yet! Go support these developers!
[/list]

review:
Nach ca 10 Std. Spielzeit ist es Zeit dieses Juwel zu bewerten. AnfÃ¤nglich war ich doch etwas skeptisch, da ich nicht sicher war, ob mich das Spielprinzip fesseln kann. Aber es kann. Und zwar in einem nicht vorhersehbaren AusmaÃŸ :D

Die Grafik ist stimmig und das Entwerfen von immer neuen Schiffen macht unglaublich viel SpaÃŸ. Ich ertappte mich dabei 5 Std am StÃ¼ck zu spielen, ohne an die Zeit zu denken. Und das will was heiÃŸen.

Es lÃ¤uft stabil und die immer neu generierten Welten haben einen hohen Wiederspielwert. 

Das Prinzip ist eindeutig Mikrobiologischem Leben entnommen und zeigt wie einfach im Grunde Leben und Evolution ist.
Man kann sogar behaupten, dass es im Grunde eine philosophische Frage aufwirft, nÃ¤mlich...wer desingt eigentlich neue Raumschiffe...Ã¤hhhh...Lebensformen. ;)

Aber um hier nicht vÃ¶llig den Faden zu verlieren beschrÃ¤nke ich mich darauf eine Kaufempfehlung auszusprechen.

Auch von mir gibts ein kurzes Let's Play, um die Grundprinzipien verstÃ¤ndlich zu machen. Vielen Dank an die Entwickler, die wirklich etwas, fÃ¼r mich, einzigartiges geschaffen haben.

http://youtu.be/B9x2vlflexA

author: {'steamid': '76561197966610754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1567732838}
review:
tl;dr Spore meets SubSpace (aka Continuum), 8/10. Remember SubSpace? Need I say more? I do? Okay.

As others have said, this game is extremely addictive. In a good way. The ship editor in itself is hours of lego-style building fun, but add to that a really immersive single-player world with player-made ships and you have a game that is both simple and compelling at the same time. 

Definitely worth the money, tons of replayability. Summarizing my experience as follows:

Pros:
- Great physics / destructable levels, and combat is super fun.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- World is huge but not infinite. That's a good thing for a space game.
- Building ships is surprisingly fun. I'm not usually the type to want to buy a game then spend hours in an editor customizing things. The editor is very featureful and forgiving (undo, redo, copy paste), unlike many other in-game editors out there.
- Sending your ship into a wormhole uploads your fleet into the ether so they can be run in other player games as the bad guys, Spore-style! In other words, tons of player-made content.
- If you get sick of your world, fly into a wormhole and explore a parallel dimension instead.

Cons:
- Controls are a little quirky, especially on gamepads. Don't use a gamepad. Occasionally you'll find yourself slamming into an asteroid and getting completely stuck because the "fly backwards" key gets completely rotated and you and up flying into the asteroid and flailing around until you're killed by a passing enemy.
- Ship editor is missing a MANUAL test flight option to get a sense of the maneuverability of the ship you spent an hour making. 
- Ship editor is missing important info about total mass / total thrust / total energy created which could help to approximate the above stuff. Only total resource capacity is listed-- everything else you have to calculate yourself.
- NO MULTIPLAYER! The player-made content is fun in SP, but a game like this just begs for multiplayer.
- Once you've maxed out points, Actual gameplay is 1-dimensional. Mostly consists of flying around and shooting everything you see-- or if you're like me and setup auto-fire, it's just flying around and letting the ship shoot everything for you. You can explore to find new bases, but that doesn't really give you anything.

On the last two points, I wonder if I'm just misunderstanding some of the game dynamics, but it seems like unlocking bases is just there to occupy your time. I also don't really know if you can ever wipe out another faction. It would be great if:

- You could watch bases expand over time, including size and number of ships, so you actually have more allies flying around. Ditto for enemies that go unchecked.
- You could actually attack enemy bases and eventually wipe out factions. It would be awesome if each faction actually had a stronghold base you have to kill in order to wipe out an enemy.
- There were new factions added over time, including to existing regions. Maybe I haven't played for long enough, but it seems like the same factions just exist in perpetuity.

There it is. Lots of cons because the pros seem obvious to me. It's damn fun! It could be even better if the above things were addressed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984877534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3135, 'last_played': 1688516312}
review:
This game is awesome.  Ever played a game and wished you could tweak your ship?  Well now you can.
Any type of ship imaginable is buildable: Carriers that launch leigons of drone fighters; Battleships with heavy cannons and a myriad of point defense lasers; Missile Cruisers with racks upon racks of guided missiles; Destroyers with cannons, lasers, beam weapons, and torpedo launchers; Fighters with rapid-fire plasma guns, lasers, and rockets.  Weapons can be bound to control groups and can be set to fire in grouped bursts or in a continuous chain.

The game starts you out with a well-made tutorial.  It provides guidance on learning the game and getting your fleet up and running (yes, you can build ships that can build more ships), without being intrusive or pushy.  All of this building requires competing for and collecting the resources that grow on nearby asteroids.  These raw resources can then be used to construct additional ships or exchanged at one of the friendly stations you've activated for credits to fund research and fleet upgrades.

The physics in this game are fantastic.  Fire a heavy cannon, and your ship recoils.  Hit something or blow something up, and chunks fly off and blow apart.  The field of wreckage that remains after an epic battle is part of what makes this game so satisfying.

The graphics are beautiful.  Colors and effects are vibrant. (Just go look at the screenshots!)

The music is suitable and soothing, but not particularly noteworthy, but the sound effects from firing weapons are right on point.

There are still a few bugs.  The game never seems to remember my control settings, and the game sometimes has trouble starting (restarting the launcher seems to work for the latter).

TLDR:  I don't usually write reviews, but this game is too awesome not to.  It is a definite must buy and well worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051816523', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1928, 'last_played': 1676520160}
review:
Wow, Is all I can say really.
This is just an incredible game, I bought it and started playing at around 8PM, Next thing you know, I take a second glance at the clock and it's 5AM.

There are 7 factions, they all play and work differently, One faction is the high damage, high armour faction, but all but one of their weapons cannot do damage to shields. Another faction has incredibly low armour/health, but has the highest damaging weapons. You unlock the other factions by killing large valuable ships of that faction, once you kill a certain amount, or a certain value of ship, You unlock that faction to play as.

Ships are assigned value based on their size, So for instance, if your build cap is 500P, and you build a ship up to say, 460P, your ship is worth 460P. Most factions will cap out at 8,000P, and it will take some time to get there.

Inside each map, There are usually around 8-10 "Agents" Agents being player fleets spawning in your world, They can range from being total garbage, to an impossible force. Each time you go through a Wormhole, the way you change maps, It will spawn your current fleet setup randomly in other players worlds. 

The gameplay is very nice, It plays like a twin stick shooter and it works. The game itself is very well optimized, even after spawning around 150 large ships it still ran smoothly and at a decent framerate. The graphics are nice and stylized.

I really have nothing negative to say about this game, It's just amazing.

With 22 hours in the game, I've managed to completely clear only 2 of the 7 Factions, By that I mean, unlocking all the parts, upgrading the build cap to max and building a very powerful ship. With it's recent price drop to 17$, It's DEFINITELY worth the price, You'll be getting a lot of game.

Solid 10/10, You NEED to buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060663769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1065, 'last_played': 1688676107}
review: It took me about an hour to fall into this game but once I finally got the hang of it I was hooked.  Its not until you can start producing your own personal fleet of ships that this game really starts to shine.  The graphics are beautiful, however there are some slowdowns when the huge battles start.  I turned a few physics options down a bit and it was much better.  I felt like I took a bit of a chance buying this in early access but I feel like its well worth it.  I hope to see some more multiplayer options soon.  There is a lot to do already to keep you busy while the devs work on even more content as it sets now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108269527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1429064408}
review:
Reassembly is a game that is difficult to categorize. There are elements of building, space combat, and rts (in a somewhat abstract way). The game allows great creativity in shipbuilding style and combat philosphy. 

I find this game to be great fun. You can start with a pre-built ship, or make your own right away. The game includes an AI driven tester that will pit your design against other designs so that you can tweak and perfect your ship before flying it. I prefer to fly around and earn some credits first for upgrades. The goal is simple - expand your territory, earn credits, use credits to upgrade the power level of ship you are permitted to fly, unlock upgrades and build better ships.

The game learns from how you play and from facing your ships. Eventually you will face ships made by other players. Also you will unlock other factions that you can play which have different ship components. The replay value is immense as no playthrough will ever be identical to another. 

The graphics are clean and simple, not ultra-detailed, with nice effects, slightly retro and modern at the same time.  The game includes excellent controller support for in-game play, but for ship creation you have to use mouse and keyboard. I think controller support for the building phase of the game would probably be awkward and difficult to implement, so I don't blame the devs...

10/10 If there is something wrong with this game, I don't know what it is!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973546137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1541833940}
review:
Like building ships? Buy this game. Like hectic combat? Buy this game. Like leading fleets with very little control over your subordinates? Buy this game. Like minimalistic art style that still manages to be beautiful, where you can sit and watch the asteroid flowers grow for hours on end in a strange zen-like state? Buy this game.

(I kickstarted this game, and am by far the most pleased with this product out of any other game I've "invested" in)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025216321', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1035, 'last_played': 1484525117}
review:
I am REALLY amazed about this game. This game absolutely nails the playability and usability. For me this game is up there with FTL and Minecraft, where you can just keep playing and playing for the fun of the experience itself, not the winning.

The building of new spacehips, trying out combinations, and just trying to make things look good is a lot of fun. Combined with the amazing slickness of the editor you can spend hours in a Zen-like mode of tweaking, playing, and tweaking some more.

What sets this game apart as well is that you fight the creations of other players, and that others will play against yours. That makes you care about your creations much more than you would have in a purely single player game.

All in all highly recommended if you like 2D space shooters and building games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984487409', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1990, 'last_played': 1424991474}
review:
This is a giant sandbox top down builder/shooter. You design your ships and stations then head out to conquer the galaxy. I'm not sure how each race works, two of them seem useless, and another two seem endgame only.. Maybe I'm missing something when trying to figure out what they are for.

If you love topdown sandbox shooters where you build your fleet and have amazing lightshows... I mean lazer fights! Then grab the game, I've got my money's worth already and am still enjoying it.

Build ships that look like things (beatles, scorpions, star destroyer, etc. Blow stuff up and enjoy the lightshow, at this price how can you say no?!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997316475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1482609073}
review: Somewhere between the arcade classic Asteroids and the joy of playing with LEGOs is Reassembly.  The learning curve can be steep, the balance a bit off, but the gameplay remains addictive and designing your own spaceships is a breeze.  I designed an Imperial Star Destroyer that craps out Millennium Falcons and Enterprises.  'Nuff said.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024966235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1585002224}
review: A well-designed space exploration game.  While gameplay has the potential to get somewhat repetetive after a time, the ship-building modes allow for endless experimentation.  The ship builder was surprisingly well-designed, and controls were easy and intuitive.  My only complaint is that, when storing games on the Steam Cloud, data compaction and sync times are extremely long.  This doesn't affect gameplay, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044812702', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1465200608}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024953217', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1218, 'last_played': 1424879843}
review:
Awesome game! You can build ships to your liking and adept your fleet to the situations at hand. It is very satisfying to equip a horde of drone minions and take them into battle against ships designed by other players that appear as agents in the game.

9.5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198124328535', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1415, 'last_played': 1592623387}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040885905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3750, 'last_played': 1681091150}
review:
Seriously an amazing game if you're looking for something to stretch your creative muscles.  You choose one of many playable factions, each unique in the parts and weapons available to them.  Using said parts, you create a 2D spaceship and begin to pioneer your faction to victory.

Things to note:
-This game has no story.  It is purely driven by you making a story yourself, or simply wanting to conquer the generated world.

-All movement in the game is physics based, and your ships are only as good as you build them.  This means there is something similar to a puzzle/strategy aspect of the game when building your ships.  If this is unappealing, I would be hesitant to recommend this game to you.
    A possible solution to this problem is the implementation of the Steam Workshop.  This allows people to upload entire factions/fleets for you to use, but in my opinion you are mission out on half if not more of the game if you aren't building things.

-Replay value is arguable, and very dependant on the player.  If you are someone who likes experimenting with strategies, or challenging yourself by say, limiting your options by a personal rule, then you will most likely find it easy to sink hours into Reassembly.

    In closing, I will simply say that Reassembly is a very rewarding game for those who enjoy top-down shooters, side scrollers, and creating functional and even beautiful things.  If you find it difficult to find personal motivation with a game, maybe double check other games on your wishlist before buying.

P.S. If you're into systematically destroying A.I. populations, this game could be for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003552620', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1450999723}
review:
After kickstarting this with high hopes, the end result is pretty disappointing.  

Building ships isn't very fun in their editor.  There is an inverse relationship between how good a ship is in a fight, versus how cool it looks and how fun it is to actually fly around in.  The world rapidly fills up with similar, boring, min-max ships designed by other players, which you need your own min-maxed boring, un-fun ships to fight against successfully.  The alternative path to victory is basically, get bigger numbers and spam more boring ships in a bigger blob of boring than the other guy.  

There just isn't much of a designed "game" in here.  The tricky part where you make doing the individual actions you perform in the game cohere into something interesting, balance out various weapons and tactics, etc, seems not to have been done at all as yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044831489', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1672084317}
review:
Kickstarted this game because it looked awesome.

Essentially, procedurally-generated (and with wormholes, basically infinite) shmup with a focus on customizing your ship. It gives you basically lego-style building blocks (e.g. square or triangular hull blocks) plus various components like your ship's core, harvesters, storage, etc. as well as a plethora of increasingly fun weapons to use. Once you have your ship, you simply fly out and battle all the ships in the world -- this isn't procedurally generated, but the devs made a huge number of ships, and it'll take ships other players made and put them in your world, so there's a lot to blow up.

Overall, and excellent and really replayable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075738086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1720, 'last_played': 1538968219}
review:
Bought this game for 31.99$, a day later it's 16.99$. Not even mad, played it for 11 hours straight. 11/10 would pay double price again. As a fan of stardrive this game takes the spaceship building aspect far and above it, floating aimlessly in space looking for ships to destroy and factions to unlock, then all of a sudden a super mega ultra death juggernaut destroys my fleet in one hit... Next objective? REVENGE. 10 hours later, mission success.

It's a hard game to describe with words, either watch some videos/streams, or take a chance and buy it! the price is a steal!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008241330', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1478829156}
review:
Game is great. Though a little scarce on parts at the moment, I hope they are planning on adding more parts and weapons. You can make just about anything in this game from tiny scout fighters to giant dreadnaughts and space stations. Installed it and played it trying to keep making the better ship only to lose track of time 4 hours later. This is a great time killer. Graphics are unique, gameplay is solid, though can be repetitive at times with gathering resources.

I do hope they plan on adding ship sharing perhaps via steam workshop. Currently the only wait to see other peoples ships are to hunt down â€œagentsâ€ which are usually player made ships most of the time. Iâ€™m still grasping the game within the first 4 hours if me losing track of time.  Hopefully in the future, we have the ability of a more diverse fleet command system, and more parts. All in all, great game for $15 full price. 

EDIT: I should note that after putting more time into the game, I have found that you can download player fleets by just going to the Reassembly Homepage and looking at the sync list. Its as easy as just downloading and importing fleets. Check it out: http://www.anisopteragames.com/sync/latest.html

On another note, I only played as the first faction. Upon unlocking more factions, you have unique parts and weapons used by that faction. So there is quite a variety with the 6 or 7 different factions available right now. Definitely hard to break away from this, as I'm constantly facing player made fleets and always trying to enhance my fleet to defeat that fleet. I was constantly defeated by one fleet for about an hour before finally upgrading and fine tuning my weapons to defeat them. Simply one of the best arcade style games I've played in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088783978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1424414023}

The reason I can't recomend this is just . . . it's TOO addicting. Some might think of that as a great thing and I'm sure the maker is thrilled, though for those who already spend too much time with games and aren't looking to lose hours of time infront of your screen may want to stay away.

tldr; good game, time eater

author: {'steamid': '76561198090868483', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 26571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1598, 'last_played': 1710030805}
review:
Let me just begin by saying this game is in early developement and it may have its bugs but still is worth playing through. the gameplay and concept are a jewel among other games. there are strategy and shooter elements along with casual elements that make this game just an all around excellent experience both for hardcore action players and more relaxed casual players. 
The ability to make your own ship one block at a time and perfect it and then see other stations and ships spawn your design is a beautiful site. This is an excellent marriage of strategy and shooter along with a wonderful atmospheric environment. the price for this game may seem a little high but I personally think it is well worth the price for the experience you can have in the game.

pros
- modular ship building
- living ever changing environment
- unique playable factions each specializing in a particular playstyle.
- interesting encounters with other players ship designs.
- early access
- inifinite ways to play
cons
- early access
- lack of uniqueness with some factions
- weak factions
- lacking content

author: {'steamid': '76561198141129230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2338, 'last_played': 1458795846}
review:
When I first saw this game I was overjoyed. I bought it, even though $30 is quite a steep price for a game of this size, but for the most part it was worth it. Ever since I bought it the Dev has been active in updating the game and has made some major improvements on the ai and visuals as a whole. I think one of the latest updates that gave the ships and stations a glow based on their color added even more to the game's beauty. I love the idea of being able to design my own ships and take over the galaxy. Not to mention getting to see other people's creations (and getting to blow them to ****ing pieces). 

But this game does start to get old after a certain point. At the moment there are 7 factions, and I've been able to get to the endgame of just about each one of them, but after you do that.... there's nothing really to do. You conquer one galaxy, move on to the next, and do the same exact thing, and the hardest ships sadly are always the same, (the blue and pinkish purple ones) which are located in the middle, which sadly never changes. Faction balancing is also a problem right now. The red faction atm is completly useless and almost impossible to get anywhere. The blocks it has are far weaker than any other faction (other than its weapons, which do pack a punch) and its ships get completely destroyed almost instantly when you're in the starting stage with the faction. Even when you start creating bigger ships with them they get crushed by other factions who have far better blocks. That brings me to my next point, the lack of options when it comes to blocks for some factions. For example, a faction like the green race (the 2nd option in the menu) has 47 different blocks, whereas some of the others will only have a little over 20 (and are very limited when it comes to weapon variance). 

Another thing that should have been in this game but is not is multiplayer. Sure there's going to be tournaments where you can pit your ships against other ships, but only with the ai using your ship instead of you... If I created a ship to my liking, I want to use that ship to my liking in a pvp environment. Sadly the Dev said that this is probably not going to happen beacuse he'd have to take the game apart to implement a multiplayer function. So if you're going into this game thinking that that's going to be an option. It's most likely not going to happen.

Overall, this game is very fun and I would definatley reccomend buying it, but wait until after it comes out this coming thursday (the 19th) because it's going to be going down to $15 I believe. The creativity in this game is nearly endless, and many good times can be had, but unfortunetly you won't beable to do this with friends in the same galaxy and once you do conquer that galaxy, it's going to get repetetive.

I'd give it an 8/10. Pick it up and enjoy it if you want a creative experience in the sci-fi world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049688895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1933, 'last_played': 1670132387}

author: {'steamid': '76561198044571833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4330, 'last_played': 1448695890}
review:
Great Game 9.7/10. Build ship fleet and destroy other ships is great

Short Review:

+ Beautiful graphics
+ Good gameplay
+ Awesome features
+ Randomly Generated World
+ Wormhole feature to make a new world for replayability
+Amazing ship building feature

-Saves can be deleted from bugs that I've encountered (3 TIMES ALREADY)
-Performance issues on Yellow Plant Faction, even with beefy PC's

Long Version: Reassembly is a vector-graphics game with a great original topic. This game can be very addicting. The one thing i do encounter in this game is the repititive gameplay. Eventually, you will get maximum Power to upgrade your ship until you cant upgrade it anymore, creating a big, strong ship/fleet. When you go to this part, you will see it is easy to pick off the small and huge ships in the center, even if they swarm you, you would just easily kill all of them off. I do recommend to the Dev(s) to create bigger ships or even create it so that the bigger P you have, the bigger the enemy ships get. Sort of like "evolution" (idk lol). This suggestion would take time, but will be worth it.

     I have played this game for hours and it is extremely fun to play. I get more excited for updates in the game rather than updates for others (except Running With RIfles), even if they are just bugfixes. 

Overall: Game is very fun and addictive. its gr8 m8 i r8 8/8

author: {'steamid': '76561197970917644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1437, 'last_played': 1638920045}
review:
This is a bit like SPaZ with total ship customization. Completing objectives like capturing points and killing enemies awards you with upgrade points that you can use to buy more weapons and systems for your ships. You can start from the ground up to customize your ship, which gives you the freedom to make a spectacularly crappy ship or the ship of awesome, all governed by how many upgrade points you put into ship total size. It's so fun, and I constantly go back and tweak ships when I unlock new techs. 

The price is higher than an indie game, and that's a bit of a negative, but there is plenty of value in the ship customization. There are different ship races to unlock, so there is a bit of replay value. The ship races differ dramatically, so it feels different evey time you start fresh with a new race.

Creativity in ship building is the shining point of this game, and I'm glad I bought it.

This game is fun and functional in its early access state, so don't worry about buying something buggy and unfinished. It's good!

author: {'steamid': '76561198149615119', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 345, 'last_played': 1686242086}
