author: {'steamid': '76561198124636722', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4219, 'last_played': 1575179933}
review:
I've never posted a review on Steam before, but Reassembly compelled me to do so.

Summary: This game is still in beta. It also has some of the most immersive aesthetics and mechanics of any game I've ever played. I have learned to approach it with the caution of a recovering drug addict in a pharmacy-- if I click the icon I can expect to lose at least several hours of my time, if not portions of my health, dreams, and/or general human function.

Criticisms: The only reasons I would hesitate to recommend it to my friends in its current state are 1) the effective lack of directed multiplayer, 2) the comparative ease once you start building capital ships, and 3) the lack of polish/balance across some of the playable factions.

1) I found in my playtime that some of what I enjoyed most in the game was the ship design testing process, where at any point you can place your design in the hands of an AI and have it fight best-of-three battles against up to five different AI controlled ships of similar power levels. I would love to have the ability to put my designs up against the designs of my friends and other players, whether one-on-one, faction vs faction, or in larger skirmishes or king of the hill matches.

2) Speaking of the king, once I completed a 8000P juggernaut and spent some time retooling my fleet even the center factions posed little threat (provided I didn't park in a plant faction death cluster or otherwise act a fool). As well, there was no longer any real use for the upgrade currency one you've maxed out the P limit and purchased all the weapon tiles. I haven't tried to achieve complete dominion of the entire game map yet, but the endgame isn't presently as enjoyable as the 20-30 hours I spent reaching it with the first faction (which is a pretty happy problem, granted).

3) As for the factions, the first one has tiles complete with descriptions giving you an idea of each tile's use, as well as some flavor text. The other factions (more recently added to the playable roster) are a bit of a mixed bag, and often require playtesting in order to determine what certain tiles do, or why two similar appearing tiles may have very different power costs. I'm sure this will improve as the game nears release.


Conclusion: This is an excellent indie space sim that melds the fun parts of designing ships with elements of RTS and simple asteroids-style gameplay. It is worth the $30 as is, and I'm excited to see the rest of what the developers pack in before it hits release.

review: Reassembly is a amasing game for creative people that like to mess around with shapes to make some thing sorta like legos but still this game I recamend to people that are very creative, and at times it may be hard to make some ships from factions but after time of thinking who knows what you could make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143512005', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 14833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1116, 'last_played': 1642826382}
review:
I have over a hundred hours put into this game, my steam game time is off.


This beautiful diamond amongst rock, is literally the perfect game for those who possess creativity, and love to simply immerse themselves into a game that rewards for said effort contributed unto it.

I have played Hundreds upon Hundreds of rpg's, sandbox's, adventure and action gerne etc.  
This Masterpiece took the elements from many of the games I held dear, and assimilated them all into a free spirited sandbox rpg with not just replayability, but literally the best customization and diversity i've ever seen in an rpg/sandbox.

This game is simple. In said simplicity, there is an elaborate but gradual growth of complexity. The complex part of this game is the factor that you, as a player, control. This factor is your ship! Along with the other ships in your fleet. The more complex and functional you make your ship, the more beautiful it/they may become without you even realizing it.

Having made over a hundred ships, I can vouch for the ship creation system, as it is somewhat pleasing to invest ten minutes to have an exquisite and awe'ing ship emerge :)


Please! If you are contemplating whether or not to invest in this game, let the reviews and hours do the talking! 

It's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991986151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4323, 'last_played': 1476564329}
review:
Reassembly is an amazing game.  Similar to how Minecraft combined a 3D action sort of a game with gameplay that revolves around creativity using blocks and crafting, Reassembly does something similar in a sense. The combination of certain creative and radical mechanics with an existing game format makes for something much greater and more enjoyable in Reassembly.  The mechanics of the game when you are flying your spaceship remind me of asteroids, but the game is a lot deeper than that.  Reassembly is a top-down space shooter combined with a very open design mode where players create spaceships out of connectable pieces.  It also features reproducing spaceships :)

In the video posted here on Steam, the creator of the game mentions something about creating things of function and beauty.  In reassembly, both function and beauty are valuable end-goals for player creations.  No one likes an ugly ship.  However, since ships reproduce, it is important that the ships are viable.  If you want a ship to turn well and quickly, you have think out where to place the engines so that they rotate the ship.  If you want to protect the core, you may have to surround it with armor.  Design in the game becomes a very interesting process as the original concepts behind a design merge with the necessary requirements for survivability to generate successful ships, or perhaps I should say, successful offspring.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999841420', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 12935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1614196479}
review:
This game may not look like much. Heck, there aren't even any textures, but i must say, Reassembly has quickly become one of my favorite steam games of all time.

The main focus of the game is collecting resources from space plants (which seem to grow on anything that isn't constantly flying at full speed) and ships that belong to enemy factions. These resources can then be sold to friendly stations, who will not only give you credits, but also use the collected resources to build friendly ships, who in turn also collect resources to continue the cycle. Other than the initial ships in the world when you start the game, every ship, turret, and station must be spawned in from a factory (which is attached to another ship, turret, or station) when said factory has enough resources to build. All ships, plants, and debris are persistantly exsistant in the world, even when you leave the area. I cannot express in words how tantalizing the very idea of such a vast yet simple cycle is. Fortunantly, I CAN say (and with absolute certainty) that you MUST buy this game!

PS: The dev team is actually active, so don't be scared of the "early access" label.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970327808', 'num_games_owned': 1999, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1512, 'last_played': 1653932174}
review:
This is still early access so there is no big story or anything, but still this is a REALLY great game already!
Building your spaceships is incredibly fun, plus updates are quite frequent.
Already you can play as different factions with different blocks (weapons, shields, etc) and the dev promised even more blocks to build ships with. There are wormholes through which you can enter newly created "universes" where there are ships from other players - flying through wormholes will also upload the ships you have built.
I can really recommend this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009310694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1486597301}
review:
Essentially, if we all think back to the games we played long ago most of us will remember a game where the player controlled a small and weak little fish. Your aim in this game was to swim around in the ocean and eat any of the fish small enough to fit in your mouth and then hall ass away from fishes that were large enough to eat you in one go.

That is a game i feel thay Reassembly can quite easily be compared to. You start off with a small array of 'stock' ships, provided by the dev team to get you started. These are your small fish. As the game provides you with tutorial messages and objectives you will fail at killing a couple of ships as you get used to the aiming and flying mechanics and you will find that if the ship is smaller than yours... It blows up. The moment you see a ship that consists of a number of blocks higher than yours. Run. Or more likely get blown up and respawn. 

But as you kill the little ships and gather your resource, convert it into C and then purchase upgrades or convert it into P. Your ship begins to grow. You test out designs but eventually you realise as long as you make it big and fast and cover it in as many guns you can hide beneath shields... You're doing the a good job. Your ship begins to get larger... You can kill larger ships... Your ship gets larger still. You begin ignoring the smaller craft you once relied on for resources as they are just a minor neusance to you. You feel like a God amongst the stars. Then a Scythe ship one shots you and you start farming those little guys again just to boost your ego back up. 

Great game, very long review. Essentailly Hungry Fish with lasers and 'spolsions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030969096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1613, 'last_played': 1549342736}
review: Logged 13 hours in the first 24 of owning it. Kind of like Asteroids meets Gratuitous Space Battles meets heroin. If you like games where you get to customize your ship and love to optimize your design and adapt them to new challenges, this game is for you. Purchased at the $30 price point and never questioned it. First I couldn't believe the 100% positive review ratio, and then I played it. This might be considered Early Access but it's more polished than many fully released studio games. There were no crashes, no glitches, no bugs. Once they get more content this game will enter my top 10 of all time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038440613', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1678525196}
review:
Reassembly is a game where you start out with a little ship and use various blocks and weapons to upgrade it. Eventually add a factory to it so you manufacture ships, maybe even give them factories so they can make more... 
Put simply, there's a million different things to do. There's a reason this game doesn't have a single bad review - There's next to no complaints. The only thing I could comment on is what I think could be added, but it's all minor stuff like multiplayer.
The style is amazing. Using just vectors and particle physics the game is beautiful and doesn't need textures. It's appealing to the eye and good on those older computers.
The gameplay mirrors this. It's imple WASD to move, mouse to look, and mouse buttons to shoot. However weapon variants are high. Some are turret types that follow your mouse, some are fixed. You've got everything from plasma weaponry (Moderate range and moderate damage) to the feared Antimatter cannon (Moderate range EXTREMELY high damage.)
If you've ever wanted a game that actually brings something new to the "creative sandbox" genre, this game is for you. The price is a little steep but in my opinion this is one of the few Early Access games that deserves the $30. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061383202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 8284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7369, 'last_played': 1577044831}
review:
This game is pretty badass, except for all the damage and the amount of cluster fucks the enemies put on you every second, it is pretty good. But really, i would not mind if the game creators decided, for some exttremely smart reason, to put in a difficulty guage so that, well you know, players dont get fucked up every other second

Edit: Wow, in 2014 I sucked apparently. My opinion now is the complete opposite. I am always able to make ships that cannot be defeated. I have made ships so powerful, that I have taken on 23 ship agents at max level, and destroyed all their ships with only one of mine. My ships are so armed, that I don't worry about cramped areas cause I shoot a path through them, completely destroying all debris in the way. 
This game allows you to run tests on the ships you create. The tests involve putting your ship up against a number of different opponents, individually that is. But some opponents have multiple ships, so it is your one ships against multiples at a time. 
There are player made ships throughout the game, as the agents and as other factions. The tests also include player made ships, so there is a lot of diversity. As well as a chance to see what design other people use. 

I'm just going to put this out there, I have created quite a few ships that have never been defeated, and if you ever have to face them, I'm sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198074943301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 120639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108664, 'last_played': 1696676057}
review:
This game has got to be the most addicting game ive played in a few years, even thought not fully finished. I have to say for anyone who loves building space ships this as its going is a must buy. To give you an understanding of the game, you start as a small prebuild ship which over time with enough resources, you can make your own or even just start making your own right away. 

At the start i spent 2 hours building ships and watching the testing battles, rather than actually playing the core game which isn't even done yet. In short this game is great even in Early Access, and unless you play it for your self you will have a hard time seeing if you like this game. But i will say even as fun and addicting as this game is, there are some things not finished and even small down sides. For instance, the gameplay its self is very simple on its own, but is completly over shadowed by the rest of the game which is great.

Honestly i hope people buy this game to try it out as it may not appeal to everyone, but it is in no right a bad game, and i hope for the best that this game will be fantastic and live up to the developers and the communities expectations.

NOTE WAS EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

author: {'steamid': '76561197993617089', 'num_games_owned': 718, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1419047192}
review:
Short Version:

Crack. Heroin. Nicotine. Alchohol. Reassembly. What do these things have in common? They're all highly addictive. With that being said, Reassembly deffinately has it's faults, but if their's something that interests you about this game, then it's probly worth checking out.

Long Version:

    Reassembly is a 2d, top down, vector graphic space shooter that lets you build your own fleet to conquer the galaxy with. You start out the game with a few premade ships to select from, a faction that looks just like you, and a galaxy full of things that want to kill you. Your objectives are to capture space stations, gather raw resources, turn them into your faction for credits, use those credits to research new parts and upgrade the power of your ship. The further into the galaxy you go, the harder it gets. Whilst exterminating all life that isn't allied to you from the galaxy, you use the very easy to use ship builder to customize or build from scratch both your ship, and your allied ships. (They either automatically spawn based on designs from your inventory, or are spawned by you from a factory ship.) When designing a ship, you can also elect to 'test' your ship in a series of 1v1 ai controlled deathmatches, exactly like the anisoptera contests.

Then there's the asynchronus multiplayer, this game's greatest feature, and biggest pitfall. Essentially, ships that other players have designed will be found strewn throughout the galaxy, in their own factions. Typically, these factions are far stronger than any of the vanilla factions you will encounter, however, that's not true of all of them. For example, one user created a troll ship in the sandbox mode, which allows ship designs that aren't legal in the normal game mode. Only now, here's that ship in _my_ normal game mode. I have a problem with that. Further compounding this problem, are the contest ships. Those ships are purpose built to fall into a specific category of ship, and dominate anything with the same power level or below. Sounds about right, doesn't it? I mean, isn't that the whole point of the contest, and ship design in general? The problem is, you're playing a game that isn't a 1v1 deathmatch. You need storage tanks for your raw resources, factories to spawn your death fleet, and just in general use components that take up space that could be used for more killing devices, or maneuverability. For example, one ship I came across was designed to ram into you, shove a ton of armor between you and his control module, while having 6 plasma cannons on these fragile little arms. The idea being, there's no way for you to chew through his armor before those untouched cannons melt your entire ship. This works great in those ai controlled deathmatches, however it's completely useless in the main game. I'd like to see all sandbox ships blocked from the main game, as well as a user set flag in the designer for "competition mode" or some such, where any ships that have that flag aren't used for the main game.

    I've come across few other issues, like occasionally getting stuck in other objects when changing your ship (solved with a relog) and minor bugs.

    An early access game, and my complaints are fairly minor in nature? Why are you still reading? Go forth and buy immediately! ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990417679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1704945530}
review: This is one must have game. It features amazingly beautify and entrancing gameplay, An always evolving combat and space system, you can literally pass the same area 3 minutes later and have it be completly diffirent. The upgrade system is alot more compex than first glance may imply (fitting just the right pieces to your ship to have the job done, yet having a cap that alters quicly by playing pressures you to grow, but grow to fast and you find yourself in trouble, faceing equally hard enemies.) bored of one world? enter a wormhole and start fresh with your current ships!. I really cannot say enough about this game, I feel lucky to have the chance to play it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060940728', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1476739516}
review:
I feel beta has been out long enough to write this. I was part of alpha since the summer, and ever since my first glance at the game I was in love. Polygons with partical effects moving polygon clumps that fire polygons with effects at other polygons? What not to love! Although the graphical style is symplistic, it keeps amazing me how complex a ship that's essentially shifting shades of  two colours can look. Gameplay? Great. Although at times I dearly wish there was a way to choose your spawn point so you don't get almost trapped at a station over and over again because enemies keep attacking you as you spawn, it's for the most part rediculously fun trying to continually improve your ship to take down enemies while at the same time making a fleet that's not too shabby for fighting.

What do I Give this? Solid 8/10. It could do better in some respects, so it's not worthy of a nine, and in my opinion no game is ever worth a ten since there are faults in every game, but for the most part I'm in love. I highly recommend this game and I also believe that the thirty dollars will be worth it to help with the development and likely get your ideas implemented, as well as getting to see the game evolve into it's final state like I and many others have been doing for a long time.

review:
VERY good game, certainly worth the price, i cannot even imagine what more content could be added. extremly unique wepons and utilities make ship building a blast, and then evolving your design. eg: i abandoned banks of railguns in my design of rows upon rows of far cheaper heat seeking missiles, and now i can engange at much longer range and sustain much heavier volumes of fire with a weapon that you start with at level 1.  the balance in this game is wonderful, and the art work is beautiful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006535739', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1638142119}
review:
I have a normal format for my reviews; I will eschew it for Reassembly. Normally I speak of a game's good, bad and ugly qualities, in hopes of bringing excitement for the games perks, and light to its flaws.

I can give this game no higher praise but to say this: I can find no faults in it. The game is brilliantly executed, if perhaps still limited, but then I haven't beaten the game yet. The exploration draws you in in a way that I was utterly surprised by. Since the first day of exploring this title, I have been eager to resume it, to stretch my ship building talents, to bring vengeance to the evil red bastards who always seem to be one step ahead.

The music is nothing short of masterful. Most of the time I tire of the music and mute it in favor of my normal playlists, but the soundtrack is so beautifully atmospheric that there is no need. 

Now let's speak of the elephant in the room, a two headed monstrosity. The first head is the game's graphics. From it's trailer, you have accurately seen the game's aesthetics, and they are indeed simple. Then, you have the $40 price tag, a cost very near a AAA title. I showed this game to a roommate who immediately got sucked in, but when he saw the price, said, "Well, maybe I'll get it if it goes on sale."

Take a look at this game's reviews thus far. It scarcely has more than 30, but EVERY SINGLE ONE of them is positive. I have never seen a 100% approval rating on steam. I take from this two things: For those with the means, you WILL enjoy this title. I guarantee it. Two: It is beyond what most people would reasonably expect to pay.

For a delivery system that has no manufacturing, little overhead, and still in early access, $40 seems steep. It is my opinion that if that price were to get cut in half, its sales would SKYROCKET, by much more than double.

That being said, with EVERYTHING that I said, this game is WORTH the forty dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066508514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1421322316}
review:
ATTENTION:

The price will lower to $10 - $15 on FEBRUARY.

My advice is to wait for the price drop.

but if price isn't an issue for you its definitely worth picking up NOW.

Price aside the game is pretty awesome and its totally what you'd expect or have hopes for. The amount of blocks and the gorgeous art style doesn't disappoint. 

The factions are very very unique from each other and each faction has different kinds of blocks/weapons/ship parts.This game is what Ive been hoping for! Its not overly complicated and and has about 6 or 7 factions at its current build.

It has a random/procedural generated galaxy and has an endless amount of galaxies via wormholes! ( wormholes are the means of travel into other new galaxies ) 

You can upload your fleet/ships and other players would see your ships invading their galaxy! Awesome right?!

For example: Id see a cool ship and if i hover my cursor over it I would be able to see the name of the player who made it and the name of of his ship!

Overall this game is very addicting and would even be more so when more parts are added in the future!

Id score this game a solid:

8.5-9/10 at its current build and could easily be a 10/10 with the more upcoming updates!

I hope this helped! Hurry up and invade my galaxy! I would love to destroy those puny ships of yours!

WAHAHAAHAH! XD

author: {'steamid': '76561198002440676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1681468592}
review:
FÃ¼r alle Fans von SPAZ (Space Pirates and Zombies) ein absoluter muss. Denn man kann seine Flotten bauen wie man lustig ist und ist nicht an irgendwelche vorgefertigten SchiffshÃ¼llen gebunden, die dann nur mit Equipment bestÃ¼ckt werden. 

Man entwirft alles selber und hat dafÃ¼r Punkte zur VerfÃ¼gung, Ã¤hnlich wie bei Spore. FÃ¼r Credits kann man die Punktezahl erhÃ¶hen und neue Teile freischalten. Insgesamt gibt es 3 verschiedene Ressourcen, die da wÃ¤ren: R (man kann es Ã¼berall sammeln) C (bekommt man fÃ¼r aktivierte Stationen und abgeliefertes R) P (sind die Punkte die man zum Bauen fÃ¼r die Schiffe braucht, welche man fÃ¼r C eintauscht)

Die Stationen denen man die R Ressource bringt, werden ihre eigene Flotte aufbauen und ihre eigenstÃ¤ndige Konflikte gegen den Feind fÃ¼hren, sofern welche in der NÃ¤he sind. Mit der [Tab] Taste kann man fÃ¼r C auch Schiffe anheuern die einem dann folgen, dazu muss man sie einfach anklicken und dann wieder [TAB] zum abbrechen drÃ¼cken. Besser ist aber selber eine Fabrik am Schiff einzubauen und eigene Schiffe zu erzeugen. Das kostet dann nur R.

Nicht jede VerbÃ¼ndete Station benÃ¶tigt R, also fliegt einfach zu einer anderen, wenn sie nicht wollen, haben sie wohl genug. Am besten fliegt man zu Stationen nahe der Grenze zum Feind.

Leider ist das Spiel komplett auf Englisch, aber es erklÃ¤rt sich fast von selbst. Wenn man beim Bauen eines Schiffs Schwierigkeiten hat, kann man sich die nÃ¶tigen Tasten mit deren ErklÃ¤rung einblenden lassen.

Alle Schiffe die man erstellt hat, werden von der VerbÃ¼ndeten KI nachgebaut und benutzt, sofern sie die benÃ¶tigten Mittel hat. 

Alles in allem ein sehr gelungenes Spiel, nur ein wenig teuer. 25â‚¬ hÃ¤tten es auch getan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119572799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 25067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1711220660}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025779293', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1638485045}
review:
Reassembly is a simple and well executed concept. It is a beautiful, fun game that facinates. The developer works very hard, is involved with the community, and listens to ideas! I cannot wait to watch this game go from beta to release. The Beta is VERY stable with a few UI design that need some tweaking. But this does not mar the game at all.

It is so easy to get lost in Reassembly. I continually tweak, change, upgrade, rehash, redesign, and customize my ships. Its facinating to watch your own creation evolve as you gain access to more and more powerful weapons. Such a joy.
The world is vast in scope, colorful, busy, living and beautiful. The "grind" in this game is fun because you get to build, test and tweak your ship exactly the waty you want too.

There are three different ways to control the ship which can take some getting use too, but they all work very well. The art choice is stellar, and beautiful. And the ambiant music sets such an amazing tone as you realize you are a very small dot in a expansive universe. Nothing is as exciting as watching your mini probe evolve into a giant mother ship.

Not enough good things can really be said. If you dont want to pay the price now, wait till its cheaper. The game is highly worth it either way! I shall leave it at this, if not i will just continue rambling.

But really...its Legos that actually fire lazers and fly. How can you say no?

author: {'steamid': '76561197961397363', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1585510680}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015539882', 'num_games_owned': 3125, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1417296113}
review:
As of Beta build from Nov 26:
Reassembly is kind of the game that takes one and only one thing and does it very very well. In this case it's crazy custom ship skirmishes.
Target of the game is pretty simple - conquer the whole map. And all you have to accomplish that is you own ship, some raw resources and a couple of supporting space stations.
You have to farm (literally, they grow on space plants) resources, fight enemies, build your fleet and slowly proceed to the center of the map. That's a game in a nutshell. But, I want to stress this once more, the game does this one thing very VERY good.
Add here a nice async multiplayer - all players can share their ship builds online, and those shared ships will appear in other players' games. Which is pretty awesome if ask me.
But is it enough? Well, that's for you to decide. If you ask me - it definitely is.
Oh, and don't forget the amazing soundtrack!

More detailed look in the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VG-RP0yBg8M

author: {'steamid': '76561198059740355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 3022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1585426627}
review:
This game is lots of fun, especially if you already enjoy shipbuilders. Constructing your ship is simple, and you can even test it against other AI before you take a spin in it. Gameplay so far is farely simplistic. Build up your faction by collecting resources and designing better ships to take on the other factions. Buy new parts to upgrade your ships. Upgrade your ships. Blow up other ships. Despite the simplicity the game is tons of fun and I highly recommend it.

And don't forget, this is only in beta, so I have good hopes of more content being added on later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002734128', 'num_games_owned': 3358, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1548298110}
review:
A very interesting concept that is implemented well.  I am not someone who enjoys overly complex "X" (ships, mechs, etc.) builders and I'm pleased to report that designing my own ship in this game was incredibly easy.  Essentially, you'll start off with a small ship, earn credits and raw resources, and then build up both your ship and faction in an attempt to get to the center of the map (the difficulty increases as you go, like in "Spore").

It's a bit pricey for the content it currently offers, though to be fair, the price listed now is actually higher than what it'll be at launch.  This was intended so as to "ensure a higher degree of focus between us and our testers/players."  Those who really enjoy games of this type and don't mind the aspect of Beta testing and playing Early Access games would be best suited to pick this up.  Otherwise, wait for launch and grab it then.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RSlhT-7ieVI

author: {'steamid': '76561198007324693', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 16827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4124, 'last_played': 1486744067}
review:
Upon trying this out, I really did not know what to expect. At first, however, I found myself a little lost in this strangely organic world that is somewhere in the far reaches of space.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swxfEZJtZAk
It doesn't take long for you to realize that you are not alone, and, in fact, you have a whole faction that shares your own desire for expansion in the untamed universe. Unlike many in this loose genre, you fight side by side with your AI friends from beginning to end. 

Make no mistake, this is, at it's core, a block building game, where you build your spaceship, and can build fleets of custom ships to fight with you or just let them loose to go it on thier own. Where they will build more ships of thier own and fight the good fight for the faction gathering resources and growing your empire just like yourself. In many ways, when I play this I feel like just another small, but important, peice of a larger hive doing my part. Although I would like to think that I might contribute a little more than my AI companions, I hope. 

In Reassembly, you will explore, expland, exploit, and exterminate. Yes, this is, in fact, a 4X game, hidden underneath a very well crafted version of a top down space shooter. 

The more I play, the more I want to play, and I find myself losing time. It's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998807353', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10962, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 33, 'playtime_at_review': 940, 'last_played': 1711339145}
review:
Reassembly is an excellent mix of 2D space combat, spaceship building, exploration and resource gathering.

In the Beta you start with a small group of ships to choose from, which you can totally ignore and build your own if you desire. As you blow up enemy ships and explore you can choose to increase the limit of how big your ship can be and/or unlock more powerful components. You start on the edge of the galaxy where it's relatively safe, as you explore towards the center the enemies become bigger and way more powerful.

There are wormholes you can fly into. These will either take you to a fresh galaxy or send an AI controlled copy of your ship to other player's galaxies. My goal is not only to take over my own galaxy but be the bane of other galaxies as well :)

The "ecosystem" in Reassembly reminds me of microscopic organisms growing, reproducing, fighting and dying... but IN SPACE!

The Early Access is $30, which might seem high but I gladly chipped in more than that in the Kickstarter because I want to support what they are doing. If that's too rich for your blood just put it on the WIsh List until the game is actually released.

If you like Geometry Wars, Minecraft and/or Kerbal Space Program you will very likely dig this game. Just be careful, I stayed up until 4am on Beta release day playing this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023219648', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 27746, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1678038892}
review:
Reassembly is one of those games you find hidden in broad daylight, a gem in a sea of hyped up fast paced fps games.

And boy is it a gem. The kind where it will suck you in for hours if you're not careful. As it is now in its beta phase, some new features are now part of the game. Most notably asynchronous Multiplayer.

This does not mean players will directly fight other players. Rather, it is still single player in that retrospect. What you do fight, are the ships that other players have spent countless hours, or a few seconds throwing together, in a big mashup found dotted about in the ecosystem.

You will find many different tactics and build strategies are required to best some of the more difficult enemies, and ultimately, your goal will be universal annihilation!! MWAHAHA!! Or at least that's my goal.

You can either wander aimlessly, killing everything you see, avoiding everything you see, copying everything, building everything, or just plain sit there while you watch hordes of allied AI ships, drones, and missiles beat the crap out of your foes in shiny balls of explosions!

There is a relatively small but lively community found on this game's forums, where the Developer himself, Arthur, runs and frequents.

One more thing! Every few weeks, there are design contests held where players can create ships to blow each other up in a big tournament! Further excitement is based solely on player discrecion.

Update! I forgot to mention some stuff

There are currently over 500 different parts, the player has direct access to about 40 of them. (the others are parts from other factions, of which there are 15)

You can fly around and kill things, design ships, and collect resources. There isn't much of a story mode, but there is a sandbox where you can spawn any faction and build with every part. (requires a basic level of coding knowledge)

The ai is incredibly smart. There are ai competitions every few weeks where players build ships to a certain danger level, then submit them to different classes, where they fight to the death round robin style, and the best 16 are pitted in a single elimination bracket for all to see.
From these tournaments, the developer (Arthur) works on tweaking the ai so that it can better fend for itself during battles, leading to more aggressive enemies.
The current system of ai smarts has to do with profile tags that are randomly assigned to each ai, some will get a "bad aim" tag, others might have "Reckless" or "runs away", and any combination of tags will eventually result in harder enemies. The hardest so far is one that has tags "smart fire, reckless, dodges, chases"

Updates are between daily and monthly, it really depends on what's being changed. They are usually just a few megabytes, the game itself is only 160 mb.

The game runs very well in huge fights. Even with 1k ai (missiles, ships, drones) flying everywhere, there is hardly a noticeable tax on performance. (60 fps is average)

The balance is relatively good. The learning curve is not too steep, and starting newbies will be challenged to survive. and you will die, even if you try to play defensively, it's bound to happen.
